AAS membership was lowest in cardiothoracic surgery, plastic surgery and among Ph.D. faculty working in departments of surgery; however, AAS members from these subspecialties had significantly greater academic output compared with AAS non-members as well.

Conclusion: AAS membership is associated with substantially better academic metrics and NIH funding rates for junior and midlevel surgical faculty across all subspecialties. Individuals and academic departments interested in improving publications and funding should encourage participation in the AAS. Causes for the low membership rate for certain subspecialties in AAS should be examined and addressed to potentially improve academic metrics within these subspecialties.

abstract_title: The Use of Smart Phone Thermal Imaging for Assessment of Peripheral Perfusion in Vascular Patients
author_block: G. Wallace<sup>1</sup>, E. Quiroga<sup>1</sup>, N. Tran<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Washington,Vascular Surgery,Seattle, WA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ankle brachial index (ABI) is a reliable quantitative determination of extremity perfusion but required specialized training and could cause patient's discomfort or not feasible in trauma patients with mangled extremities. Smart phone based thermal imaging utilizing forward looking infrared imaging (FLIR) can easily determine temperature of the extremity. This study reports on the feasibility of using smart phone based FLIR to assess peripheral perfusion by measurement of extremity temperature.

Methods: Patients seen in a vascular clinic with ABI's measured by an ICAVL certified vascular lab were selected. Patients then underwent imaging using a smart phone based FLIR. Color spectrograph was taken and surface temperature of each extremity was determined and recorded. A single operator who was blinded to ABI's results obtained all images. Comparison between ABI and extremity's temperature was performed. Thermal ankle brachial index (TABI) was calculated by dividing the temperature of the lower extremity by that of the upper extremity. Temperature accuracy of FLIR was determined against known standard. Statistical analysis was done using Pearson's correlation and Bland-Altman plot.

Results: 23 patients had both ABI and extremity temperature recorded on the same day resulting in 45 lower extremities analyzed (one patient has a BKA). ABI ranged from 0.33 to 1.46 with mean (IQR) of 0.92 (0.35). Lower extremity temperature ranged from 60.67 to 96.87°F with mean of 83.41 (14.10). Upper extremity range was 81.86 to 94.60°F with mean of 91.03 (3.44). Positive correlation between ABI and FLIR temperature was seen with Pearson's correlation coefficient r = 0.66 p = .001, n = 45. Using ABI and the newly described TABI, positive correlation was also seen with r = 0.83, p < .0001, n = 45 (Fig 1). Thermal sensitivity of FLIR was determined at 0.18°F. When comparing against known standard, thermal imaging has an average of 3.16% error across temperature range of 34 to 144°F.

Conclusion: Smart phone based FLIR imaging can be used to reliably determine extremity perfusion as an alternative to traditional ABI measurement. FLIR can be easily done, portable, and has a variety of potential applications from intraoperative assessment of revascularization to evaluation of the injured extremity in trauma.

abstract_title: Sphingosine Treatment Prevents Lung Pseudomonas aeruginosa Infection in Burn Injured Mice
author_block: T. C. Rice<sup>1</sup>, E. F. Midura<sup>1</sup>, E. Gulbins<sup>1,2</sup>, M. J. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, C. C. Caldwell<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Division Of Research,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>University Hospital Essen,Department Of Molecular Biology,Essen, NORTH RHINE - WESTPHALIA, Germany
abstract_body:
Introduction: Burn-injured patients are susceptible to severe pulmonary infection by Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA). Here, we investigate a potential role of the ceramide/sphingosine axis in increased susceptibility. Ceramide levels are regulated by acid sphingomyelinase (Asm) activity that converts the membrane phospholipid sphingomyelin to ceramide. Subsequently, ceramide is hydrolyzed via acid ceramidase to the long chain base, sphingosine. Beyond its cellular localization, sphingosine can be observed extracellularly in microparticles (MPs). Although it is known that sphingosine treatment can be used to combat infection, the role of cellular sphingosine or sphingosine-containing MPs in the defense against pulmonary infection in burn patients has not been elucidated. Altogether, we hypothesize that 1) injury alters Asm activity and subsequently sphingosine levels such that susceptibility to infection is increased and 2) sphingosine treatment will prevent lung PA infection in burn injured mice.

Methods: Outbred mice were subjected to a dorsal 28% total body surface area, full thickness scald injury. First, we characterized sphingosine expression in the lungs (by immunohistochemistry) and in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) derived MPs (by Nanoparticle Tracking Analysis) on post burn day one (PBD1). Second, Asm activity and MP numbers were determined in BAL fluid in mice 24 hours following inoculation with PA. Finally, to determine the effects of sphingosine on infection, some PBD1 mice were pre-treated with sphingosine. All mice were then inoculated with PA and four hours later, colony forming units (CFUs) were enumerated.

Results: Similar to what is seen clinically, infected burn-injured mice had increased mortality as compared to infected uninjured mice (50.0% vs 18.2%, p=0.048). To determine underlying mechanisms of this mortality, we first observed on PBD1, there is a four-fold reduction in bronchial epithelial sphingosine expression in burn injured mice compared to sham. Further, these mice have a significant reduction in total MPs in BAL fluid. Secondly, there was a significant reduction in Asm activity and total MPs in BAL fluid in infected burn mice compared to infected uninjured mice. The BAL MPs from burn infected mice have significantly reduced sphingosine expression. Finally, following PA inoculation, burn mice have a three-log increase in pulmonary infection compared to sham. However, when burn mice are treated with inhaled sphingosine prior to inoculation, there is a significant reduction in pulmonary infection to a level similar to control mice.

Conclusion: The data demonstrate that 1) burn decreases bronchial sphingosine levels and MP numbers, 2) upon infection, injured mice have decreased Asm activity and MP sphingosine levels, and 3) sphingosine treatment prevents lung infection of PA in burn injured mice. These data suggest that in burn patients, treatment with sphingosine will reduce subsequent pulmonary infection.

abstract_title: Intestinal Alkaline Phosphatase Prevents Burn Induced Intestinal Permeability and Bacterial Translocation
author_block: F. Adiliaghdam<sup>1</sup>, M. Gharedaghi<sup>1</sup>, S. Yan<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. R. Hamarneh<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Morrison<sup>1</sup>, L. G. Rahme<sup>1,2,3</sup>, R. A. Hodin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,General Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Shriners Hospitals For Children,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Department Of Microbiology And Immunobiology,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Burn patients are at increased risk for systemic sepsis and multi-organ failures. Burn-induced gut barrier dysfunction and bacterial translocation is thought to be one of the sources of bacterial presence in the blood stream. Previously, we have shown that IAP detoxifies bacterial pro-inflammatory factors, prevents endotoxemia, enhances gut barrier functions, and preserves intestinal microbial homeostasis. We have hypothesized that supplemental intestinal alkaline phosphatase (IAP) could be used as a therapeutic modality to prevent gut-derived sepsis.

Methods: 6-week old CD-1 mice were divided into 4 groups (n=5 in each group). We inflicted a 30% total body surface area burn on the back of mice +/- intradermal Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) infection mid-eschar of burn site to induce gut barrier dysfunction. IAP or vehicle were administered orally by gastric gavage in a dose of 200U per gavage at 3 and 12 hours post infection. The results were compared to a non-burned control group that underwent a sham procedure. The change in intestinal permeability was assessed by measuring FITC-Dextran 20kD presence in the blood stream at 6 hours post gavage. Bacterial burden in the blood and in intestinal samples was assessed. Intestinal inflammation and cytokine levels were also measured using ELISA.

Results:TThe experimental group underwent the burn procedure and infection had significantly higher intestinal permeability to FITC-Dextran compared to burn alone or control group mice. (p = 0.01) Oral IAP supplementation significantly reduced the gut barrier dysfunction seen in the treated group. (FITC-Dextran concentration in blood: 0.255 µg/ml in infected group compared to 0.074 µg/ml in IAP treated group, p = 0.04) Consistently, infected mice showed significantly lower serum endotoxin levels in IAP-treated group (2.69 ± 0.60 EU/ml) compared to infected and no treated group (17.51 ± 6.14 EU/ml, p = 0.003). IAP treatment reduced the bacterial load in the blood of burn and infected mice (6.3 x 105 CFU/ml of blood in infected group compared to 4.2 x 103 CFU/ml in IAP treated infected mice) and in the ileal tissue (1.4 x 106 CFU/g of ileal tissue in infection group compared to vs 2.8 x 104 CFU/g in IAP group, p = 0.049). Lastly, the burn procedure combined with infection resulted in significant levels of intestinal inflammation, as evidenced by elevated levels of TNF-a in the intestinal tissue. IAP treatment reduced TNF-a level.

Conclusion:IAP is a major regulator of the gut mucosal barrier and is able to ameliorate burn-induced gut barrier dysfunction. It appears that IAP functions through preventing intestinal inflammation. Oral IAP supplementation may represent a novel approach to prevent sepsis in burn patients.

abstract_title: Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Blinded Trial: ICG Angiography In Abdominal Wall Reconstruction
author_block: C. R. Huntington<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Wormer<sup>1</sup>, S. W. Ross<sup>1</sup>, P. D. Colavita<sup>1</sup>, T. Prasad<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Lincourt<sup>1</sup>, I. Belyansky<sup>2</sup>, S. B. Getz<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Heniford<sup>1</sup>, V. A. Augenstein<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Carolinas Medical Center,Charlotte, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Anne Arundel Medical Center,Annapolis, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Indocynanine green angiography (ICG-A) has been utilized to measure tissue perfusion during surgical reconstruction procedures and intestinal anastomosis, despite a lack of high quality evidence to support its use. While unsubstantiated, ICG-A has also been proposed to reduce complications in abdominal wall reconstruction (AWR). Two tertiary referral hernia centers conducted a prospective, randomized, controlled, blinded trial to investigate the utility of ICG-A in reducing wound complications in complex AWR.

Methods: After IRB approval, all consented patients underwent ICG-A utilizing the SPY Elite deviceTM prior to flap/skin closure after AWR. In the control group, both the Hernia Surgeon and Plastic Surgeon were blinded to ICG-A images. In the experimental group, the surgery team viewed the images and modified tissue flaps if warranted. ICG-A videos were saved and reviewed by independent, blinded surgeons to ensure correct interpretation. Outcomes included medical, surgical and wound complications and reoperation over 3 months. Groups were compared with Chi square and Wilcoxon rank sum analysis.

Results: Among 95 patients, n=49 control and n=46 experimental, preoperative characteristics were similar: age (58.3vs.56.7years,p=0.4), BMI (34.9vs. 33.6kg/m2,p=0.8), tobacco use (8.2%vs. 8.7%,p=0.9), diabetes (30.6%vs.37.0%,p=0.5), and previous hernia repair (71.4%vs.60.9%,p=0.3). The mean hernia defect was 293cm2 and mesh size 1033cm2. Operative characteristics were also equivalent, including rate of panniculectomy (69.4% vs. 58.7%,p=0.3), component separation (73.5%vs. 69.6%,p=0.6), estimated blood loss (160vs.180mL,p=0.4) and mean operative time (204vs.217minutes,p=0.4). The experimental group was more likely to have skin and subcutaneous flaps modified (37%vs.4.1%,p<0.0001). However, there was no significant difference between control vs. experimental groups in wound infection (10.2%vs.21.7%,p=0.12), skin necrosis (6.1% vs. 2.2%,p=0.3), fat necrosis (10.2% vs. 13.0%,p=0.7), overall wound-related complications (32.7% vs. 37.0%,p=0.7), reoperation rates (14.3%vs. 26.1%,p=0.7), or long-term hernia recurrence (4.1% vs. 2.2%,p=0.6) with mean follow-up of 8.3 months. When limited to significantly at-risk patients (obese, diabetic, concomitant component separation, or panniculectomy), there was no significant difference in wound-related complications between groups. Patients with hypoperfusion on ICG-A (below a threshold of 10 units) had higher rates of wound infection (28%vs.9.4%,p<0.02), however flap modification after viewing images did not improve wound-related complications in these patients (15.6%vs.12.5%,p=0.99).

Conclusion: Though intra-operative ICG-A use during complex AWR may aid in identifying patients at risk of wound infection, it did not decrease wound-related complications or reoperation rates in complex abdominal wall reconstruction. The use of ICG-A in complex AWR is not warrented in ventral hernia repair.

abstract_title: Toll-like Receptor 4 Regulates the Expression of Intracellular Serpins in Necrotizing Enterocolitis
author_block: D. F. Nino<sup>1</sup>, S. Sho<sup>3</sup>, C. P. Sodhi<sup>1</sup>, M. Good<sup>2</sup>, C. J. Luke<sup>2</sup>, G. A. Silverman<sup>2</sup>, D. J. Hackam<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Pediatric Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC,Newborn Medicine,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most frequent and lethal pathology that afflicts the gastrointestinal tract of premature infants. Our lab has previously demonstrated the critical role that the innate immune receptor for lipopolysaccharide (LPS), toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), and subsequent exaggerated inflammatory signaling play in the pathogenesis of NEC and intestinal necrosis. Intracellular serpin B3 has been identified as a pro-survival factor with a novel role in necrosis inhibition. Given the characteristic necrosis observed in NEC, we hypothesized that TLR4 signaling in the gut plays a role in the regulation of intracellular serpin expression.

Methods: Under IRB approval, intestinal samples were obtained from patients diagnosed with NEC and evaluated for the expression of serpin B3 by qRT-PCR and immunohistochemistry (IHC). The role of TLR4 was determined using a model of endotoxemia (LPS 1mg/kg IP 3 h) or experimental NEC in neonatal (7 – 12 day old) C57Bl/6, TLR4 KO or mice lacking TLR4 in the intestinal epithelium (TLR4ΔIEC). NEC was induced by feeding formula supplemented with bacteria isolated from human NEC via gavage five times/day and exposure to hypoxia (5%O2, 95%N2) for 10 min in a hypoxic chamber twice daily for 4 days. TLR4 and serpin B3 deficient enterocytes (IEC-6 cells) were generated using lentivirus-TLR4-shRNA or lentivirus-serpin B3-shRNA, respectively. The role of serpin B3 in the inflammatory response of enterocytes challenged with LPS was evaluated by IL-6, iNOS and IL-1b mRNA expression determined by qRT-PCR.

Results: Human and murine NEC intestinal samples display a significantly increased expression of serpin B3 by mRNA (58 fold and 6 fold, respectively) and evidenced by IHC. These findings were determined to be TLR4-dependent, since serpin B3 expression was significantly lower in TLR4-deficient enterocytes compared to wild-type controls (0.16 vs. 8 fold relative to actin) when challenged with endotoxin. These results are further supported by the fact that endotoxemia leads to upregulation of serpin B3 in wild-type mice (2 fold) but have no effect on TLR4 deficient mice. Moreover, TLR4ΔIEC mice were protected from developing NEC and had decreased levels of serpin B3. Strikingly, when compared to wild-type IEC-6 cells exposed to LPS, serpin B3-deficient cells were found to have increased expression of the inflammatory mediators iNOS (4 fold), IL-6 (2 fold) and IL-1b (3 fold).

Conclusion: Intracellular serpin B3 levels are significantly increased in the intestine of both human and murine NEC. Normal TLR4 expression in the intestinal epithelium is required for serpin B3 expression. Our findings suggest a potential role for TLR4 regulation of serpin B3, a molecular modulator of intestinal inflammation and necrosis, hallmarks of this devastating disease.

abstract_title: Bladder Tumor Initiating Cells as Predictors of Outcome
author_block: K. Skowron<sup>1</sup>, J. Namm<sup>5</sup>, S. Pitroda<sup>3</sup>, M. Beckett<sup>3</sup>, N. Khodarev<sup>3</sup>, M. Posner<sup>1,4</sup>, G. Steinberg<sup>2</sup>, R. Weichselbaum<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery / Section Of General Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery / Section Of Urology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Radiation And Cellular Oncology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>Loma Linda University Health,Department Of Surgery,Loma Linda, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery / Section Of Surgical Oncology,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bladder cancer is the 9th leading cause of cancer death in the U.S. Treatment consists of radical cystectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy or bladder-sparing chemo-radiotherapy in selected cases. Volkmer et al. identified bladder tumor initiating cells (BTICs) in progressive stages of differentiation (1). We established patient derived xenografts (PDX) in order to study BTIC biology in vivo. We hypothesized that patient tumors with a greater population of basal or poorly differentiated BTICs would have a poor clinical outcome compared to patients with well-differentiated tumors. Gene expression analysis was performed with the goal of identifying prognostic markers.

Methods: Patients undergoing cystectomy are recruited under an IRB-approved protocol. Tumor samples are received from pathology; fragments are injected subcutaneously into the flank of NOD/SCID mice and monitored for engraftment. Remaining tissue is analyzed with flow cytometry to quantify the BTIC populations. Any tumors which engraft are excised, reimplanted into further generations of mice, and sorted for RNA extraction of the BTIC populations. Subsequent xenograft tumors are treated with either radiation or cisplatin, and analyzed for tumor growth and changes in BTIC populations. Clinical data are gathered using the REDCap web-based data server. RNA expression is assessed using Illumina Human HT-12 array.

Results:Of 70 patient samples, 41 tumors have engrafted in mice. There was no correlation between engraftment and survival. However, a correlation between greater basal BTIC populations and overall survival approached significance (p=0.09). If patients did not receive systemic chemotherapy (n=28), the basal BTICs conferred a greater risk to overall survival (LR 5.5, p=0.06) than among patients (n=21) who received any systemic chemotherapy (LR 0.62, p=0.74). The basal BTICs comprise an average of 1% of the tumor cells (range 0-17%). Early results indicate a differential response to cisplatin and radiation among PDX tumors for both agents. Analysis of the RNA array identified a signature of 54 genes suppressed in basal BTICs relative to the more differentiated tumor cells. This gene signature correlates with overall survival (p=0.0047) and disease-specific survival (p=0.0085) in a large cohort of patients.

Conclusion:Our results suggest that the presence of a small percentage of basal BTICs portends a poor clinical outcome, which may be improved by the addition of chemotherapy. RNA evaluation of these BTICs has revealed potential biological markers and targets for future therapy, as well as a gene signature which may provide a tool for improved patient selection for therapy. (1) Volkmer JP, Sahoo D, Chin RK, et al. Three differentiation states risk-stratify bladder cancer into distinct subtypes. PNAS 2012;109:2078-2083.

abstract_title: Human Breast Cancer Cells Grow on Ex Vivo 4D Lung Model and Form Tumor Nodules
author_block: K. A. Pence<sup>1</sup>, D. K. Mishra<sup>2</sup>, M. J. Thrall<sup>3</sup>, B. Dave<sup>2</sup>, M. P. Kim<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Houston Methodist Research Institute,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Houston Methodist Hospital,Pathology And Genomic Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>1</sup>Houston Methodist Hospital,Surgery,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We have demonstrated that various human lung cancer cell lines can be successfully grown on ex vivo 4D lung model derived from acellular rat lung. In fact, this 4D model has been shown to mimic the histopathology, MMPs secretion and gene signatures pattern similar to patients with lung cancers compared to cell lines grown on a petri-dish. In this study, we want to determine if breast cancer cell lines can grow in acellular lung matrix in the ex vivo 4D model.

Methods: Rat lungs were harvested and native cells were removed using sodium dodecyl sulfate and Triton X-100 to create acellular lung matrix. We seeded 5-20 million SUM159, MCF7, and MDMB231 cells through trachea into the epithelial space of 4D lung model and grew in a customized bioreactor with perfusion of oxygenated media for 6 days. Tissues were harvested upon tumor nodule formation and processed for Hemotoxyline and eosin staining to analyze the histopathology.

Results: All three cell lines grew well in the ex vivo 4D model and formed the tumor nodules with similar histology and morphology as the primary tumors. Additionally, the two triple negative breast cancer cell lines derived from malignant pleural effusions—SUM159 and MDMB231—showed aggressive growth in lung matrix including bronchioles and bronchus. These cells appeared more mesenchymal, with prominent nuclei and spindle morphology. ER/PR positive MCF7 cells, derived from primary breast cancer tumor, were more like typical breast cancer.with ductal morphology and prominent nuclei. Due to absence of other normal lung cells, the growth pattern was not clearly indicative of metastatic breast cancer with invasion to lung parenchyma. Compared to the same tumor cells that were grown on a petri dish, the breast cancer cell lines grown in the acellular lung matrix had more features of tumor seen in patients with breast cancer.

Conclusion: Overall, our study showed that human breast cancer cells can be grown on ex vivo 4D lung model, which forms tumor nodules that mimic the morphology, and histology of the original tumor. This model may be used as a more accurate model to study tumor growth compared to growing the tumor cells on a petri dish.

abstract_title: Disturbed Hemodynamics Leads to Arterial Stiffening in a Murine Partial Carotid Ligation Model
author_block: S. Dalal<sup>1</sup>, K. Kuo<sup>1</sup>, A. Morris<sup>1</sup>, H. Li<sup>1</sup>, L. Brewster<sup>1,4</sup>, L. Timmins<sup>2,3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Divison Of Vascular Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>2</sup>Georgia Institue Of Technology,Parker H. Petit Institute Of Bioengineering And Bioscience,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Department Of Radiology And Imaging Sciences,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>Atlanta VA Medical Center,Division Of Vascular Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Arterial stiffness, which doubles a patient's risk of cardiovascular mortality, is a consequence of aging and contributes to the development and progression of arthrosclerosis. However, stiffness is difficult to quantify in vivo, as it requires an invasive pressure measurement, so surrogate markers (e.g., pulse wave velocity) aid in assessing temporal changes in stiffness. We developed a novel method to quantify vascular stiffness in vivo and applied it on mouse model of atherosclerosis. We hypothesize that disturbed flow (i.e., low and oscillatory wall shear stress) leads to progressive arterial stiffening.

Methods: A partial carotid artery ligation was performed on the left side of C57Bl/6 (wild-type, WT; n = 9) to induce a disturbed hemodynamic environment. Serial ultrasound imaging data of the ligated and non-ligated (control) carotid arteries were acquired at days (d) 3, 7, 14, 21, and 28 post-ligation in each animal. Arterial cyclic deformation was extract from the imaging data with a custom image-processing algorithm, and the maximum circumferential (Green's) strain, which is a surrogate marker for vascular stiffness, was calculated across a cardiac cycle. Recognize that stiffness and strain exhibited an inverse relationship. ??

Results: ???As early as 7 days post-ligation, we observed a significant difference in circumferential strain between the non-ligated (0.35± 0.10) and ligated (0.25 ± 0.08) arteries (p = 0.01; i.e., the ligated arteries became more stiff). The ligated arteries exhibited a continued decrease in circumferential strain throughout serial image acquisition, while the non-ligated arteries remain unchanged. At day 28, the non-ligated arteries had greater than two times the circumferential strain of the ligated (0.35 ± 0.09 vs. 0.15 ± 0.07; p = 0.003). Overall, there was a 36% decrease in circumferential strain observed from day 3 to day 28 in the ligated compared to 25% increase in the non-ligated.

Conclusion: ??In conclusion, our data indicates a strong relationship between disturbed hemodynamics and arterial stiffness. We observed that arteries exposed to surgically-induced disturbed hemodynamics become stiffer over time, while control arteries did not. Furthermore, we observed continued stiffening over time in the ligated arteries. Our model of partial carotid ligation will serve as a validated method for investigating causes, treatments, and prevention of arterial stiffness.

abstract_title: Microarray Analysis of Treatment Induced Inflammatory Gene Changes in Human TNBC Cells
author_block: K. Deshpande<sup>1</sup>, P. Shah<sup>1</sup>, A. Vyas<sup>1</sup>, L. Chaturvedi<sup>1</sup>, D. Vyas<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Michigan State University,College Of Human Medicine,Lansing, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inflammation is well known to be a key culprit behind tumor promotion in Triple Negative Breast Cancer. Pro-inflammatory secretion of interleukins and chemotaxic agents results in increased cell motility, invasiveness, and ultimately enhanced survival and metastasis. Several chemotherapeutic drugs currently used for treatment are effective in targeting proliferated malignant cells and attenuating disease prognosis—however, not without significant shortcomings. Doxorubicin, the current first-line therapy for MDA-MB-231 triple negative breast cancer has its benefits but at the same time, causes serious drug-induced inflammation that often leads to further tumor cell proliferation and metastasis. In hopes of further understanding TNBC pro-inflammatory drug effects, we have studied a novel class of drugs known as second-generation proteasome inhibitors that demonstrate a reduction in inflammation. In this study, we focused on conducting a gene array to elucidate the effects of carfilzomib and doxorubicin on pro-inflammatory gene expression in both MCF-10A and MDA-MB-231 cells.

Methods: MCF-10A normal breast cells and MDA-MB-231 TNBC cells were treated or left untreated with vehicle control (0.1% DMSO), Carfilzomib (5 nM), Doxorubicin (30 nM), or a combination of both in complete growth medium for 24hr. The concentrations of Carfilzomib and Doxorubicin used were in accordance with previous studies conducted in the lab. Total RNA was extracted using RNeasy Mini Kit and The Taqman Human Inflammation Array was used for gene expression. A comparison of the amount of inflammatory gene expression was made via quantitative PCR.

Results:93 Inflammatory Gene Microarray design. The actions of inflammatory cytokines, growth factors, chemokines, transcription factors, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes are well recognized in both malignant and non-malignant states. Control cDNAs of the housekeeping gene such as 18S were used for signal normalization and quantitation. Genes that were up-regulated by more than 1.5 fold or down-regulated by at least 1.5 fold were considered significant and a comparison of fold-change in expression of these controls, MCF-10A versus MDA-MB-231, was made. The design resulted in 6 main genes being identified as significant inflammatory modulators: HPGD, KLKB1, TNFSF13B, VCAM1, IL1RAPL2, and PTAFR.

Conclusion:Both carfilzomib and doxorubicin are seen to suppress several up regulated pro-inflammatory genes in MDA-MB-231 cells. Most notably, KLKB1, IL1RAPL2 and VCAM1 pro-inflammatory genes demonstrated drug-induced effects, resulting in inflammatory suppression. On the other hand, HPGD, TNFSF13B, and PTAFR genes showed pro-inflammation upon giving the specific drug regimen. This suggests that these genes, along with the others identified through microarray, are significantly involved in inflammatory pathways. Further studies are needed to assess how their down-regulation may serve to supplement TNBC therapy.

abstract_title: Pharmacokinetic Regulation of Novel Cancer-Targeting Alkylphosphocholine Analogs
author_block: J. S. Kuo<sup>1,2</sup>, R. R. Zhang<sup>1,2</sup>, P. A. Clark<sup>1,2</sup>, L. Hall<sup>2,3</sup>, J. P. Weichert<sup>2,3</sup>, J. S. Kuo<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Neurological Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Carbone Cancer Center,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Radiology,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Novel alkylphosphocholine (APC) analogs (CLR1404, 1501, 1502) show prolonged cancer-specific retention in over 55 different rodent & human cancer and cancer stem cell models (lung, breast, pancreatic, renal, GI, GU, melanoma, GBM…etc). Ongoing early phase multi-institutional clinical trials are testing 124I-CLR1404 for oncologic PET imaging, 131I-CLR1404 for cancer therapy, and the fluorescent analogs CLR1501 (green) and CLR1502 (near infrared) are poised for an intraop cancer fluorescence trial. Pharmacokinetics & structure analyses of APC analogs were performed to inform safety and dosing parameters.

Methods: Standard biological, pharmacological & computational methods were used.

Results: Plasma partitioning studies suggest APC analogs bind predominantly to serum albumin. Crystal structures of related molecules and in silico modeling suggest seven distinct albumin high-affinity binding sites. In vivo binding and pharmacokinetic studies showed that APC distribution and clearance kinetics are effectively predicted by physiochemical properties combined with regulation by albumin binding.

Conclusion: APCs are novel synthetic analogs with promise as broad spectrum, tumor-selective molecular imaging and therapies for human cancers. Combined application of these chemically identical APC-based radioisosteres, with detailed pharmacokinetic understanding of human distribution and clearance kinetics, will ideally form a new personalized dual-modality cancer management strategy of using 124I-CLR1404 and fluorescent analogs for preop and intraop imaging, with follow-up 131I-CLR1404 therapy of residual or recurrent cancer cells.

abstract_title: Associations Among Body Composition, Tumor Gene Expression and Survival in Renal Clear Cell Carcinoma
author_block: C. A. Cooper<sup>1</sup>, G. Jiang<sup>2,3</sup>, Y. Liu<sup>2,3</sup>, T. A. Zimmers<sup>1,4,5</sup>  <sup>4</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,IU Simon Cancer Center,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>5</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Anatomy & Cell Biology,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Medical And Molecular Genetics,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Center For Computational Biology And Bioinformatics,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is frequently associated with cachexia, a wasting syndrome characterized by the loss of skeletal muscle (SKM) and adipose tissue (AT) mass. In ccRCC patients, cachexia is correlated with decreased survival, while obesity is associated with increased survival. Cachexia results in part from host response to tumor-produced cytokines. Here we assessed the associations between body composition, tumor cytokine expression and overall survival (OS) in ccRCC.

Methods: The Cancer Imaging Archive and the Cancer Genome Atlas were queried for ccRCC patients with available abdominal computed tomography (CT) imaging studies, survival information and tumor RNAseq data. All three datasets were available for 215 patients. SKM, intramuscular AT tissue (IMAT), visceral AT (VAT), and subcutaneous AT (SAT) area were measured at the L3 vertebral level in CT scans using Sliceomatic. Data were stratified by gender and tissue area quartiles. Kaplan-Meier survival analysis and log rank test (p<0.05) were used for OS comparisons between highest and lowest quartiles for each tissue area. Associations between tumor expression of 21 cachexia-associated cytokines and SKM were analyzed with Spearman's rank correlation (rho>0.1, p<0.05) with False Discovery Rate for multiple comparisons. Identified genes were probed for OS differences between groups stratified below and above median gene expression.

Results:OS was lower in the lowest versus the highest quartile for SKM in both males and females (p=0.002 and p=0.010, respectively). OS was lower for low SAT and total AT areas in males only (p=0.003 and P=0.015, respectively). A difference in OS for VAT area approached significance in males only (p=0.069). No differences in OS for IMAT were noted in either sex. Correlation coefficients for gene expression and any tissue measurement were small (<0.2). For SKM, the tissue presumably most functionally important for survival, correlated genes were INHBB, CTF1, and TGFB2 (p=0.029, p=0.010 and 0.028). Gene expression of 7 other cytokines were robustly associated with reduced OS (Table).

Conclusions:Body composition analysis showed sex-specific differences in body composition. Low SKM area was robustly associated with decreased OS in both males and females independent of stage in ccRCC, consistent with abundant data linking muscle loss and mortality. Differences in the other associations of body composition and OS indicated a possible gender-specific role of AT in ccRCCC. Tumor-derived mediators of cachexia are highly associated with survival in ccRCC, although not with body composition, suggesting they might act indirectly.

abstract_title: The inhibition of cfDNA released following radiation therapy in pancreatic cancer
author_block: I. A. Naqvi<sup>1</sup>, A. Moreno<sup>1</sup>, H. Juwarker<sup>1</sup>, B. Sullenger<sup>1</sup>, D. Pisetsky<sup>2</sup>, R. White<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Surgery,Durham, NORTH CAROLINA, USA <sup>2</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Medicine,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic cancer (PC) is the deadliest of the major cancers, and response rates to standard therapies are low. DNA and DNA-protein complexes are released by tumor and host cells. We have previously shown that circulating cell-free DNA (cfDNA) increases in the serum of patients with PC in response to radiation therapy. Current evidence suggests that increased cfDNA may play a role in tumor progression via Toll-Like Receptors (TLR) 9 and 4, which are activated by DNA and DNA-associated proteins, respectively. We hypothesized that we would be able to inhibit the downstream effects of cfDNA and associated protein complexes with nucleic acid binding polymers (NABPs).

Methods: MiaPaCa-2 cells were seeded and grown to confluence and were irradiated at 0, 8, and 10 cGy. The cells were then incubated for 5 days at which point their conditioned media (CM) were collected. Paired patient sera, before and following radiation therapy, were also collected. Both the media and sera were then incubated with immobilized NABP after which the supernatant was collected and incubated with TLR 4 and 9 reporter cells. DNA and total protein were quantified in all CM and serum supernatants by Picogreen and BCA, respectively.

Results: We observed that all CM and serum samples activated both TLR 4 and 9 more intensely than controls and that activation was increased in post-radiation CM and sera (not shown). These increases in activation correlated with increases in cfDNA in patient sera (Figure). Treating the serum samples with NABP decreased cfDNA to normal levels and (Figure) also decreased protein levels as well as TLR4 and 9 activities (not shown).

Conclusion: We were able to successfully inhibit the activation of TLR 4 and 9 by cfDNA and associated proteins through the use of NABP. Future directions include testing the functional effects of cfDNA and associated proteins in vitro and in vivo and whether those effects can also be inhibited by NABP.

abstract_title: Dysregulation of Sphingolipids in Human Breast Cancer
author_block: M. Nagahashi<sup>1</sup>, J. Tsuchida<sup>1</sup>, K. Moro<sup>1</sup>, T. Niwano<sup>1</sup>, K. Tatsuda<sup>1</sup>, C. Toshikawa<sup>1</sup>, M. Hasegawa<sup>1</sup>, Y. Koyama<sup>1</sup>, T. Kobayashi<sup>1</sup>, S. Kosugi<sup>2</sup>, H. Kameyama<sup>1</sup>, H. Aoki<sup>3</sup>, K. Takabe<sup>3</sup>, T. Wakai<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Niigata University Graduate School Of Medical And Dental Sciences,Division Of Digestive And General Surgery,Niigata, NIIGATA, Japan <sup>2</sup>Uonuma Kikan Hospital,Digestive And General Surgery,Minami-Uonuma, NIIGATA, Japan <sup>3</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University School Of Medicine And The Massey Cancer Center,Surgical Oncology,Richmond, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sphingolipids including sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) and ceramide have emerged as key regulatory molecules, controlling various aspects of cell growth and proliferation in cancer and implicated in the mechanism of action of cancer chemotherapeutics. S1P is known to play important roles in cancer cell survival and progression. We previously demonstrated that S1P is a crucial mediator of breast cancer-induced angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis and promote metastasis. On the other hand, ceramide has been considered to mediate anti-proliferative responses, such as cell growth inhibition, apoptosis induction, senescence modulation and autophagy. Interestingly, recent studies suggest that de novo-generated ceramides may have distinct functions based on their fatty acid chain lengths, subcellular localization and/or direct downstream targets. Although important roles of sphingolipids in breast cancer progression has been revealed in experimental models, its roles in human patients are yet to be determined. In this study, we measure the levels of sphingolipids including S1P and ceramides in tumor and normal breast tissue by state-of-the-art mass spectrometry.

Methods: Tumor and normal tissue were obtained from 11 patients with breast cancer. Sphingolipids were measured by liquid chromatography-electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-ESI-MS/MS).

Results: The levels of sphingolipids including sphingosine, dihydro-sphingosine, S1P, dihydro-S1P, ceramides, monohexosylceramides, and sphingomyelin were detected successfully in the tumor and normal breast tissue from 11 breast cancer patients. The levels of S1P and dihydro-S1P in tumor tissue were significantly higher than those in normal breast tissue with almost two-fold increase. Further, C16:0, C22:0, C24:1 and C24:0 ceramides in tumor tissue were also significantly higher than those in normal tissue. Levels of monohexosylceramides and sphingomyelin in tumor tissue were also higher than those in normal breast tissue.

Conclusion: Our results indicate important role of sphingolipids in breast cancer. Further study will be required to investigate the distinct roles of each sphingolipid in human patients. This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research Grant Number 15H05676 and 15K15471 for M.N and 15H04927 for W.T. M.N. is supported by the Uehara Memorial Foundation, Nakayama Cancer Research Institute, Takeda Science Foundation, and Tsukada Memorial Foundation.

abstract_title: Role of Leptin in Enhancement of Proliferation of Gastro-Intestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST-T1) Cells.
author_block: R. Gadde<sup>1</sup>, C. Ripat<sup>1</sup>, A. Paz-Mejia<sup>2</sup>, F. Pendola<sup>1</sup>, R. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, J. Trent<sup>2</sup>, N. Merchant<sup>1</sup>, D. Yakoub<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Unversity Of Miami-Miller School Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,Miami, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami-Miller School Of Medicine,Medical Oncology,Miami, FL, USA
abstract_body:
BACKGROUND: Leptin, an adipokine secreted by adipose tissue has been shown to induce cell proliferation. In vitro and in vivo studies have demonstrated increased expression of leptin receptors in various human malignancies including breast and colorectal cancer. We aimed to investigate the role of leptin in induction and regulation of proliferation of GIST-T1 cells.

Methods: Anticipated inhibitory effect of imatinib on proliferation of GIST-T1 cells was demonstrated at different doses up to 72 hours. Cells were then incubated with exponential doses of leptin alone, proliferative effects were determined by cell viability assay (MTS assay) and flow cytometric cell cycle analysis. Western blotting was done to assess presence of Ob-R receptors. Subsequently, we stimulated the cells with leptin at doses of 12 & 48 ng/ml, and increasing concentrations of NF-kβ inhibitor (Curcumin) at doses of 0 – 51 ng/ml in order to assess blocking possible secondary pathways of leptin effect. We then treated the cells with increasing doses of imatinib (0 uM – 0.1 uM) in the presence of leptin and NF-kβ inhibitor with re-evaluation of proliferation activity.

Results: Cells exhibited a 20-60% increase in proliferative activity with leptin alone at doses > 12 ng/ml; however, western blotting showed absence of Ob-R receptors denoting that leptin activity is likely to be through secondary signal transduction pathway(s). NF-kβ inhibitor nullified the proliferative effect of leptin on the cells at all doses, denoting possible leptin action via an IL-6 mediated pathway. NF-kβ inhibitor, specifically, at a dose of 17 ng/ml combined with imatinib (at all doses) rendered maximum inhibitory effect on proliferation of GIST-T1 cells in the presence of leptin.

Conclusions: Leptin was shown to have a proliferative effect on GIST-T1 cells, albeit possibly via an IL-6 mediated pathway as opposed to its described effect via Ob-R cell surface receptors. Further analysis needs to be done to study the exact mechanism of leptin activity via the IL-6 mediated pathway in order to identify possible molecular therapeutic targets.Introduction: Leptin, an adipokine secreted by adipose tissue has been shown to induce cell proliferation. In vitro and in vivo studies have demonstrated increased expression of leptin receptors in various human malignancies including breast and colorectal cancer. We aimed to investigate the role of leptin in induction and regulation of proliferation of GIST-T1 cells.

abstract_title: Renalase Signaling Enhances Cell Invasion and Promotes Metastasis of Human Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: L. Hollander<sup>1,2</sup>, X. Guo<sup>1</sup>, G. Desir<sup>1</sup>, C. Cha<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Surgical Oncology,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Connecticut,Surgery,Storrs, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Renalase (RNLS) is a secreted flavoprotein that functions as a survival factor for cells and organs exposed to ischemic and toxic injury. We have recently proven it is also overexpressed in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and promotes both growth and survival of pancreatic cancer cells. Elevated RNLS levels were found to be predictive of worse survival in pancreatic cancer. The effects of RNLS on the migratory and invasive abilities of PDAC cells have yet to be investigated.

Methods: Wound healing and matrigel invasion assays were performed to investigate the impact of RNLS on PDAC cell migration and invasion ability. PDAC cell mRNA and protein levels were studied with qRT-PCR and western blots to determine the probable signaling pathways utilized by RNLS in pancreatic cancer cell invasion.

Results: Treatment with RNLS enhanced both the migration and invasion of pancreatic cancer cells. Migratory abilities increased over 2-fold (p=0.01) with RNLS treatment, and the percentage of pancreatic cellular invasion more than doubled with RNLS treatment (82.4% vs. 166.2%, p=0.02). Inhibition of RNLS signaling reversed these findings. RNLS carried out these effects on pancreatic cancer cells likely via the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.

Conclusion: These data suggest RNLS enhances the migration and invasion of PDAC by activating and signaling through the PI3K/AKT pathway, and targeting RNLS could be an attractive therapeutic strategy for pancreatic cancer.

abstract_title: The International General Surgery Journal Club: 12-Month Experience with a Twitter-based Journal Club
author_block: S. B. Bryczkowski<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Cochran<sup>2</sup>, N. J. Gusani<sup>3</sup>, C. Jones<sup>4</sup>, L. S. Kao<sup>5</sup>, B. C. Nwomeh<sup>6</sup>, M. E. Zenilman<sup>7</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New Jersey Medical School,Surgery/Rutgers,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah,Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>Penn State Hershey Medical Center,Surgery,York, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Ohio State University,Trauma/Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Texas Health Science Center At Houston,Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>6</sup>Ohio State University,Pediatric Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>7</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Physician use of social media is becoming more common. Twitter-based journal clubs (JC) are effective, feasible venues for discussing high-impact articles. The purpose of the study was to describe the authors' experience starting the Twitter-based JC, the International General Surgery Journal Club (IGSJC).

Methods: Monthly 2-3 day Twitter JCs were scheduled to discuss recent JAMA Surgery articles. The IGSJC executive committee moderated discussions among authors, followers, and Twitter participants. Descriptive analyses of Twitter transcripts were done. IGSJC followers and Tweets including the #IGSJC hashtag identified participants. The primary outcomes were number and profession of participants, transcript themes, and article downloads.

Results: During the first 12 months of JCs (March 2014 – March 2015), 514 participants from 69 countries tweeted 4,574 times creating 7,085,470 impressions. IGSJC transcript analyses revealed three themes: discussion of articles, physician education, and patient advocacy. There were 5,915 HTML views and PDF downloads combined for the first quarter.

Conclusion: A Twitter-based JC for general surgeons is feasible and surgeons are interested. The IGSJC is dynamic, allowing real-time conversations. The asynchronous design allows international involvement, making it superior to standard JCs. Future potential to communicate new surgical data and offer continuing medical education needs to be explored.

abstract_title: Factors Influencing US Medical Students' Career Choice in Surgery: A Systematic Literature Review
author_block: L. E. Schmidt<sup>1</sup>, C. A. Cooper<sup>1</sup>, W. A. Guo<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>State University Of New York At Buffalo,Surgery,Buffalo, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Interest and applications to surgery have steadily decreased over years in the US. The goal of this review is to collect literatures regarding US medical students' attitude regarding their experience and factors influencing their intentions to pursue surgery as a career. We hypothesize that factors influencing US medical students' career choice in surgery are multi-factorial.

Methods: Six electronic databases (PubMed, SCOPUS, Web of Science, ERIC, Embase and PsycINFO) were searched. The inclusion criteria were studies published after 2000 related to factors influencing surgical career choice among US medical students. We identified 33 relevant articles out of more than 1,000 non-duplicated titles. A quality index score was given to each article to minimize risk of bias.

Results:More than half of medical students made the decision for a surgical career prior to entering medical schools. Good mentorship was a positive influence on students' decision, and students who participated more in the operating room were more likely to pursue surgery. Bias and stereotypes had a large impact on students' perception of general surgery, and influenced their decision. Lifestyle was an important deterrent in pursuing a surgical career. The increase in the importance of lifestyle is generational rather than gender-based. Numbers of articles on each factor are shown in Table 1.

Conclusion:This comprehensive systemic review identifies a comprehensive number of factors involved in US medical students' decision to choose a surgical career. Among them, mentorship, bias and stereotypes, clerkship experience and lifestyle are the major factors. These represent areas that can be improved to attract applicants to general surgery residencies. Since this is an early decision even before entering medical school, early introduction to the field of surgery, recruitment strategies during the preclinical and clinical years of medical school can increase their interest in a future surgical career. Surgical residents and faculty can have a positive influence on medical students' decision to pursue surgery as a career.

abstract_title: The Creation of a Medical School Curriculum in Global Surgery
author_block: S. Mukhopadhyay<sup>1,3</sup>, G. A. Anderson<sup>2,3</sup>, S. Sharma<sup>3</sup>, H. Holmer<sup>5</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>3,4</sup>, L. Hagander<sup>5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Connecticut,General Surgery,Farmington, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,General Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Department Of Global Health And Social Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Children's Hospital Boston,Plastic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Lund University,Pediatric Surgery And Global Pediatrics, Department Of Pediatrics,Lund, SKANE, Sweden
abstract_body:
Introduction: Student interest in global surgery is extremely high. Despite this, few courses in global surgery for medical students exist and none offers a combined approach of didactics and field experience. Trends within global health education demonstrate the importance of didactic and practical components in immersive learning. We have endeavored, therefore, to create a comprehensive course in global surgery offered to medical students.

Methods: We performed a search of the peer-reviewed and grey literature on surgical education. The search revealed a number of international rotations for residents as well as several medical schools offering global health rotations. We found only three with didactic curricula for students interested in global surgery. We reached out to each of these organizations and were able to obtain their full curricula. We reviewed these courses as well as the peer-reviewed literature on global surgery in order to design a curriculum.

Results:We developed a course with a format unlike those of other global surgery courses for students. The students will spend two weeks in Sweden in didactic lectures, small groups, and simulation training followed by two weeks of clerkship activities at a teaching hospital in Zimbabwe. They will return to Sweden for a final week of wrap-up, testing, and presentations. The course will be evaluated using adaptations of previously validated pre/post-course surveys of the student's knowledge and attitudes toward global health and surgery's place in the field.The major themes covered in the course will be global health, surgery as an integral component of global health, clinical skills and knowledge relevant to low resource settings, international partnerships and cultural competency. A key to this course was finding the right international parnter. The swedish university established a partnership with a university in Zimbabwe. Through this partnership students in this course will rotate on the various surgical services at the teaching hospital where they will be accompanied by instructors. Nightly meetings will be held to share experiences from the day. Planned future course iterations will include further collaboration with students from Zimbabwe coming to Sweden.

Conclusion:Despite an enormity of interest, few medical schools offer organized curricula in global surgery. None offer a combination of a didactics in global surgery and a field experience in a low resource setting. This course, which represents a partnership between universities in the U.S., Sweden and Zimbabwe will be the first of its kind. Students and faculty at the three institutions welcomed the unique nature of the curriculum. Students filled the registration spots for the course and will begin in October 2015.

abstract_title: Stress and Balance in Life in General Surgery Residency Training
author_block: C. Mueller<sup>1</sup>, C. Liebert<sup>1</sup>, M. Esquivel<sup>1</sup>, A. Salles<sup>1</sup>, D. Morrison<sup>1</sup>, R. Greco<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical residency can be a trying period, during which many demands are placed upon young adults both personally and professionally. Increasingly, attention is being paid to the concept of achieving 'balance' in life in an effort to preserve social and psychological fitness during the stressful years of residency. We have created a committee to address Balance in Life in our department and in this study attempt to assess the level of balance experienced by our general surgical residents over time and to identify particular causes of stress during their training.

Methods: General surgical residents in an academic medical center were surveyed during their clinical and professional-development years at separate time points over a three-year period (2013-2015). Two paper-and-pencil questionnaires were used: The Life Balance survey consists of 15 true/false questions, the Causes of Stress survey requires ratings of 10 potential stressors.

Results:General surgical residents from all post-graduate levels, including professional development years, participated in the study in 2013, 2014, and 2015. We found that residents felt significantly more 'out of balance' as they progressed in training year, with more PGY1s reporting being 'in balance' than their more senior colleagues. Further, there was improvement in overall 'balance' over time. In terms of causes of stress, we noted that personal stressors were more frequently cited than professional stressors across all years.

Conclusion:Balance in life appears to be more difficult to achieve for general surgical residents as they advance in training. However, we have been able to show improvement in overall balance in our academic program over a three-year period, perhaps due to the dedication of departmental resources to this specific issue. We also were able to identify important causes of stress for all residents, with personal (eg, health problems, break-ups, finances) being cited more frequently than professional (difficult colleagues or faculty) issues.

abstract_title: Improved Outcomes for Inborn Babies with Gastroschisis
author_block: B. G. Dalton<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Gonzalez<sup>1</sup>, S. R. Reddy<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Hendrickson<sup>1</sup>, S. D. St. Peter<sup>1</sup>, C. W. Iqbal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Mercy Hospital- University Of Missouri Kansas City,Pediatric Surgery,Kansas City, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastroschisis (GS) a common abdominal wall defect necessitating neonatal surgery and intensive care. Since the opening of a delivery center within our free-standing children's hospital in 2011 the majority of patients treated for GS at our center are inborn. We hypothesized that inborn patients had improved outcomes compared to patients born at an outside hospital (outborn) and transferred to our center for definitive treatment.

Methods: A single center retrospective chart review at a pediatric tertiary care center was performed from 2011 to 2014. All patients whose primary surgical treatment of GS was performed at this center were included. Findings are reported in mean ± standard deviations. Comparative analysis was performed using student t test for continuous variables and Fishers exact for binary variables. Significance was defined as a P ≤ 0.05.

Results: During the study period 79 patients with GS were identified. Of these, 53 were inborn and 26 were outborn. The rat e of complicated GS was higher in the outborn group (32%) compared to the inborn population (11%) (p=0.03). Given the expected wide variability in outcomes for patients with complicated GS, outcomes for uncomplicated GS were analyzed. Table 1 shows perioperative outcomes comparing inborn and outborn patients with uncomplicated GS. Length of stay, readmission rate and TPN were all significantly decreased for inborn patients, while time to definitive closure was similar. Mortality was 0% for both inborn and outborn patients.

Conclusion: Benefit is derived for patients with GS who are inborn rather than outborn.

abstract_title: Risk Factors Associated With Morbidity And Mortality In Patients With Peritonitis In Rwanda
author_block: C. Ngarambe<sup>1,3</sup>, L. Ndayizeye<sup>1,3</sup>, B. Smart<sup>5</sup>, R. Riviello<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Majyambere<sup>4</sup>, J. Rickard<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Teaching Hospital Of Kigali,Kigali, , Rwanda <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Rwanda,College Of Medicine And Health Sciences,Kigali, , Rwanda <sup>4</sup>Kibungo Referral Hospital,Kibungo, , Rwanda <sup>5</sup>Rush University Medical Center,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Peritonitis is a surgical emergency associated with significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. In Rwanda, peritonitis is linked with major complications and mortality, though little is known regarding risk factors associated with morbidity and mortality. This study aimed to identify risk factors associated with mortality among patients with peritonitis and propose strategies to improve management of peritonitis at a referral hospital in Rwanda.

Methods: All patients operated for peritonitis at a referral hospital in Rwanda over a six-month period were analyzed. Charts were prospectively reviewed for demographic, clinical and administrative data. Univariate and multivariate regression analyses were used to determine factors associated with in-hospital mortality and return to the operating room. Factors included in the analyses included sociodemographic factors, clinical presentation, laboratory studies, diagnoses and operative findings.

Results:Over a six-month period, 281 patients underwent operation for peritonitis. The in-hospital post-operative mortality rate was 17%. 36 (13%) patients required a return to the operating room. On multivariate analysis, factors associated with mortality included: high American Society of Anesthesiology (ASA) score (ASA>3) (Odds Ratio (OR) 7.4, 95% Confidence Interval (CI): 1.2, 44.6) and vasopressor requirements (OR 20.6, 95% CI: 2.3, 185.7). Hypoxia on admission was associated with a return to the operating room (OR 9.4, 95%CI: 1.7, 52.7).

Conclusion:Peritonitis causes significant morbidity and mortality in Rwanda. By identifying factors associated with complications and mortality, mechanisms to improve the quality of care and improve resource utilization can be achieved. As mortality is correlated with high ASA score and vasopressor use, greater availability of critical care services and intensive care access could potentially improve outcomes.

abstract_title: Outcomes of Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy in a Senegalese Center.Papa Saloum DIOP, I Ka, B FALL
author_block: P. S. DIOP<sup>1</sup>, P. S. DIOP<sup>1</sup>, P. S. DIOP<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cheikh Anta DIOP University,Surgery,Dakar, DAKAR, Senegal
abstract_body:
Introduction: As in the western countries the concept mini-invasive surgery and the avantages it offers to the patients have led to consider in Senegal also laparoscopic cholecystectomy as the gold standart for surgical treatment of gallblader lithiasis.

Methods: Authors report their experience of laparoscopic cholecystectomy between March 2006 to March 2015. During that period 255 patients underwent cholecystectomy by this way; 171 women and 84 men, 6 to 80 years old (mean age: 45,5), Forty seven(47/255) of them had sickle cell anemia.

Results: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy was done in American position with 3 or 4 trocars. The operative time was 20 to 120 minutes (mean time 57 minuties). The conversion rate was 19/255. The complications were 4 biliay wounds, 6 hemorrhges, 1 slipped cystic duct ligation, 1 lost stone. 17 gallblader effractions, 1 discovery of cancer. The morbidiry rate 10/255; 7 trocars site infection and 2 post operative wound dehiscinces, 1 choledochal stenosis.

Conclusion: Laparoscopic surgery is possible in developping countries. With improvement of the instuments, laparoscopic surgery should take an important part in surgeons training and will play an important role in surgical activities in developping coountries.

abstract_title: The Impact of Major League Baseball on the Incidence of Operative Hand and Face Trauma
author_block: J. A. Ricci<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Vargas<sup>1</sup>, O. A. Ho<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Lin<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Lee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sponsorship deals between hospitals and professional sports teams are not only a sign of prestige, but are also a powerful advertising tool to attract patients. Our medical center is not only the official hospital for a professional baseball team, but our center is located a half mile from the stadium. Anecdotal evidence suggests there is a link between trauma and home games; however, there is a paucity of data regarding the variability of operative hand and facial trauma. This study aims to characterize the hand and facial trauma requiring reconstructive surgical intervention at a Level 1 trauma center over a 14 year period, focusing on the effect of a professional baseball team.

Methods: A retrospective review of all reconstructive surgical cases for traumatic hand or facial injuries at a Level 1 center between 1/1/1999 and 12/31/2012 was performed. The dates of injury, admission status, and operative repair were collected as well as demographic information including: gender, age, state of residence, and insurance status. Patients were categorized into groups based on whether their trauma occurred on the date of a home game. Descriptive analysis of the variability in injury volume was performed for all cases.

Results: Overall, the highest incidence of hand and facial trauma requiring subsequent operative plastic surgical intervention was in the month of October, followed by July and August. Hand trauma peaked in July, while facial trauma peaked in October with a relative nadir in the summer months. The most injuries overall occurred on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, though hand trauma was most commonly seen on Friday and facial trauma on Monday. Overall, operative trauma requiring reconstructive interventions occurred at a rate of 33.4 injuries per 100 days when home games were played, compared to 22.2 injuries per 100 days when the team did not have a home game. Similar trends were noted when subgroup analysis was performed individually for hand or facial trauma. Additionally, when the groups were compared, patients were more likely to present as a result of motorcycle accidents (3.1% v. 1.5%; p =0.04) or bicycle accidents (5.0% v. 2.6%; p =0.01) when home games were played. Other mechanisms of trauma, age, gender, insurance status, need for admission and length of stay were not statistically different between the groups.

Conclusion: Overall volume of operative hand and facial trauma is similar to previous findings with relative peaks during late summer months and on weekends. Subgroup analysis reveals considerable variability in the monthly and weekly patterns of traumatic hand and facial injuries. Importantly, although there were few differences between the groups, there was an increased rate of injuries associated with dates when there our local professional baseball team had home games. Further analysis of these trends may allow improved specialty resource allocation and strategies for injury prevention and treatment.

abstract_title: A Short Course in Medical Malpractice for Academic Surgery Faculty
author_block: S. E. Raper<sup>1</sup>, J. Joseph<sup>1</sup>, M. Nepps<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Office Of General Counsel,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In Pennsylvania, medical malpractice premiums are a major cost to individual physicians and academic departments. Physicians fear malpractice claims but there is a dearth of literature regarding how to educate physicians on medical malpractice. The purpose of this work is to describe one approach for educating academic faculty surgeons on current concepts of medical malpractice and provide some guidance on how to minimize the risks of being named in a malpractice claim.

Methods: The course had five parts: the basics of negligent torts, the special case of medical malpractice, and the role of expert witnesses; the cost of malpractice insurance, divisional and individual risk rating based on experience points; current departmental claims experience; strategies for decreasing the risk of being named in a claim, and, an overview of malpractice reforms designed to make compensation for medical error more efficient. 80% participation was set as a successful attendance rate. CME credit was offered and a portion of the annual at risk salary was awarded. An anonymous survey was distributed and the results tabulated to assist in improving future courses. Two free text questions about positive and negative aspects of the course. A weighted average of 4.5 or above was considered satisfactory. Seven questions were cast in a five point Likert scale format with anchors of Strongly Disagree and Strongly Agree:Q1: The goals were clearly communicated;Q2: The legal elements of negligence and medical malpractice was instructive;Q3: The role of expert witnesses in malpractice litigation was interesting;Q4: Malpractice premium allocation as applied to individual Penn physicians was helpful;Q5: Departmental malpractice claim analysis was clear and educational;Q6: The examples of good and bad documentation were useful;Q7: Communication techniques were helpful in future communications;

Results:95 faculty were eligible to attend. 80 attended either in person or by reviewing a web-based video (completion rate of 84%). Quantitatively, five of seven questions had a weighted average of more than 4.5 (N = 48, response rate = 60%, see Table). Qualitatively, the course was reviewed very favorably (data not shown).

Conclusion:The high percentage of participation and overall rating suggest that the course was successful. This course was one facet of an approach to decrease the risk of malpractice claims. Unique aspects of this course include an emphasis on Department-specific data and the approaches to minimize risk of future claims. Further work is necessary to document a sustained reduction in the number of claims. Given the state-specific nature of malpractice claims and litigation, individual departments must particularize similar presentations.

abstract_title: Medical Student Hand Preference, Perceived Dexterity, and Impact of Handedness on Training
author_block: D. S. Callahan<sup>1</sup>, C. DeVirgilio<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Tillou<sup>2</sup>, D. DeUgarte<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harbor UCLA Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Torrance, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine, University Of California At Los Angeles,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Historically, the ubiquity of right-handed instruments and a predominance of right-handed surgical faculty have presented a challenge to left-hand dominant surgeons. We sought to evaluate contemporary trends in hand preference, perceived dexterity, and impact of handedness on training amongst medical students.

Methods: An anonymous survey was distributed to third and fourth year medical students at the end of the academic year (when they were likely to have completed at least one surgical clerkship). Hand preference was queried for various activities (i.e. throwing an object, cutting with scissors, holding a needle driver, using a scalpel). A Likert scale was utilized to assess perceived dexterity and impact of handedness on surgical training. We also evaluated whether handedness and perceived dexterity were associated with a decision to pursue a surgical specialty. Fisher's exact test was utilized to compare the proportion of students reporting a positive response (e.g. agree/strongly-agree), contrasting students who reported writing with left and right hand.

Results: Of the medical students queried, 131 (37%) responded. The majority (80%) reported writing with their right hand (19% left hand; 1% both). Results are summarized in Table 1. Left-hand writers frequently prefer their right hand for other activities: 42% holding a needle driver, 29% cutting with scissors, 21% using a scalpel. A greater percent of left-handed students felt that their performance would improve if trainers better adapted to their handedness (70% vs. 14%, p<0.001), that they would benefit from additional training with right-handed instruments (61% vs. 31%, p<0.01), and that they would benefit if left-handed instruments were made available (63% vs. 8%, p<0.001). Perceived dexterity was significantly associated with plans to pursue a surgical specialty (p<0.0001).

Conclusion: Medical students who write with their left hand reported being more ambidextrous than those who write with their right hand. They also perceive that their handedness may impact their training and decision to pursue a surgical specialty. Left-handed medical students were also more likely to report that they would benefit from left-handed instrumentation and training that adapts to their handedness. These results provide a contemporary snapshot of hand preference in medical students and a compelling argument for improving and adapting surgical training for left-handed individuals.

abstract_title: The Impact of Confident Behavior on Perception of Competence in Practicing Surgeons
author_block: I. Lizarraga<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Kibbe<sup>3</sup>, K. Reid Lombardo<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Kapadia<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Iowa,Iowa City, IA, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>3</sup>Northwestern University,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Differences in reported confidence have been reported in surgical trainees of the same level. It is unclear whether this persists in practicing surgeons or affects performance, but anecdotal evidence suggests that this is likely. The purpose of this study is to gather opinions from practicing surgeons about the role of professional confidence in order to develop a survey instrument about surgeon confidence.

Methods: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with fourteen practicing surgeons from a variety of practice environments (private, academic), specialties (general surgery, urology, obstetrics and orthopedics) and geographic locations. Answers to open-ended questions about surgeon confidence were transcribed, coded and analyzed by two independent researchers. An iterative process was utilized to identify well-defined themes. Saturation was achieved.

Results:More than half the interviewees were male (64%), and the average age was 47 years (range 35-74 years). Time since entering practice ranged from 1-42 years (mean 15.1 years). All respondents felt that confidence was important for surgeons, and the main reasons given were the need to make important decisions quickly with limited information, and to perform complex procedures based on those decisions. Decision-making was felt to be difficult without confidence in one's skills, knowledge and judgement. Additionally, one-third observed that confidence was necessary to tolerate poor outcomes and the inherent uncertainties associated with surgical practice. Most surgeons (86%) agreed that, in general, a confident surgeon was a better surgeon, although many respondents (71%) stressed the dangers of overconfidence. Confidence was felt to facilitate better decision-making (36%) and arise from experience and good outcomes. Surgeons viewed low confidence as arising from less preparation, knowledge, or skill (43%). A surgeon was perceived as confident if he/she was decisive and rarely deviated from plan (29%), articulated thoughts clearly (29%), appeared calm and organized (36%) and appeared to be well-prepared (21%). Several surgeons (43%) acknowledged projecting more confidence in certain clinical situations than was felt, stating that it was important for instilling trust in patients and providing leadership for the medical team. Additionally, projecting confidence was felt to be self-reinforcing.

Conclusion:Confidence is often equated with competence by practicing surgeons, and is felt to be essential to the type of decision making inherent in surgical practice. This underlines the importance of fostering confident behavior in trainees. It also highlights the need to teach techniques that allow both trainees and practicing surgeons to address uncertainty in decision-making and gaps in knowledge and skill without fearing loss of respect from colleagues and patients. A national survey querying surgeons regarding confidence will be developed using these themes.

abstract_title: Intercostal to Phrenic Nerve Grafting in Ventilator Dependent Patients with High Spinal Cord Injury
author_block: K. Nandra<sup>1</sup>, M. Harari<sup>1</sup>, T. Price<sup>1</sup>, P. J. Greaney<sup>1</sup>, M. Weinstein<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Jefferson Univeristy Hospital,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diaphragmatic pacing can be used in patients suffering from ventilator-dependent respiratory failure as a means to reduce or even eliminate the need for ventilator support. However, this technique relies on intact phrenic nerve function and is significantly less effective in patients with a spinal cord injury in the C3-C5 levels. Recently, the use of phrenic nerve reconstruction with intercostal nerves has expanded the indications for diaphragmatic pacing. Our study aimed to evaluate the use and efficacy of intercostal nerve transfer in diaphragmatic pacing.

Methods: 5 ventilator dependent patients with high cervical injuries were selected for this study. Each patient demonstrated either unilateral or bilateral phrenic nerve dysfunction via external neck or intra-operative nerve stimulation. Each patient underwent laparoscopic implantation of the diaphragmatic pacer followed by a thoracotomy for an intercostal to phrenic nerve graft. The patients were followed post operatively and ventilator dependence was reassessed for at 1 year post-op.

Results: Initial results of this ongoing study show that 3 out of 5 patients are tolerating ventilator weaning trials. One patient can tolerate spontaneous breathing for 24 hours at a time. 1 patient is only 4 months post op and is still awaiting axonal regeneration, which takes approximately 1 year.

Conclusion: We demonstrate that intercostal nerve reconstruction of the phrenic nerve with diaphragmatic pacing is a safe and promising procedure for ventilator dependent patients with direct phrenic nerve injury, offering unprecedented improvements to functional status. The nerve's proximity to the diaphragm and its length make it amenable for this surgery. With further research, diaphragmatic pacing can be extended to more patients with direct phrenic nerve injuries and/or high cervical spine injuries.

abstract_title: Comparing Transanal Endoscopic Microsurgery & Transanal Minimally Invasive Surgery in the Modern Era
author_block: J. P. Costello<sup>1</sup>, Y. Alimi<sup>1</sup>, C. Long<sup>1</sup>, C. Vadlamudi<sup>1</sup>, A. P. Chudzinski<sup>1</sup>, M. Bayasi<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>MedStar Georgetown University Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Colorectal Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Transanal endoscopic microsurgery (TEM) is a well-established technique for the local excision of rectal tumors compared to traditional transanal techniques. However, it requires specialized equipment with significant cost that is not commonly available in most clinical settings. The recent emergence of transanal minimally invasive surgery (TAMIS) as an additional technique to address these tumors provides the opportunity to embrace the benefits of TEM while using commonly available and less expensive operative equipment. However, as with any new technique, the oncologic principles and outcomes must not be compromised. This review will focus on comparing outcomes between TEM and TAMIS utilizing available studies in the published literature.

Methods: A systematic review of the literature (PubMed, EBSCO, Cochrane Library) was conducted to identify studies related to TEM and TAMIS (since its emergence in the literature in 2010). Only one experimental study to date has compared TAMIS and TEM head-to-head from a technical standpoint, although several studies on quality of life between these two techniques do exist.

Results: Margin positivity following resection is low with both techniques (TAMIS approximately 4%). Recurrence of disease is infrequent occurring in 4% of TAMIS cases and approximately 5% of TEM cases for small tumors (up to 3 cm), although the rate of recurrence for TEM does rise with larger tumors. Overall complication rates between TAMIS and TEM are comparable with perioperative morbidity from TAMIS ranging from 7.4%-19% and from TEM ranging from 6%-31%. One experimental comparison study reveals that TEM is quicker and subjectively allows for better appreciation of the surgical dissection and less difficulty with suturing compared to TAMIS.
