Quality of life after resection and anorectal function are similar between TAMIS and TEM. In addition, TAMIS is now being applied to total mesorectal excision of rectal tumors although early data are limited.

Conclusion: Although long-term data for TAMIS are limited, both TAMIS and TEM are valuable techniques for the local excision of Early stage rectal cancer. Given its lower cost and faster learning curve, TAMIS holds significant promise in becoming the favored technique. However, randomized prospective data comparing these two techniques does not exist. As such, a randomized, controlled trial comparing TEM to TAMIS in the management of rectal cancer is timely and essential.

abstract_title: A 14 Year Review of Operative Hand and Facial Trauma at a Level 1 Medical Center
author_block: C. R. Vargas<sup>1</sup>, M. K. Markarian<sup>1</sup>, P. G. Koolen<sup>1</sup>, A. Abbasi<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Lee<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Lin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Plastic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Despite anecdotal trends, there is a paucity of data regarding the weekly and monthly incidence of hand and face trauma requiring Plastic and Reconstructive surgical intervention. The goal of this study was to evaluate the variability of operative hand and face trauma over a 14 year period at a Level 1 trauma center.

Methods: A retrospective review of all Plastic and Reconstructive surgical cases for traumatic hand or face injuries at a Level 1 center in New England between 1/1/1999 and 12/31/2012 was performed. The dates of injury, admission (if applicable), and operative repair were collected and patients organized based on the date of injury. Demographic information included gender, age at injury, state of residence, and health insurance status. Length of stay and traumatic mechanism were also identified for comparison. Descriptive analysis of the variability in injury volume was performed for all cases as well as for hand trauma and face trauma subgroups.

Results:Overall, the highest incidence of hand and face trauma requiring subsequent Plastic or Reconstructive surgery intervention was in the month of October, followed by July and August. Hand trauma peaked in July, while face trauma peaked in October with a relative nadir in the summer months (Figure 1). The most injuries overall occurred on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday - though hand trauma was most common on Friday and face trauma on Monday.

Conclusion:Overall volume of operative hand and face trauma is similar to previous findings with relative peaks during late summer months and on weekends. Subgroup analysis reveals considerable variability in the monthly and weekly patterns of traumatic hand and face injuries. Further analysis of these trends may allow improved specialty resource allocation and strategies for injury prevention.

abstract_title: A Novel Approach to Diaphragm Resection in Cytoreductive Surgery
author_block: C. Schlegel<sup>1</sup>, C. Kiernan<sup>1</sup>, N. Merchant<sup>2</sup>, C. Bailey<sup>1</sup>, A. Parikh<sup>1</sup>, K. Idrees<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Miami,Miami, FL, USA <sup>1</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Nashville, TN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Full-thickness diaphragm resection is often necessary during cytoreductive surgery (CRS) for peritoneal surface malignancies including gastrointestinal peritoneal carcinomatosis, ovarian cancer and peritoneal mesothelioma. Traditional methods of resection risk exposure of the thoracic cavity to direct peritoneal contamination. We describe a novel technique using a stapling device for full-thickness diaphragmatic resection without entering the pleural cavity.

Methods: A retrospective review of all patients undergoing CRS at our institution from December 2012 to June 2014 was performed. Full-thickness diaphragm resection was performed secondary to gross involvement of the diaphragm using sequential fires of the Endoscopic Linear Cutter stapler (Echelon FlexTM with cartridges of open staple height of 3.8 to 4.2mm depending on thickness). Breathing was held during individual stapler firings.

Results: A total of sixty patients were included in the cohort. Nine patients (15%) underwent diaphragm resection to achieve complete cytoreduction. Seven patients underwent unilateral diaphragm resection (right-sided). One patient required suture line reinforcement using #1 PDS because the staple line was thought to be tenuous. Two patients underwent bilateral diaphragm resection. Thoracostomy tubes were electively placed intraoperatively in the initial three patients, and were removed prior to discharge. In the subsequent six patients, no thoracostomy tube was placed. All patients were extubated immediately post-operatively or within 24 hours of their operation. There were no postoperative respiratory complications, including pneumonia, thoracic abscess, thoracostomy placement, or respiratory failure requiring reintubation. To date, there has been no documented thoracic recurrence of disease on cross-sectional imaging in the patients who underwent diaphragm resection.

Conclusion: Full-thickness diaphragm resection using the Endoscopic Linear Cutter stapler in patients undergoing cytoreductive surgery for peritoneal carcinomatosis involving the diaphragm is a safe, hemostatic, and expeditious technique. More importantly, this technique prevents oncological contamination of the thoracic cavity and reduces the need for pleural drainage.

abstract_title: Oncoplastic Breast Surgery: Achieving Oncological and Aesthetic Outcomes
author_block: M. Van Paridon<sup>1</sup>, M. Paul<sup>1</sup>, P. Kamali<sup>1</sup>, A. Ibrahim<sup>3</sup>, S. J. Lin<sup>1</sup>, R. Sharma<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Division Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Louisiana State University Health Sciences Center,Divison Of Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,New Orleans, LA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast-conserving therapy (BCT) has become the preferred treatment modality for breast cancer. Oncoplastic surgery combines both BCT and reconstructive techniques. Choosing the best method to repair a defect is essential in optimizing outcomes and minimizing the potential for postoperative complications within this patient population. The aim of this study is to present a treatment algorithm based on diagnosis, tumor size, tumor location, breast size and patient satisfaction.

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of all patients undergoing immediate oncoplastic reconstruction (simple closure, tissue rearrangement, pedicle flap, mastopexy, bilateral reduction) between 2010 and 2015. Operative data, pre- and post-operative pathology reports and follow-up appointments from patient records were analyzed. Patient satisfaction was measured using the BREAST-Q questionnaire.

Results: A total of forty-two women were included in the study. A majority of women had invasive ductal carcinoma (n=21, 45.7%). In most, the tumor was located in the upper outer quadrant (n=25, 54.3%). Twenty-two women (52.4%) had a bra cup size of either A, B, or C and 18 women (42.9%) had cup size of D or larger. The most common approach in women with cups A, B, or C was a simple closure or tissue rearrangement, and, when needed, a pedicle flap. In patients with a D cup or larger and grade II-III breast ptosis, a bilateral reduction technique was performed. These approaches provided the best aesthetic and oncological outcomes with negative resection margins. Patient satisfaction was high within our patient population.

Conclusion: In this study the authors present a reconstructive algorithm describing different oncoplastic approaches and aimed at providing a validated guideline for oncoplastic reconstructive surgery.

abstract_title: An Improved Humanized Murine Model for Excisional Wound Healing Using K14 Transgenic Mice
author_block: M. S. Hu<sup>1</sup>, A. T. Cheung<sup>1</sup>, T. Leavitt<sup>1</sup>, G. G. Walmsley<sup>1</sup>, E. R. Zielins<sup>1</sup>, W. Hong<sup>1</sup>, T. Zhu<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Wan<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Gurtner<sup>1</sup>, H. Lorenz<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Longaker<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,School Of Medicine,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: An appropriate murine model of wound healing should replicate human wound repair to accurately predict therapeutic outcomes. By placing a silicone splint, contracture of the panniculus carnosus is prevented allowing the wound to heal primarily by granulation and re-epithelialization, resembling the human wound repair process. However, accurate determination of when the wound is fully healed is difficult and may skew results. Herein, we describe a novel methodology to more accurately determine wound healing using a double transgenic mouse.

Methods: Double transgenic mice were created by crossing K14-Cre mice with reporter line ROSAmT/mG, effectively labeling skin with GFP. Circular cutaneous full-thickness excisional wounds 6 mm in diameter were created on the left and right dorsum of mice just caudal to the scapula. Silicone splints were placed and affixed to the skin using cyanoacrylate glue and 8 simple interrupted stitches using 6-0 nylon suture. The wounds were covered with a clear occlusive dressing, which was replaced every other day when gross macroscopic light and fluorescence images were taken.

Results:By using gross macroscopic light imaging, the average time to full closure was determined to be 13.6 days post-wounding. Using fluorescence imaging, the average time to full closure was 11.6 days (*p<0.05) post-wounding. Histology with fluorescence imaging confirmed wounds were fully healed by 12 days following wound creation.

Conclusion:These data suggest that wound closure is more accurately determined using the K14-Cre/ROSAmT/mG double transgenic mouse and fluorescence imaging. Based on our data, this mouse model should be utilized as a quantitative and reproducible model of excisional wound healing.

abstract_title: Bariatric Surgery:  Is Additional Training Really Needed?
author_block: J. P. Kuckelman<sup>1</sup>, J. Bingham<sup>1</sup>, M. Barron<sup>1</sup>, M. Lallemand<sup>1</sup>, S. R. Steele<sup>1</sup>, V. Sohn<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Madigan Army Medical Center,General Surgery,Tacoma, WA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: As a reflection of the world-wide obesity epidemic, an increasing percentage of a surgical resident's cumulative operative experience is in bariatric surgery. As these are often complex cases, the impact of resident involvement on patient safety has been questioned. Our aim was to review patient outcomes in resident-associated bariatric procedures

Methods: We reviewed patients undergoing a bariatric procedure from July 2007 to July 2014 in a tertiary care single center. All procedures were performed primarily by a general surgery resident and proctored by an attending general surgeon. Primary outcomes were operative volume and leak rate.

Results:A total of 2,245 bariatric procedures were performed with resident involvement from July 2007 to July 2014. Bariatric operations studied included laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (32%) and laparoscopic bypass (68%). Eighteen leaks were identified with an overall leak rate of 0.74%. Average operating times over all resident levels was 161 minutes. The average number of bariatric procedures performed by graduating chief residents is 89. The number of leaks and operative duration between resident year groups were not statistically significant (p .54 and p=.97), respectively.

Conclusion:Involvement of general surgery residents does not have a negative impact on outcomes in bariatric surgery. Furthermore, these operations can safely be performed with staff supervision at the junior resident level without a significant difference in leak rate.

abstract_title: CHARACTERIZATION OF PATIENTS ADMITTED TO THE ACUTE CARE SURGERY SERVICE OF A TERTIARY CARE HOSPITAL
author_block: B. Misercola<sup>1</sup>, J. Dreifus<sup>1</sup>, M. Douglas<sup>1</sup>, S. Ranney<sup>1</sup>, K. Sihler<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Maine Medical Center,Surgery,Portland, ME, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: To identify and characterize patients accepted to the Acute Care Surgery (ACS) service at a tertiary teaching hospital and compare patients accepted from outside hospitals (transferred patients) to those accepted through the emergency department (local patients). We sought to describe multiple characteristics including origin, reason for transfer, co-morbidities, LOS, ICU admission, and surgical treatments or specialist procedures undertaken for all patients. We hypothesized those patients being transferred would be older, have more co-morbidities, and longer LOS than local patients.

Methods: This is an observational, cross sectional study using chart review of hospital medical records. Adult (>18 yrs) patients admitted to the ACS service between January 2014 – December 2014 were eligible for inclusion. We calculated a co-morbidity score based on the Charlson Co-morbidity Index. T tests or non-parametric equivalent and chi square tests will be used for statistical analysis. Significant differences in clinical outcomes will be examined by regression analysis.

Results:A majority of transfer patients originated from community hospitals affiliated with our medical center. Pancreaticobiliary complaints were the most common reason for admission, followed by problems associated with the small bowel (ischemia, obstruction). Transferred patients had a longer LOS, were older, and had more co-morbidities. ICU admission was four times more common in transfer patients. Medicare was the most common insurance for all patients.

Conclusions:Patients accepted in transfer to the ACS service at our center were older, more complex, and had longer LOS than those admitted through the emergency department. This study forms the basis of planning for the support of general surgery in smaller hospitals with regionalization for more complex care.

abstract_title: Initiation of a Medical Student Run Surgery Journal Club
author_block: C. H. Williams<sup>1</sup>, K. S. Malek<sup>1</sup>, M. K. McLeod<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Michigan State University,College Of Human Medicine,East Lansing, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Michigan State University,Department Of Surgery,Lansing, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Journal clubs can be an integral part of learner and provider continuing medical education. Journal clubs encourage participants to keep abreast of current medical literature and to practice critical analysis and discussion of primary literature; as well, there is increasing emphasis on application of evidence-based medicine and primary literature analysis in the education of medical students. Often, when medical students become residents, they have never taken an active role in a journal club discussion. To our knowledge, there are no journal clubs that are intended for and led by medical students. We sought to implement a Surgery Journal Club that was led by medical students under guidance of attending surgeons, with the goals of giving students opportunities to practice analyzing primary literature, to practice facilitation and participating in journal club discussion, and to educate students on important issues in surgery.

Methods: We conducted a needs assessment survey of 38 third-year medical students. The journal club met once monthly for five consecutive months based on findings from that survey. Articles were chosen by students with input from an attending surgeon and were distributed at least one week in advance. Each meeting was attended by 3 to 8 students and a different attending surgeon. Discussion was facilitated by both student leaders and the attending surgeon. At the end of the semester, we conducted a feedback survey of both participating students and attending surgeons.

Results: 24/38 (63%) students responded to our needs assessment survey. 33% of these students were interested in surgery as a career; 50% said a surgery journal club would add value to the clinical curriculum. 50% of the respondents had never before participated in a journal club. Feedback from the faculty (4/5 responded) indicated they all 'strongly agreed' that they enjoyed facilitating a journal club, that the journal club was a good use of their time, and that they would facilitate another session in the future. Student feedback was received from 7 students out of 10 (70%) who attended at least one session. They indicated that the two main benefits to journal club participation were 'practicing critical analysis of primary literature' and 'reading and discussing ‘classic' articles in the field'. Additionally, students noted that a benefit to the journal clubs was networking with faculty and mentorship opportunities. All students agreed that they enjoyed the session(s) they attended, and 6/7 (86%) said the Journal Club should continue.

Conclusion: The initial implementation of a Surgery Journal Club was successful, as gauged by both participating medical students and attending surgeons. The Journal Club met the initial objectives, with the added benefit of mentorship opportunities. We plan to continue the Journal Club, and we encourage other medical school clinical sites to develop similar programs.

abstract_title: Electronic Medical Record Use Outside the Hospital: Impact on Resident Work Hours and Satisfaction
author_block: M. A. Simon<sup>1</sup>, F. Scott<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Carson<sup>1</sup>, B. Hamby<sup>1</sup>, N. Hedayati<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Davis,Surgery,Sacramento, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although the implementation of the electronic medical record (EMR) has led to some positive changes in health care systems such as improved delivery of care, decreased medication errors, and decreased cost, physicians have reported a decline in overall work satisfaction since EMR implementation. To date, few studies that have ever evaluated resident work hour compliance or resident satisfaction in relation to the use of EMR. The objective of our study was to assess whether EMR access impacts resident duty hours as well as resident satisfaction.

Methods: This was an institutional review board approved single site study of all residents at an academic center. Residents were invited to participate through email and asked to complete an anonymous ten question survey.

Results:151 residents responded to the on-line survey. There were 77 men and 72 women. 39 surgical residents in various years of training participated. 80.1% of respondents reported spending 1-3 hours per day charting or reviewing EMR outside of the hospital (Figure 1). 66.9% of residents reported being 'satisfied' with EMR use, and 62% reported that they were 'satisfied' professionally.

Conclusion:Remote EMR access is clearly associated with a significant proportion of time resident physicians spend on patient care outside of the hospital setting. However, residents satisfaction with EMR and professional satisfaction remain high. The nature of remote EMR work, which could be continuation of unfinished patient charting or preparation for conference or operative room planning, has not been well defined. Furthermore, the impact of increased EMR use on resident education and work hour compliance needs better evaluation. Future studies are required to evaluate how resident work hour compliance can be implemented in this era of advancing technologies and easy accessibility.

abstract_title: Mastering the Interpretation of the Ubiquitous Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve
author_block: J. Carter<sup>1</sup>, J. Pan<sup>2</sup>, S. Rai<sup>2</sup>, S. Galandiuk<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Louisville School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Colorectal Surgery,Louisville, KY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Louisville School Of Public Health And Information Sciences,Department Of Bioinformatics And Biostatistics,Louisville, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Clinicians and researchers should have basic knowledge of research methodology used to evaluate the efficacy of diagnostic tests. In order to help understand and more correctly interpret statistics reported in clinical studies, we provide a simple, yet comprehensive, explanation of common research methodology involving receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves. ROC curves are most frequently used in medicine as a quantitative method of evaluating diagnostic tests. While this type of statistical analysis is widely used in surgical research and publication, in fact, many of these methods are not fully understood by clinicians or researchers.

Methods: In order to demonstrate the interpretation of an ROC curve we utilized results from a plasma-based test developed to diagnose colorectal cancer. Blood samples were taken from 67 patients, 18 patients with colorectal cancer and 49 patients with other types of cancer (breast, lung or pancreas). Using plasma miRNA as biomarkers, a model was developed to predict from which patients the blood sample had come from. ROC curves were generated to determine the accuracy of this plasma test. ROC curves are made by plotting sensitivity (true positive rate) on the y-axis, and 1-specificity (false positive rate) on the x-axis. Each point plotted on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular threshold cut off. It is generally accepted that at least 100 pair values are generated to create a curve; note that more pair values provide a better estimate of area under the curve (AUC).

Results:Curves that approach closest to coordinate (x=0, y=1) are more highly predictive, whereas curves that lie close to the line of equality indicate that the result is no better than chance. The optimum sensitivity and specificity can be determined as the point where the minimum distance line crosses the ROC curve (see figure). This point corresponds to the Youden Index, J, a function of sensitivity and specificity commonly used to rate diagnostic tests. The AUC is used to quantify the overall ability of a test to discriminate between two outcomes.

Conclusion:By following these simple guidelines, interpretation of ROC curves will be less difficult and more useful when writing, reviewing or interpreting scientific papers. Parameters such as test sensitivity and specificity can be obtained from ROC curves and can be helpful in deciding whether a diagnostic test is acceptable for use.

abstract_title: Clinical Outcomes of Ventral Mediastinal Hernias: A Tertiary Care Center Experience within the Past Decade
author_block: S. M. Cruz<sup>1,2</sup>, A. C. Akinkuotu<sup>1,2</sup>, D. L. Cass<sup>1,2</sup>, M. L. Peterson<sup>2</sup>, T. C. Lee<sup>1,2</sup>, C. I. Cassady<sup>3</sup>, A. R. Mehollin-Ray<sup>3</sup>, R. Ruano<sup>4</sup>, S. E. Welty<sup>5</sup>, O. O. Olutoye<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Radiology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Obstetrics And Gynecology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Texas Children's Hospital,Pediatrics-Newborn,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ventral mediastinal hernia (VMH) is a rare variant of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) that is not well described in current literature. We sought to describe the outcomes of VMH patients managed at a pediatric tertiary care center.

Methods: We reviewed and classified all CDH patients managed at our institution based on the Texas Children's Fetal Center CDH classification system from January 2004-July 2014. VMH was defined as a defect secondary to incomplete formation of the secundum transversum but without the presence of omphalocele or bifid sternum to suggest a variant of Pentalogy of Cantrell. Hernia locations were confirmed based on operative and autopsy findings. Patient characteristics, prenatal imaging and outcomes were evaluated.

Results:Of 205 patients evaluated, 4 (2%) were classified as VMH. 3 out of 4 did not have associated anomalies. All patients were diagnosed prenatally. Table 1 illustrates characteristics and outcomes of patients with VMH. Intraoperatively, all patients had liver herniation with colon and small bowel herniation (75%) also present. The presence of a hernia sac was noted in three cases. Survival at 6 months was 75% with the only death occurring in the patient with an associated Tetralogy of Fallot and dysmorphic features.

Conclusion:In this series, we describe the course of four patients with VMH, a rare variant of CDH. Patients with VMH had a fair postnatal course with a 6 month survival rate of 75%. These findings may help guide counseling in the immediate postnatal period for patients with this rare anomaly.

abstract_title: Feasability of Laparoscopic Ureteroneocystostomy In A Resource-limited Setting in Eastern DRC
author_block: D. Mukwege<sup>2</sup>, A. De Cort<sup>1</sup>, B. CadiFre<sup>3</sup>, B. Mukanire Ntakwinja<sup>2</sup>, D. Guha-Sapir<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>UniversitT Catholique De Louvain,FacultT De Medecine,Woluwe-Saint-Lambert, BRUSSELS, Belgium <sup>2</sup>H(pital De Panzi,Bukavu, SOUTH-KIVU, Congo <sup>3</sup>The European School Of Laparoscopic Surgery,Department Of Gastrointestinal Surgery,Brussels, BRUSSELS, Belgium
abstract_body:
Introduction: Onsrud et al. reported that 61% of ureterovaginal fistulae (UVF) in Eastern DRC are caused by Cesarean delivery, whereas in high-income countries, the main etiology of UVF is hysterectomy for benign uterine disease. Few studies have reported laparoscopic repair of UVF in a resource-limited setting and none with a high prevalence of post-Cesarean UVF.

Methods: We conducted a prospective study of the 5 first patients diagnosed with UVF who underwent laparoscopic ureteroneocystostomy between November 2014 and February 2015. We collected data on patients' demographics and pre-operative, per-operative and post-operative data including costs. Surgical steps were described. A voiding cystourethrogram was performed 3 months post-operatively and we conducted a patient satisfaction questionnaire after follow-up.

Results:2 out of 5 cases followed Cesarean section , 2 out of 5 cases followed hysterectomy and 1 out of 5 followed uterosacral ligament fixation . Mean operative time was 198 min , blood loss was <25ml for all patients. Mean hospital stay was 19 days with an immediate return to work on the first day after discharge . There were no major complication and all patient were continent at the 3 months follow-up with a satisfying voiding cystourethrogram.

Conclusion:UVF including those caused by Cesarean sections can be treated safely and effectively by a standardized laparoscopic approach in a population with limited means and social structures.

abstract_title: Long Segment Tracheal Reconstruction in Neonates with Severe Tracheo-Bronchial Stenosis
author_block: M. E. Mitchell<sup>1</sup>, D. Beste<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Of Wisconsin,Pediatric Cardiothoracic Surgery/Surgery/Medical College Of Wisconsin,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Slide tracheoplasty has been used widely for reconstruction of long segment tracheal stenosis secondary to complete tracheal rings. We present the successful use of a variation of slide tracheoplasty, side to side Bronchus Suis Tracheoplasty in three extreme cases of complete tracheal rings, tracheo-bronchial hypoplasia and tracheal bronchus in premature neonates and infants.

Methods: Three patients age less then 60 days presented with long segment tracheal stenosis in the context of a Bronchus Suis, complete tracheal rings, and a pulmonary artery sling. All patients had inability to ventilate consistently despite intubation and required urgent tracheal reconstruction. All patients underwent long segment tracheoplasty consisting of a side to side anastamosis between the Bronchus Suis and the hypoplastic trachea and right lower lobe bronchus.

Results:There was no mortality. One patient who underwent initial slide tracheoplasty and required tracheostomy, was ultimately decannulated following side to side tracheal reconstruction. The other two patients who underwent one stage side to side tracheoplasty as neonates did well and were discharged without ventilatory support.

Conclusion:Side to side tracheal reconstruction using a Bronchus Suis to augment a severely hypoplastic trachea is feasible in severe cases of long segment tracheal stenosis.

abstract_title: Industry-Academic Partnerships: A Trans-disciplinary Approach to Accelerate Surgical Innovation
author_block: J. Chen<sup>1</sup>, T. Pickett<sup>2,4</sup>, A. Langell<sup>1</sup>, A. Trane<sup>1</sup>, B. Charlseworth<sup>4</sup>, K. Loken<sup>3</sup>, S. Lombardo<sup>1</sup>, J. T. Langell<sup>1,2,3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Department Of Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah,Department Of Bioengineering,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Utah,School Of Business,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Utah,School Of Design,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Mature biotechnology companies are process-driven organizations and as a result struggle with their ability to innovate. Universities, on the other hand, thrive on discovery and variation as a source of innovation. As a result, we believe that properly structured academic-industry partnerships in medical technology development will enhance and accelerate innovation. We recently created an industry-university partnership focused on global cervical cancer prevention. Our industry partner provided expertise in medical technology commercialization, the validated clinical problem and mentoring in product-market-fit and regulatory-based product development. The University provided subject matter experts in human factors design, engineering, clinical care and usability testing.Cervical cancer is a leading cause of death for young women with >250,000 attributed deaths annually; 90% in the developing world. Therapeutic modalities for the management of cervical intraepithelial neoplasms (CIN) are not designed for developing regions; they are expensive, require a skilled workforce, a stable electrical grid or availability of cryogenic liquids. Our task was to develop a solution that would effectively treat CIN in low-resource settings.

Methods: Our Center for Medical Innovation created a trans-disciplinary team of graduate and medical students, surgical residents and clinical faculty. Our industry partner presented the validated need and business mentorship. Solution development was left entirely to the student team to optimize the innovation process and reduce bias. The team studied the therapeutic landscape, environmental constraints, and treatment guidelines and used simulation to understand human factors design and usage requirements. Prototyping and verification testing was conducted in our in-house facility. A final design was selected, prototyped, tested.

Results: Based on treatment guidelines and regulatory data our team pursued development of a thermo-coagulation device. Our efforts resulted in a functional battery powered hand-held thermo-coagulation prototype in just 72-days. Total cost of development was <$400. Verification trials demonstrated a 55 second therapy cycle, comprised of 10 seconds of heating and 45 seconds of sustained temperatures of 120°C or greater, meeting WHO treatment requirements. Fresh tissue testing demonstrated consistent coagulation to a minimum depth of 5 mm, exceeding the WHO standards. The team is now pursuing regulatory clearance, manufacturing, and clinical trails.

Conclusion: Our experience with using industry-academic partnerships as a means to create medical technologies resulted in an innovative solution to treat CIN and can serve as an integral piece of the 'screen-and-treat' approach to premalignant cervical lesions as outlined by WHO. This case study highlights the impact of accelerating medical advances through industry-academic partnership that leverages their combined resources.

abstract_title: Increased prevalence of systemic inflammatory disease in patients with carotid stenosis
author_block: S. Y. Shalaby<sup>1,2</sup>, T. R. Foster<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Hanisch<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Vasilas<sup>2</sup>, A. Dardik<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Section Of Vascular Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>VA Connecticut Healthcare System,Section Of Vascular Surgery,West Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Carotid atherosclerosis has an inflammatory pathogenesis and is associated with inflammatory diseases such as metabolic syndrome. We hypothesized that a history of systemic inflammatory disease (SID), such as autoimmune, autoinflammatory, or allergic disease, is associated with end-stage carotid stenosis. Therefore we examined the prevalence of SID in patients with carotid stenosis who were treated with carotid endarterectomy (CEA).

Methods: The records of all patients having CEA 2002-2013 were reviewed. A history of SID was determined by diagnosis and/or treatment. The peak systolic velocity (PSV) of the internal carotid artery was recorded at the last follow up visit.

Results: 57 of 79 (72%) patients undergoing CEA had an AID, most commonly osteoarthritis (34%) or gout (15%). There were no significant baseline differences between patients without or with SID other than a trend towards increased history of myocardial infarction in patients with an SID (10.5% vs. 0%; p = 0.11); there was no difference between PSV (426.7 ± 20.2 vs. 381.2 ± 31.9 cm/sec; p=0.23) or preoperative incidence of stroke (10.5% vs. 13.6%; p=0.69). There was no difference in perioperative complications (12.3% vs. 4.5%; p=0.31). The duration of follow up did not differ between the two groups (4.4 ± 0.3 vs. 4.4 ± 0.5 years; p=0.55). There was a trend towards increased postoperative stroke in patients with SID (10.5% vs. 0%; p = 0.11). In late follow up, the mean postoperative PSV was significantly lower in patients with SID (114.5 ± 71.3 vs. 183.5 cm/sec; p=0.01).

Conclusion: Patients with severe carotid stenosis undergoing CEA have a high prevalence of SID, and a trend towards an increased rate of postoperative stroke. A larger sample size will be required to confirm these results. Careful perioperative control of autoinflammatory disease may enable further reduction of perioperative stroke after CEA.

abstract_title: Selective Smo-Inhibition Interferes With Cellular Energetic Metabolism In Colorectal Cancer
author_block: P. Magistri<sup>1</sup>, F. D'Angelo<sup>1</sup>, M. Valerio<sup>3</sup>, L. Casadei<sup>3</sup>, C. Battistelli<sup>2</sup>, R. Strippoli<sup>2</sup>, L. Amicone<sup>2</sup>, M. Tripodi<sup>2</sup>, G. Ramacciato<sup>1</sup>, G. Nigri<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Sapienza University Of Rome,Department Of Medical And Surgical Sciences And Translational Medicine,Rome, RM, Italy <sup>2</sup>Sapienza University Of Rome,Department Of Cellular Biotechnology And Hematology, Division Of Molecular Genetics,Rome, RM, Italy <sup>3</sup>Sapienza University Of Rome,Department Of Chemistry,Rome, RM, Italy
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colon Cancer (CC) is the fourth most frequently diagnosed tumor and the second leading cause of death in the USA. It has been demonstrated that the presence of activated Hedgehog pathway (Hh) in epithelial tumor cells of colorectal cancer is essential for tumor growth, recurrence and metastatic growth, and regulates the behavior of human CC stem cells in vivo.

Methods: HCT 116 human colon cancer cells were grown in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and antibiotics. Cells were treated with 1 μM Smo-Inhibitor (Hh-Antag, provided by Genentech, Inc. ®) or vehicle for 48 hours. Conditioned medium samples (2 ml) were lyophilized then dissolved and finally homogenized by vortex mixing for 1 min. After centrifugation the supernatant was transferred to a 5-mm NMR tube and used for the NMR analysis. 2D 1H J-resolved (JRES) NMR spectra were acquired on a 500 MHz Varian/Agilent spectrometer using a double spin echo sequence with 4 transients per increment for a total of 32 increments. Metabolites responsible for the separation between treated and untreated samples were identified using an in-house NMR database and Chenomx NMR suite v. 7.7 (Chenomx Inc., Alberta, Canada). To compare the spectra, the integrals derived from the binning procedure were normalized to the total integral region, following exclusion of bins representing the residual water peak (d 4.33-5.17 ppm) and the TSP peak (d 0.5-0.5 ppm). The resulting data was used as input for multivariate analysis. The experiment was repeated three times.

Results:1H-NMR metabolomics profiles of HCT 116 cell culture media display significant differences between HhAntag-treated and vehicle-treated cells (p<0.00001). The first component t1 included the following variables with the highest correlation levels: valine, alanine, N-acetyl groups, glutamate, pyruvate, succinate, tyrosine and phenylalanine. Therefore, considering the net balance of these metabolites, t1 indicates that HhAntag treatment induces higher consumption of pyruvate, succinate and tyrosine as well as a lower consumption of valine, glutamate and phenylalanine. Moreover, HhAntag-treated cells have higher production of alanine, acetate and N-acetyl groups compared to vehicle-tread ones.

Conclusion:Our results show that treatment with a Smo selective inhibitor affects the metabolism of different amino acids. Moreover, it modifies the energetic metabolism of colon cancer cells, deregulating in particular the metabolism of nucleotide sugar, purine, pyrimidine and pyruvate, as well as citrate cycle (TCA cycle) and oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, we can postulate that the inhibition of the Hedgehog pathway in colorectal cancer cells counteract tumor growth by modulating cellular energetic pathways.

abstract_title: Practicing surgeons' motivations and goals for participation in a statewide surgical coaching program
author_block: L. Frasier<sup>1</sup>, H. Beasley<sup>1</sup>, H. Ghousseini<sup>2</sup>, S. Pavuluri Quamme<sup>1</sup>, N. Brys<sup>1</sup>, D. Wiegmann<sup>3</sup>, C. Greenberg<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Education,Madison, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Engineering,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgical performance is defined by three dimensions: technical, cognitive, and inter-personal skill. Surgical coaching offers an innovative approach to improve performance, with content tailored to individual surgeons across these dimensions; however, little is known about surgeon willingness to participate. We sought to determine what motivated surgeons to participate and which dimension(s) surgeons are most interested in improving in a statewide video-based surgical coaching program.

Methods: We matched surgeons with a trained coach for review of intra-operative performance via video recordings of the surgeon's operations. Eight surgeons were recruited by peer nomination to serve as coaches and trained in concepts of coaching that include constructive feedback. We recruited twelve surgeons in academic and community practice to participate as coachees. An introductory conversation between coach and coachee was part of the program to set goals and discuss motivations for participation. Sessions were audio-recorded and transcribed. Data about coachees' motivation and goals were analyzed using an inductive qualitative approach.

Results: The most common motivation for participation was the view of self-improvement as an aspect of professional responsibility or 'the right thing to do'. Improvement goals included all three dimensions (technical, cognitive and interpersonal) of surgical performance. While the program was designed to focus on intra-operative performance, participants also identified performance targets outside of the operating room. Coachees fell into two broad categories: those making the transition to independent practice, and those who had been practicing surgeons for some time; these groups identified differing goals and challenges. Coachees transitioning to independence identified goals related to teaching and leadership. Common themes that emerged included challenges in working with non-trainee surgical assistants and 'operating from the other side of the table'. Additional goals included altering one's surgical practice to conform to institutional norms and protocols, and balancing clinical practice with other demands (teaching, research, and administrative) on one's time. In comparison, more senior surgeons identified goals related to the changing healthcare environment including staying abreast of current surgical practices, learning and incorporating new surgical procedures or techniques into practice, and adjusting to changing surgical culture.

Conclusion: Participants in a peer coaching program were self-motivated to improve and identified a variety of goals dependent on the stage of their career. While more research is needed, these results suggest surgeons are willing to participate in a video-based program and seek to address a variety of challenges. Surgical coaching represents a promising new approach for surgeons to improve aspects of their performance with a program tailored to their individual needs.

abstract_title: Using Biomarkers to Detect Anastomotic Leakage Following Colorectal Surgery: A Systematic Review
author_block: B. Su'a<sup>1</sup>, H. Mikaere<sup>1</sup>, J. Rahiri<sup>1</sup>, I. Bissett<sup>1,3</sup>, A. G. Hill<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>3</sup>Auckland City Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Auckland, AUCKLAND, New Zealand <sup>1</sup>The University Of Auckland,Department Of Surgery,Auckland, AUCKLAND, New Zealand <sup>2</sup>Ko Awatea,Middlemore Hospital, Counties Manukau District Health Board,Auckland, AUCKLAND, New Zealand
abstract_body:
Introduction: Anastomotic leakage (AL) following colorectal surgery is a serious complication associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Its early diagnosis remains difficult due to its non-specific presentation. This review aims to provide an overview of studies that have evaluated biomarkers in the context of AL following colorectal surgery.

Methods: A comprehensive literature review was conducted according to the PRISMA guidelines. All published studies evaluating inflammatory biomarkers for the diagnosis of AL were searched for in three electronic databases (MEDLINE, PubMed and EMBASE), from 1990 to August 2015. The different biomarkers and their respective behaviours in the presence of an AL were extracted.

Results:Twenty three studies evaluated biomarkers in the context of AL after colorectal surgery. Analysis of different biomarkers showed that most were non-specific markers of inflammation and infection. Marked changes seen in both local and systemic biomarkers often preceded AL, although at different time points and with significant variance.

Conclusion:This review demonstrates that both local and systemic biomarkers are poor predictors of AL after colorectal surgery. Marked changes seen in systemic circulation do not necessarily reflect the local environment. Studies with large numbers of participants and additional specific biomarkers may be useful to improve the early diagnosis of AL.

abstract_title: Trauma Patients Warrant Upper and Lower Extremity Venous Duplex Ultrasound Surveillance
author_block: A. H. Tyroch<sup>1</sup>, J. Smith<sup>1</sup>, A. Andrade<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Ramos<sup>2</sup>, S. McLean<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center,Paul L. Foster School Of Medicine/ Surgery,El Paso, TEXAS, USA <sup>2</sup>University Medical Center Of El Paso,Trauma,El Paso, TEXAS, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Due to the high incidence of thromboembolic events (DVT & PE) after injury, many trauma centers perform lower extremity surveillance duplex ultrasounds.

Methods: Retrospective chart and trauma registry review of ICU trauma patients with upper and lower extremity DVTs detected on surveillance duplex ultrasound from 01/10 to 12/14. Variables reviewed were age, gender, ISS, injury mechanism, clot location, day of clot detection, CVP catheter, IVC filter, mechanical ventilation and fracture site.

Results: 36 paitents had a DVT in a five year period: upper- 71(52.2%), lower- 61 (44.9%), both upper and lower -4 (2.9%). Overall, 75 (55.2%) patients had an upper extremity DVT. Upper DVT vein: brachial (62), axillary (26), subclavian (11) and internal jugular (10). Lower DVT vein: femoral (58), poplital (14), below knee (4) and iliac (2). 10.3% had a PE: upper extremity DVT- 5 (6.7%) and lower extremity DVT- 9 (14.8%); p= 0.159.

Conclusion: The majority of the DVTs in the study were in the upper extremities. One can debate the merits of an aggressive thromboembolic screening program, especially since hospitals may receive financial penalties resulting from the Affordable Care Act due to 'preventable' hospital-acquired conditions. On the other hand, severly injuried trauma patients are at significant thromboembolic risk despite appropriate prophylaxis. For trauma centers that aggressively screen the lower extremities with venous duplex ultrasound, surveillance to include the upper extremities is warranted.

abstract_title: Use of iPad Minis During the Core Surgery Clerkship
author_block: R. B. Robbins<sup>1</sup>, R. Braga<sup>1</sup>, D. Stonehocker<sup>1</sup>, A. Cochran<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Department Of Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The use of mobile technology has rapidly expanded in the clinical setting to assist with decision-making, learning and productivity. Mobile technology offers students' flexibility and access to large amounts of medical content and knowledge through various applications, websites and learning modules. However, optimization of mobile technology during clinical clerkships continues to evolve. We sought to better understand medical student adoption of mobile technology, preferred resources and barriers to use of electronic applications for educational and clinical purposes.

Methods: Third year medical students at a single institution were provided an Apple iPad mini for use during their required 6-week surgical clerkship. The iPads were pre-loaded with specific applications and bookmarked links to recommended references through the medical school library. Each device had access to the clerkship curriculum through the institutional learning management system, to the electronic medical record (EMR) and to required on-line learning modules. Students received training in the use of the iPad and the key apps during their clerkship orientation. At the conclusion of their surgery clerkship, students were invited to fill out an open-ended online survey identifying the most and least effective features of the iPad as a resource.

Results:The survey response rate was 30% (n= 19/62). Students identified that the most effective features of the iPad required access to Wi-Fi and included its portability and the access to didactic schedules, learning modules and the EMR. Least effective features included poor interface of some applications, which limited the use of the electronic medical record and didactic modules on the iPad. Students who chose not to use the iPad provided by the clerkship indicated that they already owned an iPad for personal use. Students who used clerkship-provided devices as well as those using their personal devices documented concerns about their potential financial liability if the loaned iPad was lost or damaged. Further, the iPad was felt to be of no value for students at one rotation site because of the absence of Wi-Fi in that hospital.

Conclusion:The use of an iPad during the surgical clerkship still has strong potential for both education and clinical applications. However, students identified that the utility of the iPad for medical education during a surgical clerkship is limited by application interface and availability of Wi-Fi. Optimizing the design of applications for education and clinical purposes on the iPad mini may enhance the adoption of mobile technology during training and into clinical practice.

abstract_title: The Top 100 Manuscripts in Thoracic Surgery: A Bibliometric Analysis
author_block: T. M. Connelly<sup>1</sup>, W. Kolcow<sup>2</sup>, J. Kelly<sup>1</sup>, D. Veerasingam<sup>2</sup>, M. DaCosta<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospital Galway,Surgery,Galway, GALWAY, Ireland <sup>2</sup>University Hospital Galway,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Galway, GALWAY, Ireland
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bibliometric analysis highlights the key topics and studies which have led to the current understanding and treatment of a disease of interest. We aim to analyze the 100 most cited manuscripts in the field of thoracic surgery including non vascular, non cardiac thoracic pathologies. Analysis of this data provides insight into both the evolution of the understanding of thoracic pathobiology and to how the field of thoracic surgery has evolved in response.

Methods: A search of the citation indexing database Thomson Reuters Web of Science was completed using over 20 key words relevant to thoracic surgery. The top 100 cited manuscripts were further analyzed by topic, institution, author, journal and year.

Results: 98,743 full length English language papers were returned. The New England Journal of Medicine and Radiology published the most papers in the top 100 with 13 each. The country with majority of publications in the top 100 was the USA (n=55). Memorial Sloan Kettering was the institution with the greatest number of manuscripts (n=8). Orringer and Rusch had 3 first and 1 senior authorship each. The majority of the papers featured carcinoma (Oesophageal n=34/Lung n=41). Non small cell cancer was the pulmonary subtype of most interest (n=18). Twenty one manuscripts focused on benign lung pathologies including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and transplantation (4 and 6 manuscripts respectively).

Conclusion: The current practice of the thoracic surgeon is well represented in the top 100 manuscripts. The quality of the journals in which these manuscripts are published reflects the importance of these works in both the clinical and scientific communities. The predominance of research focusing on lung carcinoma represents the associated morbidity and mortality of the disease. The current work serves as a concise reference of the most studied and cited topics in thoracic surgery.

abstract_title: Fires In Refugee Camps: Current Situation And Opportunities To Improve Fire Prevention And Control
author_block: Y. Kazerooni<sup>1</sup>, A. Gyedu<sup>4</sup>, G. Burnham<sup>7</sup>, B. Nwomeh<sup>8</sup>, A. Charles<sup>9</sup>, B. Mishra<sup>2</sup>, S. Kuah<sup>11</sup>, A. Kushner<sup>5,7,10</sup>, B. Stewart<sup>3,4</sup>  <sup>11</sup>International Rescue Committee,Emergency Response Team,New York, NY, USA <sup>1</sup>Ohio State University,College Of Medicine,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>King Georges Medical University,Department Of Plastic , Re-constructive & Aesthetic Surgery,Lucknow, UTTAR PRADESH, India <sup>3</sup>University Of Washington,Department Of Surgery,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>4</sup>Kwame Nkrumah University Of Science And Technology,Department Of Surgery,Kumasi, ASHANTI, Ghana <sup>5</sup>Columbia University,Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>7</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Public Health,Department Of International Health,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>8</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Division Of General And Acute Care Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>10</sup>Surgeons OverSeas,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: An estimated 59 million people worldwide are refugees or internally displaced persons (IDPs). Although many are increasingly living in urban centers, refugee and IDP settlements are common. Persons living in these settlements are vulnerable to violent attacks with resultant fires and burn injuries. We aimed to describe the burden of intentional fires in these settlements, review humanitarian organization guidelines for fire control, and identify interventions and innovation to address any gaps.

Methods: A systematic review of academic (e.g. PubMed) andnon-academic (e.g. LexisNexis, humanitarian news wires) literature databases was conduced. MESH terms included:('Refugee' OR 'Displaced') AND ('Fire' OR 'Burn'). Only English language papers were included. Additionally, we reviewed fire prevention andcontrol guidelines from the 15 leading humanitarian organizations.

Results: Of 1,521 records, 131 described distinct settlementfires in 31 host countries since 1990. From 2000 to 2014 intentional fires increased from 0.003 to 0.01 fires per 100,000 persons, respectively. Incidents were classified as: unintentional (36, 27%); intentional(26, 19%); unknown cause (43, 33%); with 26 reports not reporting a cause. Intentional fires resulted in 329 deaths, 359 burn injuries,139,498 displaced individuals, and destruction of 16,142 shelters. Sudan had the most intentional incidents (11, 42% of intentional fires).Humanitarian organization guidelines only focused on prevention and control of unintentional fires(e.g. cooking-related fires). Guidelines did recommended firebreaks and outlined security protocols including disarming residents and using local police or international military to prevent attacks. No guidelines specified fire alerting, response,extinguishing, or reporting. Interventions and innovations identified included: more fuel-efficient stoves to reduce deforestation by the settlement residents to prevent upsetting local residents; fire retardant shelter material to prevent fires from spreading; fire alert bells; regularly spaced water/sand buckets for extinguishing fires; and volunteer fire services to aid control of both intentional and unintentional fires.

Conclusion: Violent attacks and intentional fires are increasing in refugee and IDP settlements. Significant numbers of injuries and further displacement highlight the need to address gaps in fire prevention and control guidelines. The way forward includes: i) improving and developing consensus among humanitarian organization for fire prevention and control strategies; ii) evaluating the impact of interventions and innovations on the burden of intentional fires; and iii) engaging organizations and groups responsible for settlement maintenance in a broader discussion about protecting settlement residents from armed groups.

abstract_title: Surgery in the South Pacific: A Systematic Review of the Literature
author_block: E. E. Lee<sup>1,2</sup>, L. Lam<sup>1</sup>, K. Inaba<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Tan<sup>3</sup>, A. L. Kushner<sup>2,4,5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Southern California,Department Of Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School Of Public Health,Department Of International Health,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>World Health Organization, Western Pacific Regional Office,Division Of Health Systems,Manilla, MANILLA, Philippines <sup>4</sup>Columbia University,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>5</sup>Surgeons OverSeas,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgery is increasingly recognized as an important component of global health. While there are increasing data on surgical and infrastructure needs from low and middle income countries, there is a paucity of data from many parts of the world such as the South Pacific. The archipelago islands of the South Pacific have a distinct geography that requires patients from remote islands to be transported to the nearest large island health facility for higher levels of care. In addition to their baseline surgical needs, these islands also have high rates of surgical diseases including Hirschprung's disease, thyroid cancer and congenital diaphragmatic hernias. The purpose of this study was to search the published literature to characterize the surgical needs and capacity of this region.

Methods: Using PRISMA guidelines, a search of PubMed with the following MeSH terms: 'Pacific Island' and 'Surgery' were used to identify relevant titles and abstracts. The search was restricted to reviews of surgical outcomes, analyses of hospital infrastructure, and surgical training program reports from 2005-2015. Case reports were excluded. South Pacific islands were restricted to Melanesia (Fiji, New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands), Micronesia (Guam, Palau, Kiribati, Nauru, Marshall Islands, Federal States of Micronesia), and Polynesia (Pitcalm Island, Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, Cook Islands). Country data were also collected from the World Health Organization.

Results: The search identified 29 papers meeting inclusion criteria. Of these, 13 articles reviewed surgical outcomes of the following: valve replacements (5), cataract surgery (4), large-vessel injuries of the neck (1), penetrating abdominal wounds (1), perforated appendicitis (1), and airway scleromas (1). 7 articles addressed surgical training and the 'brain drain' of the medical work force. 4 articles evaluated access to surgical care.

Conclusion: Limited data on surgical needs and capacity are documented from the South Pacific. To adequately plan programs to care for patients in need of surgery, detailed assessments of personnel, infrastructure, equipment and supplies are required to assist local governments and international partners in developing appropriate programs to provide care and retain local health professionals.

abstract_title: Socioeconomic impact of pediatric surgical conditions requiring ostomies in Uganda: a pilot survey
author_block: A. Muzira<sup>1</sup>, N. Kakembo<sup>1</sup>, P. Kisa<sup>1</sup>, R. Ayikoru<sup>1</sup>, T. Fitzgerald<sup>3</sup>, M. Langer<sup>2</sup>, J. Sekabira<sup>1</sup>, D. Ozgediz<sup>4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mulago Hospital,Kampala, , Uganda <sup>2</sup>Maine Medical Center,Portland, MAINE, USA <sup>3</sup>Texas Tech University At El Paso,El Paso, TEXAS, USA <sup>4</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multiple pediatric surgical conditions require ostomies in the course of treatment in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Most commonly, these include congenital colorectal conditions such as anorectal malformations (ARM) and Hirschsprung Disease (HD), and acquired conditions such as typhoid perforation and intussusception with bowel gangrene. These conditions more frequently require an ostomy in an LMIC, most commonly due to late presentation. In this Ugandan national referral hospital pediatric surgery ward, over half of all patient hospital days are due to HD or ARM, underscoring the local clinical burden. This pilot study of socioeconomic assessment of the impact of these conditions was designed to inform a larger mixed methods study.

Methods: A literature search was performed concerning pediatric general surgical conditions requiring ostomies in LMICs, and their socioeconomic impact, in multiple databases, yielding no results. A broader search of the social and economic impact of other congenital anomalies yielded several publications for clubfoot, cleft lip/palate, neural tube defects, and cardiac defects. Some of these studies were adapted to design themes for focus group discussions (2) and directed questions for individual interviews (15) of mothers of children with ostomies in the inpatient and outpatient setting. Selected themes covered: cost of care, beliefs about illness, socioeconomic impact children and families, and sources of economic and social support.

Results:Mothers in both individual interviews and focus groups had a very limited understanding of the conditions that led to the need for a stoma, but all acknowledged the necessity. The majority of mothers limited interaction of their child with others in the community for fear of stigma. The management of stoma with cloth shreds was the most common method for stoma care in the absence of stoma supplies, with the resulting odor and associated hygiene challenges the most disturbing feature. Nearly all working mothers reported leaving their jobs to care for the child, and many reported selling assets such as livestock and taking out loans to cover out of pocket expenses for health care, despite seeking care in 'free' public facilities. Over half of the mothers reported that their spouse left the family after the stoma was placed. Nearly all the mothers emphasized the support from the 'informal' community of affected parents on the ward, and in the outpatient setting.

Conclusion:This limited pilot survey underscores the significant impact of conditions requiring stomas on children and their families. Children are socially excluded and families are frequently impoverished due to catastrophic health expenditure. The informal network of affected families plays a significant supportive role. This data will inform the design of a larger more expansive survey of this patient population to better measure this impact and guide advocacy efforts.

abstract_title: Bridging the Knowledge Gap:  Open-Access Surgical Journals in Low and Low-Middle Income Countries
author_block: A. V. Gore<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Granick<sup>1</sup>, Z. C. Sifri<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rutgers - NJMS,Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While traditional surgical journals are an effective means of transmitting updated surgical information, their prohibitive cost limits their value in low and low-middle income countries (LMIC). This barrier to dissemination of new surgical knowledge limits the transmission of up-to-date surgical information to surgeons and practitioners in these countries. We hypothesize that open access peer-reviewed electronic surgical journals can facilitate the dissemination of up to date surgical knowledge to those with limited resources in LMIC.

Methods: We investigated a US-based non-profit open-access peer-reviewed electronic surgical journal (ePlasty), intended to make current surgical literature available in LMIC. All articles published through this journal between May 2012 and May 2015 were reviewed. Data collected from the editorial office included the number of articles per year, type of article, country of origin of submissions, rejection rate, and operating costs. Journal access data including the frequency of online access and geographic location of access was obtained from the website-monitoring service Web-Stat.

Results: In this 3-year period, the journal published 286 original open-access articles. The average number of submissions/year was 115 articles with a 30% rejection rate. Types of article included original science, case report, case series, interesting cases, report on technique, and letters to the editor. The majority of articles originated from the US, UK, and Japan. Over this period, the journal was accessed 441,909 times in 213 countries/territories, or on average 403 times/day, with 53% of views originating in the US. 19% of the non-US readers came from 71 different LMIC (Figure 1), accessing the journal an average of 36 times/day. Average yearly operating cost were $25K with an average cost of $263/article borne by the authors.

Conclusion: On average this journal publishes 95 peer-reviewed original articles yearly, reaching about 400 readers per day in 213 countries/territories. One third of these countries are classified as LMIC, representing almost 10% of total readers. This open-access peer-reviewed surgical journal format is a cost-effective method of disseminating relevant surgical knowledge the world over, bridging the knowledge gap between developed and LMIC.

abstract_title: Phytodrug-loaded Nanoceria Formulations Against Neuroblastoma
author_block: I. Kalashnikova<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Neal<sup>2</sup>, S. Das<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Westmoreland<sup>3</sup>, S. Seal<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Central Florida,Nanoscience Technology Center, Advanced Materials Processing And Analysis Center,Orlando, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Central Florida,Materials Science And Engineering, College Of Medicine,Orlando, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>Nemours Children Hospital,Surgery,Orlando, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor afflicting infants with about 700 cases per year in the US. Approximately 70-80% of patients older than 18 months present with metastatic disease and less than half of these patients are cured. Curcumin (C) has displayed anticancer activities in different cancer types, including neuroblastoma. Nanoceria (CNPs) has recently shown toxicity to neuroblastoma in a size and dose-dependent manner. Dextran(Dx)-CNPs possess pH-dependent therapeutic activities: cytoprotection of nontransformed cells and oxidative damage of cancer cells. We hypothesize that the combination of nanoceria with curcumin can acquire synergic activity against neuroblastoma.

Methods: Several formulations of C-CNPs and Dx-C-CNPs were synthesized by varying CNPs concentrations (5 and 10mM) and curcumin load (1-2mg/ml). Physico-chemical properties of the formulations were analyzed by DLS, FT-IR, UV-Vis spectrophotometry, DSC, ICP-MS, and TEM. Two neuroblastoma cell lines (SK-N-AS and IMR-32) were used for testing the formulations. Anticancer effects of the formulations were characterized by MTT and ROS assay at different time points. Bare CNPs and curcumin were used as controls. Signaling pathway of particle-induced apoptosis was studied by qPCR, TUNEL assay, and caspase 3/7 assay.

Results:Screening of the formulations with MTT (24h) revealed that a higher starting CNPs:curcumin ratio was more effective. Concentration- and time-dependent anticancer effect of the formulations was observed. HUVEC cells were exposed to both types of formulations as control cells and no cytotoxic effect was established. IMR-32 appeared to be more sensitive towards the treatment, probably due to a more intensive uptake of nanoparticles (28-55% after 2h of exposure). Dx-C-CNPs formulation showed the highest amount of ROS which was dependent on time of incubation. This formulation was more effective for IMR-32 with45% cell viability vs 55% when C-CNPs were used (250uM, 72h of treatment). Maximum C-CNPs uptake by SK-N-AS was found in 4h after loading (78%) and ROS accumulation was at the highest level after 10h of treatment. Formulation with double the curcumin load (C2-CNPs) allowed stimulation of continued ROS production over time in SK-N-AS. A higher degree of SK-N-As apoptosis was observed for C2-CNPs (58% of survival cells, 24h), in agreement with ROS assay data. The longer treatment (72h) improved the toxic effect of Dx-C-CNPs for the SK-N-AS line with 53% cell survival vs 64% for C-CNPs. TUNEL assay verified particle-induced apoptosis of neuroblastoma cells. Caspase 3/7 assay revealed an increase in caspase activity.

Conclusion: Curcumin-nanoceria is able to induce apoptosis in both tested neuroblastoma cell lines; with the highest toxic effect produced by Dx-C-CNPs, for both cell lines. Longer treatment significantly increased the toxic effect of the formulations on neuroblastoma.

abstract_title: Intraoperative Molecular Imaging Of Pulmonary Adenocarcinomas Using A Targeted Near-Infrared Dye
author_block: J. J. Keating<sup>1</sup>, O. Okusanya<sup>1</sup>, S. Nims<sup>1</sup>, J. Predina<sup>1</sup>, C. Deshpande<sup>2</sup>, S. Nie<sup>3</sup>, P. Low<sup>4</sup>, S. Singhal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Thoracic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Pathology,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University,Biomedical Engineering And Chemistry,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>Purdue University,Chemistry,West Lafayette, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intraoperative molecular imaging for the localization of lung cancers has been successful with the NIR dye indocyanine green (ICG). However, the non-targeted nature of ICG has led to a high false positive detection rate that limits its diagnostic potential. We propose to localize pulmonary adenocarcinomas with a novel NIR dye targeted to folate receptor alpha (FRα), OTL38

Methods: The presence of FRα was measured on 24 human samples of pulmonary adenocarcinomas using flow cytometry and immunohistochemistry. Then, NOD scid gamma mice with KB flank tumors were imaged with a NIR camera at various time points following tail vein injection of several concentrations of OTL38 (from 0.05 mg/kg to 0.5 mg/kg). The histopathology as well as fluorescence of vital organs from OTL38 were measured to assess biodistribution and toxicity. Lastly, intrapleural KB tumors were established to assess smallest detectable tumor using NIR imaging. All tumor samples were correlated with fluorescence microscopy and final pathology.

Results: Twenty out of 24 human tumor samples expressed FRα with minimal staining of surrounding stroma and immune cells. FRα co-localized to EpCam+ (epithelial cell marker) cells with no co-expression with CD45 (immune cell marker) or CD11b (myeloid cell marker) cells. In 17 specimens, FRα was expressed on 76% ± 28% (range 36-99%) of EpCam+ tumor cells. In the remaining 3 samples FRα was expressed on <10% EpCam+ tumor cells. Immunohistochemistry confirmed these findings showing strong staining on samples with a large FRα+ population. In our murine flank model, tumor-to-background ratio (TBR) peaked at 3 hours after injection and were similar at OTL38 dose of 0.075 mg/kg and above, making 0.075 mg/kg the lowest effective dose. Mean TBR of mice injected with 0.075 mg/kg at the three-hour time point was 3.2 (IQR 2.4-4.1). Fluorescent signal was noted only in the kidneys and GI tract, which is consistent with high levels of FRα within the proximal tubules and the hepatic clearance of OTL38. In our intrapleural model, the smallest tumors detectable by NIR imaging were discovered on days 4 and 5 following tumor cell inoculation. These tumors were 1.03 mm +/- 0.22 with a mean TBR of 3.1 +/- 0.29.

Conclusion: OTL38 successfully localizes to pulmonary adenocarcinomas during NIR intraoperative molecular imaging. This work provides the groundwork for a clinical trial to identify and diagnosis pulmonary adenocarcinoma during surgery.

abstract_title: Benefits of Ex Vivo Lung Perfusion Persist Despite Increasing Warm Ischemia Time Prior To Procurement
author_block: E. J. Charles<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Huerter<sup>2</sup>, J. H. Mehaffey<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Sharma<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Isbell<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Lau<sup>1</sup>, C. G. Tribble<sup>1</sup>, V. E. Laubach<sup>1</sup>, I. L. Kron<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,Department Of Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Illinois At Chicago,Department Of Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The demand for lungs deemed suitable for transplantation far outweighs the current supply. As the wait list continues to grow, efforts to improve utilization of uncontrolled donation after cardiac death (DCD) lungs is necessary to expand the donor pool. We hypothesized that ex vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) would allow for rehabilitation of DCD lungs after prolonged periods of warm ischemia time with resultant oxygenation capacities acceptable for transplantation.

Methods: Porcine donor animals were intubated, anesthetized, and subjected to hypoxic cardiac arrest, followed by various periods of warm ischemia time prior to lung procurement. Three groups (n=3/group) that differed by warm ischemia time (60, 90, or 120 minutes) were compared. Following warm ischemia, lungs were flushed with cold preservation solution, procured, and subjected to 4 hours of normothermic EVLP. At each hour of perfusion, lungs were challenged with 100% FiO2 and perfusate samples were obtained for PaO2/FiO2 calculations. Lungs were ventilated with protective tidal volumes of 8 mL/kg and 5 cmH2O of positive end-expiratory pressure. Airway pressures were monitored at each hour allowing for calculation of dynamic lung compliance.

Results: Mean PaO2/FiO2 values consistently improved over all 4 hours of EVLP in all three groups (Figure 1). There was a decrease in mean PaO2/FiO2 values in the 120 min of warm ischemia group compared to both the 60 min and 90 min groups at all four time points. The final mean PaO2/FiO2 values after 4 hours of EVLP were not significantly different (518.3±33.7, 539.3±19.0 mmHg, and 466.1±49.5 mmHg in the 60, 90, and 120 min groups, respectively). Among all three groups, there was no significant difference in the mean increase in PaO2/FiO2 values between the first hour of EVLP and the fourth hour of EVLP (100.4±10.1, 96.1±19.7, and 101.7±58.1 mmHg in the 60, 90, and 120 min groups, respectively). No significant difference in change of dynamic compliance over 4 hours of EVLP was observed between groups, however all three groups had a decrease in compliance (-1.5±1.3, -1.4±1.7, and -0.2±1.6 L/cmH2O in the 60, 90, and 120 min groups, respectively).

Conclusion: Rehabilitation of DCD lungs subjected to 60, 90, or 120 min of warm ischemia prior to procurement is possible with EVLP and results in consistent improvement in oxygenation capacity over a period of 4 hours. Expanding the donation pool to include uncontrolled DCD lungs exposed to varying lengths of warm ischemia time is a reasonable strategy with the use of EVLP and may allow for the reduction of both donor wait list times and mortality.

abstract_title: Cardiac Progenitor Cell Recruitment Inhibition Following Fetal MI Leads to Increased Inflammation
author_block: C. Zgheib<sup>1</sup>, J. Xu<sup>1</sup>, M. Allukian<sup>2</sup>, M. W. Morris<sup>1</sup>, R. C. Caskey<sup>2</sup>, M. Hodges<sup>1</sup>, J. H. Gorman<sup>2</sup>, R. C. Gorman<sup>2</sup>, K. W. Liechty<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology, Department Of Surgery, School Of Medicine, University Of Colorado Denver - Anschutz Medical Campus And Colorado Children's Hospital, Aurora,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>The University Of Pennsylvania School Of Medicine, Philadelphia,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Myocardial infarction (MI) is one of the leading causes of death in the United States. The adult response to MI is associated with left ventricle remodeling that results in significant cardiac myocytes loss and increase in fibrotic tissue formation which eventually lead to heart failure. In contrast, the normal fetal response to MI results in regeneration of functional myocardium. We have shown that inhibition of stromal-derived factor-1α (SDF-1α) in the fetal infarct blocks the recruitment of cardiac progenitor cells and results in a lack of regeneration, similar to the adult response. We hypothesize that this lack of regeneration is due to increased inflammatory response and inflammatory cell infiltration

Methods: To test this hypothesis, 20% apical infarcts were created in adult and fetal sheep by LAD ligation. In a subset of fetal sheep, the infarcts were injected with a lentivirus containing the SDF-1α inhibitor transgene or control. Hearts were harvested 3 or 30 days following infarction. Echocardiography was performed to assess cardiac function and infarct size. Histology was used to assess inflammatory cells infiltration and scar formation. Real-time PCR was used to assess IL-6, IL-8, and NFkB gene expression.

Results: At 3 days following MI, we observed significant infarcts in both fetal and adult hearts. At 30 days, the adult heart showed infarct expansion and decreased function. In contrast, the fetal hearts demonstrated resolution of the akinetic myocardium and restoration of cardiac function. At 3 and 30 days, fetal infarcts had significantly lower NFkB, IL-6 and IL-8 gene expression whereas in the adults it was significantly higher in the infarct area at both time-points. SDF-1α inhibition transformed the regenerative fetal response into a reparative response similar to the adult. At 30 days, fetal hearts treated with the SDF-1α inhibitor demonstrated a significant increase in infarct size as well as scar formation. SDF-1α inhibition resulted in increased IL-6, IL-8, and NFkB gene expression.

Conclusion: Our results demonstrate that the fetal regenerative response to MI is dependent on the recruitment of cardiac progenitor cells mediated by SDF-1α. These recruited progenitor cells may create an environment conducive to restoration of functional myocardium by altering the inflammatory response. These findings provide the first evidence that SDF-1α plays a role in the regulation of inflammation and or scar formation. Further studies are need to define the role of progenitor cell recruitment in promoting fetal cardiac regeneration.

abstract_title: Calpain Inhibition Effects Cystoskeletal Protein Expression A Model of Chronic Myocardial Ischemia
author_block: B. A. Potz<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Sabe<sup>1</sup>, N. Y. Elmadhun<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Feng<sup>1</sup>, I. J. Lawandy<sup>1</sup>, F. W. Sellke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brown University,Surgery/Cardiothoracic Surgery/ Warren Alpert Medical School,Providence, RHODE ISLAND, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Calpain is a family of cysteine proteases that has an important role in the initiation, regulation and execution of cell death. Our recent studies using a hypercholesterolemic swine model demonstrate that in the setting of metabolic syndrome calpain inhibition improved collateral dependent perfusion, decrease oxidative stress and increased expression of proteins implicated in angiogenesis. Research suggests that calpains may have an effect on regulation of cytoskeletal structure. In this study, we hypothesized that moderate calpain inhibition (CI) would affect cytoskeletal protein expression in the myocardium of the same pig model.

Methods: Yorkshire swine, fed a high cholesterol diet for four weeks, then underwent placement of an ameroid constrictor on the left circumflex artery. Three weeks later animals received either: no drug, high cholesterol control group (HCC; n= 8); low dose CI (0.12 mg/kg; LCI, n= 9); or high dose CI (0.25 mg/kg; HCI, n= 8). The high cholesterol diet and CI were continued for five weeks, after which the pig was euthanized and the left ventricular myocardium was harvested and analyzed via western blots. Data was analyzed via the Kruskal-Wallis test.

Results:There was a significant decrease in both the LCI and HCI groups in alpha tubulin compared to the control (p<0.05). There were significant increases in Troponin and alpha fodrin in both the LCI and HCI groups compared to the control (p<0.05). There were significant increases in Desmin and N-Cadherin in the HCI group and a trend increase in the LCI group compared to the control (p<0.05). There were significant increases in Vimentin and Filamin in the LCI group and a trend increase in the HCI group compared to the control (P<0.05). There were no significant changes in Connexin 43 (p=0.167), pan keratin (p=0.94), Beta Actin (p=0.76), Troponin T (p=0.309), or B tubulin (p=0.67).
