Conclusion:In the setting of hypercholesterolemia and chronic myocardial ischemia, CI increased cytoskeletal protein expression which may be a mechanism by which calpain inhibition increases myocardial blood flow and decreases oxidative stress.

abstract_title: Calpain Inhibition Decreases Inflammatory Protein Expression In A Model Of Chronic Myocardial Ischemia
author_block: B. A. Potz<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Sabe<sup>1</sup>, N. Y. Elmadhun<sup>1</sup>, I. J. Lawandy<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Feng<sup>1</sup>, F. W. Sellke<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brown University,Surgery/Cardiothoracic Surgery/ Warren Alpert Medical School,Providence, RHODE ISLAND, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Activation of calpain has been reported to be associated with an enhanced inflammatory response in the cardiovascular system. Our recent studies using a hypercholesterolemic swine model demonstrate that in the setting of metabolic syndrome calpain inhibition improved collateral dependent perfusion, decreased myocardial oxidative stress/apoptosis and increased myocardial angiogenesis. In this study, we hypothesized that moderate calpain inhibition (CI) would affect inflammatory protein expression in the myocardium of the same pig model.

Methods: Yorkshire swine, fed a high cholesterol diet for four weeks, then underwent placement of an ameroid constrictor on the left circumflex artery. Three weeks later animals received either: no drug, high cholesterol control group (HCC; n= 8); low dose CI (0.12 mg/kg; LCI, n= 9); or high dose CI (0.25 mg/kg; HCI, n= 8). The high cholesterol diet and CI were continued for five weeks, after which the pig was euthanized and the left ventricular myocardium was harvested and inflammatory protein expression was analyzed via western blots. Data was analyzed via the Kruskal-Wallis test.

Results: There was significant decrease in IL-1 in the HCI group and a trend decrease in the LCI group compared to the control(p<0.05). There was a significant decrease in TNF-alpha in the LCI group and a trend decrease in the HCI group compared to the control(p<0.05). There was a significant increase in PKC in the HCI group compared to the control(p<0.05). There was a significant increase in ICAM in the LCI group compared to the control and a trend increase in the HCI group compared to the control(p<0.05).[Table]There were no significant differences in IFN-gamma (p=0.130), p-IKB-alpha (p=0.14), I-NOS (p=0.122), NFK-B (p=0.532), or VCAM (p=0.569) in the HCI and LCI groups compared to the control.

Conclusions: In the setting of hypercholesterolemia and chronic myocardial ischemia, CI decreased inflammatory protein expression which may serve as a mechanism by which calpain inhibition decreases oxidative stress/apoptosis, increases myocardial angiogenesis and improves myocardial blood flow.

abstract_title: Biomimetic Scaffolds for the Guided Orientation of DFAT Cells for Cardiac Tissue Engineering
author_block: E. Tsang<sup>1</sup>, K. Chyu<sup>1</sup>, L. Iancu<sup>1</sup>, P. Benharash<sup>1</sup>, R. Shemin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>David Geffen School Of Medicine At UCLA,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The loss of functional cardiomyocytes following myocardial infarction (MI) often progresses to heart failure due to the limited ability of the adult heart to self-regenerate. Consequently, there is an intensive effort to investigate the transplantation of pluripotent cells as a viable therapy for the regeneration of myocardial tissue and preservation of cardiac function. Cellular cardiomyoplasty by intravenous, intracoronary, or direct injection is a popular strategy to restore cardiac function. However, issues with cell retention and engraftment limit this approach. To address this, it has been proposed that in vitro microenvironments in the form of a cardiac patch can be developed that recapitulate the appropriate physical cues found natively in the heart, leading to improved cellular functionality and organization. In this study, we investigate the feasibility of an electrospun conductive polymer scaffold to effectively organize and enhance cellular interconnectivity of pluripotent dedifferentiated adipose (DFAT) cells.

Methods: To fabricate the scaffolds, PCL, gelatin, and melanin were dissolved in HFIP (10% w/v) and electrospun with a flow rate of 2.5 ml/hr, 20 kV, and spinneret-collector distance of 15 cm. Fibers were collected on a rotating mandrel (3000 RPM) to create aligned fibers. The resulting scaffolds were characterized by SEM, ATR-FTIR, and Instron tensile testing. Primary DFAT cells were obtained from the dedifferentiation of mature murine adipocytes. After 5 days of cultivation, the cells were seeded onto the PCL/gelatin/melanin hybrid scaffolds and cell viability, morphology, and orientation were assessed.

Results:Our results demonstrate the ability to successfully fabricate aligned nanofibrous scaffolds from electrospun PCL/gelatin/melanin polymers. The incorporation of melanin was successfully confirmed by ATR-FTIR analysis. Elastic modulus was decreased with the addition of melanin in the scaffold compared to control PCL scaffolds, but was closer to literature values for native myocardium. The aligned fiber material demonstrated good biocompatibility, promoted cell attachment, and effectively directed cell orientation along the fiber direction.

Conclusion:Electrospun PCL/gelatin/melanin hybrid scaffolds with aligned fibers support the regulation of pluripotent DFAT cell organization and interconnectivity. The incorporation of conductive melanin component may allow the electrospun scaffold to support electrical stimulation of the DFAT cells to augment their functionality as a cardiac patch. Recapitulation of cardiac signaling through nanofibrous scaffolds and electrical stimulation offer a promising approach for the development of DFAT-derived cardiomyocytes using a patient's own cells.

abstract_title: Regulation of Cardiac fibroblast transformation and collagen synthesis by gain of function RAF1 mutation
author_block: A. Badami<sup>1</sup>, M. Razzaque<sup>1</sup>, P. Klepacz<sup>1</sup>, A. Resop<sup>1</sup>, X. Xu<sup>1</sup>, M. Han<sup>1</sup>, S. Akhter<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Cardiothoracic/Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: RAF1 is a signaling molecule of MAPK signaling pathways which relays signal though MEK-ERK to the downstream molecules. Previously we reported that gain-of-function (constitutive active) RAF1 mutations are associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and causes early death in Noonan Syndrome (NS) but the role of gain of function RAF1 mutation in cardiac fibroblasts (CF) remain to be explored. NS is an autosomal dominant disorder and about 20% of patients are present with HCM which is the leading cause of death in these children and young adults. We hypothesized that gain of function RAF1 play an important role in the regulation of cardiac fibroblast (CF) biology with regards to myofibroblast transformation, increased collagen synthesis, and myocardial fibrosis which are important in the development of Heart Failure (HF).

Methods: CFs were isolated from the LV of adult Sprague-Dawley rats. Cells were infected with 10 MOI either with control adeno virus (Ad-GFP) or with RAF1 mutant adeno virus (Ad-S257L). Protein or RNA was collected 72 hours after adenoviral infection. Cells were treated with MEK-ERK pathways inhibitor U0126 after 48 hours of adenoviral infection and protein or RNA was collected 24 hours after inhibitor treatment.

Results:To understand the role of gain of function RAF1 mutation in vitro, we infected rat CF with Ad-S257L and compared with Ad-GFP. We have found that profibrotic molecules such as collagen I, fibronectin and α-SMA were increased in Ad-S257L infected cells in compared with Ad-GFP infected cells, which were examined by western blotting and RT-PCR. We have also found that RAF1 mutation activate MEK-ERK, STAT3 in CF which were examined by western blotting with phospho-specific MEK, ERK and STAT3 antibodies. Inhibition of MEK-ERK pathways by U0126 decreases collagen I, fibronectin and a-SMA but didn't decrease STAT3 phosphorylation.

Conclusion:These findings suggest that gain of function RAF1 mutation regulates CF transformation to myofibroblasts, and collagen synthesis by activating MEK-ERK and STAT3. Targeted inhibition of both MEK-ERK and STAT3 pathways in CF may represent a novel therapeutic approach to prevent fibrosis and abnormal ventricular remodeling.

abstract_title: Estrogen-induced SDF-1 in Stem Cell-related Cardiac Protection in Females following Acute Ischemia
author_block: M. Wang<sup>1</sup>, W. Zhang<sup>2</sup>, T. G. Cook<sup>3</sup>, L. Wang<sup>1</sup>, M. Turrentine<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Cardiothoracic/Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>2</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Pediatrics,Indianapolis, IN, USA <sup>3</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Medicine,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies from our group and others have confirmed cardiac protective effect of estrogen on females during myocardial injury. In addition, we have previously shown higher levels of SDF-1 in female hearts compared to male hearts after acute ischemia/reperfusion. Depletion of endogenous estrogen by ovariectomy (OVX) decreased post-ischemic SDF-1 production in female hearts, while exogenous estrogen treatment restored myocardial SDF-1 level in OVX females (OVX F). Notably, SDF-1 is an important factor of chemoattraction for stem cell homing, thus able to initiate stem cell-based repair. Here, we hypothesize that estrogen-upregulated SDF-1 mediates endogenous stem cell accumulation in the ischemic heart, leading to enhanced cardiac repair in females.

Methods: The age-matched female and OVX F Sprague-Dawley rats were randomized into the following: 1) sham; 2) female + left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD) ligation; 3) OVX F + LAD; and 4) OVX F + LAD + SDF-1 (50ng/ul in 50ul of PBS, instant injection post-LAD). Cardiac function was detected by echocardiography and the peripheral blood (1ml) was collected on both day 3 and 7 post-ischemia for analysis of SDF-1 level (ELISA). The heart tissue was harvested at day 8 after surgery for assays of both myocardial collagen deposition (histochemistry) and Sca-1+ cell accumulation (immunofluorescence). Data were analyzed using student t-test, p<0.05= statistically significant.

Results: Depletion of endogenous estrogen worsened myocardial dysfunction in female hearts on both day 3 and 7 post-ischemia (Fig. A). Detrimental left ventricular (LV) remodeling was evident by the decreased LV wall thickness, increased LV internal dimensions, and elevated collagen deposition. Additionally, depletion of endogenous estrogen significantly decreased plasma SDF-1 levels following myocardial ischemia in OVX F compared to normal female (Fig. B). Intriguingly, increased accumulation of Sca-1+ cells was observed in the ischemic female myocardium compared to OVX F heart (Fig. C). More importantly, intra-myocardial injection of SDF-1 led to improved myocardial function (Fig. A) and ventricular remodeling, as well as increased Sca-1+ cell accumulation in the ischemic OVX F myocardium (Fig. C4) compared to their untreated counterparts.

Conclusion: Our results represent initial evidence suggesting the potential role of estrogen in regulating endogenous stem cell-based repair during acute myocardial ischemia.

abstract_title: Metformin Alters Myocardial Substrate Selection During Normokalemia and Potassium Cardioplegia
author_block: C. Holmes<sup>1</sup>, L. Powell<sup>1</sup>, N. Clarke<sup>1</sup>, M. Jessen<sup>1</sup>, M. Peltz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Cardiovascular And Thoracic Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Metformin may improve outcomes after cardiac surgery in diabetic and non-diabetic patients. The mechanism of action of metformin is unknown but likely involves alterations in myocardial metabolism. We hypothesized that metformin influences myocardial substrate selection by reducing fatty acid oxidation under conditions encountered during cardiac surgery. We investigated this hypothesis in a rodent model of normokalemic perfusion and potassium cardioplegia.

Methods: Groups of male Sprague-Dawley rat hearts (n=4 per group) were perfused with either standard Krebs-Heinseleit buffer or potassium modified (20mM) Krebs-Heinseleit buffer (to simulate potassium cardioplegia) containing physiological concentrations of fatty acids (.35mM), ketones (.17mM), lactate (1.2mM), pyruvate (.12mM), and glucose (5.5mM) with different Carbon-13 (13C) labelling patterns. After stabilization, animals were perfused under both conditions in the presence of no additives (Control), 500mM metformin (Metformin), 10 units/L insulin (Insulin), or both insulin and metformin (Metformin + Insulin).After perfusion, hearts were removed and freeze clamped in liquid nitrogen. Cardiac tissue was extracted with perchloric acid and lyophilized. Proton decoupled 13C NMR spectra were obtained. Fractional substrate oxidation was determined by glutamate isotopomer analysis under non-steady-state conditions. Groups were compared by one-way analysis of variance or t-tests.

Results: Fatty acids were the preferred substrate during normokalemic perfusion. Insulin mardedly reduced ketone oxidation with a corresponding increase in lactate and pyruvate oxidation. The addition of metformin to the buffer reversed this effect. In the cardioplegia groups, ketones were the major myocardial substrate. Fatty acid oxidation was suppressed in all cardioplegia groups compared to normokalemic perfusion. Metformin further reduced fatty acid oxidation and suppressed ketone oxidation while increasing the utilization of endogenous/unlabeled substrates. Glucose was a minor substrate under all conditions tested. See Table 1.

Conclusion: Metformin has differential effects on myocardial substrate oxidation in normokalemic perfusion and conditions simulating potassium cardioplegia. In the beating heart, insulin induced alterations in myocardial substrate selection are reversed by metformin. During cardioplegia, metformin reduces fatty acid oxidation. These findings may have important implications for improving myocardial protection in cardiac surgery.

abstract_title: Signature of Calcium Handling in Right Ventricular Failure and Recovery
author_block: M. E. Bowen<sup>1</sup>, H. Li<sup>1</sup>, X. Liu<sup>1</sup>, P. M. Sundwall<sup>1</sup>, M. H. Stephen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,Cardiothoracic Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Right heart failure affects many different patient populations, and with limited treatment options, carries a poor prognosis. The purpose of our investigation was to identify changes in calcium metabolism in both right ventricular failure (RVF) and recovery (RVR) in order to identify potential therapeutic targets. We aimed to identify alterations in cytosolic calcium levels between RVF and RVR, and to correlate these changes with the transcriptome.

Methods: We used our rabbit model of chronic, pressure-overload RVF and RVR. For calcium transient analysis, cardiomyocyte isolation on right ventricular (RV) tissue was performed and cardiomyocytes from control (n=12), RVF (n=11), and RVR (n=13), which, were field-stimulated at 0.5 Hz. Intracellular calcium was measured with fluo-4 epifluroresence. RNA sequencing was performed.

Results:We observed increased amplitude for absolute calcium in isolated RVR cells, 2.64 ± 0.149 (F/F0), compared to control and RVF, 1.95 ± 0.115, and 2.16 ± 0.117 (F/F0) respectively, P < 0.01. The decline of calcium transients from peak to 10% of peak was prolonged in RVR cells, 1332 ± 30.7 ms, compared to control and RVF cells, 1296 ± 23.6 and 1180 ± 24.2 ms, P <0.01. Conversely, the decline of calcium transients from peak to 10% of peak was decreased in RVF cells, P <0.01. The decay time constant of calcium transient was largest in RVR cells, 446.5 ± 20.6, compared to control and RVF cells, 377 ± 15.8 and 377 ± 16.2, P = 0.01. The RNA sequencing showed down regulation of the calcium signaling pathway and regulation of cellular mechanics by calpain protease pathway when comparing RVF to control. Several genes involved in calcium handling were significantly changed during RVF (see table). Minimal transcriptional changes were identified between RVR and control.

Conclusion:Multiple differences in calcium handling were identified in RV failure and recovery tissue including cytosolic calcium levels and transcription of calcium handling proteins. RV recovery tissue showed a return to the control transcriptome. Absolute calcium was increased in RV failure and recovery cells. Increase of calcium transient amplitude was observed in RVR compared to RVF, which indicates sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium might be partially restored during RVR. Decay of time constant of calcium transient was prolonged in both RVR and RVR suggesting reduced calcium update. This change in calcium metabolism likely plays a role in abnormalities of excitation-contraction-coupling. Further mechanistic studies concerning calcium metabolism are warranted.

abstract_title: Ca<sup>2+</sup>/Calmodulin-Dependent Kinase IV Contributes to Intestinal Inflammation During Murine Colitis
author_block: K. E. Cunningham<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Novak<sup>2</sup>, G. J. Vincent<sup>2</sup>, M. R. Rosengart<sup>1</sup>, K. P. Mollen<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh Medical Center,Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC,Pediatric Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chronic intestinal inflammation, as seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), is largely mediated by T-cells. Ca2+/Calmodulin-dependent kinase IV (CAMKIV) is a serine/threonine specific protein kinase predominantly found in lymphocytes and is known to play a critical role in T-cell activation. We now hypothesize that CAMKIV activation leads to intestinal inflammation via direct T-cell stimulation leading to pro-inflammatory cytokine production and a breakdown of the intestinal barrier.

Methods: Male CAMKIV KO mice (Camk4tm1Tch/Camk4tm1Tch) and wild-type (WT) counterparts (C57BL/6J) were subjected to dextran sodium sulfate (DSS) colitis for 7 days. RAG-/- mice were subjected to T-cell transfer colitis by IP injection of CD4+CD45RBhigh naïve T-cells from either CAMKIV KO mice or WT counterparts. Animal weights and disease activity index (DAI) were recorded daily. Intestinal tissue was analyzed for expression of inflammatory cytokines, generation of reactive oxygen species, and changes in barrier function. H&E staining was used to evaluate histological changes. Immunofluorescence was used to observe differences in the quantity and localization of key proteins as well as to identify infiltrating bacteria within the intestinal mucosa. Infiltrating intestinal epithelial T-cells were isolated and measured for purity using flow cytometry and separate nuclear and cytoplasmic fractions were extracted for analysis.

Results: WT mice subjected to DSS displayed increased levels of activated CAMKIV within the nucleus of infiltrating T-cells within the intestinal mucosa relative to cytoplasmic fractions. CAMKIV-deficient mice subjected to DSS were protected from intestinal inflammation relative to their WT counterparts, as demonstrated by H&E staining, PCR, and immunofluorescence. KO mice also demonstrated a decrease in HMGB1 activation within the intestine as compared to WT mice. Mice subjected to T-cell transfer experimental colitis with CD4+CD45RBhigh CAMKIV-deficient T-cells were protected when compared to mice receiving CD4+CD45RBhigh T-cells from WT mice.

Conclusion: We investigate for the first time the role of CAMKIV in the pathogenesis of intestinal inflammation. We demonstrate that the global absence of CAMKIV confers protection against murine experimental colitis, while the presence of CAMKIV predisposes to inflammation. Nuclear shuttling of activated CAMKIV in T-cells likely activates transcription of downstream regulators of inflammation, such as HMGB1, and contributes to murine colitis. Strategies aimed at suppressing CAMKIV activity may lead to novel treatment strategies for human IBD.

abstract_title: Hydrogen-saline Protects against Postoperative Ileus Associated with Reduced Nitric Oxide Production
author_block: A. Okamoto<sup>1</sup>, Y. Yamashita<sup>1</sup>, M. Aoyama-Ishikawa<sup>1</sup>, K. Kohama<sup>1</sup>, T. Nishimura<sup>1</sup>, N. Fujisaki<sup>1</sup>, J. Kotani<sup>1</sup>, A. Nakao<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hyogo College of Medicine,Department Of Emergency And Critical Care Medicine,Nishinomiya City, HYOGO PREFECTURE, Japan
abstract_body:
Introduction: Postoperative ileus a transmit impairment of bowel mortality, is a common phenomenon after abdominal surgery and leads to increased hospital stay and healthcare costs.Hydrogen has recently been shown to have therapeutic value with potent anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidant properties. Although inhalation of low concentrations of hydrogen gas been reported to prevent various diseases, solubilized hydrogen may be a portable, easily- administered, and safer/more practical means of hydrogen gas treatment. Therefore, we hypothesized that intraperitoneal (i.p.) administration of hydrogen-saturated physiological saline would ameliorate postoperative ileus in mice.

Methods: Ileus was induced via surgical manipulation (SM) of male C57BL/6 mice. Under general anesthesia, ileus was induced by applying two cotton-tipped applicators to the small intestine, using a rolling motion. Hydrogen-saturated physiological saline was produced by mixing saline with hydrogen gas using a pressure-resistant container (hydrogen concentration was 1.0 ppm and more, equivalent to 0.46mM). After SM, the peritoneal cavity was filled with 1.0mL of either physiological saline or hydrogen-saturated physiological saline that was inoculated into the peritoneal cavity before closure of the abdominal incision. Intestinal transit of a non-absorbable, fluorochrome-labeled dextran was assessed 24 hours postoperatively. The sham-surgery group underwent abdominal incision and closure without surgical manipulation. Griess reaction was performed to measure nitric oxide (NO) release form the muscularis extema in 24 h organ culture.

Results:SM resulted in a marked delay in intestinal transit associated with proinflammatory cytokine expression compared with sham controls. Bowel dysmotility induced by SM was attenuated by intraabdominal administration of hydrogen-saturated saline. Real time RT-PCR indicated increased mRNA levels for intercellular adhesion molecule (ICAM)-1, interleukin (IL)-6, IL-10, and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) after SM. Hydrogen-saline significantly reduced the upregulation of these inflammatory markers. The muscularis whole mount from sham-operated animals treated with saline or hydrogen-saline was virtually devoid of myeloperoxidase-positive leukocytes. SM was associated with extensive leukocyte infiltration 24 hrs after SM when treated with saline; however, this extravasation was significantly decreased when hydrogen-saline was i.p. administered. While NO production increased after SM, hydrogen significantly reduced NO levels in organ culture six hours after SM.

Conclusion: A single i.p. dose of hydrogen-saturated physiological saline ameliorates postoperative ileus by inhibiting the inflammatory response and NO production.

abstract_title: Effect of Geraniol on a Murine Model of Colitis
author_block: S. A. Morrison<sup>1</sup>, S. Hamarneh<sup>1</sup>, D. Hu<sup>1</sup>, H. Hu<sup>1</sup>, W. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, K. Economopoulous<sup>1</sup>, S. Gul<sup>1</sup>, R. Hodin<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Massachusetts General Hospital,Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Geraniol is a natural plant oil found in rose and lemon, commonly used as a flavoring agent, with newly discovered anti-inflammatory properties. Recent studies have demonstrated a protective role in carcinogenesis, peptic ulcer disease, metabolic syndrome, and a variety of infections. To date, the effect of this oil has never been studied in the context of inflammatory bowel disease. This study aimed to investigate the novel use of Geraniol in attenuating the severity of colitis in a murine model.

Methods: 8 week old female C57BL/6 wild type mice were used in this study. Study groups consisted of a control group, and two colitis groups, one receiving treatment. Colitis was induced in the experimental group by the addition of 3.5% Dextran Sodium Sulfate (DSS) to the drinking water for 7 days. Animals in the treatment group received Geraniol in the drinking water in addition to DSS. Animals were evaluated for weight daily. At the time of sacrifice, they underwent scoring based on their disease acuity index. The histologic slides of the colon were also scored. Additionally, the RNA of colonic samples was analyzed via qPCR for various inflammatory markers.

Results: Treatment with Geraniol resulted in significantly decreased disease acuity scores (DSS vs. Geraniol: 8.0 vs. 2.4, p=0.019), as well as decreased weight loss (average weight loss DSS vs. Geraniol: 2.4g vs. 0.28g, p=0.007). The mice treated with Geraniol also exhibited lower histology scores (DSS vs. Geraniol: 3.5 vs. 2.54, p=0.05). Treatment with Geraniol resulted in marked reductions in RNA levels of a number of inflammatory markers (DSS vs. Geraniol: IL-1b: 46.4 vs. 20.4, p=0.14, IL-6: 132.1 vs. 2.58, p=0.08, TLR4: 82.3 vs. 2.97, p=0.07, CD-14: 76.04 vs. 5.31, p=0.09, iNOS: 0.45 vs. 0.1, p=0.12).

Conclusion: The anti-inflammatory plant oil, Geraniol, is effective in decreasing the severity of DSS colitis in a murine model.

abstract_title: IL33 from Liver Sinusoidal Endothelial Cells Induces NET Formation in Hepatic Sterile Inflammation
author_block: D. J. Van Der Windt<sup>1</sup>, H. Huang<sup>1</sup>, H. Chen<sup>1</sup>, B. R. Rosborough<sup>1</sup>, H. Yazdani<sup>1</sup>, P. Loughran<sup>1</sup>, A. Tsung<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Department Of Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body: Introduction.Liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) and neutrophils interact and contribute to the inflammatory response in liver ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury. We recently found that infiltrating neutrophils form neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) and exacerbate sterile inflammatory injury during liver I/R. However, whether damaged LSECs can release signals to stimulate NET production is unknown. We thus sought to determine the role ofIL-33, a novel inflammatory mediator mainly released from LSECs, in NET formation during liver I/R.Methods.WT or IL-33 KO mice (both n=12) were subjected to a non-lethal warm liver I/R model of 1h ischemia followed by blood and tissue sampling after 1 h and 6h of reperfusion. The effects of recombinant IL-33 (rIL-33) or soluble ST2 (sST2, decoy receptor of IL-33) wereinvestigated. In vitro, isolated WT and IL-33 KO LSECs were exposed to hypoxia (1% O2) and co-cultured with neutrophils in the absence or presence of rIL-33, IL-33 neutralizing antibody (Ab), or sST2 to evaluate NET formation.Results.IL-33 KO mice or sST2-treated WT mice were significantly protected from I/R injury, having significantly less serum sALT and hepatic necrosis, lower levels of systemic cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α), and abrogation of MAP-kinase proinflammatory signaling pathways, compared to WT mice. rIL-33 administered during I/R exacerbated hepatotoxicity and systemic inflammation. Although significant neutrophil infiltration was found in both IL-33 KO and WT mice, NET formation was decreased in IL-33 KO mice during liver I/R compared with WT mice, as evidenced by a significant reduction inserum levels of myeloperoxidase (MPO)-DNA complexes, and in tissue levels of citrullinated-histone H3 (which are known NET markers). In addition, treatment of WT mice with sST2 reduced NET formation, whereas rIL-33 significantly increased numbers of NETs after liver I/R. In vitro, IL-33 released from LSECs that were subjected to hypoxia promoted NET formation. Directly stimulating neutrophils with rIL-33 confirmed the activation of the IL-33/ST2-MyD88 signaling pathway in NET formation. NET formation was blocked in experiments using IL-33 KO LSECs, as well as in the presence of IL-33 neutralizing Ab or sST2. Conclusion.Our study demonstrates that IL-33 released from hypoxic LSECs during liver I/R stimulates neutrophils to form NETs, leading to excessive inflammation and hepatotoxicity.

abstract_title: Invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells modulate expression of interleukin (IL)-25 in sepsis
author_block: T. T. Chun<sup>1</sup>, D. S. Heffernan<sup>1</sup>, C. Erlyana<sup>1</sup>, W. G. Cioffi<sup>1</sup>, C. Chung<sup>1</sup>, A. Ayala<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brown University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Providence, RI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: iNKT cells are a group of regulatory T cells that are critical in coordinating immune response, and are implicated in various immunological diseases. The recently described group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) may have an important role in crosstalk between innate and adaptive aspects of the immune response, and they are implicated in lung inflammation and allergic responses. These cells differentiate from their precursor cells with stimulation by IL-25 as well as IL-33, and result in the secretion of Th-2 associated cytokines including interleukins (IL)-5, -9 and -13. As such, they may contribute to immunosuppression in polymicrobial sepsis. Previously, we demonstrated, in murine model of sepsis, that iNKT cells are required to illicit production of IL-33. We hypothesize that iNKT cells would, in a similar fashion, affect the expression of IL-25 in the circulating blood, peritoneal fluid and in the liver in sepsis.

Methods: Cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) and sham laparotomy were performed in both wildtype (WT) C57BL/6 and iNKT-/- mice. At various time points (6, 12, and 24 hours) following surgery, mouse serum, peritoneal fluid and liver tissues were harvested, and IL-25 levels were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA).

Results: In septic WT mice, there was a rapid decline in liver IL-25 levels, starting as early as 6 hours (54.8 vs 108pg/ml; p=0.009) and persisting for up to 24 hours (59.3 vs 108pg/ml; p=0.034) following CLP, in keeping with previous observations of the rapid and persistent migration of iNKT cells from the liver. iNKT-/- mice demonstrated low baseline levels of liver IL-25, which were unchanged by sepsis throughout the time course (49.1 vs 62.1pg/ml at 24hrs post-CLP; p=0.63). CLP did not induce any changes in serum IL-25 levels in WT mice compared to sham (7.0 vs 11.0pg/ml at 24 hours; p=0.21). However, in iNKT-/- mice, sepsis resulted in a rapid and persistent decline in IL-25 levels (3.3 vs 15.6pg/ml at 24 hours; p=0.01). In the peritoneal cavity, we noted an early decline in IL-25 levels in septic WT mice (5.8 vs 16.7pg/ml at 6 hours; p=0.03), but this was noted to rise by 24 hours (9.3pg/ml), in keeping with the known migration of iNKT cells into the peritoneal cavity. iNKT-/- mice did not demonstrate changes in peritoneal IL-25 levels following CLP.

Conclusion: The observation that hepatic IL-25 levels decrease with concomitant initial decline, followed by rise of IL-25 in the peritoneal cavity is consistent with our previous data describing iNKT cell migration from the liver to the peritoneal cavity in animal models of peritonitis. This further supports the notion that iNKT cells modulate the expression of IL-25, which is a known stimulator/activator of ILC2s. Further work will elucidate the exact mechanisms and potential pathways underlying the interactions between iNKT cells and ILC2s.

abstract_title: Ursodeoxycholic Acid Protects Against Experimental Peritonitis By Promoting Enterocyte Migration
author_block: J. Golden<sup>1</sup>, O. Escobar<sup>1</sup>, L. Illingworth<sup>1</sup>, K. Shin<sup>1</sup>, H. Ford<sup>1</sup>, C. Gayer<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) is a secondary bile acid that has anti-inflammatory properties and plays a role in enterocyte signaling. Previous work in our lab has shown that UDCA promotes enterocyte migration in vitro using rat intestinal epithelial cells. However, the effect of UDCA on enterocyte migration in vivo is unknown. We propose that the protective effects of UDCA are related to its ability to enhance intestinal wound closure. Therefore, we hypothesized that UDCA would protect against inflammation and intestinal barrier breakdown in experimental peritonitis by promoting enterocyte migration.

Methods: C57/Bl6 wild-type mice were used in all experiments. Sixteen hours prior to sacrifice, mice were orally gavaged fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-dextran with or without 100mg/kg UDCA and injected with 30mg/kg lipopolysaccharide (LPS) intraperitoneally (IP). 5-ethynyl-2'-deoxyuridine (EdU) was administered IP 2 hours prior to sacrifice. Blood samples were analyzed for FITC-dextran levels to determine barrier breakdown. Intestinal tissue was analyzed for mRNA expression and was stained for cell migration and proliferation using an EdU assay, as well as for apoptosis using the TUNEL assay. Statistical analysis was performed using Student's t-test.

Results: Four mice were included in each group. Compared to controls, UDCA increased villus height and enterocyte migration but did not affect enterocyte proliferation. UDCA decreased apoptosis and barrier breakdown in mice injected with LPS compared to levels seen in untreated animals. Animals who received UDCA in addition to LPS injection had decreased iNOS, IL-6, and IL-10 mRNA expression compared to those who were injected with LPS alone as measured by real-time RT-PCR.

Conclusion: UDCA is protective against experimental peritonitis by decreasing intestinal barrier breakdown, protecting against villus destruction, increasing enterocyte migration, and decreasing inflammation and apoptosis. Our data suggest that UDCA may have potential therapeutic benefits by preventing barrier breakdown in patients with sepsis and peritonitis.

abstract_title: Therapeutic Treatment With Saquinavir Improves Acetaminophen-Induced Hepatotoxicity
author_block: T. Li<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Deng<sup>1</sup>, V. Gollapudi<sup>1</sup>, E. Bauer<sup>1</sup>, T. Billiar<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Surgery/ School Of Medicine,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Central South University,Xiangya School Of Medicine,Changsha, HUNAN, China
abstract_body:
Introduction: Acetaminophen (APAP) is the active ingredient of Tylenol. Its overdose (intentional or accidental) has led to thousands of deaths over the last decade nationally. APAP overdose can lead to fulminant hepatic failure as glutathione stores in the liver are depleted resulting in increased accumulation of toxic metabolites. The role of Damage Associated Molecular Pattern molecules (DAMPs) as contributors to hepatoxicity is well established, especially the role of the DAMP High Mobility Group Box One (HMGB1). Here we present data showing that mice treated THERAPEUTICALLY with the first generation- protease inhibitor saquinavir (SQV) present with significantly attenuated liver failure.Methods : We used a murine model of APAP overdose: Mice were fasted for 14hrs followed by injection with an APAP overdose (400mg/kg. i.p). Three hrs after the overdose injection mice were treated therapeutically with saquinavir (5mg/kg) or the vehicle itself as control. Mice were sacrificed at 12hrs post APAP injection and analyzed for the development of liver failure using the following endpoints: A) serum analysis for AST/ALT levels, B) histologic evaluation of liver necrosis, C) Western blot analysis of liver tissue for mechanistic studies.

Results: THERAPEUTIC TREATMENT with SAQUINAVIR three hrs post APAP overdose led to significantly lowered ALT/AST values compared to vehicle treated controls alone. Evaluation of H&E stained liver sections also presented significanlty less tissue necrosis. Furthermore, HMGB1 levels were attenuated in mice treated therapeutically with SQV. Western blot analysis of liver homogenate points to a mechanism involving apoptosis as we observed distinct changes in the protein expression of Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (Parp), beclin-1 and caspase-3.

Conclusion: Here show for the first time that the protease inhibitor SQV has great potential for drug repurposing. Saquinavir demonstrates strong THERAPEUTIC value in this murine model of APAP induced acute liver failure leading to decreased HMGB1 release and significant decreased levels of apoptosis.Clinical Significance: The identification of HMGB1 as a target of SQV could potentially allow for a rapid transition of the discovery to the bedside, by re-purposing a drug already approved by the FDA with a well-known safety profile.

abstract_title: Morbid Obesity Provokes Resistance to Endogenous Tissue-Type Plasminogen Activator
author_block: A. P. Morton<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Schoen<sup>1,5</sup>, H. B. Moore<sup>1,2</sup>, P. Lawson<sup>2</sup>, M. Dzieciatkowska<sup>2</sup>, M. P. Chapman<sup>2</sup>, C. Fleming<sup>2,3</sup>, C. Silliman<sup>2,4</sup>, E. E. Moore<sup>2,3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Hospital,Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Colorado,Trauma Research Center,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>3</sup>Denver Health Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Denver, CO, USA <sup>4</sup>Bonfils Blood Center,Denver, CO, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Colorado,Surgical Weight Loss Center,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body: IntroductionMorbid obesity increases the risk for both arterial and venous thrombotic events, including myocardial infarction (MI) and venous thromboembolism (VTE). This risk has been attributed to the pro-inflammatory state, which is known to upregulate coagulation. In trauma, the inflammatory response to injury causes resistance (shutdown) to tissue-plasminogen activator (tPA) mediated fibrinolysis which is associated with multiple organ failure and VTE. This shutdown is mediated through regulatory proteases, such as plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAI-1). We hypothesize that obese patients exhibit fibrinolysis shutdown that is driven by chronic inflammation and regulatory proteases, and that this will be normalized by weight loss. MethodsTwenty three subjects meeting NIH criteria for morbid obesity and bariatric surgery were enrolled in this study. 11 patients were evaluated preoperatively (Pre) and 12 patients (9 roux-en-y gastric bypass and 3 sleeve gastrectomy) had blood samples obtained 6 months postoperatively (Post). Citrated native thromboelastography (TEG) was performed with the addition of tPA (150 ng/ml) to quantify fibrinolysis resistance, measured by the lysis at 30 minutes after maximum clot strength (LY30). These results were compared to a group of 137 healthy, non-obese subjects (HS). Fibrinolysis was measured using the percent lysis at 30 minutes after maximum clot strength is achieved (LY30). Targeted proteomic analysis of 129 coagulation-related proteins were performed in each sample. Data were analyzed using the Mann-Whitney test with a two-tailed alpha of 0.05.ResultsThe Pre and Post groups were comparable with median age (40 vs 42 years; p=0.9), pre- op Body Mass Index (BMI) (41.3 vs 45.9 p=0.60), and gender (82% vs 75% female). The Post group had a reduced post-op BMI of 30.5 (p<0.001) at 6 months. The HS group was younger (31 years) with lower BMI (24) and was 52% female. The Pre group exhibited reduced LY30 compared to the HS group (8% vs 53%; p<0.0001) and the Post group (8% vs 21%; p=0.016). Proteomic analysis identified that 11% of proteins analyzed differed between Pre and Post groups, including a 21% reduction in vitronectin in the Post group (p=0.007), but no difference in PAI-1.ConclusionPreoperatively, obese patients exhibit fibrinolysis shutdown compared to controls. Six months after surgery tPA sensitivity is markedly improved, which correlates with weight loss. While PAI-1 levels were unchanged, other coagulation proteins differed, including lower levels of post-op vitronectin. This finding suggests the pathologic basis for hypercoagulability may differ between populations, and warrants further study of these differences in order to develop pathology-specific anti-thrombotic strategies.

abstract_title: Histone Deacetylase Inhibitors Modulate Platelet and Coagulation Function In-Vitro
author_block: T. Bambakidis<sup>1,2</sup>, S. E. Dekker<sup>1</sup>, I. Halaweish<sup>1</sup>, B. Liu<sup>1</sup>, P. Piascik<sup>1</sup>, W. He<sup>1</sup>, Y. Li<sup>1</sup>, M. Sillesen<sup>1</sup>, V. Nikolian<sup>3</sup>, H. Alam<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,General Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan Health System,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Reduced platelet function has been associated with adverse outcome in trauma patients. This may in part be due to initial platelet hyperactivation but a subsequent decrease in platelet function, referred to as exhausted platelet syndrome. We have previously demonstrated that histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDACI) treatment attenuates coagulation imbalance and increase platelet activation following injury. We now investigate whether this could be due to a direct effect of HDACIs on platelets following injury.

Methods: Eleven female Yorkshire swine were anesthetized and instrumented in our established model of Traumatic Brian Injury (TBI) and hemorrhagic shock (HS). Blood samples were drawn prior to TBI+HS insult (healthy group) and two hours following hemorrhagic shock (shock group). Samples were incubated with pan-HDAC inhibitor valproic acid (VPA, 10mM), selective isoform-specific HDAC6 inhibitor Tubastatin A (TubA, 1μM), or vehicle controls for 1 hour. Platelet aggregation was analyzed via impedance aggregometry using collagen (COL), arachidonic acid (ASPI), and adenosine diphosphate (ADP) agonists. Global coagulation parameters were measured using thromboelastography (TEG).

Results: Direct ex vivo VPA or TubA dosing in healthy blood did not affect platelet aggregation or global coagulation parameters. In shock blood, however, VPA significantly reduced COL- (p=0.05), ASPI- (p<0.01) and ADP- (p<0.05) induced platelet aggregation compared to vehicle controls (Figure). Conversely, in shock blood TEG alpha angle and maximum amplitude (MA) were significantly increased in the VPA group, indicating increased clot formation rate and strength (p<0.05 and p<0.01, respectively). Similarly, TubA significantly decreased ASPI- (p<0.01) and ADP- (p<0.05) induced platelet aggregation, while significantly increasing TEG clot strength (MA, p<0.05). Both HDACIs exhibited variable effects on fibrinolysis.

Conclusion: This is the first study to investigate the direct effects of HDACI on platelet function ex vivo. Our results suggest that HDACI decrease ADP, ASPI and COL platelet hyperactivation but improve overall clot strength in shocked whole blood, indicating a selective platelet sparing effect while maintaining clot strength integrity. This may be mediated through inhibition of HDAC6. These findings may in part explain the previously observed prevention of platelet exhaustion following VPA resuscitation in vivo. HDACI administration may potentially play an important role in the prevention of platelet dysfunction following traumatic injuries.

abstract_title: SDF-1a improves collagen homeostasis in diabetic wounds through modulation of miR-25 expression
author_block: J. Xu<sup>1</sup>, C. Zgheib<sup>1</sup>, J. Hu<sup>1</sup>, K. W. Liechty<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado Denver, Laboratory For Fetal And Regenerative Biology,Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Complications of diabetes, such as the development of a chronic wound, represent a significant clinical problem. The etiology of this wound healing impairment is multifactorial and includes a decreased deposition of extracellular matrix (ECM) or collagen. We have previously shown that murine diabetic wounds are deficient in Stromal Derived Factor-1a (SDF-1a) and that treatment of diabetic wounds with SDF-1a can improve healing, however, the mechanisms of this correction are not well characterized. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) regulate the translation of mRNAs at the post-transcriptional level. Specifically, MiRNA-25 has been shown to inhibit collagen protein synthesis. We have recently shown that miR-25 expression is increased in murine diabetic wounds. We hypothesized that the improved diabetic wound healing following treatment with SDF-1a is due, in part, to correction of the dysregulated miR-25 gene expression resulting in increased collagen hemostasis.

Methods: To test this hypothesis, 8mm full-thickness wounds were created on the flank of diabetic (Db/Db) and non-diabetic (Db/+) mice with a dermal punch instrument. At the time of wounding, the wounds were treated with an intradermal injection with either 108 plaque-forming units (PFU) of a lentivirus containing the SDF-1a or GFP transgene. The wounds were harvested 7days after injury and processed for histology and isolation of total cellular RNA. We also isolated diabetic and non-diabetic dermal fibroblasts and treated them with either 106 PFU of a lentivirus containing the SDF-1a or GFP transgene. Gene expression was analyzed using Real-time PCR analysis.

Results:At 7 days, diabetic wounds treated with lenti-SDF-1a exhibited a significant decrease in wound surface area compared to lenti-GFP treated wounds. Morphologically, SDF-1-treated diabetic wounds demonstrated increased granulation tissue volume and cellularity compared to controls. Diabetic wounds treated with SDF-1a also demonstrated a significant decrease in miR-25 expression, and a significant increase in the miR-25 targets Col1a1, compared to GFP treated diabetic wounds. At the cellular level, miR-25 was significantly up-regulated in diabetic fibroblasts at baseline, compared to non-diabetic fibroblasts. In addition, SDF-1a treatment corrected the miR-25 gene expression to levels similar to the non-diabetic fibroblast.

Conclusion:SDF-1a mediated correction of the diabetic wound healing impairment is due, in part, to correction of dysregulated miR-25 expression. Decreased expression of miR-25 may result in increased collagen homeostasis resulting in improved diabetic wound healing. Further studies are needed to define the role of abnormal miRNA regulation in the pathogenesis of the diabetic wound healing impairment.

abstract_title: Bladder Tumor Initiating Cells as Predictors of Outcome
author_block: K. Skowron<sup>1</sup>, J. Namm<sup>5</sup>, S. Pitroda<sup>3</sup>, M. Beckett<sup>3</sup>, N. Khodarev<sup>3</sup>, M. Posner<sup>1,4</sup>, G. Steinberg<sup>2</sup>, R. Weichselbaum<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery / Section Of General Surgery,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery / Section Of Urology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Radiation And Cellular Oncology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>5</sup>Loma Linda University Health,Department Of Surgery,Loma Linda, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery / Section Of Surgical Oncology,Chicago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Bladder cancer is the 9th leading cause of cancer death in the U.S. Treatment consists of radical cystectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy or bladder-sparing chemo-radiotherapy in selected cases. Volkmer et al. identified bladder tumor initiating cells (BTICs) in progressive stages of differentiation (1). We established patient derived xenografts (PDX) in order to study BTIC biology in vivo. We hypothesized that patient tumors with a greater population of basal or poorly differentiated BTICs would have a poor clinical outcome compared to patients with well-differentiated tumors. Gene expression analysis was performed with the goal of identifying prognostic markers.

Methods: Patients undergoing cystectomy are recruited under an IRB-approved protocol. Tumor samples are received from pathology; fragments are injected subcutaneously into the flank of NOD/SCID mice and monitored for engraftment. Remaining tissue is analyzed with flow cytometry to quantify the BTIC populations. Any tumors which engraft are excised, reimplanted into further generations of mice, and sorted for RNA extraction of the BTIC populations. Subsequent xenograft tumors are treated with either radiation or cisplatin, and analyzed for tumor growth and changes in BTIC populations. Clinical data are gathered using the REDCap web-based data server. RNA expression is assessed using Illumina Human HT-12 array.

Results:Of 70 patient samples, 41 tumors have engrafted in mice. There was no correlation between engraftment and survival. However, a correlation between greater basal BTIC populations and overall survival approached significance (p=0.09). If patients did not receive systemic chemotherapy (n=28), the basal BTICs conferred a greater risk to overall survival (LR 5.5, p=0.06) than among patients (n=21) who received any systemic chemotherapy (LR 0.62, p=0.74). The basal BTICs comprise an average of 1% of the tumor cells (range 0-17%). Early results indicate a differential response to cisplatin and radiation among PDX tumors for both agents. Analysis of the RNA array identified a signature of 54 genes suppressed in basal BTICs relative to the more differentiated tumor cells. This gene signature correlates with overall survival (p=0.0047) and disease-specific survival (p=0.0085) in a large cohort of patients.

Conclusion:Our results suggest that the presence of a small percentage of basal BTICs portends a poor clinical outcome, which may be improved by the addition of chemotherapy. RNA evaluation of these BTICs has revealed potential biological markers and targets for future therapy, as well as a gene signature which may provide a tool for improved patient selection for therapy. (1) Volkmer JP, Sahoo D, Chin RK, et al. Three differentiation states risk-stratify bladder cancer into distinct subtypes. PNAS 2012;109:2078-2083.

abstract_title: MiR-23a Down-regulates Interferon Regulatory Factor-1 (IRF-1) in Hepatocellular Carcinoma
author_block: Y. Yan<sup>1,2</sup>, Z. Liang<sup>1,2</sup>, Q. Du<sup>1</sup>, M. Yang<sup>1</sup>, D. A. Geller<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Department Of Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>The First Affiliated Hospital Of Guangxi Medical University,Nanning, GUANGXI, China
abstract_body:
Introduction: Interferon regulatory factor-1 (IRF-1) is a tumor suppressor gene induced by interferon-γ (IFNγ) and plays an important role in the death of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). HCC tumors evade death in part by down-regulating IRF-1 expression, but the molecular mechanism accounting for IRF-1 suppression in HCC is not characterized. Previous studies showed that microRNA-23a(miR-23a) can suppress apoptosis by targeting IRF-1. Therefore, we hypothesized that miR-23a promotes HCC by down-regulating IRF-1.

Methods: For in vivo studies, seven cases of HCC and adjacent liver tissues were obtained from patients who underwent hepatectomy. For in vitro studies, IRF-1 mRNA and protein were examined in HepG2 and Huh7 HCC cells after IFNγ stimulation. IRF-1 mRNA and protein expression was determined by real-time PCR and Western blot analysis, respectively. To determine the role of miR-23a in regulating IRF-1, HepG2 cells were transfected by miR-23a mimic or inhibitor, and IRF-1 expression examined. Specific binding of miR-23a with IRF-1 3'-untranslated region (3'-UTR) was assessed by cloning the 528-bp human IRF-1 3'-UTR sequence into reporter luciferase plasmid pMIR-IRF-1-3'UTR. Luciferase activity was performed in HCT116 cancer cells transfected with empty pMIR-Luc vector, pMIR-IRF-1 3'UTR, or pMIR-IRF-1 3-'UTR + miR-23a mimic or inhibitor.

Results: IRF-1 mRNA expression was down-regulated in 6 of 7 HCC human tumors compared to adjacent background liver (p<0.001, Fig. A). IRF-1 protein was induced by IFNγ stimulation in HepG2 cells in a time-dependent manner (Fig. B). Addition of miR-23a mimic down-regulated IFNγ-induced IRF-1 expression, while miR-23a inhibitor increased IRF-1 in HepG2 cells (Fig. B). Likewise, miR-23a inhibitor also increased IRF-1 mRNA and nuclear protein in Huh7 cells (data not shown). We identified a putative miR-23a binding element in the 3'-UTR of IRF-1. Ligation of the IRF-1-3'UTR decreased basal luciferase reporter activity in HCT116 cells. Addition of miR-23a mimic further repressed pMIR-IRF-1-3'UTR reporter activity, while miR-23a inhibitor restored the reporter activity (Fig. C).

Conclusions:These results demonstrate that 1) IRF-1 expression is down-regulated in resected human HCC tumors compared to background liver; 2) IRF-1 expression is induced by IFNγ in HepG2 cells; 3) miR-23a downregulates the expression of IRF-1 in HCC cells, and 4) the IRF-1 3'-UTR has a miR23-a binding site that binds miR-23a and decreases reporter activity. These findings suggest that miR-23a targeting IRF-1 might be the molecular basis for IRF-1 down-regulation in HCC and provide new insight into miRNA regulation of HCC.

abstract_title: Hexokinase 2 Promotes Primary Tumor Growth and Metastasis in Pancreatic Cancer
author_block: R. Marayati<sup>1</sup>, M. Anderson<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Yeh<sup>1,2,3,4</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,School Of Medicine,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Surgery,Chapel Hill, NC, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Department Of Pharmacology,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Over half of all pancreatic cancer patients initially present to the clinic with metastatic disease and the 5-year overall survival rate for this cohort is less than 2%. Treatment options for these patients are limited, as they are not candidates for surgery and often prove to be unresponsive to chemotherapy. Current research efforts are, therefore, focused on understanding tumor biology with the goal of identifying new targets for therapy. Previous work in a genetically engineered mouse model of pancreatic cancer showed anabolic glucose metabolism to be essential for primary tumor growth. Hexokinase 2 (HK2) is a key enzyme necessary for glucose uptake and processing that is commonly dysregulated in solid tumors. We aimed to assess the role of HK2 in promoting pancreatic cancer tumor growth and metastasis.

Methods: Microarray gene expression data was analyzed from 149 primary and 61 metastatic pancreatic cancer tumors, and 47 normal pancreatic samples. Pancreatic cancer cell lines were stably transfected with doxycycline-inducible lentiviral shRNA constructs targeting either HK2 (shHK2) or a nonspecific control (shNS). Subcutaneous and tail vein injections of these lines were performed to monitor primary tumor growth and metastasis, respectively. Mice were treated with either doxycycline, to induce shRNA expression, or vehicle. Tumor growth was assessed biweekly using caliper measurements for 30 days of treatment, and mice were examined for lung metastasis using bioluminescence for 6 weeks after tail vein injection.

Results: HK2 was significantly upregulated in both primary and metastatic pancreatic tumors relative to normal pancreas. Kaplan-Meier survival analysis showed that patients with high expression of HK2 in primary pancreatic tumors had a significantly worse overall survival (13 vs 21 months, p=0.033). Mice subcutaneously injected with shHK2 and treated with doxycycline to induce HK2 knockdown (n=9) had a significant decrease in tumor volume compared to those treated with vehicle (n=8, p=0.049). This tumor growth inhibition was not observed with the induction of shNS expression (shNS doxycycline vs. vehicle, p=0.339), suggesting that HK2 expression is necessary for primary tumor growth in vivo. Furthermore, HK2 knockdown impaired the formation of lung metastasis. All control mice with tail vein injections of nonspecific shNS (n=7) developed lung metastasis during the six-week period, while only 2 out of 9 mice with HK2 knockdown developed metastasis (p=0.003).

Conclusion: Our results show that glycolytic enzyme HK2 has decreased expression in normal pancreas and is upregulated in pancreatic tumors. Furthermore, increased HK2 expression is associated with a poor clinical prognosis. In vivo studies support an important role for this gene in promoting both primary tumor growth and metastasis. Together, these results suggest HK2 may represent a good therapeutic target for the treatment of pancreatic cancer.

abstract_title: Mir-205 Derived From Pancreatic Cancer Cells Induces CXCL10 Production by the Associated Stroma
author_block: S. Han<sup>1</sup>, D. Delitto<sup>1</sup>, D. H. Gonzalo<sup>2</sup>, J. George<sup>1</sup>, D. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, M. Beveridge<sup>1</sup>, R. M. Thomas<sup>1</sup>, J. Trevino<sup>1</sup>, S. Hughes<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida,Pathology,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Florida,School Of Science,Gainesville, FL, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Florida,Surgery,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: We recently reported that co-culture of pancreas cancer (PC) cells with tumor associated stroma (TAS) leads to significant and lasting changes in cytokine, chemokine, and growth factor production by the TAS, including CXCL10. microRNAs are small non-coding RNA molecules that have recently emerged as important players involved in regulation multiple aspects of cancer biology as well as in tumor microenviroments. We hypothesized that microRNAs function as signaling molecules between PC and TAS.

Methods: Monolayer co-culture was performed by seeding TAS and PC cells in 10:1 ratio. TAS and PC cells from co-culture were then separated by FACS using epithelial surface marker EpCam. Extracellular vesicles from PC conditioned media were isolated by differential centrifugation with size filtration. Total RNA from cultured cells and exosomes were isolated using Trizol. microRNA reverse-transcription and real-time PCR was performed using exiqon microRNA cDNA synthesis and PCR SYBR green kits. CXCL10 secretion was detected with BD OptEIA.

Results: Of the panel of microRNAs analyzed, we focused on mir-205 as it was highly expressed in the PC cell lines (relative expression of 0.846 in copy number index normalized to mir-let-7a expression levels), yet all six primary cultures of TAS cells lacked mir-205 expression (relative expression of 0.008 in copy number index normalized to mir-let-7a levels). mir-205 was subsequently confirmed in vesicle preparations of conditioned media from PC cultures. Following co-culture with PC cells and subsequent cell-sorting to purify the TAS cells, mir-205 expression was observed in the TAS lines (increased fold of 115.6±4.2, p<0.05). Over-expression mir-205 in TAS cells by lipofactamine transfection induced CXCL10 secretion by the TAS (2.37-fold increased, p<0.05) but not in nonsense microRNA plus vehicle controls.

Conclusion: Taken together, these studies suggest that mir-205 expressed by PC cancer cells can be transferred into neighboring TAS cells and result in changes in cytokine (CXCL10) production. Shed microRNA may serve as signaling molecules within the tumor microenvironment.

abstract_title: Genetic polymorphisms in 5-FU related enzymes predict complete pathologic response in rectal cancer
author_block: B. A. Nelson<sup>1</sup>, J. Carter<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Eichenberger<sup>1</sup>, U. Netz<sup>1</sup>, S. Galandiuk<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Louisville School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Colorectal Surgery,Louisville, KY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with locally advanced rectal cancer undergo preoperative neoadjuvant chemoradiation with approximately 70% exhibiting pathologic downstaging in response to treatment. Of these, 15-20% of patients exhibit 'complete pathologic response' with no remaining viable cancer. There is currently no accurate test to identify patients who are complete responders to neoadjuvant therapy who may be able to avoid undergoing radical surgery. 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is an antimetabolite drug that is widely used in the neoadjuvant treatment of rectal cancer. Genetic polymorphisms affect the activity of enzymes involved in 5-FU metabolism, such as thymidylate synthase (TYMS) and dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenease (DPYD), and may also account for differing responses to neoadjuvant treatment seen in rectal cancer patients. Detection of such polymorphisms might permit identification of patients likely to have a complete response to neoadjuvant therapy.

Methods: DNA was isolated from whole blood taken from patients with newly diagnosed rectal cancer who received neoadjuvant therapy (n=54) and whole genome amplification was performed. Medical records were reviewed and a tumor regression score was given based on pre- and post-operative TNM staging. PCR was performed using previously published primers targeting the promoter region of TYMS. PCR products were separated by electrophoresis on a 3% agarose gel to visualize if a patient was homozygous for a double-tandem repeat (2R), a triple-tandem repeat (3R), or heterozygous (2R/3R). A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) may also be present in the second repeat unit of the 3R allele. Restriction fragment length polymorphism assays were performed on patients with at least one 3R allele using HaeIII, a restriction enzyme that recognizes the GGCC sequence and cleaves between the second and third nucleotides. The fragments were separated by electrophoresis. For DPYD, single SNP assays were performed on two alleles with RT PCR. The major and minor alleles for each SNP fluoresced with different dyes.

Results: Successful DNA extraction, whole genome amplification, and PCR were confirmed by spectrophotometry. Of 54 patients, 14 patients were homozygous for 2R allele, 10 patients homozygous for 3R allele and 30 patients heterozygous for 2R/3R alleles. Patients with at least one TYMS 3R allele were more likely (OR 4 95% CI: 0.79 – 20.3) to have a complete pathologic response to treatment following 5-FU based neoadjuvant therapy than patients with two TYMS 2R alleles (p 0.07). Patients with at least one major allele in DPYD were more likely (OR 1.3 95% CI: 0.5 – 3.9) to exhibit pathologic downstaging with neoadjuvant therapy (p 0.5).

Conclusion: Identification of patients with specific genetic polymorphisms in enzymes involved in 5-FU metabolism appear to predict the likelihood of complete response of rectal cancer to preoperative 5-FU based neoadjuvant therapy and may alter surgical decision making.

abstract_title: Differences In Expression Patterns Between Early- And Late-onset Rectal Tumors
author_block: J. Jandova<sup>1</sup>, V. N. Nfonsam<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Arizona,Surgical Oncology/Surgery/Medicine,Tucson, AZ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most commonly diagnosed cancer and the second leading cause of cancer related deaths in the US. The overall incidence of CRC in the US has decreased over the past three decades, yet recent literature indicates alarming increase in incidence among individuals under the age of 50. More importantly, the younger patients present with more advanced and aggressive disease. Despite alarming increase in incidence of early-onset rectal tumors (EORC), the etiology is not quite understood. Increased frequency of EORC, poorer prognosis and lack of molecular data emphasizes a need for improved and novel molecular markers for use in the treatment and prognosis of this disease.

Methods: Two cohorts of patients with sporadic early- onset (EO) and late-onset (LO) rectal tumors were identified. We obtained tumor samples from six patients under age 50 and six patients over 65. We also obtained their matching non-involved tissues. Patients with Lynch syndrome, familial adenomatous polyposis and inflammatory bowel disease were excluded from study. De-paraffinized tissues were macro-dissected from FFPE sections, RNA isolated and used for NanoString nCounter mRNA gene expression analysis to assess expression levels of up to 800 cancer genes. Statistical analysis was performed using the Gene Expression R-script module within the nCounter software v2.5. A gene was considered to be above background if the average count for the target gene was greater than the average counts for the eight negative control genes and if the P value of the t-test was less than 0.05.

Results:We analyzed EORC and LORC tumors and compared their expression profiles to matched non-involved tissues in order to identify genes that are unique to rectal neoplasm. Out of 770 cancer pathway genes assayed, 275 genes were found to be differentially expressed between EORC and LORC. From all differentially expressed genes found in rectal tumors, the alterations in expression were statistically significant in 82 genes (p<0.05). Seventy seven genes were uniquely expressed in EORC with 57 genes being up- and 20 genes down-regulated with a fold change higher than two.

Conclusion:This study suggests that early-onset rectal cancer might be characterized by distinct molecular events and represents a distinct molecular subtype from late-onset disease. Further studies using larger cohorts of patients might validate these findings and thus offer the possibilities of coming up with novel molecular markers that might enhance newer, faster and noninvasive detection modalities. Additionally, it might help in the advancement for the search of new chemotherapeutic agents that will ultimately improve overall survival of young patients with rectal tumors.

abstract_title: Oligometastatic microRNAs are regulated by DNA methylation.
author_block: G. Oshima<sup>1,2</sup>, S. P. Pitroda<sup>2,3</sup>, C. Zhang<sup>4</sup>, L. Huang<sup>4</sup>, A. Uppal<sup>1</sup>, S. C. Wightman<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Stack<sup>1</sup>, S. Lim<sup>1</sup>, X. Huang<sup>2,3</sup>, T. E. Darga<sup>2,3</sup>, J. Andrade<sup>4</sup>, M. C. Posner<sup>1,3</sup>, N. N. Khodarev<sup>2,3</sup>, R. R. Weichselbaum<sup>2,3</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Radiation And Cellular Oncology,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Chicago,Ludwig Center For Metastasis Research,Chicago, IL, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Chicago,Center For Research Informatics,Chciago, IL, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Chicago,Department Of Surgery,Chciago, IL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Oligometastasis is a clinically distinct patient subset characterized by a limited numbers of metastases, low rates of progression and favorable prognosis after resection or ablative local therapy. Recently we found oligometastatic lesions are associated with the expression of several microRNAs located in a distinct microRNA cluster in chromosome 14 (14q32 locus, see ref. 1). This locus and chromosomal locus 19q13 represent two unique microRNA clusters in the human genome. They both are located in imprinted regions of the genome, where gene activity is regulated by allele-specific DNA methylation. We therefore hypothesized that DNA methylation is implicated in regulation of microRNAs associated with oligometastatic disease and located in methylation-dependent loci 14q32 and 19q13. We suggest that suppression of DNA methylation will reactivate these microRNAs and achieve an oligometastatic state.

Methods: HCT116 cells were stably transfected by luciferase and tdTomato genes for in vivo and ex vivo monitoring of metastases development. Cells were treated by DNA-methyltransferase I (DNMT1) inhibitor 5'-Aza-C (5μM) for 48 hours. Whole-genome differentially methylated CpG loci were assessed with Illumina Infinium HumanMethylation450 BeadChip. For whole-genome expressional profiling of mRNAs and microRNAs we used Illumina HT-12 bead arrays and Affymetrix GeneChip arrays. For ectopic expression of selected microRNAs (miR-127-3p, miR-329-3p, miR-382-5p and miR-432-5p) that were up-regulated after DNMT1 inhibitor treatment in vitro, HCT116 cells were transfected by microRNA mimics with subsequent intrasplenic injection of transfected cells to generate liver metastases. Growths of liver metastases were monitored based on in vivo luminescence with subsequent ex vivo fluorescent imaging as described in (2).

Results: We found that limited demethylation of genomic DNA led to predominant reactivation of 14q32 and 19q13-encoded microRNAs. Using DIANA-microT and miRBase databases of predicted interactions between microRNAs and mRNAs we further found that ~80% of down-regulated genes can be explained by demethylation-dependent reactivation of microRNAs located in these two regions of the human genome. Methylation levels were significantly reduced in 78% of CpG loci in 14q32 after DNMT1 inhibitor treatment. Intrasplenic injection of HCT116 cells, ectopically expressing miR-382-5p led to the 1.5-fold reduction of liver metastases as compared with non-targeting control.

Conclusion: Our findings represent first indication that microRNAs implicated in the development of clinical oligometastases may be regulated epigenetically by differential DNA methylation and target genes involved in metastases development. Our results also suggest therapeutic potential of DNA methylation inhibitors and microRNAs in the treatment of liver metastases.(1) Uppal A, et al. Oncotarget. 28;6(6):3540-52 (2015)(2) Oshima G, et al. Sci Rep. 22;5:10946 (2015)

abstract_title: Overexpression of Cytochrome P450 CYP2 Family in Adrenocortical Carcinoma
author_block: T. D. Murtha<sup>1</sup>, T. C. Brown<sup>1</sup>, F. Haglund<sup>2</sup>, C. C. Juhlin<sup>2</sup>, C. Larsson<sup>2</sup>, J. C. Rubinstein<sup>1</sup>, R. Korah<sup>1</sup>, T. J. Carling<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,Deparment Of Surgery,New Haven, CT, USA <sup>2</sup>Karolinska Institutet,Department Of Oncology-Pathology,Stockholm, , Sweden
abstract_body:
Introduction: Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is a rare endocrine malignancy that portends a poor prognosis. Adjuvant therapies, including mitotane, have demonstrated efficacy, though frequently fail due to drug resistance. Complete R0 resection offers the only hope for a durable cure. In other cancers, cytochrome P450 (CYP) mediated metabolism of anti-cancer agents has been shown to contribute to chemotherapy resistance. Recent comprehensive genetic analyses of ACCs by our group and others have shown recurrent arm-level copy number gains of chromosome 19 that carry a group of CYP genes. The role of these genes in adrenocortical carcinogenesis has yet to be clarified. Demonstrated functions of CYP enzymes in xenobiotic metabolism and biotransformation of carcinogenic compounds prompted us to investigate the potential influence of Chr 19q13 CYP genes in adrenocortical malignancy.

Methods: Using TaqMan real-time qPCR techniques, we investigated the expression patterns of seven CYP genes (CYP2A6, CYP2A7, CYP2A13, CYP2B6, CYP2F1, CYP2S1, & CYP4F2) affected by predicted chromosome 19 copy gains in histologically confirmed ACC (n = 29) and normal adrenal cortex (n = 11). We used TaqMan copy number assays to verify the gene copy numbers in a subset of samples to assess the contribution of gene copy gains in promoting gene expression. Correlations between gene expression patterns and clinical parameters including patient age, gender, tumor size, pathological stage, metastatic status, and hormonal profile were also evaluated. Continuous variables and variables with > 2 dependent values were analyzed with the Mann-Whitney U and Kruskal-Wallis tests, respectively. The Spearman correlation assessed matched continuous variables while categorical variables were analyzed with the Fisher's exact test.

Results: Two chromosome 19q13 CYP genes (CYP2A6 & CYP2A7) showed increased overall expression levels compared to normal adrenal tissue (p < .05). Increased expression of CYP2A6 and CYP2A7 was found in 98% of samples with average expression levels 25 (0.7-115.7) and 38 (1.8-368.1) fold greater than normal adrenal tissue. The remaining five CYP genes evaluated (CYP2A13, CYP2B6, CYP2F1, CYP2S1, & CYP4F2) had unaltered or decreased expression levels compared to normal adrenal cortex. Copy number analysis of selected ACC samples showed copy gains of CYP2A6 in only 27% of specimens and no copy gains in CYP2A7, suggesting alternative mechanisms underlying CYP overexpression. Analysis of patient and tumor characteristics revealed a statistically significant relationship between >10 fold overexpression of CYP2A6 and non-metastatic status (p < .05).

Conclusion: Global increase in expression of CYP2A6 and CYP2A7, possibly independent of gene copy gains, was observed in 98% of ACC samples tested. Whether the selective amplification of these CYP2 enzymes plays a role in the metastatic spread and/or chemoresistance of ACC warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: Splice Variants Of The Long Non-Coding RNA GAS5 In Neuroblastoma
author_block: A. Rosado<sup>1</sup>, J. Mazar<sup>2</sup>, T. Westmoreland<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nemours Children Hospital,Orlando, FL, USA <sup>2</sup>Sanford Burnham Prebys Medical Discovery Institute,Orlando, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Neuroblastoma (NB) is one of the most common extracranial tumors of childhood. With challenging heterogeneity within the tumor subpopulation, prognostic factors for survival include age at diagnosis, tumor grade, tumor site, and MYCN amplification (MA). To this end, we focused on long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) which we demonstrated in the past to have increased expression in pre-treatment NB cells with MA. LncRNA Growth Arrest 5 (GAS5) is a putative tumor suppressor and promoter of apoptosis, which has known splice variants in other systems. Here, we investigate the role of lncRNA GAS5 splice variants in NB.

Methods: MA (pre-treatment) and unamplified (UA) (post-treatment) cell lines were transfected with lncRNA GAS5 siRNA to decrease expression. Conversely, over-expression of lncRNA GAS5 was determined using functional expression cloning techniques. During the cloning process, four lncRNA GAS5 splice variants were identified. Apoptosis and cell viability were measured after 24 hours using Caspase-Glo® 3/7 Assay Systems and CellTiter 96® AQueous One Solution Cell Proliferation Assay (MTS), respectively. Native expression of each variant was determined using real-time reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (qPCR). Knockdown and over-expression efficiency was also determined using qPCR.

Results: In NB cell lines, we have shown increased expression of lncRNA GAS5 in a MA cell line compared to an UA line. Decreased lncRNA GAS5 expression caused a greater reduction in caspase activity in a MA line compared to an UA line. Decreased lncRNA GAS5 expression also resulted in less cell viability in a MA line and relatively no change in an UA line. During the cloning process, we observed various size fragments of lncRNA GAS5 and upon sequencing, at least four splice variants were observed. In the MA lines, GAS5 clone #2 expression was double that of the full length (FL) GAS5 clone. In UA cell lines, the expression of the clone #2 GAS5 variant was two-thirds of the expression of FL GAS5. We over-expressed two of these variants which resulted in differential effects in the cell biology assays. Caspase activity and cell viability in a MA line was more affected by the #2 variant compared to the UA line which was more regulated by the FL lncRNA GAS5 variant.

Conclusion: Knockdown of lncRNA GAS5 in a MA NB cell line resulted in decreased apoptosis and cell viability, while there seemed to be minimal effect of knockdown in an UA cell line. It is known that accumulation of lncRNA GAS5 results in decreased levels of apoptosis-related genes. Therefore, it is possible that knockdown of GAS5 could increase these genes, resulting in the reduced apoptosis in our studies. Furthermore, splice variants of lncRNA GAS5 function differently depending on if the NB cell line is pre-treatment versus post-treatment, which could serve as a treatment marker for more tailored medical therapy for this difficult to treat tumor.

abstract_title: HMGB1 mediates mitochondrial biogenesis in cancer cells to promote tumorigenesis and progression
author_block: S. Tohme<sup>1</sup>, H. Yazdani<sup>1</sup>, Y. Liu<sup>1</sup>, H. Huang<sup>1</sup>, A. Tsung<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg,General Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The mechanisms of hypoxia-induced increased tumor growth remain unclear. High Mobility Group Box (HMGB)-1 protein can be rapidly mobilized from the nucleus to the cytoplasm in response to different cellular stresses, such as hypoxia generated in the center of the tumor tissue. The intracellular HMGB1 has been shown to play an essential role in regulating energy homeostasis. Mitochondrial biogenesis, the genetic program by which new mitochondria are synthesized, is integral in maintaining sufficient numbers of mitochondria to adapt to different cellular stresses. However, a mechanistic understanding of how mitochondrial biogenesis contributes to cell growth and tumorigenesis and the role of HMGB1 in the process remain underexplored.

Methods: A mouse model of diethylnitrosamine (DEN)-induced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) was generated with wild type and HMGB1-liver-specific knockout mice and the development and progression of HCC was assessed. In vitro, the bioenergetics profiles of HCC cancer cell lines (Hep1-6 and Huh7) were examined with or without HMGB1 silencing using siRNA.

Results: We found that genetic blocking of HMGB1 in hepatocytes decreased susceptibility to DEN-induced HCC carcinogenesis and progression, which was indicated by a decrease in number of tumor nodules and volume, The attenuated HCC was associated with a significant decrease in expression of PPARgamma coactivator (PGC)-1alpha and other markers of mitochondrial biogenesis within the hypoxic tumor in HMGB1-liver-KO mice compared to WT mice. In vitro, silencing HMGB-1 in human and murine HCC cancer cells suspended their ability to proliferate, migrate and invade when subjected to hypoxic conditions. In addition, silencing of HMGB1 resulted in a decrease in mitochondrial biomass, decreased expression of respiratory chain enzymes and decreased rates of oxygen consumption when compared to wild type cancer cell lines. This effect was mediated by HMGB1 activation of cytoplasmic Toll-like receptor (TLR)-9 which subsequently phosphorylates PGC1-alpha to increase the transcription of Transcription Factor A Mitochondrial (TFAM) to induce cancer cell mitochondrial biogenesis and survival in the setting of hypoxia.

Conclusion: These results suggest that cancer cell survival and growth in the setting of hypoxia is dependent on a mitochondrial biogenesis pathway in which HMGB1 plays an integral part.
