abstract_title: Absence of NFkB in Tumor Stroma and Infiltrating Immune Cells Impedes Pancreatic Cancer Progression
author_block: K. Majumder<sup>1</sup>, N. Arora<sup>1</sup>, B. Garg<sup>1</sup>, S. Modi<sup>1</sup>, B. Giri<sup>1</sup>, M. K. Singh<sup>1</sup>, S. Ramakrishnan<sup>1</sup>, S. Banerjee<sup>1</sup>, A. Saluja<sup>1</sup>, V. Dudeja<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Minnesota,Surgery,Minneapolis, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: NF?B activation in cancer cells plays a critical role in tumor growth and metastases. However, the role of NF?B activation in the tumor microenvironment, i.e. tumor stroma and immune infiltration, on tumor growth has not been extensively studied. We have evaluated the effect of p50 NF?B subunit deletion in the host and tumor microenvironment on pancreatic tumor progression, using our recently validated Syngeneic Tumor Implantation Model (STIM).

Methods: In the STIM model, tumor pieces from KPC mice (Pdx-Cre KrasG12D/+ p53−/−) are implanted in the pancreas of wild type (WT) or syngeneic gene knock-out mice. We have previously shown that STIM in WT mice has predictable tumor growth, has a robust desmoplastic reaction and intra-tumoral immune infiltration as well as recapitulates the metastatic capabilities of human pancreatic cancer. To specifically evaluate the effect of p50 deletion in the tumor microenvironment (stroma and immune cells) on tumor growth, we implanted KPC tumors (which are p50 replete) in a p50-/- background. The growth rate of KPC tumors implanted in WT mice (STIM-WT) and p50-/- KO mice (STIM-NFKO) was compared and, their stromal (αSMA and collagen) and immune components were studied by IHC and flow cytometry.

Results:Significantly lower tumor volumes and tumor weights were observed in the STIM-NFKO mice as compared to STIM-WT mice [4 wks: 60±34 vs 1101±347 mm3, 8 wks: 269±74 vs 1958±593 mm3; p<0.05]. Moreover at 8 weeks post-implantation, 30% of STIM-WT mice (3/10) had metastatic disease [peritoneal metastases (n=3 mice), liver metastases (n=1 mouse)] whereas none of the STIM-NFKO mice had evidence of systemic metastases. Tumors from the STIM-NFKO mice had significantly decreased stromal collagen [38.1 % of STIM-WT, p<0.05] and αSMA content [normalized to DAPI: 0.07±0.02 vs 0.55±0.05, STIM-NFKO vs STIM-WT, p<0.05]. On flow cytometry analysis, there were no significant differences among the two groups in terms of intra-tumoral immune cell infiltration (CD4+ T cells, CD8+T cells, myeloid-derived suppressor cells/MDSCs and macrophages).

Conclusion:Using a novel mouse model of pancreatic cancer, we have demonstrated that the presence of p50 subunit of NF?B in the tumor microenvironment is necessary for tumor growth. Further evaluation of mechanisms by which NF?B in tumor microenvironment impacts tumor growth can elucidate novel chemotherapeutic targets against pancreatic cancer to halt tumor progression and systemic metastasis.

abstract_title: Recombinant thrombomodulin suppresses tumor growth of pancreatic cancer by inhibition of NF-κB
author_block: Y. Shirai<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Shiba<sup>1</sup>, T. Uwagawa<sup>1</sup>, N. Saito<sup>1,2</sup>, H. Sugano<sup>1,2</sup>, T. Horiuchi<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Iwase<sup>1</sup>, K. Haruki<sup>1</sup>, Y. Fujiwara<sup>1</sup>, K. Furukawa<sup>1</sup>, T. Ohashi<sup>2</sup>, K. Yanaga<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>The Jikei University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Minato-ku, TOKYO, Japan <sup>2</sup>The Jikei University School Of Medicine,Gene Therapy,Minato-ku, TOKYO, Japan
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pancreatic cancer remains difficult to cure, with an overall 5-years survival rate of only 1% to 4%. Recombinant thrombomodulin (rTM) is an investigational drug for DIC, which is an anticoagulant for vascular endothelial cells, and thrombin-thrombomodulin complex has an anti-inflammatory effect by producing active protein C. Furthermore, N-terminal domain of rTM inhibits NF-kB activation. Both inflammation and NF-kB activation play a crucial role in cancer progression. NF-kB has been known to be activated in pancreatic cancer and is associated with poor prognosis. We hypothesized that rTM downregulates NF-kB activation and suppresses tumor growth in pancreatic cancer.

Methods: We established xenograft orthotopic pancreatic cancer in mice by injection of human pancreatic cancer cells (PANC-1). At one week after injection, the animals were treated with i.p. injection of recombinant thrombomodulin 5 times a week or PBS as control for 4 weeks. We compared sequential tumor volume by MRI and conclusive tumor weight and volume. NF-kB activation was evaluated by measuring nuclear localization of p65 protein. To assess adverse effects of rTM, we measured body weight, hemoglobin, and subcutaneous hemorrhagic diathesis.

Results: Tumor growth was significantly suppressed by using rTM (p<0.05). rTM significantly inhibited the expression of IKK β (p<0.05) and pIKBα (p<0.01), and the activation of NF-kB (p<0.001). Furthermore, the expression of both cIAP-1 (p<0.01) and cIAP-2 (p<0.01) was suppressed. Immunohistochemical staining revealed down-regulation of VEGF in rTM group. The body weight was significantly higher in rTM group after 4 weeks of treatment (p<0.05). There were no anemia and hemorrhagic diathesis.

Conclusion: rTM significantly inhibited NF-κB activation and suppressed tumor growth against human pancreatic cancer without obvious adverse effects.

abstract_title: Dectin-1 Signaling Promotes Pancreatic Oncogenesis by Inducing Peritumoral Immune Suppression
author_block: D. Daley<sup>1</sup>, L. Seifert<sup>1</sup>, A. Ochi<sup>1</sup>, N. Akkad<sup>1</sup>, R. Narayanan<sup>1</sup>, S. Chang<sup>1</sup>, S. Jonnadula<sup>1</sup>, R. Barilla<sup>1</sup>, A. Torres-Hernandez<sup>1</sup>, G. Werba<sup>1</sup>, M. Hundeyin<sup>1</sup>, G. Miller<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>New York University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are the most well studied family of pattern recognition receptors (PPRs) and specific TLR signaling has been shown to play a critical role in promoting chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic oncogenesis. C-type Lectin receptors (CLRs), including Dectin-1, are a family of trans-membrane PRRs that are required for recognition of fungal or mycobacterial pathogens. However, while TLR signaling has been implicated in pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDA), the role of Dectin-1 in sterile inflammation, and specifically in the development of PDA, has not been studied. Our work determines the significance of Dectin-1 signaling in pancreatic oncogenesis

Methods: We evaluated the effects of deletion or blockade of dectin-1 signaling in pancreatic cancer on tumor size and survival, peri-tumoral fibro-inflammation, and epithelial transformation. We utilized p48Cre;KrasG12D (KC) mice as our murine PDA oncogenesis model and we crossed KC mice with Dectin-1-/- mice to create a Dectin-1-/- pancreatic cancer mouse model. Components of the dectin-1 signaling pathway and the immune infiltrate within the pancreatic TME were assessed and characterized using immunohistochemistry, flow cytometry and western blotting in human and murine tissue.

Results:The Dectin-1 receptor and endogenous ligands for the receptor are highly expressed in the inflammatory and epithelial compartments in the pancreatic TME in humans and mice. Dectin-1 deletion or signaling blockade significantly delayed the progression of PDA in mice, while dectin-1 ligation accelerated oncogenesis. Dectin-1 signaling results in the infiltration of pro-tumorigenic tumor associated macrophages (TAMs) in the pancreatic TME. Furthermore, Dectin-1 signaling in TAMs directly inhibited the activation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes and induced the differentiation of immune suppressive or regulatory T-cell phenotypes.

Conclusion:In PDA, Dectin-1 receptor ligation induces tumor-permissive inflammatory changes in the pancreatic TME thus contributing to the progression of pancreatic oncogenesis. This implicates the Dectin-1 pathway as a target for the treatment of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

abstract_title: SMAD4 Loss is Associated with Recurrence After Resection of Gastrointestinal Neuroendocrine Tumors
author_block: L. F. Starker<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Roland<sup>1</sup>, K. Yaan<sup>1</sup>, D. Chatterjee<sup>2</sup>, J. Estrella<sup>2</sup>, A. Rashid<sup>2</sup>, J. Lee<sup>1</sup>, J. Yao<sup>2</sup>, M. Katz<sup>1</sup>, T. Aloia<sup>1</sup>, J. Fleming<sup>1</sup>, J. Fleming<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Department Of Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Pathology, And Gastrointestinal Medical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Studies by comparative genomic hybridization have demonstrated that the 18q chromosomal region is frequently lost in gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumors (GI-NET). Mutational analysis of gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumors identified frequent loss of DPC4/SMAD4 expression, a known tumor suppressor gene located on the q21 arm of chromosome 18. However, the impact of SMAD4 loss in the pathogenesis of GI-NET is yet to be elucidated. In this study, we sought to determine the protein expression of SMAD4 in primary GI-NET and the impact on oncologic outcomes.

Methods: After appropriate institutional IRB approval, a retrospective analysis inclusive of tissue expression and clinical oncologic outcomes was preformed. This study included patients who underwent surgical resection for primary locoregional GI-NET, in which tumor tissue and clinical follow-up were available for analysis. Immunohistochemical staining of tumors for SMAD4 expression was independently scored and classified as SMAD4-negative (SMAD4-neg) or SMAD4-positive (SMAD4-pos). Staining results were correlated with clinicopathologic features and oncologic outcomes.

Results: A total of 38 GI-NET tumors were available for examination (30 Small bowel, 8 Large Bowel). Sixteen of the patients were female, 22 were male with a median age of 69 years. Lymph node metastases were common, with 30 patients having lymph node positive disease. Twenty-nine percent of the tumors were SMAD4-neg and 61% SMAD4-pos. No association was observed between SMAD4 and tumor stage. At a median follow-up of 103 months, an overall survival of 155 months was observed. Loss of SMAD4 was associated with a significant difference in disease-free survival and time to recurrence; SMAD4-neg patients experienced a 42 month disease-free survival vs. 185 month (p=0.03; Figure) for SMAD4-pos patients. Importantly, a significantly shorter time to recurrence after surgery was observed in the SMAD-neg patients (28 vs 223 months, p=0.01). A reduction in overall survival, which was not statistically significant was observed (SMAD4-neg: 132 months vs. SMAD4-pos: 184 months; p=0.06).

Conclusion: Consistent with the known biology of the DPC4/SMAD4 gene, the absence of SMAD4 protein expression in the primary gastrointestinal neuorendocrine tumor is negatively associated with cancer-related outcomes after surgical resection.

abstract_title: Targeting Sphingosine-1-phosphate in Obesity-induced Angiogenesis in Breast Cancer Progression
author_block: M. Nagahashi<sup>1</sup>, K. Moro<sup>1</sup>, J. Tsuchida<sup>1</sup>, T. Niwano<sup>1</sup>, K. Tatsuda<sup>1</sup>, C. Toshikawa<sup>1</sup>, M. Hasegawa<sup>1</sup>, Y. Koyama<sup>1</sup>, T. Kobayashi<sup>1</sup>, S. Kosugi<sup>2</sup>, H. Kameyama<sup>1</sup>, A. Yamada<sup>3</sup>, T. Aoyagi<sup>3</sup>, K. Takabe<sup>3</sup>, T. Wakai<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Niigata University Graduate School Of Medical And Dental Sciences,Division Of Digestive And General Surgery,Niigata, NIIGATA, Japan <sup>2</sup>Uonuma Kikan Hospital,Division Of Digestive And General Surgery,Minami-Uonuma, NIIGATA, Japan <sup>3</sup>Virginia Commonwealth University School Of Medicine And The Massey Cancer Center,Surgical Oncology,Richmond, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is well established that obesity evokes chronic inflammation, which aggravates cancer progression by facilitating interactions between cancer cells and stromal cells including blood endothelial cells. We have recently discovered that the SphK1/S1P/S1PR1 axis plays critical roles in inflammation-associated cancer progression, and that the S1PR1 functional antagonist, FTY720, suppresses cancer progression by inhibition of the S1P axis during chronic inflammation. Our hypothesis is that obesity and its related inflammation up-regulate SphK1, which produces more S1P. Elevated levels of S1P in both tumor and its microenvironment stimulate angiogenesis, which results in increased metastasis of breast cancer. Disruption of the S1P axis, which is strengthened by obesity, will reduce cancer metastasis. In this study, we test this hypothesis utilizing two different animal models.

Methods: Orthotopically-implanted E0771 syngeneic breast cancer and MMTV-PyMT transgenic breast cancer mouse models were used. Mice were fed with normal or high-fat diet (HFD). FTY720 was administered orally (1 mg/kg/day). Immunofluorescent staining was performed for primary tumor sections to detect blood endothelial cells and macrophages with antibodies for CD31 and F4/80, respectively. Angiogenesis in the primary tumor was determined by measurement of microvessel density. RT-qPCR and western blot were used.

Results:Orthotopic E0771 cell implantation model allow evaluation of identical tumor burden between the treatments, and MMTV-PyMT model allow evaluation of the effect on spontaneous tumor. In both mouse breast cancer models, HFD induced obesity and it significantly worsened the cancer progression. Obesity elevated inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF-α in both circulation and in the tumor. In the tumor, gene expressions of SphK1 and S1PR1, as well as S1P levels are all elevated. FTY720 dramatically reduced the levels of cytokines as well as SphK1, S1PR1 and S1P in both primary and metastatic sites. Further, FTY720 suppressed not only primary tumor growth, but also angiogenesis in the primary tumor with suppression of aggregation of tumor-associated macrophages.

Conclusion:Our results indicate an important role of S1P in obesity-related angiogenesis in breast cancer progression. We speculate that S1P may become one of the promising targets for breast cancer patients with obesity. This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research Grant Number 15H05676 and 15K15471 for M.N and 15H04927 for W.T. M.N. is supported by the Uehara Memorial Foundation, Nakayama Cancer Research Institute, Takeda Science Foundation, and Tsukada Memorial Foundation.

abstract_title: Tissue and Serum Cytokine Profiles in Sporadic Colon Cancer: Shift from Th-1 to Th-17 Response
author_block: S. Sharp<sup>1</sup>, D. Avram<sup>2</sup>, W. O'Connor<sup>1</sup>, E. Lee<sup>1</sup>, S. Stain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Albany Medical College,Surgery,Albany, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Florida,Gainesville, FL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Inflammation has long been a known major environmental risk factor for colorectal cancer initiation and progression. Little is known about how the immunologic microenvironment changes during tumor progression including metastatic spread. Recently, mouse models of colorectal cancer have shown the Th17 pathway to play an important role in promoting cancer. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the systemic and local cytokine profiles in order to determine if the tumor microenvironment changed during disease progression and if these changes were manifested systemically.

Methods: Serum and tissue cytokine profiles were assayed among patients with documented adenocarcinoma prior to surgical resection at a single institution from September 2014 to February 2015. Using the Bio-Plex Pro TM Human Th17 Cytokine Assay Kit (Bio-Rad Laboratories), the concentrations of interleukin-10 (IL-10), IL-1β, IL-4, IL-6, IL-17A, IL-17F, IL-21, IL-22, IL-23, IL-25, IL-31, IL-33, CD40L, interferon-γ (IFN-γ), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), were determined. Multiple logistic regression analyses were used to evaluate the association between TNM staging and cytokine levels.

Results:A total of 33 patients with documented adenocarcinoma were included. Tumor location was as follows: left-sided 54% (18/33), right-sided 36% (12/33), and transverse colon 9% (3/33). AJCC TNM classification was used, with incidence as follows: stage I-18% (6/33), stage II-27% (9/33), stage III-45% (15/33), and stage IV with metastasis to liver-9% (3/33). Higher tumor stage correlated with elevated levels of the proinflammatory cytokine TNF-a, as well as elevated levels of the T-cell polarizing cytokines IL-4 and IL-10. IFN-g levels were decreased in stage IV samples compared to stage II and III, and IL-17A and IL-17F were elevated, although the latter was not statistically significant. Furthermore, patients with stage IV disease had elevated serum levels of IL-17F, IL-21, and IL-23. These cytokines were undetectable in the serum of patients with non-metastatic disease.

Conclusion:These findings suggest that the Th17 pathway has important implications in human colorectal cancer. Metastatic disease was shown to involve multiple Th17-associated cytokines both in colonic tissue and systemically, as well as a decrease in Th1-associated cytokines. This shift in the tumor microenvironment could establish important treatment targets for colorectal cancer and warrants further investigation.

abstract_title: A Smad4-modulated gene profile is associated with high-risk stage II/III colorectal cancer patients
author_block: J. Smith<sup>1,6</sup>, H. S. Park<sup>1</sup>, S. Chen<sup>3</sup>, B. Zhang<sup>4</sup>, R. Beauchamp<sup>2</sup>, C. Sawyers<sup>5</sup>, J. Garcia-Aguilar<sup>1,6</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Weill Cornell Medical College,New York, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Section Of Surgical Sciences,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Miami,Bioinformatics And Biostatistics,Miami, FL, USA <sup>4</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Biomedical Informatics Department,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>5</sup>Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center,Human Oncology And Pathogenesis Program,New York, NY, USA <sup>6</sup>Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center,Surgical Oncology / Colorectal Service,New York, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States. Identifying stage II/III patients at risk of recurrence and death from metastatic disease has been elusive. Smad4 loss has been associated with worse outcomes but the underlying mechanism is unknown. Our prior work showed that Smad4, the central node in the TGF-β superfamily, suppresses Wnt activity by repressing β-catenin via upregulation of the Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP) arm of the pathway. With the understanding that Smad4 has a direct role in regulating multiple components of the deeply conserved BMP and Wnt pathways, we hypothesized that a Smad4-modulated gene profile would identify high-risk CRC patients.

Methods: Gene ontology and bioinformatics tools were used to generate a combined BMP/Wnt target gene list. Transcriptome analysis was done in two independent datasets on the Affymetrix U133 Plus 2.0 Array platform (discovery set, n=250; validation set, n=566). To develop a Smad4-modulated profile, we correlated the genes in the BMP/Wnt list with Smad4 expression levels. To examine putative Smad4 activity in the profile, we used ExPlain from the Biobase tool to retrieve promoter sequences and determine enrichment of Smad-binding elements (SBEs) for each gene. The Smad4-modulated profile was evaluated by unsupervised hierarchical clustering in the two datasets. Kaplan-Meier analysis was performed to test association with disease-free survival (DFS).

Results: We identified 50 target genes common to BMP and Wnt pathways. Among them, 15 genes were significantly associated with Smad4 expression (Spearman's correlation, p<0.005). Notably, 14 of 15 genes (93%) had palindromic SBEs in their promoter sequences. We examined the Smad4-modulated gene profile in the discovery set and identified distinct patient groups by clustering analysis and noted significant association with DFS. To test this profile, we applied it in the validation set and noted distinct groups by clustering (Figure 1a) as well as significant association with DFS in 461 stage II/III patients (p=0.02, Figure 1b). In addition, the Smad4-modulated gene profile correlated with lymph node status, hindgut/midgut derivation and enrichment of stem cell signaling (p<0.01).

Conclusion: A Smad4-modulated target gene profile identified a subset of high-risk CRC patients. Specifically, the Smad4-modulated gene profile identified stage II/III patients who recurred. The profile demonstrated enrichment of SBEs, and this specific subset of molecular variables could be used in both diagnostic and prognostic settings. Future work will focus on the mechanistic implication of Smad4 perturbation on this profile for tumorigenesis and resistance to therapy.

abstract_title: Transdifferentiation of Prominin-1 Expressing Progenitor Cells Promotes Biliary Fibrosis
author_block: M. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, J. Zagory<sup>1</sup>, W. Dietz<sup>1</sup>, N. Mavila<sup>1</sup>, A. Park<sup>1</sup>, M. Adoumie<sup>1</sup>, P. Trinh<sup>1</sup>, K. Asahina<sup>2</sup>, K. Wang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Southern California,Research Center For ALPD And Cirrhosis, Department Of Pathology,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Biliary atresia (BA), a congenital fibro-obliterative cholangiopathy, is the most common cause of pediatric end-stage liver failure and the leading indication for liver transplant in children. Post-surgical transplant-free survival is impacted mostly by the progression of biliary fibrosis, which is poorly understood. Activated hepatic stellate cells (HSC) and portal fibroblasts (PF) produce collagen during liver injury, but PF activation predominates during cholestatic injury. We previously showed that in BA, ductular reactions (DR) or biliary ductular hyperplasia, are associated with the expansion of collagen-producing epithelial-mesenchymal cells expressing the stem/progenitor cell marker PROMININ-1 (PROM1)(Mavila et al, Hepatology 2014). Hypothesis: PROM1+ cells transdifferentiate into DR cells and activated, collagen-producing portal fibroblasts (PF) to promote biliary fibrosis.

Methods: 6-8 wk old Prom(cre-ert2)-GFP(lsl) were injected intraperitoneally with tamoxifen 10 days prior to injury to induce GREEN FLUORESCENT PROTEIN (GFP) expression to fate map all Prom1-expressing cells at the time of tamoxifen exposure. Cholestatic (Bile duct ligation (BDL)) or hepatotoxic (carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)) injuries were induced. Quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) was performed to evaluate gene expression of Prom1 and activated PF genes (aSma, NTPDase, Elastin) early (<2 wks) and late (>5 wks). Immunofluorescence (IF) was performed to quantify co-expression of GFP with either biliary (CK19) or PF markers. An Affymetrix gene array analysis was performed on FACS-isolated, Collagen-producing hepatic stellate cells (GFP+VitA+) and portal fibroblasts (GFP+VitA-GMP6A-) from Collagen 1a-GFP mice, 3 wks post-BDL.

Results: Prom1 expression (normalized to sham) were higher at 2 wks and 5wks post-BDL, than those of CCl4 (2 wks: 3.10.7 vs 0.60.1, n=6, p<0.05; 5 wks: 9.32.3 vs 1.30.1, n=6, p<0.05). Relative levels of activated PF gene expression increased significantly 5 wks post-BDL (Ntpdase2: 10.62.4, HNF1v: 26.33.3, Elastin: 8.22.5, n=3, p<0.05) and were significantly greater than those of CCl4 (NTPDase: 0.50.2, HNF1v: 1.80.6, Elastin: 3.50.7, n=3, p<0.05). Lineage tracing of PROM1-expressing cells by IF demonstrated rare GFP+ cells in periportal regions of sham livers. At 2 wks post-BDL, GFP+ cell expansion was noted within CK19+ DRs, and at 5 wks, most CK19+ cells were also GFP+, indicating that DR cells derive from PROM1+ cells. Rare periportal GFP+aSMA+ and GFP+NTPDase2+ cells were observed. However, FACS-isolated activated PFs (post-BDL) exhibited 23-fold higher Prom1 expression than non-activated PFs and 12-fold higher Prom1 expression than activated HSC.

Conclusion: The expansion of the PROM1+ cell population is a biliary injury specific phenomenon. PROM1+ cells further transdifferentiate mostly into biliary epithelial cells of DRs and some PF, thus, making them a potential therapeutic target of biliary fibrosis.

abstract_title: Fibrogenic Signaling in Hepatic Stellate Cells is Triggered by Exosomes from Injured Hepatocytes
author_block: L. Chen<sup>1</sup>, R. Chen<sup>1</sup>, D. Brigstock<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital,Pediatric Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Ohio State University,Pediatric Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A key event in chronic liver injury is the activation of hepatic stellate cells (HSC) which causes these normally quiescent cells to become proliferative, to express alpha-smooth muscle actin (αSMA), and to perpetually synthesize fibrogenic mediators such as connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), resulting in unrelentingly deposition of collagen which causes fibrosis and ultimately compromises liver function. The goal of this work was to establish if pathways of HSC fibrogenesis are regulated by hepatocyte-derived exosomes. Exosomes (which arise by inward budding of the limiting membrane of multivesicular bodies (MVB)) are membranous nanovesicles which function as intercellular molecular shuttles for delivering their complex payload (microRNA, mRNA protein) to other cells.

Methods: Exosomes that had been isolated from cultures of primary mouse hepatocytes or AML12 mouse hepatocytes were stained with PKH26 fluorescent dye and incubated with primary mouse HSC for up to 48 hrs after which HSC-associated fluorescence was evaluated. GFP-transfected hepatocytes, treated with or without the exosome inhibitor GW4869, were co-cultured with HSC in which GFP uptake was assessed. mRNA encoding exosome biogenic components was evaluated by RT-PCR in hepatocytes after exposure of the cells to 0-50mM ethanol. Expression of αSMA or CTGF in HSC was evaluated by RT-PCR following their 48-hr treatment with exosomes from control AML12 hepatocytes, or from AML12 cells that had been treated with 50mM ethanol for 48hr, or 30ng/ml TNFα for the last 24hrs or ethanol for 48hrs and TNFα for the last 24hrs.

Results: Expression of nSMase2 (required for biosynthesis of ceramide on which exosome production depends), Rab5b/c (regulates biogenesis of precursors of MVB), and/or Rab27a/c (promotes fusion of exosome-laden MVBs with the plasma membrane) was dose-dependently stimulated in hepatocytes by ethanol. PKH26-stained hepatocyte-derived exosomes were taken up by HSC. GW4869-mediated inhibition of nSMase2 in GFP-transfected AML12 cells caused reduced delivery of exosomal GFP to recipient HSC without affecting donor cell GFP expression. Fibrogenic activity or activation in HSC was not stimulated by exosomes from healthy hepatocytes whereas exosomes from ethanol-sensitized hepatocytes exposed to TNFα stimulated αSMA or CTGF expression, an effect that was more pronounced as compared to the response to exosomes from hepatocytes exposed to each stimulant alone.

Conclusion: Exosomes from hepatocytes are able to bind to HSC with the result that, if the exosomes are from injured hepatocytes, they can stimulate HSC activation and fibrogenesis. These results identify exosomes as molecular shuttles which can transmit pro-fibrogenic molecular cues from injured hepatocytes to HSC. This identifies a novel mechanism of hepatocyte-HSC cross-talk and provides a new lead for developing novel strategies for liver fibrosis therapy.

abstract_title: Human Tissue-Engineered Liver Demonstrates Synthetic and Metabolic Function
author_block: A. Trecartin<sup>1</sup>, N. Mavila<sup>1,2</sup>, R. Spurrier<sup>1,2</sup>, Y. Xiao<sup>1</sup>, M. Wieck<sup>1</sup>, X. Fu<sup>1</sup>, K. Wang<sup>1</sup>, T. Grikscheit<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fulminant hepatic failure and end-stage liver disease continue to claim a high mortality and donor organ availability remains severely limited. Liver transplantation is associated with multiple complications including those resulting from immunosuppression. Consequently, opportunity for drastic improvement in the current standard of care exists and tissue-engineered liver carries potential to meet this need. Our lab has successfully engineered human intestine and therefore we hypothesized that with a similar technique, functional tissue-engineered liver (TELi) would grow from post-natal human liver progenitors. Liver failure often progresses slowly and cryopreservation prior to advanced hepatic fibrosis could provide the patient's own tissue for subsequent liver regeneration. Our lab noted previous success with vitrification for intestine and we hypothesized it would also successfully cryopreserve human liver tissue prior to generation of TELi.

Methods: Human liver tissue was obtained from pediatric surgical specimens and prepared similar to our previously published protocol for generating intestinal organoid units. The majority of the organoid units underwent vitrification and storage in liquid nitrogen according to the published protocol prior to generation of TELi. The liver organoid units were loaded onto biodegradable scaffolds and implanted subcutaneously into NSG mice. Control mice received a sham operation of subcutaneous dissection or polymer implant lacking human liver organoid units. Four weeks later the mice were treated with debrisoquine, primarily metabolized by the human enzyme CYP2D6 into 4-OH-debrisoquine prior to serum harvest. The implants were sectioned for H&E staining. Serum from the mice (n=16) hosting human TELi and sham (n=6) was subjected to ELISA detection of human albumin. The serum of control (n=10) and hTELi (n=16) mice harvested between 1 and 4 hours post-gavage underwent liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry to obtain ratios of parent drug to metabolite.

Results:Both TELi generated after cryopreservation and native liver demonstrated presence of hepatocytes on H&E staining. The human albumin concentration was detectable in the mice hosting human TELi and rose significantly with increasing number of implants per mouse (Figure). The serum harvested at 1 and 2 hours after debrisoquine gavage showed no significant metabolite difference between TELi and sham. However, at 4 hours post-gavage the mice with human TELi had significantly increased levels of the human metabolite 4-OH-debrisoquine compared to sham.

Conclusion:Human TELi derived from post-natal liver tissue is capable of synthesizing albumin in-vivo and the hepatocytes in human TELi appear to possess metabolic function. Also, vitrification of human liver tissue allows generation of human TELi after cryopreservation. Taken together this novel technique demonstrates another step toward making autologous liver regeneration possible for human therapy.

abstract_title: Tissue Engineered Liver Replacement Using Autologous Vascular Beds
author_block: P. Than<sup>1</sup>, C. Davis<sup>1</sup>, M. Findlay<sup>1</sup>, W. Liu<sup>1</sup>, S. Khong<sup>1</sup>, M. Rodrigues<sup>1</sup>, A. Whittam<sup>1</sup>, M. Melcher<sup>1</sup>, G. Gurtner<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Surgery,Stanford, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: While transplantation is often the only available therapy for end-stage organ failure, current strategies are limited by donor organ shortage and the need for life-long immunosuppression. Creating patient-specific replacement organs promises to address these issues. However, traditional approaches to tissue engineering using sell-seeded scaffolds ultimately rely on diffusion and vascular ingrowth from the wound bed, which are insufficient to meet the metabolic demands of hepatic tissue. Synthesizing and integrating a vascular system de novo requires precise orchestration of progenitor cells and regulatory cues that are not currently well understood. Here, we describe a novel approach to fabricate vascularized neo-livers by repurposing expendable microvascular beds (EMBs) found within autologous free flaps. The intact, patterned circulatory beds allow immediate perfusion of the neo-livers after surgical vascular anastomosis.

Methods: Adipose derived stem cells (ASCs) were differentiated into hepatocyte-like cells in vitro. Superficial inferior epigastric (SIE) flaps from male Wistar rats (n=3) were raised and detached at the vascular pedicle. The vascular beds were seeded with adipose derived stem cells (ASCs), hepatocytes, and endothelial cells through intra-vascular perfusion. Following a dwell period to allow cellular egress and engraftment into the perivascular parenchyma, the nascent neo-liver construct was re-implanted with vascular anastomoses to the femoral vessels. Simultaneous partial hepatectomy provided a systemic stimulus for hepatic proliferation within the neo-livers.

Results: ASCs, when co-cultured with hepatocytes, drive spontaneous auto-assembly into functional liver buds. Bioluminescence imaging, confocal microscopy, histology, and immunohistochemistry confirm efficient cell seeding and hepatic tissue formation within the vascularized constructs in vivo. Co-delivery of ASCs and hepatocytes recapitulates the hepatic developmental environment and contributes to improved bulk engraftment and facilitates auto-assembly into hepatic tissue resembling native liver in both form and function. Neo-liver exhibits a sinusoidal appearance similar to native liver. Immunofluorescence demonstrates production of liver-specific proteins including albumin, cytochrome P450, and alpha-1-antitrypsin.

Conclusion: We have developed a strategy for engineering autologous, vascularized hepatic tissue. Repurposing native circulatory beds is a viable platform for integrating an intact circulatory system into engineered tissue. Mesenchymal stem cells provide a renewable source of hepatocytes and also serve in a supportive role, recapitulating key developmental interactions that facilitate auto-assembly into functional liver. This tissue can be implanted in bulk and perfused by standard vascular anastomosis, representing a major leap forward in tissue-engineered organ replacement therapy.

abstract_title: BMPR-IA+ Adipose-Derived Stromal Cells: Promising Candidates for Soft Tissue Reconstruction
author_block: E. R. Zielins<sup>1</sup>, K. J. Paik<sup>1</sup>, A. Luan<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Brett<sup>1</sup>, G. G. Walmsley<sup>1</sup>, K. Senarath-Yapa<sup>1</sup>, C. Blackshear<sup>1</sup>, O. Marecic<sup>1</sup>, J. Flacco<sup>1</sup>, M. T. Longaker<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Wan<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Stanford University,Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Reconstruction of soft tissue defects has traditionally relied on the use of grafts and flaps, both of which undergo relatively unpredictable patterns of resorption over time. This is particularly true in the case of fat grafting, where resorption rates have been reported to vary from 10-90%. In this study, we have investigated the potential of a subpopulation of adipose-derived stromal cells (ASCs) positive for bone morphogenetic protein receptor IA (BMPRIA) for de novo adipogenesis.

Methods: Human lipoaspirate was enzymatically digested in order to obtain stromal vascular fraction (SVF), the cell population containing ASCs. Magnetic-activated cell separation (MACS) was utilized to obtain BMPR-IA+ and BMPR-IA- cells. These cells, along with unsorted cells, were expanded in vitro, and the proliferation ability of each population assessed. Cells from each group were cultured in adipogenic differentiation medium for 7 days. In vitro adipogenic differentiation experiments were repeated in the presence of matrigel. Oil-Red-O staining and quantification was performed for all groups, as was qRT-PCR for adipogenic gene expression. Cells from each group were labeled with a GFP lentivirus and subsequently transplanted into the inguinal fat pads of immunocompromised mice for evaluation of de novo adipogenesis. In order to assess the translatability of these studies, transplant experiments were performed using phosphate buffered saline, collagen gel, and matrigel as cell delivery vehicles.

Results: Proliferation, gene analysis, and histological staining assays were performed, showing differences between BMPR-1A+, BMPR-1A- and unsorted cell populations. Oil-Red-O staining and quantification showed more lipid droplet formation in BMPR-IA+ cells (*p<0.05). BMPR-IA+ cells additionally showed significantly increased expression of FABP4 (*p<0.05), a marker of terminal adipocytic differentiation. In vivo, BMPR-IA+ cells were found to form significantly more adipocytes than both BMPR-IA- and unsorted ASCs (*p<0.05).

Conclusion: BMPR-IA+ ASCs show an enhanced capability for adipogenesis both in vitro and in vivo. This suggests utility for these cells in augmenting soft tissue reconstructive procedures when adipose tissue formation is required, and autologous fat is in limited supply.

abstract_title: Topical Jagged1, a Notch Activator, Results in Increased Wound Closure Rates in Diabetic Mice
author_block: K. E. Leibl<sup>1</sup>, A. Martin<sup>1</sup>, T. W. King<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Plastic Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Decreased rates of wound healing affect millions of diabetic patients annually. We are interested in discovering novel strategies to enhance the wound healing process in diabetic patients. We have previously shown that inhibiting Notch inhibits wound healing. Based upon our previous work, we propose that upregulation of Notch would increase rates of wound healing. JAG1 is a known activator of Notch. Therefore, we hypothesized that applying topical JAG1 to stented excisional wounds on the backs of diabetic and wild-type mice would result in increased Notch activity, and thus an increased wound healing rate as compared to untreated wounds.

Methods: 8-week old, healthy male diabetic mice (db/db, n=44), or heterozygous mice exhibiting wild-type phenotype (WT/db, n=44) were anesthetized & after depilation, two 1cm2 full-thickness wounds were placed on their backs extending through the panniculus carnosus. A 12 mm diameter silicone stent was secured around each wound with cyanoacrylate glue & interrupted 5-0 nylon suture to prevent healing by contraction. Wounds were dressed with sterile N-terface & Tegaderm, then the mice were wrapped with Coban, which was secured with Transpore tape. Dressings were changed every day after topical application onto the open wound bed of JAG1 (10 nM) or vehicle (PBS) for 14 days. Digital photographs were taken at every dressing change. At the end of the experiment, the mice were sacrificed & wounds were harvested for histological and protein analysis. Wounds were analyzed using ImageJ software & expressed as a ratio of wound area to stent area, with scaling normalized to the inner circumference of the splint as a standard. Wound area was calculated as a percent area of the original wound size. Statistical significance was defined as p<0.05 using the students' t-test.

Results:Partial to complete re-epithelialization was seen in the wounded tissues over the experimental period in both the control & JAG1 treated groups. Both diabetic and wild-type mice treated with topical JAG1 had an increased rate of wound closure when compared to wounds treated with PBS. As expected, the control wounds on diabetic mice demonstrated a slower rate of healing than control wounds on wild-type mice. No significant local side effects such as increased edema or allergic reaction were noted in the JAG1-treated mice.

Conclusions:JAG1 increases the rate of re-epithelialization of cutaneous wounds in the in vivo diabetic murine stented wound-healing model, indicating that Notch signaling plays a crucial role in wound healing in mice. Based upon our findings, further study of Notch in diabetic wound healing should be conducted which may then lead to better therapeutics for the wound healing process in patients.

abstract_title: Fibroblast Growth Factor Signal Alters Intestinal Adaptation in Zebrafish Short Bowel Syndrome Model
author_block: K. A. Holoyda<sup>1</sup>, K. A. Schall<sup>1</sup>, C. Lien<sup>2</sup>, T. C. Grikscheit<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles/The Saban Research Institute,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles/The Saban Research Institute,Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Fibroblast growth factor (Fgf) signaling is critical for the development of many organs, including the intestine, through its role in cell proliferation and differentiation of the epithelium. Fgf receptor (Fgfr) expression has been induced during intestinal adaptation following massive bowel resection. The components of this pathway are conserved between humans and zebrafish. The role of Fgf signaling in the adult zebrafish short bowel syndrome (SBS) model is not yet defined. We hypothesized that inhibition of Fgf signaling would impair intestinal adaptation in the zebrafish SBS model.

Methods: With IACUC approval, SBS was generated in adult male hsp70:dnfgfr1-GFP zebrafish. These were compared to sham operation zebrafish that underwent laparotomy alone. Heatshock was performed on sham and SBS zebrafish daily for 2 weeks (HS SBS n=5, HS sham n=4) to reduce fgfr expression. These groups were compared to non-heatshock treated transgenic zebrafish (NHS SBS n=5, NHS sham n=4). Zebrafish weights were obtained at the time of surgery and weekly before sacrifice. Proximal intestine was harvested at 2 weeks. H&E and Alcian blue staining was performed. Immunofluorescence was performed for BrdU and TUNEL. RT-qPCR was performed for fgfr1. Villus epithelial perimeter (VEP) was measured and percentages of BrdU(+), Alcian blue(+) and TUNEL(+) cells per hemivillus were calculated by a blinded, trained observer with ImageJ. Student's T-test was employed to determine significance.

Results: HS zebrafish demonstrated significantly decreased fgfr1 expression compared NHS zebrafish (p<0.05). While SBS zebrafish lost more weight relative to sham operation zebrafish in both groups, HS SBS lost more weight compared to NHS SBS (69.0±3.1% v. 79.2±5.7% preoperative weight, p<0.05). NHS SBS revealed increased VEP compared to NHS sham (627.0±20.1μm v. 519.8±32.4μm, p=0.03). HS SBS VEP was significantly shorter than NHS SBS (385.4±44.5μm v. 627.0±20.1μm, p=0.003). NHS SBS displayed a 2.5-fold increase in BrdU(+) cells per hemivillus compared to NHS sham(p=0.02) and HS SBS displayed a 3.9-fold increase in BrdU(+) cells per hemivillus compared to HS sham (p=0.02). NHS SBS demonstrated a significantly increased percentage of Alcian blue(+) cells per hemivillus compared to NHS sham (18.5±1.4% v. 10.1±1.3%, p=0.04). No difference was demonstrated in HS SBS compared to HS sham (5.7±0.8% v. 3.7±1.0%, p=0.17) and both HS groups demonstrated significantly fewer Alcian blue(+) cells per hemivillus compared to NHS sham(p<0.05). No difference in percentage TUNEL(+) cells per hemivillus was appreciated between NHS sham and NHS SBS (2.8±1.2% v. 3.2±0.2%, p=0.8) or between these groups and HS sham and HS SBS (3.0±0.8% v. 6.6±2.6%, p=0.3).

Conclusion: Inhibition of Fgf signaling abrogated changes associate with intestinal adaptation in a SBS zebrafish model.

abstract_title: Ischemia Reperfusion Injury Stimulates Neurogenesis In The Myenteric Plexus Of The Murine Small Bowel
author_block: N. Gandotra<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Tackett<sup>1</sup>, C. J. Greig<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Cowles<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Yale University School Of Medicine,New Haven, CT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The small intestine has the ability to recover from injury in large part due to the presence of enterocyte precursors that rapidly divide and repopulate the mucosal surface of the bowel. Enteric neurons, in contrast, are considered terminally differentiated and are not felt to have the ability to give rise to new components of the enteric nervous system (ENS) after injury. Since the ENS resides in close proximity to the noxious contents of the intestinal lumen and since the intestine appears to recover from many types of injury, some process for repair of the injured ENS must exist. We hypothesized that moderate intestinal injury via ischemia and reperfusion (I/R) would have effects on the intestinal mucosa and that the ENS would generate new neurons in response to injury.

Methods: In order to identify newly generated enteric neurons, Nestin CreER/EGFP bitrasngenic mice were generated from the two separate transgenic strains. Mice were given a daily intraperitoneal injection of tamoxifen for four consecutive days to induce expression of GFP in nestin-postitive neural progenitor cells and their progeny. Intestinal ischemia was induced by clamping the superior mesenteric artery for 45 minutes followed by release of the clamp and abdominal wall closure. Mice were sacrificed at varying time points after I/R injury. The ileum was harvested, washed with PBS and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde in sucrose or prepared for standard histology. Whole mounts of the myenteric plexus were generated by manually peeling away the overlying layers and these were analyzed by immunofluorescence microscopy. Double immunofluorescence was performed using anti-GFP and anti-Hu antibodies to identify GFP-positive cells and mature neurons respectively. Tiled images of the myenteric plexus were obtained using a confocal microscope. The number of GFP- and Hu-positive cells were counted and the percentage of GFP-positive cells was calculated. The study protocol was approved by the IACUC.

Results:Intestinal I/R caused mucosal injury that appeared to peak at 24 hours post-injury. Mucosal architecture returned to normal between 7 and 14 days after I/R and we therefore chose to study the generation of new enteric neurons at the 7 day time point. At baseline, in either unoperated controls or in mice undergoing a sham laparotomy, the percentage of differentiated (Hu-positive) neurons that appeared to be newly generated (GFP-positive) was small (0.52-0.58%) but not zero. This percentage of newly generated neurons increased 6-fold (to 3%) in mice subjected to 45 minutes of intestinal ischemia.

Conclusion:The ENS has the capacity to replace injured neurons both at baseline and in conditions of stress. Intestinal I/R injury results in changes in the mucosal and ENS layers of the bowel with significantly increased numbers of newly generated neurons in the myenteric plexus. The stimuli responsible for generation of new myenteric neurons remains unknown.

abstract_title: Ex Vivo Enteroid Cultures Can Be Used To Produce Tissue Engineered Intestine
author_block: B. Cromeens<sup>1</sup>, Y. Liu<sup>1</sup>, J. Stathopoulos<sup>1</sup>, G. Besner<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Nationwide Children's Hospital,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a clinical condition with few solutions. Tissue engineered intestine (TEI) is a potential solution to SBS, but many models require amounts of donor intestine often exceeding the amount of remaining intestine an SBS patient can provide, limiting the feasibility of this approach. Advances in intestinal epithelial culture demonstrate that intestinal crypts can produce epithelial surrogates known as enteroids that can be passaged for months and may serve as a viable tissue source for the production of TEI.

Methods: We first established a reproducible enteroid seeding technique for the production of TEI. Crypts were harvested from full lengths of LGR5-EGFP mouse intestine and cultured to produce enteroids. After 11-14 days, enteroids were seeded onto polyglycolic acid (PGA) scaffolds in either Matrigel or cell culture medium, and implanted into the peritoneal cavity of NOD/SCID mice for 4 weeks. Tissue architecture and epithelial components were analyzed using Periodic Acid Schiff (PAS) and immunofluorescence (IF) staining. The total length of neomucosa was quantified using ImageJ software. We next determined whether enteroid cultures could be established from an intestinal biopsy, expanded ex vivo, and used to produce TEI. Six 2 x 2 mm pieces of jejunum were harvested from LGR5-EGFP transgenic mice and processed separately to establish enteroid cultures. Fourteen days later, enteroids were passaged for expansion. Light microscopy was used to quantify enteroids. After 21 days, expanded enteroids were seeded onto PGA scaffolds and implanted into NOD/SCID mice for 4 weeks.

Results: Enteroids seeded in Matrigel produced TEI in 11/11 (100%) scaffolds whereas enteroids seeded in medium produced TEI in only 3/6 (50%) scaffolds. Seeding in Matrigel produced significantly more neomucosa compared to seeding in media (18,966 μm vs. 324 μm; p=0.038). Histologic examination of TEI demonstrated crypt domains and overlying epithelium with blunted villi. The presence of goblet cells, Paneth cells, enterochromaffin cells, and intestinal stem cells in the neomucosa was confirmed by a combination of PAS and immunofluorescent staining of histologic tissue sections. Crypts were successfully obtained from biopsies with an average of 103 ± 24 enteroids produced from each biopsy. A single passage produced an average of 620 ± 90 enteroids, which was enough for scaffold seeding. TEI was produced in 5/6 (83%) scaffolds seeded with enteroids that had been expanded ex vivo.

Conclusion: Enteroids grown ex vivo can be successfully seeded onto scaffolds and implanted in vivo to grow TEI. Moreover, enteroids can be obtained from minimal starting material and expanded to produce TEI. This method shows promise as a potential solution to the limited donor intestine available for TEI production in patients with SBS.

abstract_title: Alterations in Tight Junctions in a CS Model of NEC Give Insight into the Disease's Pathophysiology
author_block: B. P. Blackwood<sup>1,2,3</sup>, C. Yuan<sup>2</sup>, D. Wood<sup>2</sup>, C. J. Hunter<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Ann And Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital Of Chicago,Pediatric Surgery,Chicago, ILLINOIS, USA <sup>2</sup>Northwestern University Feinberg School Of Medicine,Pediatrics,Chicago, ILLINOIS, USA <sup>3</sup>Rush University Medical Center,General Surgery,C, I, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a devastating neonatal gastrointestinal disease. NEC makes up approximately 5% of all neonatal intensive care unit admissions. Despite years of investigation, the pathophysiology remains unknown. Cronobacter sakazakii (CS) is a bacteria that has been implicated in outbreaks of infant NEC. Tight junctions (TJ) are protein complexes in the most apical portion of the intestinal villi. These proteins are important in both intercellular pore formation and maintaining a protective intestinal barrier. We hypothesize that in an experimental model of CS-induced NEC, there are alterations in TJ protein location and expression.

Methods: Rat pups were subjected to hypoxia twice a day and fed either clean formula (control group) or CS formula (NEC group). Gavage fed FITC-dextran was used to assess membrane permeability. H&E slides of intestinal segments were scored by a pathologist blinded to the groups for assessment of disease severity. Intestinal segments were analyzed with immunofluorescence for zona occludens (ZO-1), claudin-2, and claudin-4 proteins. Protein expression was further analyzed using western blot analysis. ANOVA and students T-test were performed for statistical analysis.

Results:H&E slides revealed a significant increase in injury scores in the NEC pups as compared to the controls (p<0.003). FITC-dextran permeability was significantly increased in the NEC pups (p<0.01). Immunofluorescence staining showed internalization of ZO-1, increased expression of claudin-2, and increased localization of claudin-4 to the membrane from the nucleus. Western blot analysis revealed cleavage of ZO-1 as well as reduction in the expression of claudin-2 and claudin-4 in the NEC group.

Conclusion:In conclusion, the CS model of NEC has demonstrated a significant redistribution and change in expression of TJ proteins in the intestinal epithelium. The redistribution of ZO-1 and claudin-4, along with the increase in pore forming claudin-2, may indicate the beginning of intestinal epithelial breakdown in NEC. Further investigation into these TJ proteins could help to clarify the pathophysiology behind NEC.

abstract_title: Slit3 Knockout Mice with CDH Develop RV Remodeling and Altered Pulmonary Arterial Hemodynamics
author_block: M. Shah<sup>1</sup>, M. R. Phillips<sup>1</sup>, M. Quintana<sup>1</sup>, G. Stupp<sup>1</sup>, S. E. McLean<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill,Chapel Hill, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). The Slit3 knockout (KO) mouse model for CDH has PAH, and the PAH evolves over time. We have shown that systolic and right ventricle (RV) mean pressures are similar in wild-type (WT) and KO 2 week old mice, but there is a significant difference in WT and KO mice at 4 weeks, with increased pressures in KO mice. With the use of mouse echocardiograms, we aim to determine the timeline of the development of PAH and RV remodeling in the Slit3 mouse model for CDH.

Methods: Slit3 WT and KO mice were analyzed at 2 weeks (WT n=4, KO n=7), 4 weeks (WT n=5, KO n=4) and 2-3 months (adult) of age (WT n=8, KO n=6). Mice were anesthetized using isoflurane. Echocardiography was performed to analyze RV wall thickness, internal diameter (ID), and function. Color Doppler was used to analyze flow in the PA and across the tricuspid valve. RV pressures were obtained by direct cardiac puncture. The RV of each mouse was harvested. RNA was extracted and purified using RNeasy Mini kits (Qiagen). Real-time quantitative PCR was performed using a probe and primer targeting the mouse Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) gene (Roche).

Results: Echocardiography revealed statistically significant differences between KO and WT mice with an elevation in PA peak velocities at 4 weeks (1015.14mm/s vs. 654.59mm/s (p<0.05)) and in adulthood, decreased pulmonary acceleration times in adulthood (p<0.05), and increased pulmonary vascular resistance at 2 weeks (12.21mm2/s vs. 5.69 mm2/s (p<0.05)) and in adulthood (p<0.05). Several parameters, including RV dilation, PA velocity time indices, and pulmonary vascular resistance, were increased at 4 weeks in the KO mice, but failed to reach statistical significance. Excluding parameters stated above, no significant differences were found at 2 weeks between KO and WT mice. Consistent with RV remodeling, RV-BNP gene expression increased over time in the KO in comparison to WT mice (Fold change KO vs. WT: 2 weeks- 1.32, 4 weeks- 6.18, adult- 8.19).

Conclusion: Slit3 KO mice have echocardiographic changes and increased RV-BNP gene expression consistent with PAH. The progressive changes in the data over the time series is consistent with the increasing severity of PAH that occurs due to pulmonary arterial vascular remodeling, which leads to changes in RV and pulmonary artery morphology and hemodynamic function. Intervention prior to the period of pulmonary vascular and right ventricular remodeling may provide a time window for treating PAH associated with CDH. Further elucidation of the timing of pulmonary vascular remodeling will provide a greater understanding of the evolution of PAH in CDH.

abstract_title: Igf1r Inhibition Requires Luminal Factors to Abrogate Intestinal Adaptation in a Zebrafish SBS Model
author_block: K. A. Schall<sup>1</sup>, K. Holoyda<sup>1</sup>, C. N. Grant<sup>1</sup>, C. Lien<sup>2</sup>, T. C. Grikscheit<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Division Of Cardiothoracic Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In short bowel syndrome (SBS), luminal factors appear to influence adaptation, a process by which the intestine increases villus length, crypt depth, proliferation/apoptosis and number of stem cells leading to increased nutrient absorption, in addition to specific morphogens. We previously demonstrated that Igf1r inhibition with NVP-AEW541 significantly diminished proximal intestinal adaptation in a zebrafish SBS model. We hypothesized that both NVP-AEW541 and absent luminal nutrition in the distal intestine would further impair adaptation.

Methods: With IACUC approval, SBS was created in adult male zebrafish (n=12) by performing proximal stoma and distal intestinal ligation and compared to sham operation zebrafish (n=12). Groups were treated with NVP-AEW541 (SBS-I, sham-I); or DMSO (SBS-C, sham-C), a vehicle control, for 2 weeks. Proximal and distal intestine were analyzed by H&E for cross-sectional surface area and circumference with ImageJ. Significance by Student's t-test.

Results: In the absence of Igf1r inhibition, intestinal adaptation is exhibited in the proximal intestine with luminal flow but not the distal intestine in the absence of luminal flow. The SBS-C proximal intestine had significantly increased SA (15423μm vs 9369μm;p<0.01) and circumference (5213μm vs 3303μm; p<0.01) compared to the Sham-C proximal segment, indicating adaptation, however, the SBS-C distal intestine did not have significantly different SA (4651μm vs 4438μm; p>0.05) or circumference (2029μm vs 1874μm; p>0.05) compared to Sham-C distal intestine in the absence of luminal factors. In the presence of Igf1r inhibition, SBS-I proximal intestine had a significantly decreased SA (10498μm vs 15423μm; p<0.01) and circumference (3694μm vs 5213μm; p<0.01) compared to the SBS-C, however, the SBS-I distal intestine did not have significantly different SA or circumference when compared to the SBS-C, Sham-C and Sham-I with the common variable being absence of luminal factors (SA-4355μm vs 4438μm vs 4438μm vs 5600μm; p>0.05: Circ-1991μm vs 2029μm vs 1874μm vs 2058μm).

Conclusion: Luminal flow in conjunction with SBS, as shown in the proximal intestine, significantly increases intestinal adaptation. Inhibition of Igf1r is not enough to abrogate intestinal adaptation, as shown in the distal intestine, but also requires the presence of luminal flow.

abstract_title: Murine Model of Viral-Induced Hepatic Fibrosis
author_block: I. N. Lobeck<sup>1</sup>, P. Dupree<sup>1</sup>, B. Donnelly<sup>1</sup>, S. Mohanty<sup>1</sup>, A. Walther<sup>1</sup>, M. McNeal<sup>2</sup>, G. Tiao<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Division Of Infectious Disease,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>1</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Division Of Pediatric General And Thoracic Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Biliary atresia (BA) is a devastating neonatal obstructive cholangiopathy that progresses to fibrosis and end-stage liver disease by two years of age. Despite re-establishment of biliary drainage by portoenterostomy, many infants develop fibrosis requiring liver transplant. The mechanisms by which fibrosis occurs remain unknown. In the murine model of BA, Rhesus rotavirus (RRV) infection of newborn pups results in a cholangiopathy paralleling human BA and is used to study mechanistic aspects of the disease. Infected mice however, experience a high mortality by DOL14. The aim of this study was to develop a model of a virus-induced biliary obstruction that allows survival beyond two weeks to determine if fibrosis occurs.

Methods: Rotavirus is a double-stranded RNA virus composed of eleven genes encoding 6 structural proteins (VP1-VP4, VP6 and VP7) and 6 nonstructural proteins (NSP1-NSP6). When two rotavirus strains simultaneously infect a host cell, the resulting progeny contain different combinations of the parental strain's genome and are called reassortants. To better understand the RRV genes involved in the pathogenesis of BA, single and double gene reassortants were created by co-culture of RRV and TUCH (T), a simian rotavirus strain that does not cause the model. In the progeny, TR2 and TR4 are composed of ten genes from the TUCH parent with the VP2 or VP4 gene respectively, from RRV. TR2,4 contains both VP2 and VP4 RRV genes with the remaining nine genes from the TUCH parent. The VP4 gene was utilized due to its vital role in cholangiocyte tropism. TR2,4 was used due to its ability to replicate at a lower titer than RRV.We have previously shown 80% mortality by DOL14 with RRV injected on DOL0-3. Thus, in our new model, newborn pups underwent intraperitoneal inoculation of the viruses on DOL4 in an effort to improve survival. Mice were monitored for biliary obstructive symptomatology. At DOL28, bile ducts and livers were harvested and evaluated by an independent pathologist using the Ishak fibrosis scoring system. Analysis was performed using the Chi-square test.

Results: Mice were inoculated with RRV (n=100), TR2 (n=50), TR4 (n=65) or TR2, 4 (n=100). TR2 resulted in minimal symptomatology (14% on DOL11) and no mortality. Ninety-four percent of TR4 mice exhibited obstructive symptoms on DOL11, with minimal mortality (6% by DOL28). RRV and TR2,4 displayed similar symptom presentation (96% and 99%, respectively, on DOL11) and no significant difference in morbidity (42% versus 38% by DOL28). Upon histologic analysis, no TR2 mice were found to have fibrosis. Twenty-two percent of TR4 and 40% of RRV mice exhibited Ishak grade 3-5 fibrosis. A significantly greater amount of fibrosis was seen in TR2,4 mice (63%).

Conclusion: The novel virus strain, TR2,4, can induce fibrosis by DOL28 to a significantly higher level than RRV without increase in mortality. This is the first murine viral-induced fibrosis model in a neonate.

abstract_title: Activation of pDCs by Rhesus Rotavirus VP4: Evidence of Innate Immune Response in Biliary Atresia
author_block: P. D. Dupree<sup>1</sup>, I. Lobeck<sup>1</sup>, B. Donnelly<sup>1</sup>, A. Walther<sup>1</sup>, M. McNeal<sup>2</sup>, E. Janssen<sup>3</sup>, S. Mohanty<sup>1</sup>, G. Tiao<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Infectious Disease,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Immunobiology,Cincinnati, OH, USA <sup>1</sup>Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center,Pediatric Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Biliary atresia (BA) is a progressive obstructive cholangiopathy of infancy which leads to cirrhosis, end stage liver disease, and often times require liver transplantation. The etiology of BA still remains unclear but a current hypothesis suggests a perinatal viral infection triggers the host's inflammatory immune response. Previously we identified the VP4 gene on Rhesus Rotavirus (RRV) as the major determinant for the induction of the murine model of BA. Using a non-pathogenic strain, Ro1845, we generated a reassortant (Ro1845 R(VP4)) with 10 genes from the parent strain and one gene, VP4, from RRV. We demonstrated that Ro1845 R(VP4) is able to infect and replicate in cholangiocytes similar to that of RRV, as well as induce the BA model. Using Ro1845 R(VP4) we also showed that RRV's VP4 plays a role in NK cell activation. A previous study found that plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) activate NK cells in the murine model of BA. We hypothesized that RRV's VP4 plays an important role in activation of pDCs which subsequently activate the NK cells.

Methods: BALB/c mice were injected within the first 24 hours of life with saline, RRV, Ro1845, or Ro1845 R(VP4). Livers and bile ducts were harvested on post-infection (PI) day 7 or 10. Miltenyi column purification kits were used to isolate pDCs, CD8+ cells, and NK cells from the harvested livers. Viral titers and flow cytometry were performed on the immune cell populations. In order to isolate a larger quantity of pDCs, adult BALB/c mice were injected with B16 Flt-3 ligand, which causes expansion of the dendritic cell population. Naive pDCs were isolated from B16 Flt-3 ligand injected mice and used for RRV infection.

Results: The purified NK cells and CD8+ cells harvested from the livers on PI day 7 were found to have all three viral strains present. However, virus was only detected in the pDCs isolated from RRV and Ro1845 R(VP4) infected mice (1.6±0.1 x 103, 2.4±1.0 x 103 respectively) but not in Ro1845 infected mice. At day 10 PI, virus persisted in both the NK cells, and pDCs, of RRV and Ro1845 R(VP4) infected mice but was not detectable in Ro1845 infected immune cells. Flow cytometry demonstrated a significant increase in the activation of pDCs isolated from RRV (39.9%) and Ro1845 R(VP4) ( 42.4%) infected mice compared to Ro1845 infected mice (27.8%, p<0.05). Viral titers measured in naïve pDCs infected with RRV in-vitro demonstrated the evidence of virus replication in pDCs (9.3±1.8 x 105).

Conclusion: RRV VP4 plays an important role in the activation of pDCs and NK cells. Measurement of viral yield demonstrated that non-disease inducing strains (Ro1845) were capable of infecting CD8+ and NK cells but only those strains expressing the RRV VP4 have the potential to infect the pDCs. These findings further define the pathogenesis of biliary atresia and may have implications for future therapies to block the progression of the disease.

abstract_title: PROMININ-1 promotes biliary fibrosis associated with biliary atresia
author_block: J. A. Zagory<sup>1</sup>, M. V. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, W. Dietz<sup>1</sup>, P. Trinh<sup>1</sup>, M. Adoumie<sup>1</sup>, N. Mavila<sup>2</sup>, L. Wang<sup>1</sup>, D. Nguyen<sup>1</sup>, K. Wang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center,Gastroenterology,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>1</sup>Children's Hospital Los Angeles,Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Biliary atresia (BA), a congenital fibro-obliterative cholangiopathy, is the most common cause of pediatric end-stage liver failure and the leading indication for liver transplant in children. Post-surgical transplant-free survival is impacted mostly by the progression of biliary fibrosis, which is poorly understood. We recently demonstrated the expansion of collagen-producing cells expressing the stem cell marker PROMININ-1 (PROM1) within regions of evolving biliary fibrosis in both human and the murine model of BA induced by Rhesus rotavirus (RRV)(Mavila et al, Hepatology 2014). Thus, we hypothesized that PROM1 functionally promotes the biliary fibrosis seen in BA.

Methods: Prom1-cre transgenic BALB/c mice, in which a Cre recombinase transgene was knocked in to the Prominin-1 gene locus, were bred. Thus, Prom1-cre+/+ = Prom1 knockouts (KO), Prom1-cre-/- = Prom1 wildtype (WT), and Prom1-cre+/- = Prom1 heterozygous (HET). Newborn pups were inoculated intraperitoneally (1.5x106 colony forming units RRV or saline) within the 1st day of life to induce experimental BA (jaundice, acholic stool, obliterated extrahepatic bile ducts). 2 wks later, serum and liver were analyzed for bilirubin level, gene expression (qPCR, immunofluorescence) and collagen staining. Unpaired t-test and ANOVA were used for statistical analyses where appropriate.

Results:A robust increase in PROM1+ periportal cells within developing biliary fibrosis after RRV treatment was observed in Prom1 WT and HET mice by immunofluorescence. No PROM1+ cells were observed in KO mice. qPCR showed significantly less Prom1 expression in KO and HET livers compared to WT (0.13±0.1 vs 1.1±0.9 vs 21.6±2.4, p<0.0001). KO livers exhibited significantly less expression of the mesenchymal gene Vimentin (0.31±0.1 vs 1.0±0.2, p=0.03) and a trend toward less expression of the biliary gene Ck19 (0.48±0.2 vs 0.94±0.2, p=0.12) compared to WT/HET, consistent with decreased biliary fibrogenesis. In terms of fibrosis, RRV-treated Prom1 WT and HET mice exhibited significantly greater collagen deposition by Sirius red staining compared to their respective saline controls (WT: 5.2±0.03 vs 2.2±0.1 Collagen Proportionate Area [CPA], n=9, p=0.0002; HET: 5.1±0.3 vs 2.9±0.8 CPA, n=10, p=0.02). No difference was observed between RRV-treated KO vs control (3.6±0.2 vs 3.5±0.1 CPA, respectively n=11, p=NS). Most notably, WT and HET displayed significantly greater fibrosis than KO (p<0.0001). Moreover, serum bilirubin levels were markedly elevated in WT/HET but not in KO (20.2±5mg/dL vs 0.85±3, n=18, p=0.01).

Conclusion:Absence of Prom1 expression and, therefore, the abrogation of the expansion of the PROM1+ cell population associated with biliary atresia leads to decreased RRV-induced biliary fibrosis and jaundice, indicating a significant role of Prom1 in the pathogenesis of BA-associated fibrosis.

abstract_title: Accelerated Hepatic Steatosis is Induced by Small Bowel Resection and Prevented by Oral Vancomycin.
author_block: L. K. Barron<sup>1,2</sup>, C. R. Erwin<sup>2</sup>, C. P. Gayer<sup>3,4</sup>, B. W. Warner<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>3</sup>Keck School Of Medicine,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Southern California,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>1</sup>Washington University In St. Louis,Department Of Surgery,St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>2</sup>Saint Louis Children's Hospital,Division Of Pediatric Surgery,St. Louis, MO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intestinal failure- associated liver disease (IFALD) is a major cause of mortality in patients with short bowel syndrome and the leading indication for intestinal transplant. Hepatic steatosis is a major component of IFALD and has been shown to persist in patients even after weaning off TPN. The purpose of this study was to determine whether hepatic steatosis occurs in our murine model of massive small bowel resection (SBR). We next sought to determine whether the observed accelerated hepatic steatosis after SBR was affected by manipulation of the intestinal microbiome.

Methods: Male C57/Bl6 mice (n=4 per group) underwent 50% proximal (SBR) and followed by orogastric gavage with Vancomycin (2mg/kg) or vehicle every 3 days. Food consumption was measured daily for 1 month. Body composition was recorded by magnetic resonance weekly. The animals were sacrificed at 10 weeks. Liver sections were stained with H&E and analyzed using NIS Elements V4.3 software to obtain the percent lipid content using 4 random fields at 4x magnification per sample. Fecal samples were collected prior to resection and at 3 weeks post resection then processed with a QIAGEN stool DNA isolation kit. Sample quality was confirmed with an Agilent Bioanalyzer chip. Amplicons were generated for all 9 ribosomal hyper-variable regions of bacterial 16s rRNA and sequence analysis done using QIME, UCLUST, the Ribosomal Database Project and the GreenGene database. Operational taxonomic units consisting of more than 1% of the total reads was considered a relevant microbial constituent.

Results: Compared with unoperated mice, SBR was associated with a marked (greater than 50-fold) increase in hepatic steatosis compared to non-operated mice (6.28% vs. 0.12%, p<0.05). Oral vancomycin resulted in a 15-fold reduction in hepatic lipid content (6.26% vs. 0.4%, p<0.05) after SBR (Figure 1). There was no difference in total body composition, weight, or food consumption. SBR resulted in significant changes in 4 major constituents of the gut microbiome. Oral vancomycin resulted in further significant changes with the major driver being a 55% increase in a member of the Escherichia/Shigella genera.

Conclusion: We have shown for the first time that massive SBR is associated with the development of hepatic steatosis in our murine model, a phenotype that is prevented by oral vancomycin. These findings implicate a critical role for resection-associated gut bacteria in the pathogenesis of IFALD and illuminate a novel surgical model for future investigation into this important morbidity.

abstract_title: TPN Derived Bacteria Induces Epithelial Changes in a Human Intestinal Organoid Model
author_block: M. Barrett<sup>4</sup>, D. Hill<sup>8</sup>, M. Koenigsknect<sup>10</sup>, F. Demehri<sup>4</sup>, V. Krishnan<sup>9</sup>, Y. Feng<sup>2</sup>, J. Spence<sup>8</sup>, V. Young<sup>5</sup>, D. Teitelbaum<sup>2</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Pediatric Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>4</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of General Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Microbiology And Immunology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>7</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Gastroenterology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>8</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Cell And Developmental Biology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of Michigan,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>10</sup>University Of Michigan,Division Of Infectious Disease,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is lifesaving; however, complications associated with it are vast. These include a loss of epithelial barrier function (EBF) allowing for translocation of enteric bacteria outside of bowel lumen, resulting in infectious complications. We have demonstrated this in a mouse TPN model. As studies in human tissue are less defined, we took the novel approach of examining the interaction of dominant bacterial strains from TPN mice in human intestinal organoids (HIO). HIOs are generated through directed differentiation of human pluripotent stem cells; the result is a 3-D differentiated human intestinal tissue capable of modeling the pathogenesis of enteric disease. We hypothesized TPN derived bacteria microinjection in HIOs would result in similar translocation patterns to that seen in our mouse model.

Methods: WT C57/BI6 mice were randomized to standard Chow or TPN. Mice were euthanized after 7-days and samples of effluent, bowel mucosa, liver and spleen were harvested in sterile conditions. We then isolated bacterial strains from TPN mice, microinjected them into the HIO lumen, and co-cultured for 48h.

Results: We examined strains of bacteria which translocated—this was only seen in TPN mice. They were: E. faecalis (103 CFU/g liver; 106 CFU/g spleen) and E. faecium (106 CFU/g liver; 104 CFU/g spleen); commensal Firmicutes implicated in TPN-associated sepsis. HIOs were assessed for evidence of morphologic changes, bacterial translocation and bacterial luminal growth . Bacterial isolates derived from TPN mice (vs. sterile media) led to a dramatic change in mucosal maturation, including increase in thickness (2.4-3.4x increased, Fig 1), as well as development of crypts and villi. Isolates varied in their ability to persist within the HIO lumen. Klebsiella variicola and Enterobacter asburiae failed to persist over a 48h co-culture, while viable Enterococcus faecalis was cultured from the HIO lumen. Both K. variicola and E. asburiae translocated across the HIO epithelial barrier and were detected in the external culture media while E. faecalis was not found externally. Mucous production was studied via Alcian blue staining. K. variicola and E. asburiae, the isolates which translocated, led to increased mucous production within the organoid.

Conclusions: In a mouse model, TPN led to bacterial translocation. Translocation of bacteria across the HIO did not fully correlate with the TPN model yet it was associated with altered mucus expression, suggesting that microbial mucus induction may play a key role in modulating translocation across the epithelial barrier.

abstract_title: Improved Survival Following Induction of Sepsis by Cecal Slurry in PD-1 Knockout Murine Neonates
author_block: W. A. Young<sup>1</sup>, E. A. Fallon<sup>1</sup>, C. P. Erickson<sup>1</sup>, C. S. Muratore<sup>1</sup>, W. G. Cioffi<sup>1</sup>, D. S. Heffernan<sup>1</sup>, A. Ayala<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brown University School Of Medicine,Division Of Surgical Research,Providence, RI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sepsis and specifically neonatal sepsis, remains a major contributor to morbidity and mortality. Modeling neonatal sepsis remains a challenge. A recently described murine model of cecal slurry has offered exciting promise in mimicking neonatal sepsis. Further, with respect to sepsis induced immune pathways alterations, our laboratory has noted a key role for a family of co-inhibitory molecules in adult septic mice and ICU patients, which may be a target for development of novel therapies. We examine the role of one co-inhibitory molecule, programmed death receptor-1 (PD-1) in an evolving model of neonatal sepsis.

Methods: Our cecal slurry model consists of harvesting the cecal contents of an adult wild type (Wt) mouse and combining it with 5% dextrose to create a slurry with a concentration of 80mg/ml (LD70 at 7 days). Neonatal mice (5-7 days of age) from both C57BL/6 Wild type and PD-1 knockout underwent intraperitoneal injection (IP) of the cecal slurry (CS) versus IP of 0.9% saline for sham procedure (Sh). Western blot and immunohistochemistry were performed to assess for differential expression of PD-1. Cytometric bead array was utilized to identify changes in circulating cytokine expression. H&E was used for tissue morphology of liver, lung and cardiac tissue. Survival studies following CS and Sh in Wt and PD-1 knockout were performed and analyzed by the Kaplan-Meier method.

Results: Presence of intra-abdominal sepsis was confirmed by bacterial count of peritoneal lavage (PL) at 24 hours. PL of CS mice had 7.89 x 105 CFU/microliter vs 0 CFU/microliter in the Sh pups (p<0.05). Histologic assessment of organ specimens demonstrated alterations in tissue architecture and cell response most notable in lung, liver and thymus. Liver and thymus specimens of Wt CS mice showed apoptosis that was not present in the Wt Sh group. However, PD-1 knockout mice undergoing CS demonstrated decreased apoptosis compared to Wt. Septal thickening was present in lung specimen of Wt CS pups, which was again attenuated in CS PD-1 knockout mice. Wt CS mice had significantly decreased survival when compared to Sh, however, PD-1 mice undergoing CS had improved survival when compared to their Wt counterparts.

Conclusion: We demonstrate with a novel model of neonatal sepsis, that the checkpoint protein, PD-1, plays an important role in the development in morbidity and mortality following sepsis. Given that these molecules are altered in the neonatal and adult murine models of sepsis and are elevated in critically ill septic patients, this implies that PD-1 may be a promising potential target for improving outcomes in sepsis.

abstract_title: Deficiency in MFG-E8 Decreases Survival in Neonatal Sepsis by Exacerbating Intestinal Injury
author_block: L. W. Hansen<sup>1,2</sup>, W. Yang<sup>1,2</sup>, A. Khader<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Prince<sup>1,2</sup>, J. M. Nicastro<sup>1</sup>, G. F. Coppa<sup>1</sup>, P.
