author_block: A. Chandrasekaran<sup>3</sup>, R. S. Chamberlain<sup>1,2,3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Saint Barnabas Medical Center,Surgery,Livingston, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>New Jersey Medical School,Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA <sup>3</sup>Saint George's University,Grenada, Grenada, Grenada
abstract_body:
Introduction: Postoperative bowel atony impedes recovery following abdominal surgery. Alvimopan is a competitive, selective µ-opioid receptor antagonist that has been extensively studied (with variable reported rates of efficacy) in regards to its ability to aid GI tract recovery in abdominal surgery patients. This meta-analysis critically examines the clinical and financial impact of impact of alvimopan on GI recovery.

Methods: A comprehensive literature search of PubMed, Google Scholar, and the Cochrane Central Registry of Controlled Trials (1966-2015) was completed. Search terms were, ‘alvimopan', ‘entereg', ‘ADL 8-2698', ‘Surgery', and ‘randomized controlled trial'. Outcomes analyzed were time to tolerance of solid food and first bowel movement, time to hospital discharge order written, and opioid use.

Results:Seven RCTs involving 2,955 abdominal and pelvic surgery patients receiving alvimopan 12mg versus placebo were included in this analysis. 1,644 patients received alvimopan 12mg and 1,311 received placebo two hours before the start of surgery and twice daily for seven days or until hospital discharge. 2,558 patients underwent bowel resection, 700 patients underwent total abdominal hysterectomy, 159 underwent radical hysterectomy, and 227 underwent radical cystectomy. Alvimopan 12mg was associated with a statistically significant reduction in mean time to tolerance of solid food and first bowel movement (SDM -0.326; 95% CI -0.411 to -0.240, p<0.001) as well as mean time to discharge order (SDM -0.215; 95% CI -0.301 to -0.130, p<0.001). No significant reduction in postoperative opioid use was identified in the included studies.

Conclusion:Alvimopan significantly aids post-operative recovery after abdominal and pelvic surgery as measured by a significant decrease in return to GI function and time to hospital discharge order. No difference in opioid requirement is attributable to alvimopan use. Alvimopan should be considered an effective adjunctive aid to bowel recovery for patients undergoing abdominal or pelvic surgery. Alvimopan use in other types of surgery requires additional investigation.

abstract_title: Hospital and Payer Costs Associated with Surgical Complications
author_block: M. A. Healy<sup>1</sup>, A. Mullard<sup>1</sup>, D. A. Campbell<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Center For Healthcare Outcomes & Policy, Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The increased costs of surgical complications have been borne mostly by third party payers. However, numerous policy changes aimed at incentivizing high quality care are aimed at shifting more of this burden to providers. To better understand the impact of these policies, we sought to evaluate the costs associated with surgical quality and the relative burden on hospitals and payers.

Methods: We merged complication data from the Michigan Surgical Quality Collaborative (MSQC) to internal accounting data available at the University of Michigan hospitals, and examined 5,121 episodes of surgical care during a period between January 2, 2008 and April 16, 2015 for 24 surgical procedure groups (17 general surgical, 6 vascular, and 1 gynecologic). We used log-transformation with multiple linear regression to model risk-adjusted costs for episodes of care, accounting for patient factors and case-mix. We compared adjusted hospital costs, third party reimbursement (i.e., payer costs) and hospital profit margin for cases with and without complications.

Results: The overall complication rate was 26% for all procedures (25% for general surgery, 33% for vascular, and 23% for gynecologic). For all studied procedures combined, mean hospital costs were $16,079 higher for patients with complications ($31,091) compared to those without complications ($15,012). Likewise, mean third party reimbursement was $15,118 higher for patients with complications ($31,137) compared to those without complications ($16,019). Consequently, overall profit margin decreased by 6.9%, from 8.1% for patients without complications to 1.2% for patients with complications.

Conclusion: Hospitals and third party payers experience increased costs with surgical complications, with hospitals experiencing a reduction in profit margin. Both hospitals and payers appear to currently have financial incentives to promote surgical quality improvement.

abstract_title: Nutrition Counseling and Supplementation Following Orthopedic Trauma: a Randomized-Controlled Trial
author_block: B. Parent<sup>1</sup>, B. Hamilton<sup>2</sup>, B. Henley<sup>2</sup>, G. O'Keefe<sup>1</sup>, J. Agel<sup>2</sup>, A. Garman<sup>3</sup>, R. Firoozabadi<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Washington,General Surgery,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Washington,Orthopedic Surgery,Seattle, WA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Washington,Nutrition,Seattle, WA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Malnutrition is associated with poor outcomes in surgical patients, including wound infections, longer length of stay, and increased mortality. Targeted nutrition interventions have well-established benefits in critical-care and general surgery trauma populations, but have not been studied in a large cohort of orthopedic trauma patients. The aim of this study was to evaluate a targeted daily nutrition intervention in this population, and to measure its impact on biochemical indices of nutrition and clinical outcomes.

Methods: Adult patients (age 18-65 years-old) admitted to the orthopedic surgery service with extremity fractures were included in this trial. Patients were excluded if they had multi-system injury which required admission to another surgical service. Upon admission, subjects were randomized to receive either: a) daily nutrition counseling from a dietitian with supplementation of antioxidants, micronutrients, and protein or b) standard-of-care. Serum levels of albumin, pre-albumin, C-reactive protein, and transferrin were obtained on days 1,3,7 and at 2 weeks. The number of missed meals, daily protein and calorie intake, length of hospital stay, and the incidence of wound infections were also recorded. A student's t-test, Pearson's chi-square test, and multiple linear regression were used to ascertain statistical significance.

Results:80 subjects were enrolled (40 in each arm). The cohort was 46% female, with a median age of 47. 72% had fractures of the femur, tibia or ankle, and 15% had fractures of the humerus or forearm. Over the first week, intervention and control arms showed no differences in the median number of missed meals [6 (3.5-8) versus 4.5 (2.5-8.5), p=0.31], grams of protein intake [240 (165-401) versus 289 (149-378), p=0.91], or calorie intake [6035 (4592-9081) versus 7234 (4321-9832), p=0.64]. Intervention and control arms did not differ in any of the measured biochemical indices of nutrition (Table 1). A subgroup analysis comparing patients in the upper quartile of calorie and protein intake to those in the lower quartile also revealed no differences in nutrition labs. There were fewer wound infections (0 versus 4, p=0.04) in the intervention arm.

Conclusion:During the first week of admission, daily nutrition counseling does not appear to impact calorie, protein or meal intake in orthopedic trauma patients. Moreover, traditional biochemical indices for nutrition status do not correlate well with levels of intake. These data may indicate that current metrics for evaluation of nutrition status and intake are not clinically relevant in this population. This highlights a need for alternative diagnostic tools and novel therapeutic targets in nutrition science.

abstract_title: Complications, Not Surgical Technique, Are Associated With Increased Cost After Esophagectomy
author_block: S. J. Fu<sup>2</sup>, C. W. Towe<sup>1,2</sup>, V. P. Ho<sup>2,3</sup>, Y. Perry<sup>1,2</sup>, C. P. Delaney<sup>2,3</sup>, P. A. Linden<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Hospitals Case Medical Center,Division Of Thoracic And Esophageal Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>2</sup>Case Western Reserve University School Of Medicine,Cleveland, OH, USA <sup>3</sup>University Hospitals Case Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Cleveland, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although clinical outcomes of minimally invasive approaches to esophagectomy have been widely studied, there remains little information on the economic impact of minimally invasive esophagectomy (MIE) on overall hospital costs. Previous studies of surgery costs have suggested that minimally invasive approaches are associated with shorter length of stay and fewer complications but higher intraoperative costs. We aimed to examine if esophagectomy surgery technique affected costs.

Methods: A retrospective review was performed for consecutive patients who underwent esophagectomy between January 2012 and December 2014 at a single academic medical center. Hospital cost data, pre-, intra-, and postoperative variables were collected. Esophagectomy techniques were grouped into open (thoracotomy and laparotomy), hybrid (either video-assisted thoracic surgery (VATS) or laparoscopy for one part of the surgery), minimally invasive (both VATS and laparoscopy), and transhiatal (THE).Univariate and adjusted multivariable analyses were performed to assess the impact of surgery type on total hospital cost associated with esophagectomy. Data presented as median (IQR); costs presented in thousands of dollars.

Results: Of the 80 patients identified, there were 11 THE, 11 open, 41 hybrid, and 17 MIE cases. Median total cost of the hospitalization was $31.4 ($26.5-$48.5), and was similar between surgical technique groups. MIE was associated with significantly higher intraoperative costs and trended towards lower ICU costs (Table). Multivariable analysis revealed the presence of a complication, increased age, American Society of Anesthesiologists class IV (ASA4), and preoperative coronary artery disease (CAD) were associated with significantly increased cost. Presence of a complication accounted for an adjusted increase of $17.4 in total cost, while ASA4 was associated with an adjusted increased total cost of $47.2. Preoperative diagnosis of hypertension was associated with cost savings of $21.2 in the overall regression model.

Conclusion: MIE is associated with higher operation costs. Despite this, the total hospital cost was not different between surgical technique groups. Postoperative complications and severe preoperative comorbidities are significant drivers of hospital cost associated with esophagectomy. Surgeons should choose technique based on clinical factors and minimization of postoperative complications, rather than for cost implications.

abstract_title: Higher Pain Scores and Less Sleep Trigger Delirium in Post-Operative Intensive Care Unit Patients
author_block: D. Overbey<sup>1,2</sup>, C. Raeburn<sup>1,2</sup>, T. Jones<sup>1,2</sup>, T. Robinson<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Colorado,Department Of Surgery,Aurora, CO, USA <sup>2</sup>VA Eastern Colorado Health Care System,Department Of Surgery,Denver, CO, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hospital-acquired delirium is a common complication with direct effects on morbidity and mortality. Prior studies have implicated better pain control and sleep enhancement to have a positive impact on delirium prevention, but pain scores have yet to be proven in a goal-directed fashion as a delirium prevention measure.

Methods: A randomized therapeutic delirium prevention drug trial was performed at the Denver Veterans Affairs Medical Center involving patients aged 60 and older undergoing major elective operations requiring a postoperative intensive care admission (n=325). A pooled analysis of this data was performed to examine risk factors for development of delirium. Each delirium event was defined by the onset of new delirium (n=151 events), and that individual patient-day was evaluated for triggering events compared to delirium free days (n=1,093). Univariate and logistic regression analyses were performed to analyze which factors were independently predictive of triggering delirium.

Results: Pain score on the triggering days of delirium averaged 3.7/10 for the first episode per patient, and 3.5/10 on all triggering days, compared with 2.9/10 for days without delirium (p<0.05). Sleep-hours were also significantly less leading up to the delirium trigger days (4.1 hours versus 4.9 hours, p<0.001). Univariate analysis with all variables revealed age, sodium, and creatinine to also be statistically significant but without clinically modifiable impact. Regression modeling showed both ungrouped pain score (OR 0.919, 95% CI 0.851-0.992) and sleep-hours (OR 1.202, 95% CI 1.096-1.319) to be independently significant in predicting delirium. Grouping based on pain score cutoff and interaction revealed a pain score maintained ≤3/10 to be protective of delirium with incidence rates declining from 15% to 11% (p<0.05).

Conclusions: In post-operative ICU patients, delirium events are significantly associated with higher pain scores and decreased sleep hours. Based on these results, goals should be a pain scale value of 3/10 or less and minimum five hours of sleep to minimize delirium risk. Further studies are needed to verify these goals and establish a protective effect.

abstract_title: Enhanced Recovery After Surgery Reduces Disparities in Length-of-Stay for Colorectal Patients
author_block: T. S. Wahl<sup>1</sup>, A. A. Gullick<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Mills<sup>2</sup>, J. A. Cannon<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Morris<sup>1</sup>, J. W. Simmons<sup>2</sup>, D. I. Chu<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Alabama At Birmingham,Department Of Surgery,Birmingham, AL, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Alabama At Birmingham,Department Of Anesthesiology And Perioperative Medicine,Birmingham, AL, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) is a multimodal pathway that reduces post-operative length-of-stay (LOS) after elective colorectal surgery. Racial disparities in post-operative LOS have been observed between black and white patients after major surgery. We hypothesize that ERAS reduces racial disparities in LOS among black patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery.

Methods: A prospective, single-institution ERAS database was used to identify all patients undergoing ERAS since January 2015. ERAS patients were matched 1:2 by gender, race, indication, and procedure with pre-ERAS patients from 2013-14. The ACS-NSQIP Risk Calculator was used to calculate an expected LOS for each patient. Pre-ERAS and ERAS patients were stratified by race. Chi-square, paired t-tests and Wilcoxon Rank Sums tests were used to determine differences among categorical and continuous variables. Primary and secondary outcomes included the observed and observed-to-expected difference (OED) in post-operative LOS, respectively.

Results: Of 180 patients examined (60 ERAS and 120 pre-ERAS patients), 48.6% were women and 22.8% were black. The mean age of our cohort was 57. Indications for surgery included cancer (61%), diverticulitis (16%), inflammatory bowel disease (12%), and other benign disease (11%). Procedures included low anterior resections (27%), ileocolic resections (24%), partial colectomies (20%), stoma reversals (19%), total colectomies (8%), and ileal pouch-anal anastomoses (2%). The average ACS-NSQIP expected LOS was 5 days for both groups. Compared to pre-ERAS patients, ERAS patients had a significantly reduced post-operative LOS (4.7 vs. 6 days, p=0.01) and improved OED (-0.4 vs. +1.1 days, p=0.01). In the pre-ERAS cohort, black patients had a significantly longer post-operative LOS (7.5 vs. 5.6 days, p=0.01) and OED (+2.7 vs. +0.6 days, p=0.01) compared to white patients. After implementation of ERAS, racial disparities were reduced with black and white patients having similar post-operative LOS (3.8 vs. 5 days, p=0.21) and OED (-0.9 vs. -0.2, p=0.42).

Conclusion: Racial disparities in post-operative LOS after elective colorectal surgery are reduced with ERAS. Further investigations are necessary to identify the individual ERAS processes that may drive these results.

abstract_title: Surgical Outcomes and Expenditures for Medicare Beneficiaries Admitted to Critical Access Hospitals
author_block: A. M. Ibrahim<sup>1</sup>, J. R. Thumma<sup>1</sup>, J. B. Dimick<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Center For Healthcare Outcomes And Policy,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Critical access hospitals (CAHs) are a predominant source of care for many rural populations. The Balance Budget Act of 1997 helped financially protect these safety net hospitals by entitling them to increased imbursements through Medicare. Recent studies suggest that CAHs provide lower quality care for common medical admissions. Little information, however, is known about the outcomes and costs of patients admitted for surgical procedures.

Methods: We performed a cross-sectional retrospective review of 1,318,872 Medicare beneficiary admissions to critical access and non-critical access hospitals for surgical procedures between 2009 and 2012. Critical access hospitals were identified using data from American Hospital Association registry. For those who underwent one of four common types of surgical procedures (Appendectomy, N=125,759 (9.5%); Cholecystectomy, N=474,113 (36.0%); Colectomy, N=472,897 (35.9%); Hernia Repair, N=246,103 (16.6%)) we compared 30-day mortality, complications as well as the associated costs. A multivariate logistical regression was used to adjust for patient factors (age, gender, race, Elixhauser comorbidities,) year of operation and type of operation.

Results: Patient treated at critical access hospitals for surgical procedures were less medically complex. For example, although patients treated at critical access hospitals were older (average age 76.5 versus 75.7, P <0.0001), they were less likely to have heart failure, diabetes, obesity or multiple comorbidities ( % of patients with ≥ 2 comorbidities; 59.9% versus 69.6%, P<0.0001.) Even with these patient factors accounted for in our multivariate model to compare to non-critical access hospitals, critical access hospitals had decreased 30-day mortality rates (4.2% versus 4.7%; adjusted odds ratio [OR], 0.89; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.82-0.96; P=0.005) and decreased total complications (13.1% versus 22.4%; OR, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.49-0.55; P<0.001.) Medicare expenditures adjusted for patient factors, length of of stay, year of procedure and procedure type was decreased at critical access hospitals compared to non-critical access hospitals ($13,514 versus $15,410; difference -$1,896, p< 0.005.)

Conclusions: For common surgical procedures among Medicare Beneficiaries, critical access hospitals were associated with less complex patients, decreased mortality rates, decreased complication rates and lower costs. These findings suggest that critical access hospitals are able to appropriately triage patients in their community and provide them safe surgical care.

abstract_title: Gender Affirming Surgery: National Incidence and Trends
author_block: J. K. Canner<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Kodadek<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>3</sup>, B. D. Lau<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with a gender identity differing from their sex at birth often seek gender affirming surgical procedures to achieve concordance between self-identified gender, physical appearance, and function. We sought to describe the incidence, temporal trends, and types of gender affirming surgeries being performed in the United States from a nationally representative sample of inpatient visits.

Methods: The National Inpatient Sample (NIS) was queried for all hospitalized patients admitted with a primary or secondary ICD-9 diagnosis code of trans-sexualism (TS) and/or gender identity disorder (GID) between 2000 and 2012. We collected patient demographics, including age, race, gender, and insurance status. The proportion of patients age ≥17 undergoing elective surgery was determined. We dichotomized the time period (2000-2006 and 2007-2012) to evaluate temporal trends. We reported patient demographics, insurance coverage and types of procedures performed in each time period.

Results: Between 2000 and 2012, there were 28,642 patients hospitalized with a primary or secondary diagnosis of TS or GID. Among patients ≥17 years, 3,203 (11.2%) underwent apparent gender affirming surgery, and an additional 2,194 (7.7%) underwent other types of elective surgery. Among the 3,203 adult patients undergoing gender affirming surgery, 33% had a diagnosis of TS, 34% GID, and 33% both TS and GID. Among patients undergoing gender affirming surgery in 2000-2006, the mean age was 41.7 years, 41% had missing gender information, 92% were white, and the payer was most commonly self (70%) or private insurance (20%). Among patients undergoing gender affirming surgery in 2007-2012, the mean age was 37.2 years, 53% had missing gender information, 77% were white, and the payer was most commonly self (51%) or private insurance (40%) (all p<0.001). A greater proportion of sampled hospitals performed gender affirming surgery in 2007-2012 versus 2000-2006. Clinical characteristics of patients undergoing gender affirming surgery are presented in Table 1.

Conclusions: Based on available data, gender affirming surgery is common, and patients seeking these procedures are becoming younger and more racially diverse. Demand may continue to increase as more private insurance providers cover these procedures. However, using TS and GID diagnosis codes to identify transgender patients is limited by inconsistent reporting. Standardized collection of gender identity and sex at birth to determine discordance is necessary on a national level to improve research and clinical efforts directed at improving the health of transgender patients.

abstract_title: Emergent ventral hernia repair: disparities beyond race and insurance may impair access
author_block: L. L. Wolf<sup>2</sup>, J. W. Scott<sup>2</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>2</sup>, J. M. Havens<sup>2,3</sup>, E. B. Schneider<sup>2</sup>, A. Salim<sup>2,3</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>2,3</sup>  <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Trauma, Burns, And Surgical Critical Care,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients undergoing emergent surgery have worse outcomes than those undergoing elective surgery. In insured populations, older age, female sex, Black race, comorbidities, and hernia defect size have been shown to be predictors of emergent ventral hernia repair. However, predictors of emergent repair have not been assessed in a nationally representative US population. We sought to identify patient- and hospital-level factors associated with non-elective repair in order to identify targets to improve access to elective repair.

Methods: Adult patients (≥18y) who underwent inpatient ventral hernia repair (ICD-9CM primary diagnosis 551.1x-551.2x, 552.1x-552.2x, 553.1x-553.2x and procedure 46.42, 53.4x-53.6x) were abstracted from the 2003-2011 Nationwide Inpatient Sample. Those with any trauma diagnosis (800-959) were excluded. Admissions were categorized as emergent, urgent, or elective. Differences in patient- and hospital-level factors were assessed as possible predictors of non-elective (emergent or urgent) repair using descriptive statistics (Χ2) and multivariable logistic regression. Secondary outcomes (mortality, length of stay, total hospital cost) were similarly assessed using risk-adjusted logistic and generalized linear (family gamma; link log) regression.

Results: After weighting to the US population, 453,161 adults were included (observed n=92,295); 26% were emergent, 13% urgent, and 61% elective. Mean age was 58 (SE 0.12y); 63% were female, 78% White, 42% privately/50% publicly insured, and 4% uninsured. Significant risk-adjusted independent predictors of non-elective repair included payer status (uninsured: OR 3.50, 95%CI [3.10, 3.96]; Medicaid: 1.29 [1.20, 1.39] compared to private insurance), race/ethnicity (Black: 1.77 [1.64, 1.92]; Hispanic: 1.44 [1.28, 1.61] compared to White), age (65-75: 0.77 [0.72, 0.83]; ≥85 2.23 [2.00, 2.47] compared to <45), and comorbidities (CCI 1: 1.13 [1.09, 1.18]; 2: 1.24 [1.17, 1.30]; ≥3: 1.68 [1.56, 1.80] compared to 0). Patients undergoing non-elective repair had higher risk-adjusted odds of death (2.58 [2.08, 3.22]), a 26% [24, 29] relative increase in length of stay and a 15% [12, 17] relative increase in total hospital cost.

Conclusion: A substantial proportion of inpatient ventral hernia repairs are performed non-electively, with worse outcomes in this group. Independent predictors of non-elective repair include no insurance, Medicaid, non-White race/ethnicity, age ≥85, and multiple comorbidities. While octogenarians and patients with comorbidities have increased odds of non-elective surgery, possibly due to deferral of elective repair, those aged 65-75 have decreased odds, possibly due to increased elective care utilization as Medicare becomes available. Poor access to elective surgical care may contribute to the worse outcomes in the identified groups at risk. Efforts to improve access have potential to mitigate disparities in outcomes from ventral hernia repair.

abstract_title: Tumor Biology and Racial Disparities in Reconstruction After Mastectomy: A SEER Database Analysis
author_block: S. J. Ullrich<sup>2</sup>, P. J. Chung<sup>1</sup>, M. C. Smith<sup>1</sup>, S. Parikh<sup>2</sup>, S. Kim<sup>1</sup>, A. Duncan<sup>1</sup>, A. Alfonso<sup>1</sup>, G. Sugiyama<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>SUNY Downstate Medical Center,General Surgery,Brooklyn, NY, USA <sup>2</sup>SUNY Downstate College Of Medicine,Brooklyn, NY, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Significant disparities in immediate breast reconstruction after mastectomy have persisted, and may even be increasing, despite large-scale efforts to minimize them, such as the Women's Health and Cancer Rights Act of 1998. Immediate breast reconstruction has been shown to lead to higher rates of surgical satisfaction, minimize delay in post-operative cancer treatment, and improve the quality of life and overall well-being of mastectomy patients. However only 25-40% of eligible women in the United States receive reconstruction. The rate of reconstruction is even lower in African American and Hispanic women compared to White women. In an effort to better understand this disparity, this study uses national population-based data to examine how demographic factors, socioeconomic factors, and disease characteristics interact and affect the rate of immediate breast reconstruction (IBR) after mastectomy.

Methods: Women with AJCC7 Stage 0-III breast cancer who underwent mastectomy from 2010 to 2012 were identified in the Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results Program (SEER) database. Race, Hispanic ethnicity, age, marital status, insurance status, tumor grade, AJCC7 stage and hormone receptor/ Her2Neu profile were compared between women undergoing mastectomy with IBR and mastectomy alone using univariate and multivariate analysis.

Results: We identified 51,115 women who underwent mastectomy for Stage 0-III breast cancer from 2010-2012, of whom 15,389 (30.1%) received IBR. On multivariate analysis, age (p<0.0001), marital status (p<0.0001), race (p<0.0001), Hispanic ethnicity (p<0.0001), grade (p = 0.0045), insurance status (p<0.0001), AJCC7 stage (p<0.0001), and ER/PR/Her2 receptor status (p<0.0001) were all independantly associated with IBR. Patients more likely to receive IBR were younger (age < 40: OR = 2.11, 95% CI = 1.95 – 2.29; age 40 – 49: OR = 1.66, 95% CI = 1.57 - 1.75) and presented at a less advanced stage (stage 0: OR = 1.87, 95% CI = 1.62 – 2.16; stage I: OR = 1.37, 95% CI = 1.30 – 1.44). Factors independently associated with not receiving IBR were race/ethnicity (Black race: OR = 0.75, 95% CI = 0.70 - 0.81; Hispanic ethnicity: OR = 0.62, 95% CI = 0.57 - 0.66), insurance status (uninsured: OR = 0.39, 95% CI = 0.34 - 0.46; Medicaid: OR = 0.36, 95% CI = 0.34 - 0.39), Tumor grade 3 (OR = 0.93, 95% CI = 0.88 - 0.98), advanced stage (stage III: OR 0.64, 95% CI = 0.60 – 0.68), and triple negative disease (OR = 0.79, 95% CI = 0.74 - 0.85).

Conclusion: The decision to undergo reconstruction after mastectomy is influenced by many factors. Our results show that even after adjusting for tumor characteristics, socioeconomic factors are independently associated with receiving IBR after mastectomy. Further research is needed to elucidate the factors that influence the decision to undergo IBR in order to eliminate these persistent disparities.

abstract_title: Disparities in Receipt of Laparoscopic Surgery for Ectopic Pregnancy among TRICARE Beneficiaries
author_block: A. Ranjit<sup>1</sup>, W. Jiang<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Chaudhary<sup>1</sup>, T. Zhan<sup>1</sup>, E. B. Schneider<sup>1</sup>, S. L. Cohen<sup>2</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Little<sup>2</sup>, J. N. Robinson<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Obstetrics And Gynecology,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Ectopic pregnancy (EP) is the leading cause of first trimester pregnancy-related death. Laparoscopic surgery (LS) for EP is associated with shorter length of stay and operation time along with less intra-operative bleeding. Racial disparities in laparoscopic surgery (LS) for ectopic pregnancy (EP) are documented and are generally attributed to unequal access to care. The objective of this study was to determine if racial disparities exist in the receipt of LS for EP among universally insured population.

Methods: Using 2006-2010 TRICARE (universal insurance coverage to all members of US Armed Services and their dependents) claims data, tubal EP patients who received surgical intervention (LS or laparotomy) for EP within 48 hours and 30 days of diagnosis were identified using ICD-9 and CPT codes. Cases were then stratified into direct (military hospital) or purchased (civilian hospital) systems of care. Patient demographic characteristics were compared between each racial group (White, Black and Asian/Pacific Islander). Unadjusted and adjusted odds of receipt of LS in each racial group for surgeries performed within 48 hours and 30 days of diagnosis were compared adjusting for patient demographics, system of care and severity of EP. Sub-analysis for odds of receipt of LS for each racial group within direct and purchased care systems was performed.

Results:Among a total of 2680 tubal EP who received surgical intervention, 1620 (60.4%) received LS and 1060 (39.5%) received laparotomy for EP within 30 days of diagnosis. Ninety-one percent of these surgeries were performed within 48 hours of initial diagnosis and 52% were performed within purchased care system. Among all cases identified, 1692 (63.13%) were White, 169 (6.31%) Asian and 819 (30.56%) Black. Overall, 40.9% of White women received LS compared to 32.1% Asian and 33.7% Blacks (p-value: <0.001) within 48 hours. On multivariable analysis adjusted for demographic factors, system of care and severity of EP, Blacks were 30% less likely to receive LS for EP within 48 hours of initial diagnosis. These disparities were not present within the direct system of care (OR: 0.92; CI: 0.70-1.22) but were only present within the purchased system of care (OR: 0.53, CI: 0.38-0.72). Similar trends were seen for surgeries performed within 30 days of initial diagnosis. [See Table]

Conclusion:Black women were less likely to receive LS for EP within purchased care (civilian hospital) in the universally insured TRICARE population. These findings might help inform policy changes to ensure equal access to advanced surgical options among all beneficiaries irrespective of race and system of care.

abstract_title: Universal Health Insurance Reduces Disparities Following Surgical Intervention in African-Americans
author_block: A. J. Schoenfeld<sup>1</sup>, W. Jiang<sup>1</sup>, A. Haider<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Healthcare disparities are known to exist for racial and ethnic minorities within American healthcare, but the impact of universal health insurance on disparities remains unknown. We sought to evaluate the impact of universal health insurance on outcomes following surgical interventions among beneficiaries of Department of Defense (DoD) TRICARE health insurance.

Methods: TRICARE claims data (2006-2010) were queried to identify all individuals who received one of 12 surgical interventions (Table). Race, gender, socio-economic status, environment of care, and 30-day morbidity, including readmission and reoperation, were assessed for all patients. The environment of care was defined as direct for those who received their surgery in a DoD hospital and purchased for individuals treated at a non-DoD facility using TRICARE insurance. Individuals with missing race were excluded from the denominator and analysis was limited to patients identified as African-American or Caucasian. Reweighted estimation equation method was used to reducebias introduced by excluding patients with missing race. Thirty-day mortality following surgery complications, readmission and reoperation were the dependent variables. Unadjusted comparisons between African-Americans and Caucasians were performed, followed by weighted multivariable logistic regression that adjusted for differences in case-mix and the type of surgical intervention. Analyses were repeated to evaluate the impact of racewithin direct and purchased care facilities.

Results:The cohort consisted of 11,402 African-Americans and 69,729 Caucasians. The mortality rate for the cohort as a whole was 0.15% while complications were sustained by 15.6%. Readmission occurred in 10.2%. Final adjusted analysis revealed that African-Americans were not at elevated odds of mortality following surgical intervention (OR 1.14; 95% CI 0.70, 1.85). They were, however, found to be at increased odds of sustaining a complication (OR 1.13; 95% CI 1.04, 1.22) and readmission (OR 1.16; 95% CI 1.07, 1.25). These findings persisted among patients treated within the purchased care system [OR for complications 1.18; 95% CI 1.07, 1.31; OR for readmission 1.19; 95% CI 1.08, 1.31), but were absent for those who received direct care at a DoD facility.

Conclusion:Some disparities were present between African-American and Caucasian patients receiving surgery within a universal payer system, but the differences are markedly reduced as compared to prior reports regarding surgical care. Furthermore, no disparities were present for those patients treated at intrinsic DoD facilities. These findings hold meaning for the potential of a universal payer system to reduce disparities in care following surgery.

abstract_title: Racial Disparities in Timely Access to Surgical Cancer Care
author_block: K. T. Collier<sup>1</sup>, J. Tong<sup>1</sup>, R. Hoffman<sup>1</sup>, S. Dasani<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Racial disparities in surgical outcomes are ubiquitous. It has been demonstrated that timely surgical intervention for gastrointestinal (GI) malignancies are associated with improved outcomes and reduced costs. We sought to examine the association between race and time to treatment in a cohort of patients hospitalized for surgical cancer care.

Methods: We identified all patients who underwent a surgical resection for colon, rectal, pancreas or stomach cancer in NY and CA (2008-2011). Patients were excluded from study if they were transferred from another facility or resided out-of-state. Race was classified as white or black. Patients were classified as F24 if they underwent surgery in the first 24 hours following the index admission for the known malignancy. Descriptive statistics were performed. Multivariate logistic regression was used to compare patient and hospital characteristics by F24 status. Subset analysis was performed by malignancy type. A Bonferroni correction was used to adjust for multiple comparisons.

Results: Of 31,425 patients who underwent a cancer resection, there were 28,115 (89.5%) white patients, and 3,310 (10.5%) black patients. Within the overall cohort 22,092 (70.3%) were F24. Black patients were less likely to be F24 when compared to white patients (B:2,014, 60.9% vs W:20,078, 71.4%; p<0.001). Black and white patients differed significantly on many pre-operative characteristics (see table). In multivariate analysis, black patients had a significantly reduced likelihood of F24 when compared to white patients (OR 0.71; 95%CI 0.64-0.79). In 3 independent multivariate models developed by malignancy type, black patients were significantly less likely to F24 for colon cancer (OR 0.77; 95%CI 0.69-0.87), rectal cancer (OR 0.53; 95%CI 0.38-0.74) and stomach cancer (OR 0.52; 95%CI 0.37-0.74). In the pancreas cancer model, black patients were less likely to F24 (OR 0.57; 95%CI 0.35-0.95) but the result did not reach significance with the Bonferroni adjustment.

Conclusion: Black patients were less likely to undergo surgery within 24 hours of admission for GI malignancies. The lower likelihood of timely surgical care in black surgical patients persisted even after adjustment for multiple potential confounders including pre-operative health status and insurance status. Barriers to the provision and acceptance of timely surgical interventions should be identified and mitigated for black cancer patients. Future studies are indicated.

abstract_title: Access to Post-Discharge Rehabilitation Services Following Lower Limb Trauma
author_block: D. Metcalfe<sup>1</sup>, O. A. Olufajo<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Rios Diaz<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Chaudhary<sup>1</sup>, M. B. Harris<sup>2</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Weaver<sup>2</sup>, A. Salim<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Brigham & Women's Hospital,Department Of Orthopedic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rehabilitation is increasingly recognized as a critical component of trauma care. Patients without health insurance may not be eligible to access rehabilitation services following treatment for lower limb trauma, which could delay hospital discharge. We hypothesized that uninsured patients are less likely to be discharged to rehabilitation facilities and so have prolonged length of stay (LOS) in hospital.

Methods: The California State Inpatient Database (SID) (2007-2011) was queried for all patients with a primary diagnosis of lower limb skeletal trauma (ICD-9-CM 808, 821-828). The SID is a comprehensive population cohort that includes 98% of hospital admissions in California, with unique patient identifiers that permit tracking across different hospitals. Patients that died in hospital were excluded. Multivariable logistic and generalized linear regression models were used to risk-adjust outcomes for differences in patient- (age, sex, race, payer status, Charlson Comorbidity Index, Injury Severity Score, weekend admission, admission source) and hospital-level factors (trauma center designation, hospital bed size). All regression models accounted for clustering of patients within hospitals. The principal comparison in all analyses was between uninsured and privately insured patients. A sub-group analysis was performed that excluded patients with isolated hip fractures.

Results:A total of 283,472 lower limb trauma admissions were identified. 192,181 (67.8%) were supported by public insurance (Medicare and/or Medicaid), 60,208 (21.2%) were privately insured, and 11,340 (4.0%) were uninsured. The insurance status of the remaining patients (7.0%) was unknown.In the unadjusted analyses, self-pay patients were considerably less likely to be discharged to another facility than those with private insurance (9.9% versus 35.0%, Χ2 p<0.001). LOS was however slightly shorter in the uninsured group (4.5 versus 4.9 days, Kruskal-Wallis p<0.001). Fewer uninsured patients required readmission to hospital within 30 days (3.4% versus 12.5%, Χ2 p<0.001).Within the risk-adjusted analyses, uninsured patients were less likely to be discharged to a rehabilitation hospital or skilled nursing facility (OR 0.21, 95% CI 0.18-0.25). Their adjusted length of stay was 0.87 days longer (95% CI 0.61-1.14) than for patients with private insurance. There were no significant differences between the groups in terms of 30-day unplanned readmission to hospital (uninsured OR 1.07, 95% CI 0.93-1.22). These findings all persisted when patients with isolated hip fractures were excluded.

Conclusion:Uninsured patients are less likely to be discharged to post-acute care facilities following lower limb trauma and have prolonged LOS compared to privately insured patients. Further work should explore whether reduced access to post-discharge rehabilitation services is associated with worse functional outcomes and greater overall healthcare costs.

abstract_title: Breast Cancer in Native American Women: A Study of 863,958 Patients from the SEER Database(1973-2010)
author_block: S. Gopinath<sup>1</sup>, K. Mahendraraj<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Chamberlain<sup>1,2,3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Saint Barnabas Medical Center,Surgery,Livingston, NJ, USA <sup>2</sup>Saint George's University,Surgery,Grenada, Grenada, Grenada <sup>3</sup>New Jersey Medical School,Surgery,Newark, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Breast cancer (BC) is the most common cancer among Native American (NA) women. Despite this fact, existing data suggests NA women have a lower than expected BC incidence rates, but a markedly higher mortality to incidence ratio compared to other racial/ethnic groups. This study sought to analyze demographic and clinical factors in a large NA BC cohort to further investigate the validity of these observations and to delineate clinical and pathological factors which may better risk stratify this unique population for optimal treatment protocols and clinical trial accrual.

Methods: Demographic and clinical data on 863,958 women with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast was abstracted from the Surveillance Epidemiology and End Result (SEER) database (1973-2010). Standard statistical methodology was used.

Results:Among 863,958 BC patients, 4,289 (0.5%) were NAs and 859,669 (99.5%) were Caucasians. The majority of BC in both groups occurred in those 60 to 79 years (43.7% Caucasians and 33.5% NA). NA women had a higher incidence of BC at a younger age (9.2% vs. 5.1% for age 20-39, and 51.8% vs. 38.1% at age 40-59, p<0.001), as well as a higher rate of regional (34.0% vs. 31.3%) and distant metastasis (7.9% vs. 6.1%). The majority of women in both groups had tumor size <2 cm (56.4%) and moderately differentiated disease (42.3%), p<0.001. Mean overall survival (OS) was significantly longer in Caucasian women than NAs (7.40±6.7 vs. 6.66±6.1 years), p<0.001. The majority (54.3%) of all patients underwent surgery only. Cancer specific mortality (21.7% vs. 21.2%) as well as 1- and 5- year cumulative survival (94% and 74% vs. 94% and 76%) was similar between groups. Multivariate analysis identified that age>60 (OR 1.3), size >4cm (OR 1.8) and distant metastasis (OR 3) were associated with increased mortality, p<0.001.

Conclusion:Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast affects the NA population far less often than Caucasians. NA BC patients tend to be younger and present with more aggressive disease features. Despite these finding, NA BC patients have survival equivalent to similarly treated women in other ethnic groups. Surgical resection and combination surgery and radiation conferred the greatest survival advantage in NAs. Due to its rarity, NA women with breast cancer should be considered for clinical trial accrual to further delineate genetic and environmental factors which may affect incidence rates and prognosis.

abstract_title: The Impact of SUS Membership on the Scholarship of American Surgery
author_block: N. Valsangkar<sup>1</sup>, J. Kays<sup>1</sup>, P. Martin<sup>1</sup>, J. Parett<sup>1</sup>, M. M. Joshi<sup>1</sup>, T. A. Zimmers<sup>1</sup>, L. Koniaris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A core objective of the Society of University Surgeons (SUS) is research focused: to 'advance the art and science of surgery through original investigation.' Herein, we sought to determine the current impact of the SUS on surgical academic productivity.

Methods: Individual faculty data for numbers of publications, citations, and NIH funding history were collected for 4,015 surgical faculty at the top 55-NIH funded departments of surgery using SCOPUS, and NIH RePORTer. SUS membership was determined from membership registry data.

Results: Overall, 502 surgical faculty (12.5%) were SUS members and 92.7% were associate or full professors (versus 59% of non-members). Median publications (P) and citations (C) among SUS members were P:112, C:2460 versus P:29, C:467 (p < 0.001). Academic productivity was considerably higher by rank for SUS-members: associate (P:61 vs. 36, C:1199 vs. 591, p < 0.001) and full professors (P:141 vs. 81, C:3537 vs. 1856, p < 0.001). Among full professors, SUS members had much higher rates of any NIH funding (52.6% vs. 26%, p < 0.05) and specifically for R01, P01, and U01 awards (37% vs. 17.7%, p<0.01). SUS members were two times as likely to be serving in divisional leadership or chair positions (23.5% vs. 10.2%, p < 0.05).

Conclusion: SUS society members are academically a highly productive group. These data support the premise that the SUS is meeting its research mission and identify its members as extremely academically productive contributors to research and scholarship in American surgery and medicine.

abstract_title: Catastrophic health expenditure risk among uninsured trauma patients in the United States
author_block: J. W. Scott<sup>1,2</sup>, N. Raykar<sup>2,3</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>1</sup>, J. G. Meara<sup>2,4</sup>, M. G. Shrime<sup>2,5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health, Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Program For Global Surgery And Social Change,Harvard Medical School,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Children's Hospital Boston,Department Of Plastic And Oral Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>5</sup>Massachusetts Eye And Ear Infirmary,Department Of Otolaryngology And Office Of Global Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The Affordable Care Act attempts to decrease the uninsured population in the US by extension of coverage for young adults, creation of insurance exchanges, and expansion of Medicaid eligibility. However, implementation of these programs—most notably Medicaid expansion—remains incomplete. Approximately 1/5th of US trauma patients ages 18-64y are uninsured, and lack of insurance may increase the risk of potentially impoverishing catastrophic health expenditure--previously defined as any expense exceeding 10% of annual household income. We aimed to use a nationally-representative patient sample to determine the proportion of uninsured trauma patients admitted to a hospital who incurred catastrophic medical bills.

Methods: Uninsured patients ages 18-64y who were admitted for traumatic injury (ICD-9-CM 800-959) were abstracted from the 2007-2011 National Inpatient Sample (NIS). To provide a more detailed estimate of median household income, patients were matched to data obtained from the US census bureau, wherein zip codes were ranked by median income into quartiles and linked to states. State and median zip code household income quartiles were matched to the corresponding NIS variables to provide an estimated household income for each patient. Charges were determined by the NIS total hospital charges billed to each patient. Proportions and estimations were calculated using nationally-representative discharge scaling weights provided in the NIS.

Results:A total of 117,497 patients (weighted to represent 579,656 patients nationwide) were included. Median estimated household income was $44,287 (IQR: $35,456-$56,646). Median total hospital charges were $26,339 (IQR: $14,575-$47,941). The proportion of uninsured trauma patients with total charges exceeding 10% of estimated household income was 95.8% (95% CI: 94.7-96.9%). The proportion of uninsured trauma patients with total charges exceeding 40% of estimated post-subsistence income was 71.6% (95%CI: 69.4-73.8%). When scaled to the total US population, these proportions imply an estimated total of 555,385 (95%CI: 496,728-614,041) uninsured trauma patients ages 18-64y incurred catastrophic medical bills between 2007-2011--equivalent to 110,077 patients per year (95%CI: 99,346-122,808) patients per year.

Conclusion:Applying an established definition of catastrophic heath spending, estimates from a nationally representative sample suggest that over 95% of uninsured patients ages 18-64y incur catastrophic medical bills if hospitalized for a traumatic injury in the US. Surgeons should take note, especially in states in which Medicaid has not been expanded, that nearly all of their uninsured trauma patients are at risk of financial catastrophe. Whether through enhanced insurance coverage or other means of improving access to affordable care, providers and policy makers should take note and promote efforts that favor financial risk protection for patients.

abstract_title: The Cost of Surgical Care: How Much Are We Really Charging?
author_block: F. Gani<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Makary<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hospital markups (ratios of charges-to-Medicare-allowable costs) are not subject to regulation in most states, yet contribute to increasing insurance premiums as well as rising health-care spending. We sought to characterize national variations in hospital markup for major cardio-thoracic (CT) and hepato-pancreatico-biliary-gastrointestinal (HPB-GI) surgical procedures, as well as examine perioperative outcomes at hospitals with extreme markup.

Methods: All hospitals in which a patient underwent a CT (n=577,275) or HPB-GI (n=618,700) procedure were identified using the Nationwide Inpatient Sample (NIS) for 2012. Charge-to-cost ratios(CCR) were compared across hospitals. In-hospital outcomes were examined relative to 'extreme markup'(≥75th percentile).

Results: Among the 17,490 hospitals identified, median CCR was 2.8 (IQR 2.7-3.9). 4,373 hospitals that treated 411,540 patients were in the highest CCR quartile (range, 3.9-12.2) (Figure). While patient age, gender and insurance status were not associated with extreme markup hospitals (all p>0.05), minority patients were more likely to be treated at high CCR hospitals (non-extreme CCR: 20.3% vs. extreme CCR: 30.4%, p<0.001). Extreme markup hospitals were more often large (non-extreme CCR: 33.7% vs. extreme CCR: 46.3%), non-teaching (non-extreme CCR: 37.9% vs. extreme CCR: 56.7%), and located in the South (non-extreme CCR: 32.8% vs. extreme CCR: 45.8%, all P<0.001). Extreme mark up hospitals had higher perioperative morbidity (non-extreme CCR: 26.4% vs. extreme CCR: 32.7%), failure-to-rescue (non-extreme: 10.2% vs. extreme CCR: 12.2%) and mortality (non-extreme CCR: 3.2% vs. extreme CCR: 4.4%, all P<0.001).

Conclusions: Many patients undergo surgery at hospitals charging over 4-times Medicare-allowable cost. Extreme markup hospitals had worse perioperative outcomes than non-extreme markup hospitals. Federal regulations should consider price disclosure to regulate hospital markups.

abstract_title: Where the Sun-Shines: Industry Payments to Surgeons
author_block: R. Ahmed<sup>1</sup>, S. Bae<sup>2</sup>, E. Chow<sup>2</sup>, A. B. Massie<sup>2</sup>, J. Lopez<sup>2</sup>, C. Atallah<sup>2</sup>, D. L. Segev<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery,Durham, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,General Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Under the Physician Payment Sunshine Act (PPSA), data were released publicly disclosing biomedical industry non-reasearch payments to physicians; enabling patients to be aware of potential financial conflicts-of-interests (COI). The objective of this study is to provide general surgeons a better understanding of the PPSA data.

Methods: Using the first wave of PPSA data (Aug-Dec, 2013), published December 2014, we describe the distribution of payments to all general surgeons (GS) and general surgical subspecialists (GSS), and compared it to gastroenterologists.

Results: There were total of 17,331 GSS (4.8% of all providers) who collectively received $27,015,046 (3.9% of all payments). GS received median (IQR) $100 (32-319) mean $1,199; compared to $94 ($29-$255) mean $1,900 among other providers. The largest payment to a surgeon was $253,468. The three major payment categories were speaker fees (18%), consulting (17%) and royalties (16%). Among GSS, 44.5% received payments <$100, 38.5% between ($100-<$1K), 14% between ($1K-<$10K), and 2.9% >= $10K. A total of 497 companies made payments to GSS ($9.33-$3,580,066) of which 10 comprised 54% of all payments. On average, cardiac surgeons were the highest paid GSS (ranksum, p<0.001). Gastroenterologists received higher payments than GS (ranksum, p<0.001).

Conclusion: This description of the PPSA showed that majority amount paid to GS and GSS comprised of consulting and speaker fees; 50% of GS received payments <$100. Payments to GS were lower than gastroenterologists. Although the PPSA data provides transparency to potential COI, its value is yet to be determined. Awareness of the PPSA, its data and implications are critical for all physicians.

abstract_title: Variations in Hospitals Costs for Surgical Procedures among Patients and Providers
author_block: F. Gani<sup>1</sup>, M. Daniel<sup>1</sup>, J. Hundt<sup>1</sup>, J. E. Efron<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Makary<sup>1</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Reducing unwanted variations in healthcare has been identified as an opportunity for cost containment. We sought to characterize variations in hospital costs for several surgical procedures and quantitate the variability attributable to the patient, procedure, and provider.

Methods: Patients who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair (AAA), laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC), pancreatectomy or colectomy between 2009 and 2013 were identified at a large tertiary care hospital. Inter- and intra-provider variations in costs were compared using coefficient-of-variation (CV). Multivariable hierarchical linear modeling was utilized to quantitate variation in total hospital costs attributable to the patient, procedure and provider.

Results: Among the 4,802 patients that underwent surgery, the average cost of surgery was $34,697 (SD=25,844) ranging from $11,177 (SD=$4,955) for LC to $63,654 (SD=54,046) for AAA repair. While perioperative complications resulted in increased cost (no complication: $25,864, SD=16,838 vs. complication: $47,171, SD=72,692, p<0.001), total hospital costs remained variable even among patients without complications (p<0.001, Figure). Substantial variation in total costs was observed among surgeons performing the same surgery (CV: CABG, 103%; AAA, 104%, LC, 69%, pancreatectomy, 82%; colectomy, 122%). Further, marked variations in costs were also observed within the same surgeon performing the same surgery (CV: CABG, 21%-116%; AAA, 26%-111%, LC, 19%-107%, pancreatectomy, 31%-101%; colectomy, 17%-155%). After accounting for patient comorbidity, postoperative complications and length of stay, 90% of total variability was explained by patient- and procedure-related factors, while 10% was attributed to variations in surgeon practices.

Conclusion: Hospital procedure costs varied markedly among and even within providers. While patient level factors explained most of the variation in cost, up to 10% of the variation was due to provider-level differences, which can be a potential target for cost containment.

abstract_title: Value-Based Purchasing: An Analysis of Current Utilization of In-Patient Care for GI Malignancies
author_block: J. Tong<sup>1</sup>, K. T. Collier<sup>1</sup>, S. Dasani<sup>1</sup>, R. Hoffman<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Phiadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Background: A shift from the fee-for-service system to a value-based-purchasing model(VBP) is underway. In a GI cancer model, the study aimed to examine treatment patterns and observed costs in the in-patient setting to understand the impact that VBP may have on patients.

Methods: A retrospective cohort study was performed using inpatient claims from California and New York (2008-2011) for all patients admitted with a new diagnosis of colon, rectal, stomach, or pancreatic cancer regardless of the intended treatment plan. Patterns of treatment, surgical and non-surgical, and associated costs during the index admission for cancer were examined. Patient characteristics were compared by treatment pattern using the Chi square test. Univariate costs were compared using the Kruskal Wallis test. Log-transformed wage-adjusted total costs were compared using multivariate linear regression.

Results: Of 75,177 patients, there were 39,207(52.2%) colon cancer, 14,020(18.7%) rectal cancer, 12,341(16.4%) pancreatic cancer, and 9,609(12.8%) stomach cancer admissions. Patients admitted with a new diagnosis of colon cancer were most likely to be treated with surgery during the index admission(81.8%) compared to 61.3% of rectal cancer patients, 23.5% of pancreas cancer patients and 43.1% of stomach cancer patients(p<0.001). 34% of surgical patients underwent an operation within 24 hours of admission. The median cost per admission was $20,819(IQR 12,448-34,928). Cost was greatest for patients with stomach cancer($24,168; IQR 12,861-43,978) and least expensive for pancreas cancer patients($19,474; IQR 10,506-36,708) (p<0.001). Cost for patients who had surgery during the index admission($24,177; IQR 15,311-38,714) differed from that those who did not($15,351; IQR 8,767-27,673)( p<0.001). Among patients who underwent an operation during the index admission, the cost was significantly less for those who underwent surgery within 24 hours of admission($21,606; IQR 13,990-34,396) when compared to those that were admitted for >24 hours before surgery($27,360; IQR 17,251-43,801) (p<0.001). The direction of the relationship between cost and treatment type and timing of surgery remained the same after adjustment for potential confounders.

Conclusions: Surgical care remains the definitive therapy for solid GI cancers with variable cost depending on tumor type. Not all patients are receiving surgical treatment at the time of admission. Patients that are ready for surgery at the time of admission incur less costly care. The goal of bundled cancer care should be timely diagnosis and referral for definitive surgical care. Optimizing outpatient health status prior to admission may result in substantial cost savings. While VBP offers sensible features for cost containment for insurers and employers, the current inefficiencies in utilization of in-patient services will ultimately lead to greater costs incurred by the patient.

abstract_title: The Time Required to Review Research Protocols at 10 IRBs in the Veterans Health Administration.
author_block: D. E. Hall<sup>1,2</sup>, U. Feske<sup>1</sup>, S. Gao<sup>1</sup>, R. Stone<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Zhang<sup>1</sup>, R. Arnold<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>VA Pittsburgh Healthcare System,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburg,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Although data demonstrate that VA investigators perceive the need to reduce the time required to secure IRB approval, little is known about the actual time required to secure IRB approval. Therefore, we measured IRB review times across the research portfolios of 10 large VHA IRBs.

Methods: We collected the IRB records pertaining to a random sample of research protocols from the research portfolio of 10 VA IRBs, stratified by review type (i.e., exempt, expedited, full board). We included IRBs operated by the VA, and based on the number of actively managed protocols, we sequentially approached the 26 largest IRBs to achieve our target sample of 10 participating IRBs, including the VA Central IRB. Using detailed maps of each site's review process, two independent analysts abstracted time data from the IRB records from which we calculated the overall and incremental review times. Multivariable models assessed differences between site, review type and and increments of the IRB review process.

Results:We obtained documentation for 278 protocols: 48 exempt, 106 expedited and 124 full board. Raters agreed on 3038 of 3090 time points (98.3%) abstracted from a sub-sample of 72 (22.4%) protocols. Total review time ranged from 24 to 310 days, with means of 93±51, 107±54, and 131±63 days for expedited, exempt and full board protocols respectively. Multivariable models using robust variance estimation controlling for site and review level demonstrate that, on average, expedited reviews were 45 days faster than full board reviews ( 95% CI = 31-59 days). There was no significant difference between full board and exempt reviews. However, after subtracting the time required for Research and Development (R&D) Committee review, both exempt and expedited reviews were 21 (95% CI = 1-41) and 39 (95% CI = 23-55) days faster than full board reviews, respectively, in the subgroup of protocols for which we could determine the time for R&D Committee Review (N = 178). Finally, when compared to Site 1, full board reviews at Sites 3, 8 9 and 10 were 27 (6-48), 38 (12-63), 45 (20-69) and 24 (1-46) days faster, and Site 6 was 56 (28-84) days slower (ranges show 95% CI).

Conclusion:IRB review times differ significantly between sites and review types. Some sites approach a consensus panel goal of 60 days for IRB review, but other sites need improvement to reach this goal. Review times for exempt protocols are unexpectedly long due to delay with the R&D Committee review. These data could inform site-specific initiatives for reducing the time required for IRB review.

abstract_title: Extended LOS in Patients Undergoing Orthognathic Surgery: Does Surgeon Volume Matter?
author_block: A. Gupta<sup>1</sup>, R. Chaudhary<sup>1,2,3</sup>, A. W. Davis<sup>1</sup>, A. Krasnova<sup>1,2,3</sup>, S. Haring<sup>1,3,4</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1,2,3</sup>, M. A. Morris<sup>1,3</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>1,2,3</sup>, E. B. Schneider<sup>1,3,4,5</sup>  <sup>5</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health,,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard School Of Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>3</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA <sup>4</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School Of Public Health,Health Policy And Management,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgeon-specific annual procedure volume has been associated with improved outcomes in a variety of complex surgical procedures. The relationship between surgeon volume and outcomes for patients undergoing orthognathic surgery has not been reported. We examined the relationship between surgeon volume and hospital length of stay (LOS), and total hospital charges for patients undergoing the two most common orthognathic procedures, namely segmental osteoplasty/osteotomy of maxilla or open osteoplasty/osteotomy of mandibular ramus.

Methods: All patients undergoing the aforementioned procedures as in-patients were selected from the 2002 to 2009 Nationwide Inpatient Sample. Year-specific annual procedure volumes were calculated for each surgeon and dichotomized into low- and high volume groups (<10 vs. ≥ 10 procedures/year respectively). The relationship between year-specific annual volume and the likelihood of extended patient LOS (defined as LOS ≥ 75th percentile) was examined using multivariable logistic regression, adjusting for patient and hospital-level factors. Possible provider-volume related differences in total charges were examined using a generalized linear model, with a log-link and gamma distribution also adjusting for patient and hospital-level factors.

Results:Among the 3,705 patient admissions eligible for inclusion, age ranged between 4 days to 80 years, with 68.7% of patients being between 15-30 years of age. Annual surgeon volume ranged from 1 to 36 with a mean of 6 (SD=7) procedures/year. Overall, 81.2% of procedures were performed by low-volume surgeons and 46.8% of surgeons performed 3 or fewer procedures annually. In univariable analyses, patient demographics did not differ between high and low volume providers. Also, no surgeon-volume-related differences were observed between teaching and non-teaching hospitals. Patients treated by high volume surgeons demonstrated 34% lower odds of experiencing extended LOS (OR 0.66 95% CI: 0.46-0.95) after adjusting for patient demographic factors, insurance status, comorbidities, and hospital characteristics (rural vs. urban, teaching status and bed-size). There was no association between surgeon volume and total hospital charges after adjusting for potential confounders.

Conclusion:Regionalization of patients to high volume surgeons/centers for surgical treatment has been recommended for specific subsets of surgical patients, including those with major trauma and requiring certain cardiac, cancer or gastric bypass procedures. Our findings suggest the possibility that similar regionalization strategies might reduce the likelihood of extended LOS for patients undergoing orthognathic procedures.

abstract_title: High Safety Net Hospitals and Pancreatic Surgery: Should it Be Abandoned?
author_block: D. E. Go<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Abbott<sup>1</sup>, K. Wima<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Hanseman<sup>1</sup>, A. Ertle<sup>1</sup>, A. Chang<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Sussman<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Shah<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Hoehn<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati,Department Of Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Previous work has demonstrated significant outcome and cost disparities between hospitals with different safety-net burdens, though the implications of policy changes to limit operative interventions at specific hospital types are unclear. We aimed to understand how performance of pancreaticoduodectomy (PD) at different safety-net burden hospitals affects cost and outcomes, and how redistribution of patients from low performing hospitals to high performing hospitals could improve cost-effectiveness.

Methods: Hospitals performing PD were queried from the University HealthSystem Consortium database (UHC; 2009-2013) and grouped according to safety-net burden (proportion of Medicaid and uninsured patient charges, as previously described). A decision analytic model was then constructed, populated with UHC clinical and DRG-based cost data. Primary endpoints were perioperative mortality, readmission, and cost (index hospitalization plus readmission, when applicable). Sensitivity analyses were conducted to determine how primary endpoints were affected by alternative distribution of patients between hospital types and clinical outcomes.

Results: 15,090 patients populated the final dataset. Low (LBH), medium (MBH) and high (HBH) burden hospitals were comprised of 4,220 (28%), 9,505 (63%) and 1,365 (9%) patients, respectively. Perioperative mortality was twice as high at HBH (3.7%) than at LBH (1.6%) and MBH (1.7%) (p<0.001). In the base case, when all clinical and cost data were considered, PD at HBH hospitals cost $35,628/patient, 35% and 55% higher than MBH ($26,357) and LBH ($22988) hospitals, respectively. This increased cost at HBH hospitals was associated with a significantly higher readmission rate (23%) than at MBH (18%) and LBH (15%) hospitals (p<0.001. Patients at HBH hospitals were more likely to have extreme severity of illness (SOI) (18.8%) than at MBH (12.8%) and LBH (11.4%) but less likely to have moderate SOI (74.2% vs. 78% and 79.4%, respectively) (p<0.001). After patient SOI-adjusted equal redistribution of all HBH to LBH and MBH hospitals, per patient cost remained significantly lower at LBH ($25,594; 39.2% less) and MBH ($27,860; 27.9% less), with a readmission rate of 18% (vs. 23% at HBH in the base case).

Conclusion: HBH perform a minority of PDs, but have higher readmission and perioperative mortality rates at significantly higher costs. Redistribution of patients from HBH to LBH/MBH—adjusted for patient-specific risk—demonstrates significant improvement in clinical outcomes, with a potential for over $2M in annual cost savings. While patient-specific factors partially contribute to sub-optimal clinical outcomes, these data show that inherent hospital characteristics are important in optimizing cost-effective PD care, and that certain hospital types may not be optimally equipped for complex pancreatic surgery.

abstract_title: Does Distance Matter?  Patient Travel and Pancreaticoduodenectomy Costs
author_block: L. H. Nicholas<sup>1</sup>, C. Wolfgang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Whether to concentrate risky surgical procedures in high-volume hospitals is a long-standing question among surgeons, policy-makers and payers. Despite decades of interest in this question, little is known about the potential costs of increased patient travel.

Methods: We studied all radical pancreaticoduodenectomy inpatient admissions to hospitals that exceeded low-volume thresholds (more than 6 operations per year) among Maryland residents from 2004 – 2012 (N = 1,277). We used general linear regression models to assess the relationship between the total cost of hospitalization and distance patients traveled controlling for patient demographics, complexity and severity.

Results: Maryland residents traveled an average of 34.6 miles (median 19.5) for surgery. Admissions costs averaged $46,597 (median $36,803). Total costs were higher from patients living further from their hospitals. Compared to patients in the lowest quartile of hospital distance (who lived fewer than 8 miles from their hospital), patients in the second distance quartile (8 – 20 miles) incurred an additional $5,205 in admissions costs (p = 0.001), while those in the highest quartile (47 – 300 miles) had an additional $4,616 in total costs (p = 0.055).

Conclusion: Greater patient travel distance was associated with increased costs for pancreaticoduodenectomy. Patients traveling to high-volume centers may require duplicative testing if they initiated care elsewhere and longer stays before they can return home. These costs should be accounted for in payer and policy-maker decisions about regionalizing surgical procedures.

abstract_title: Impact of Clinical Data Veracity on Survival and Molecular Analyses
author_block: D. M. Wright<sup>1,2</sup>, S. Y. Mehta<sup>3</sup>, F. Munro<sup>2</sup>, M. A. Black<sup>4</sup>, A. Anjomshoaa<sup>5</sup>, L. McNoe<sup>4</sup>, A. E. Reeve<sup>4</sup>, A. E. Merrie<sup>6</sup>, J. L. McCall<sup>2</sup>, C. G. Print<sup>3</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Southern District Health Board,Dunedin, , New Zealand <sup>2</sup>University Of Otago,Department Of Surgical Sciences,Dunedin, , New Zealand <sup>3</sup>University Of Auckland,Auckland, , New Zealand <sup>4</sup>University Of Otago,School Of Medical Sciences,Dunedin, , New Zealand <sup>5</sup>Kerman University Of Medical Sciences,Kerman, , Iran <sup>6</sup>Auckland District Health Board,Auckland, , New Zealand
abstract_body:
Introduction: Translational research combining clinical and genomic datasets has increased our understanding of cancer, improving diagnosis, prognostication, and treatment.Small private clinical databases, however, report data error rates of up to 27% and missing data rates of up to 55%. Large international genomic initiatives are also plagued by high rates of missing data. Despite this little attention has been paid to the impact of these errors on translational research findings.The aim of this study was to quantify the impact of clinical data omissions and errors on cancer genomic analysis by comparing gene associations before and after clinical data revision for our colorectal cancer dataset using simulated analyses.

Methods: Primary colorectal cancer tumour samples were collected between 1996 and 2007 at a single institution. Clinical information matched to each sample was prospectively collected for at least 5 years. RNA was isolated from these tumour samples and hybridized to microarray chips. Microarray analyses were performed using the statistical software ‘R'.Review of the clinical annotations of 205 samples elucidated the presence of data inconsistencies, which were then revised.Simulations were performed using ‘R' scripts to assess the influence of data inconsistencies on gene expression and disease free survival (DFS) for our cohort and for a cohort downloaded from the online GEO repository (GSE17536).

Results:In our dataset staging data were found to be missing for 50% of samples, and disease recurrence data for 25% of patients. Survival analyses showed significant differences between the original and revised datasets. DFS at five years increased from 62% to 83% (P=0.005), and overall survival increased from 52% to 64% with contemporary data revision alone (P=0.005).For 106 of these tumours, revision of clinical tumour annotation was found to result in a statistically significant association between DFS and APC expression (P<0.05) that was not apparent in the original data.Simulation studies demonstrated that when a change in the survival status (disease free versus disease recurrence) was introduced for even 5% of the cohort, existing associations between gene expression and survival were significantly altered.

Conclusions:These studies demonstrate the important consequences of clinical data omissions and inconsistencies on the conclusions drawn from cancer genomic studies. Such omissions and inconsistencies may be explained largely by factors such as evolution in staging practice and re-categorisation of events including metachronous disease. This highlights the need for clearly defined terms and expert clinical input into data acquisition with implications for analysis of international cancer genomic data as well as for genomic analyses by individual laboratories.

abstract_title: National Quality Forum Colon Cancer Quality Metric Performance—How Are Hospitals Measuring Up?
author_block: M. C. Mason<sup>1,2</sup>, G. J. Chang<sup>3</sup>, Y. H. Sada<sup>2,4</sup>, H. S. Tran Cao<sup>1,5</sup>, D. H. Berger<sup>1,2,5</sup>, N. N. Massarweh<sup>1,2,5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Michael E. DeBakey Department Of Surgery,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>VA HSR&D Center For Innovations In Quality, Effectiveness, And Safety,Michael E. DeBakey VA Medical Center, Baylor Collge Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center,Department Of Surgical Oncology And Health Services Research,Houston, TX, USA <sup>4</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Department Of Medicine, Division Of Medical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA <sup>5</sup>Michael E. DeBakey VA Medical Center,Department Of Surgery, Division Of Surgical Oncology,Houston, TX, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The National Quality Forum (NQF) endorses adequate lymph node evaluation (ALNE), adjuvant chemotherapy (AC) administration, and AC within 4 months as quality metrics for colon cancer care. However, the current level of hospital performance on these measures is unknown as is correlation across measures within hospitals. As such, the study objectives were to evaluate trends in hospital NQF metric performance over time and to assess within hospital inter-metric correlation.

Methods: This was a retrospective cohort study of surgically resected, stage I-III colon cancer patients using the National Cancer Data Base (2003-2009). Hospital compliance with 3 NQF metrics (≥12 LN pathologically examined [ALNE]; AC administered to stage III patients; AC administered within 4 months of diagnosis for stage III patients <80 years of age) were calculated. Facilities were stratified into individual metric performance categories (very low [0-25%]; low [25-50%]; high [50-75%]; very high [>75%]). Performance over time, metric correlation among stage III patients, and factors associated with increasing metric achievement were evaluated using the Cochrane-Armitage test, Cramer's V test, and multivariate multinomial regression, respectively.

Results: Among 199,815 colon cancer patients treated at 1449 hospitals, there were significant improvements in all 3 metrics (ALNE—52.5% 2003 vs 84.4% 2009; AC administration—75.0% vs 80.9%; timely AC—69.3% vs 75.0%; trend test, p<0.001 for all). Over time, the proportion of patients who achieved all 3 metrics (42.5% vs 67.2%, trend test, p<0.001) and the proportion of hospitals in the very high performing category for each metric increased from 13.9% to 73.1% for ALNE (trend test, p<0.001), 56.6% to 64.1% for AC administration (trend test, p<0.001), and 46.6% to 53.8% for timely AC (trend test, p=0.014). The proportion of very high performing hospitals for all 3 metrics collectively increased significantly over time (15.7% in 2003 vs 42.1% in 2009, p<0.001) with good correlation between the two AC measures (V=0.84 in 2003 vs 0.80 in 2009), but poor correlation with ALNE (V<0.1). In a subgroup of patients at low risk for a postoperative complications, hospital aggregate metric performance was better (20.7% vs 52.4%, p<0.001), but correlation with ALNE was still poor (V≤0.1). Patient age, sex, comorbidity, and comprehensive cancer/academic programs were independently associated with metric performance.

Conclusions: Despite significant national improvement on each NQF metric individually, less than half of hospitals currently perform well on all 3 metrics collectively.
