This suggests quality improvement efforts directed at diseases benefiting from multimodality treatment could be made more robust by shifting focus from the individual components of care in isolation to the entire multidisciplinary care pathway and/or transitions from one treatment modality to the next.

abstract_title: Psychosocial Distress, Physiologic Stress Markers, and Frailty among Patients with Colorectal Cancer
author_block: D. Jomaa<sup>1</sup>, K. Maturen<sup>2</sup>, J. Krauss<sup>3</sup>, C. Veenstra<sup>3</sup>, A. M. Morris<sup>1</sup>  <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Radiology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical Oncology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Psychosocial distress among cancer patients impacts quality of care, resource use, and patient outcomes. Pooled data show that about 40% of breast and prostate cancer patients overall meet criteria for distress and its measurement is now mandated by the National Cancer Center Network (NCCN). Yet little is known of the level, nature, and physiologic correlates of distress, such as cortisol level and morphometric frailty, especially as they pertain to colorectal cancer.

Methods: After obtaining IRB approval, we surveyed all new patients in the University of Michigan Cancer Center's Multidisciplinary Colorectal Cancer Clinic using the NCCN Distress Thermometer and the Impact Thermometer, visual analog scale assessments of distress and impact of cancer diagnosis ranging from 0-10. Among those who consented to participate in the study, we collected salivary cortisol level and computed tomography morphometrics including psoas area and density. Continuous variables were analyzed using Pearson correlations and multiple linear regression was used to evaluate the contribution of multiple predictors of interest.

Results: 268 of 315 patients consented to participate in the study and 184 returned both surveys and saliva samples. 70 survey respondents (31%) indicated a moderate Distress Thermometer score of 4-6 which triggered an offer of referral to a social worker and 56 respondents (25%) indicated a severe Distress Thermometer score of 7-10, which triggered an offer of a referral to the Psycho-oncology service. The Distress and Impact Thermometer scores were highly correlated (R=0.78, p <.0001) with each other but not with psoas area or density measurements. In multivariate analysis, higher salivary cortisol (p=.02), lower age (p=.009), and presence of mental health cormorbidities (p=.001) were significantly correlated with the Impact Thermometer but not the Distress Thermometer score.

Conclusion: Distress is a common and serious comorbidity among cancer patients and warrants the attention it has drawn from accrediting bodies. Our data suggest that the patient-reported impact of distress may be a better indicator of a stressed physiologic state than distress itself, and that distress and frailty are not correlated. Patient reported measures of the impact of distress, when used in combination with physiologic measures of stress, can contribute to a more accurate and comprehensive understanding of distress and its underlying psychodynamic processes. These data could ideally be used to inform the development of appropriate, targeted interventions to alleviate the impact of distress and thereby enhance the quality of cancer care and outcomes.

abstract_title: Compliance to Breast Quality Measure for Radiation
author_block: E. F. Marcinkowski<sup>1</sup>, L. Goldstein<sup>1</sup>, A. C. Polverini<sup>1</sup>, L. Taylor<sup>1</sup>, J. Yim<sup>1</sup>, C. Vito<sup>1</sup>, L. Kruper<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>City Of Hope National Medical Center,Duarte, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The American College of Surgeons Commission on Cancer (CoC) has defined an Accountability Breast Measure that radiation therapy is administered within 1 year (365 days) of diagnosis for women under age 70 receiving breast conserving surgery for breast cancer. Estimated performance rates standard is 90%. The objective of this study is to examine historically compliance to these rates in California.

Methods: Using California Cancer Registry 2000-2011, we evaluated female breast cancer cases that met breast measure criteria for radiation within 1 year. Patients were excluded if radiation treatment data were not available. We examined rates of compliance to the breast measure and recommendations for radiation and evaluated differences by patient and hospital characteristics using Chi-Square tests. Tests for Trend by Age and Year of Diagnosis were examined Cochran - Armitage Trend Test.

Results:Among the 77,522 cases examined, 55,691 (71.8%) were compliant with the breast measure of having received radiation within 1 year of diagnosis. Among the 21,831 cases that did not have radiation within 1 year, 519 (2.4%) had radiation more than a year after diagnosis, 16,407 (75.1%) were not recommended radiation, 910 (4.2%) refused, and 41 patients (0.2%) had a contraindication due to other conditions. Rates overall varied by year from 66.8% to 74.4% (Chi – Square p<.0001). Married women were more likely to comply with guidelines than women who were not married (73.2% vs 70.3%, p<.0001). Non-Hispanic Whites were most likely to comply with guidelines (74.2%), followed by Asian/Pacific Islanders (72.2%), Hispanics (67.1%), Other Races (66.9%), and Non-Hispanic Blacks (62.4%, p<.0001). There was a significantly increasing trend in compliance with age (p<.0001), patients age 18-25 had lowest compliance at 60.2% and patients age 56-69 had highest compliance at 73.8%. Medicaid (65.3%) had the lowest rate of compliance (p<.0001). Los Angeles County, which contributes the largest number of patients in this cohort, had the lowest rate of compliance at 58.1% and the Northern California Bay Area including Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, San Francisco, and San Mateo counties had the highest rate of compliance at 82.3% (p<.0001). There was an increasing trend in compliance by SES quintile, Lowest SES had lowest compliance (64.0%) to highest SES (75.9%, p<.0001).

Conclusion:This study points to disparities in compliance to radiation within 1 year of diagnosis of breast cancer. Differences are observed by marital status, age, race, region, and insurance. These differences may point to needs of improved access to care by young minorities and others who may have limited access to quality cancer treatment.

abstract_title: Variability in Post-Op Resource Utilization Following Pancreaticoduodenectomy: Patient or Provider?
author_block: A. E. Ertel<sup>1</sup>, K. Wima<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Hoehn<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Chang<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Ahmad<sup>1</sup>, J. J. Sussman<sup>1</sup>, S. A. Shah<sup>1</sup>, D. E. Abbott<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Cincinnati Medical School,General Surgery,Cincinnati, OH, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Recognizing and reducing the variability in health care and especially elective surgery to deliver more consistent, cost-effective care is a top priority. We aimed to quantify and predict variability that exists in resource utilization following pancreaticoduodenctomy (PD) and determine how such variability impacts post-operative outcomes.

Methods: The University HealthSystems Consortium (UHC) database was queried for all PDs performed between 2011-2013 from 116 centers (n=9,737). A composite resource utilization score was created using equally weighted z-scores of 8 clinically significant post-operative care delivery variables based upon our institutional post-PD care plan. These included number of lab tests, imaging tests, CT scans, days on antibiotics (excluding day of procedure), days on anticoagulation, days on anti-emetics, days on pro-motility agents, and total number of blood products transfused per patient. Scores were then broken down into three equal groups: low, medium and high. Logistic, Poisson and gamma regression models were used to determine the effects of variability in utilization scores on post-operative outcomes and predictors of increased variability in care between patients.

Results: Predictors of increased cost and length of stay (LOS) following PD included patient age, severity of illness (SOI), and hospitalization at the time of operation. Extreme SOI was predictive of increased utilization of all 8 care variables (p<0.01). Having a high resource utilization score following PD (vs. low) correlated with increased LOS (RR 2.28, 95% CI 2.2-2.3, p<0.01), cost (RR 1.92, 95% CI 1.9-2.0, p<0.01), and readmission rate (OR 1.48, 95% CI 1.3-1.7, p<0.01). Mortality was unaffected by the degree of variability. While increasing age predicted decreased resource use, predictors of increased resource use included extreme SOI, government vs. private insurance, hospitalization at the time of operation and high volume centers. (Table) 34.6% of patients at high volume centers were classified as extreme SOI compared to 5.8% & 2.6% (p<0.01) at medium and low volume centers, respectively while surgeon volume was not a predictor of variability (p=0.06).

Conclusion: These data demonstrate that there is significant variation in resource utilization between patients undergoing PD. This increased variation is associated with both inferior outcomes and higher costs, which are driven by patient-specific risk factors. Publically available outcome monitoring and reimbursement should consider that much of the variability following complex pancreatic surgery may not be provider-related.

abstract_title: Paradoxical Relationship Between Stage and Survival in Intermediate Stage Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma
author_block: D. S. Swords<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Firpo<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Johnson<sup>1</sup>, K. M. Boucher<sup>2</sup>, C. L. Scaife<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Mulvihill<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Utah,General Surgery,Salt Lake City, UT, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Utah,Study Design And Biostatistics Center,Salt Lake City, UT, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The TMN staging system of the American Joint Commission on Cancer (AJCC) is designed to stratify patients by anatomic extent of disease. It is expected that patients with progressively advanced stages will experience shorter survival. We examined how well the AJCC staging system predicted survival for patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) in the Surveillance, Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) research database. In an attempt to account for discrepancies in survival in intermediate stages in SEER data we also investigated the accuracy of clinical nodal staging in resected patients from our institution.

Methods: Data were abstracted from SEER Database from 2004-2012 and filtered for PDAC with known stage. The relation between stage and disease-specific survival was evaluated using Kaplan-Meier and Cox proportional hazard analyses. We also evaluated 110 consecutive cases at our facility from 2001-2014 that proceeded to resection without neoadjuvant therapy, comparing differences in clinical and pathological staging.

Results: 44,744 SEER cases met inclusion criteria. Median age was 67 and 51.7% were male. Tumor location was 52% in the head of the pancreas, 12% in the body, and 13% in the tail. Overall, resection was recommended in 25% and performed in 21%. In Stages IB and IIA resection was recommended in 39% and performed in 34% whereas in Stage IIB it was recommended in 73% and performed in 72%. Intermediate stages did not correlate well with the expected inverse relationship between stage and survival. We found longer survival for stage IIB than for stage IB (p<0.0001, log-rank test) and stage IIA (p<0.0001, log-rank test). However, in resected cases with pathological staging the expected inverse relationship between survival and extent of disease was evident (Figure 1). In 110 resected PDAC cases from our institution without neoadjuvant therapy, 89/110 (81%) were classified as N0 by clinical staging, whereas only 33/110 (30%) were N0 by pathological staging (p < 0.0001, Chi Square test). Only 40/110 (36%) were correctly classified for nodal status by clinical staging, with 26/110 (24%) correctly identified as N0 and 14/110 (13%) as N1. In the incorrectly classified cases, 63/70 (90%) were up-staged from N0 to N1 by pathological staging.

Conclusion: In evaluating AJCC staging of PDAC patients, survival between Stages IB, IIA, and IIB is paradoxical to what would be expected. This is likely due to clinical underestimation of nodal involvement. The high rates of surgical recommendation and resection in Stage IIB patients may reflect stage migration of patients due to unexpected nodal involvement. These findings have implications for treatment decisions in patients with intermediate stage PDAC.

abstract_title: Non-cirrhotics with early hepatocellular cancer survive longer after resection compared to ablation
author_block: R. T. Groeschl<sup>1</sup>, M. Tee<sup>1</sup>, D. Nagorney<sup>1</sup>, R. Smoot<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic,Department Of Surgery,Rochester, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: By Barcelona criteria, ablation is favored over liver resection in several subgroups of non-transplantable patients with early (≤ 3 cm) hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The comparative overall survival (OS) benefit of thermoablation and resection was tested in patients with small solitary tumors.

Methods: Patients diagnosed with solitary HCC ≤ 3 cm between 2004-2012 from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End-Results (SEER) database were stratified by degree of hepatic fibrosis. OS and the prognostic impact of covariates were tested with Kaplan-Meier curves and log-rank tests. Cox proportional hazards model results were expressed as hazard ratios (HR) and [95% confidence interval].

Results: There were 466 cirrhotic patients (348 thermoablation, 118 resection) and 159 non-cirrhotic patients (74 thermoablation, 85 resection) included for analysis. The median OS after thermoablation and resection was similar (54 vs 50 months, p = 0.36) in cirrhotic patients, and the lack of an OS difference based on treatment persisted in adjusted models. Alpha-fetoprotein elevation (HR: 1.55 [1.03-2.32], p = 0.03) and male gender (HR: 1.62 [1.09-2.42], p = 0.02) were associated with shorter OS. In non-cirrhotics, the median OS after resection was greater than after ablation (87 vs 57 months, p = 0.05, Figure 1), which was reinforced in adjusted models. A subset analysis of very early (≤ 2 cm) tumors in non-cirrhotics also suggested improved survival with resection (p = 0.03).

Conclusion: Cirrhotic patients with small, solitary HCC have equivalent survival if treated with thermoablation or liver resection. However, these results question an ablation-first strategy in non-cirrhotic patients with early HCC, as the survival after hepatectomy was superior in this population. Longer survival was also demonstrated with resection for very early (≤ 2 cm) tumors, which challenges current recommendations.

abstract_title: The Dynamic Impact of Frailty on Surgical Outcomes: The Right Patient for the Right Procedure
author_block: C. Mosquera<sup>1</sup>, K. Spaniolas<sup>2</sup>, H. S. Vora<sup>1</sup>, T. L. Fitzgerald<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine,Division Of Surgical Oncology,Greenville, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>East Carolina University Brody School Of Medicine,Division Of Bariatric And Minimally Invasive Surgery,Greenville, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Optimal patient selection is critical to ensure high quality outcomes. Current indices, such as ASA or Charlson, fail to account for the importance of functional status. In order to better quantify the impact of frailty on surgical outcomes a for high-risk procedures, a large national outcomes dataset was reviewed.

Methods: Data were obtained from the NSQIP database. Patients who underwent elective high-risk surgical procedures (colectomy, pancreatectomy, gastrectomy, esophagectomy, nephrectomy, lower extremity bypass (LEB), endovascular AAA repair (E-AAA), pulmonary resection, and cardiac procedures) from 2005-2012 were included. An 11-point frailty index classified patients as non-fraill (0 points), mild frailty (1 point), moderate frailty (2 points), or severe frailty (≥ 3 points).

Results:A total of 230,212 patients were included. Mean age was 65 years, a majority were male (54%) and white (78%). The most common procedure was colectomy (42%) followed by LEB (25%), gastrectomy (8%), E-AAA (7%), pancreatectomy (7%), cardiac procedures (5%), nephrectomy (3%), pulmonary resection (2%) and esophagectomy (1%). The majority of the patients were mildly frail (34%), followed by non-frail (29%), moderately frail (21%), and severely frail (15%). Complications occurred in 25% of patients, 40% of these were minor. Median LOS was 5 days, prolonged LOS (>16 days) occurred in 7.5%, and 30-day mortality was 2%. On univariate analysis age, race, procedure, gender, and frailty score were significantly different in patients who had complications, prolonged LOS, and or 30-day mortality (p<0.0001). On multivariate logistic regression escalation in frailty was independently associated with complications (mild OR, 1.19 p<0.0001; moderate OR, 1.68 p<0.0001; and severe OR 2.72, p<0.0001), prolonged LOS (mild OR 1.20, p<0.0001; moderate OR 1.73, p<0.0001; and severe OR 3.94, p<0.0001), and 30-day mortality (mild OR 1.68, p<0.0001; moderate OR 2.92, p<0.0001; and severe OR 6.49, p<0.0001). Increasing frailty disproportionately impacted mortality for respective procedures (Figure 1). Colectomy had the highest mortality in severely frail patients (9.36%), followed by esophagectomy (8.2%), pulmonary resection (6.4%), pancreatectomy (5.8%), cardiac procedures (4.4%), gastrectomy (4.3%), nephrectomy (3.32%), E-AAA (2.49%), and LEB (2.41%), (p=0.0001). A similar increment in LOS and morbidity was noted with frailty escalation.

Conclusion: Frailty has a significant impact on postoperative outcomes that varies with type of procedure. Identification of the frail patient is of paramount importance for both the patient and surgeon to determine surgical risk.

abstract_title: Lung Cancer Sampling Method for CD8<sup>+</sup> T Cell Count Affects Assessment of Patient Outcomes
author_block: J. M. Obeid<sup>1</sup>, Y. Hu<sup>1</sup>, D. Deacon<sup>1</sup>, W. Olson<sup>1</sup>, I. Mauldin<sup>1</sup>, M. Melssen<sup>1</sup>, C. L. Slingluff<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Non small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) can respond dramatically to immune therapy, but biomarkers predicting response remain to be defined. Infiltration by CD8+ T lymphocytes may predict response to immune therapy and improved survival; however, associations between CD8 counts and clinical outcomes vary across studies. We hypothesize that this inconsistency may be explained by differences in tumor sampling methods used for quantifying CD8+ tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TIL).

Methods: Twenty-four formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded samples of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) were stained for CD8 T cells. Slides were scanned with Leica SCN400 ScanScope and analyzed using automated image analysis software (Leica Digital Image Hub). CD8+ cell counts were assessed using eight different sampling methods. (A) whole tumor, (B) weighted average of high and low TIL density areas, (C) central tumor sampling (CTS), (D) dense lymphoid aggregates (DLA),(E) invasive margin sampling, (F) a random sample of 1 mm diameter (random1), and (G) a random sampling comprising 20% of the tumor area (random20%). We also simulated sampling a 10x1 mm core biopsy (H). Results from the different methods were compared to the whole tumor by paired T-tests. For each method, we also tested whether survival was better for tumors with high CD8+ density (greater than median).

Results: CD8 counts using F and H methods were not significantly different from whole tumor counts, with differences of 25% (p=0.17) and 8% (p=0.21) respectively. Counts obtained by B-E and G were significantly different from A, by +37% (p=0.0004), -14% (p=0.014), +350% (p<0.0001), +54% (p=0.0025) and -15% (p=0.046) respectively. Only the CTS method (C) yielded CD8 TIL counts significantly associated with overall survival (p=0.038) (figure). Other sampling methods yielded CD8 counts that were not associated with survival.

Conclusion: The distribution of CD8+ TIL is heterogeneous within NSCLC tumors so that different sampling methods yield significantly different results. Interestingly, only CD8 counts obtained by sampling the central tumor tissue were associated with patient outcomes, whereas counts of the whole tumor specimen did not. This finding suggests that CD8 T cell density within the center of the tumor, rather than at the margins, may be a valuable prognostic biomarker. Further studies with large patient numbers are recommended to validate these findings, and to test whether CD8 T cell counts in the center of the tumor predict response to immune therapy.

abstract_title: Laparoscopic vs. Open Adrenalectomy for Adrenocortical Carcinoma: Does Technique Matter?
author_block: A. I. Salem<sup>1</sup>, T. B. Tran<sup>2</sup>, G. A. Poultsides<sup>2</sup>, S. K. Maithel<sup>3</sup>, T. S. Wang<sup>4</sup>, I. Hatzaras<sup>5</sup>, J. E. Phay<sup>6</sup>, R. C. Fields<sup>7</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>8</sup>, J. D. Prescott<sup>8</sup>, S. Gad<sup>9</sup>, A. C. Yopp<sup>10</sup>, Q. Duh<sup>11</sup>, C. C. Solorzano<sup>12</sup>, C. M. Kiernan<sup>12</sup>, K. I. Votanopoulos<sup>13</sup>, S. M. Weber<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin School Of Medicine And Public Health,Department Of Surgery,Madison, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Stanford University,Department Of Surgery,Palo Alto, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Emory University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Atlanta, GA, USA <sup>4</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Department Of Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>5</sup>New York University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,New York, NY, USA <sup>6</sup>Ohio State University,Department Of Surgery,Columbus, OH, USA <sup>7</sup>Washington University,Department Of Surgery,St. Louis, MO, USA <sup>8</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>9</sup>University Of California - San Diego,Department Of Surgery,San Diego, CA, USA <sup>10</sup>University Of Texas Southwestern Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Dallas, TX, USA <sup>11</sup>University Of California - San Francisco,Department Of Surgery,San Francisco, CA, USA <sup>12</sup>Vanderbilt University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Nashville, TN, USA <sup>13</sup>Wake Forest University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Winston-Salem, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Background:The role of laparoscopic resection for adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is controversial. Few data are available on surgical outcome and survival benefit. We sought to evaluate the perioperative and long-term outcomes following laparoscopic and open resection of adrenocortical carcinoma.

Methods: Retrospective data collection of patients who underwent adrenalectomy for pathologically confirmed primary adrenocortical carcinoma in 13 experienced tertiary care cancer centers were analyzed, including demographics, clinicopathological features, and operative outcomes. Outcomes following laparoscopic resection were compared to open resection.

Results:A total of 242 patients were evaluated, including 42 laparoscopic (LAP) and 200 open resections. There was no difference in utilization of LAP approach amongst institutions (p=0.24). There was no difference in in-hospital mortality (0%, LAP vs 2.7%, open, p=0.31) or overall 30-day morbidity (27%, LAP vs 35%, open, p=0.44). The only preoperatively determined predictor of utilization of a LAP approach was radiological size (p<0.001). Of note, utilization of a LAP approach was not associated with tumor laterality, body mass index, or functional tumor status. On univariable analysis, there were a number of perioperative factors associated with utilization of LAP adrenalectomy (Table 1). There was no difference in rates of intraoperative tumor rupture or R0 resection rates. Although there was an association of improved median overall survival in the LAP group on univariable analysis (100 mo. vs 37 mo., p=0.03), after adjusting for age, tumor size, lymphatic invasion and estimated blood loss, there was no difference in overall survival (OR=0.998, p=0.89, CI=0.972 – 1.025).

Conclusion:Although LAP adrenalectomy was utilized for smaller tumors, there was no association of choice of LAP approach with body mass index, laterality, or functional tumor status. Improvements in perioperative outcomes for LAP cases included estimated blood loss, operative time, and length of hospital stay, without differences in morbidity, mortality, R0 status, or incidence of intraoperative tumor rupture. Randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm the findings of this study.

abstract_title: Extending Clinical Application of Intraoperative CT and Navigation System beyond Neurosurgical Field
author_block: J. Yang<sup>1</sup>, M. Lin<sup>1</sup>, M. Lee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Chang Gung Memorial Hospital,Neurosurgical Department,Chia-Yi, CHIA-YI, Taiwan
abstract_body:
Introduction: Intraoperative imaging and navigation are important components of the hybrid operating room . It plays an important role in surgery as it provides detailed anatomical orientation allowing precise localization of the hidden pathology and delineation of nearby critical structures.

Methods: The platform is an integration of an imaging system, either CT or MRI compatible with an intraoperative use, and a navigation system with a computer software that allows the merging of multi-modal images taken preoperatively for the use of simulations and real-time navigation. The setup improves the accuracy of the navigation system over traditional devices as it can register up-to-date reference images for the navigation system and enable serial visual assessment of the target of interest intraoperatively.

Results:This unique interface of the navigation device guides the surgical decision-making process resulting in safer and more accurate surgical procedures. The application of intraoperative imaging and navigation includes resection of intrinsic and skull base brain tumours; implantation of electrodes for neurostimulation; instrumentation in spine surgery; rhizotomy procedures for various painful conditions such as trigeminal neuralgia, thoracolumbar compression fractures and cancer related pain; and identification of new areas of multiple injury in trauma. The greatest potential lies in delicate surgeries that are approached through minimal invasive accesses that have confined surgical fields and limited orientating landmarks.

Conclusion:The use of intraoperative CT and navigation system is not limited to neurosurgery, but potentially could be applied in situations where intraoperative imaging or navigation is required. The current and future clinical applications of intraoperative CT and navigation system beyond the neurosurgical field will be discussed.

abstract_title: Surgery and Basic Science: An Identity Crisis
author_block: S. G. Keswani<sup>1</sup>, C. M. Moles<sup>1</sup>, M. Morowitz<sup>2</sup>, M. Levine<sup>3</sup>, N. Ahuja<sup>4</sup>, H. Zeh<sup>5</sup>, J. Kuo<sup>6</sup>, A. M. Goldstein<sup>7</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Baylor College Of Medicine,Houston, TX, USA <sup>2</sup>Children's Hospital Of Pittsburgh Of UPMC,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Philadelphia, PA, USA <sup>4</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>5</sup>University Of Pittsburgh Medical Center,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>6</sup>University Of Wisconsin School Of Medicine And Public Health,Madison, WI, USA <sup>7</sup>Harvard School Of Medicine,Brookline, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgeons have a long legacy of major contributions in basic/translational scientific investigation. However, currently there are several factors that are impeding the progress of surgeons succeeding in basic science. We sought to examine the challenges to becoming a successful basic investigator in today's academic surgery environment.

Methods: We conducted a survey of all members of the Association for Academic Surgery and Society of University Surgeons via an online survey, which included demographic questions to identify subgroups within the sample population and questions to identify challenges affecting basic science research. Data presented as reporting percentage and statistical analysis by t-test.

Results: A total of 1033 (41%) members, evenly divided in academic rank responded to the survey; results are accurate within a confidence interval of 95%±3% on account of the high response rate. We found 75% of surgeons who do clinical research do not believe that surgeons can be successful as basic scientists, whereas 55% of basic scientists responded this way (p<.05). Interestingly, 66% of chairmen and division chiefs also believe it's unrealistic for a surgeon to be a successful basic scientist, yet 53% of these surgical leaders indicate that surgical departments conduct too little basic science research. Surgeons most often cited the funding environment and clinical demands as the main impediments to success in basic research. Excessive administrative duties also significantly impact the ability of surgeons to conduct research, which increases with seniority. Mentorship was not identified as a key factor for academic success, although participants reported basic science mentors were more engaged than clinical mentors. Regarding funding sources, there is a perception that basic science is significantly more often supported by the NIH and surgical societies compared to clinical science. The results revealed that 80% of junior faculty conducting clinical research are unfunded, as compared to 50% of their peers in basic science (p<.05). Moreover, 59% of participants reported that the challenging funding environment has no effect on their interest in basic research.

Conclusion: We have identified critical barriers confronting surgeons pursuing basic science. These include the difficult funding environment, excessive clinical demands, and perhaps an overall belief that surgeons can't succeed in basic science. The robust response rate to the survey supports the critical nature of this topic. These findings are important for trainees and junior faculty as they consider their career path and to senior faculty exploring strategies to increase interest and participation in basic science. The data suggest there may be an identity crisis among surgeons who have historically often been pushed toward basic research and now find themselves in a new environment where multiple external pressures make that pursuit more challenging.

abstract_title: Does Conversion from Minimally Invasive to Open Surgery for Diverticulitis Portend Worse Outcomes?
author_block: S. R. Sprinkle<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sun<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Adam<sup>1</sup>, J. Kim<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Yerokun<sup>1</sup>, J. Migaly<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Mantyh<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Department Of Surgery,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diverticulitis represents a common disease that is routinely treated by surgical resection. Although the laparoscopic approach is favored, some authors have raised concerns that conversion to an open surgery results in outcomes that are inferior to both laparoscopic and open procedures. However, these published reports are limited by small sample sizes and lack of generalizability. Using a large risk-stratified database, this study examines the effect on outcomes of conversion from a minimally invasive to an open procedure for diverticulitis.

Methods: Adult patients from the 2012-2013 Colectomy-Targeted National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) database who underwent elective segmental colectomy for diverticulitis were grouped by completed surgical approach: minimally invasive surgery (MIS), MIS converted to open, and planned open surgery. Multivariable regression methods were utilized to evaluate the effect of conversion on perioperative outcomes.

Results:Among 3,263 patients included, 2,272 (70%) underwent MIS, 276 (8%) had MIS converted to open surgery, and 715 (22%) had planned open surgery. Age was the only independent predictor of conversion (adjusted odds ratio [OR] 1.016, p < 0.01). After adjusting for demographic, clinical, and treatment factors, there were no significant differences in overall complications, postoperative ileus, anastomotic leak, readmission, or reoperation between converted and planned open surgeries. The conversion group had a decrease in length of stay (-0.4 days, 95% CI -0.6 to -0.2) but an increase in wound complications (OR 1.55, 95% CI 1.08 – 2.24) (all p <0.05). MIS was associated with a significant reduction in overall complications (OR 0.49, 95% CI 0.38 – 0.63), ileus (OR 0.37, 95% CI 0.28 – 0.50), readmission (OR 0.71, 95% CI 0.51 – 0.99), length of stay (-1.2 days, 95% CI -1.3 to -1.1) and wound complications (OR 0.61, 95% CI 0.46 – 0.81) when compared to converted procedures (all p<0.05).

Conclusion:Using the most recent NSQIP colorectal database, laparoscopic conversion to open surgery for diverticulitis does not result in worse overall outcomes than a standard open approach. However, completing the procedure laparoscopically is associated with significant perioperative benefits compared to converted or planned open surgery. This suggests that an attempt at laparoscopic resection should be strongly considered for all patients with diverticular disease.

abstract_title: Sarcopenia as a Prognostic Factor in Emergency Abdominal Surgery
author_block: R. C. Dirks<sup>1</sup>, B. L. Edwards<sup>1</sup>, E. Tong<sup>1</sup>, B. Schaheen<sup>1</sup>, F. E. Turrentine<sup>1</sup>, A. L. Shada<sup>2</sup>, P. W. Smith<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Virginia,General Surgery,Charlottesville, VA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Wisconsin,Surgery,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sarcopenia, a loss of skeletal muscle mass associated with aging, is a practical measure of frailty and has been previously identified as a predictor of outcomes in surgical cohorts including cancer resection and elderly patients. We hypothesize that sarcopenia, as measured by preoperative CT scans of the psoas muscle, predicts mortality and morbidity in emergent laparotomy.

Methods: Institutional NSQIP data were queried for adult patients who underwent open emergency abdominal surgery between 2008 and 2013. Patient demographics, clinical variables, and outcomes were extracted from NSQIP. Patients with abdominal CT scans within 30 days prior to surgery were included and the cross sectional areas of the psoas muscles at vertebral level L4 were summed and normalized by patient height. Patients were assigned to sex-stratified tertiles based on this normalized total psoas area (TPA) for analysis, with the lowest tertile being classified as sarcopenic. Kaplan Meier curves were constructed to compare survival between TPA tertiles. Cox Proportional Hazards models stratified by sex and controlling for ASA score, ascites, International Normalized Ratio (INR), functional dependency and work Relative Value Units as a proxy for surgery complexity were used to evaluate the influence of TPA on postoperative mortality.

Results: NSQIP revealed 781 patients undergoing emergent open abdominal surgery and 593 of these (75.9%) had appropriate preoperative CT scans. Median patient age was 61 years (IQR 50-72), median TPA was 1719 mm2 (IQR 1341-2293), and median BMI was 26.7kg/m2 (22.9-33). Bivariable analysis demonstrated that TPA was significantly associated with total postoperative morbidity (p=0.013), increased length of stay (p<0.0001) and 90-day mortality (p=0.0008) but not 30-day mortality (p=0.26). Kaplan Meier curves demonstrated significantly decreased 90-day survival in lowest TPA tertile. A Cox proportional hazards model demonstrated that the impact of TPA was overwhelmed by previously validated predictors of mortality, most notably ASA score.

Conclusion: Sarcopenia, as measured by TPA, is significantly associated with increased 90-day mortality, length of stay, and total morbidity in patients undergoing open emergency abdominal surgery. Since many patients undergoing emergent abdominal surgery have already undergone CT scanning, TPA is readily available to the practicing surgeon at no added risk or cost. As such, sarcopenia is a convenient additional tool for preoperative risk assessment and risk counseling.

abstract_title: Age of Transfused Blood: Impact on Postoperative Outcomes Among Patients undergoing Abdominal Surgery
author_block: Y. Kim<sup>1</sup>, N. Amini<sup>1</sup>, F. Gani<sup>1</sup>, D. Wagner<sup>1</sup>, G. A. Margonis<sup>1</sup>, P. Ness<sup>2</sup>, S. Buttner<sup>1</sup>, L. Xu<sup>1</sup>, A. Tobian<sup>2</sup>, R. Goel<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Frank<sup>2</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Anesthesiology And Critical Care Medicine,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients undergoing surgery often receive packed red blood cell (PRBC) transfusions. The effect of PRBC age (i.e. storage duration before transfusion) on perioperative surgical outcomes remains poorly defined. We sought to define the impact of transfused PRBC age on peri-operative morbidity among patients undergoing hepatic, pancreatic and colorectal resections.

Methods: We identified 1,341 patients who underwent hepatic, pancreatic, and colorectal resections who received ≥1 unit of PRBCs between 2009-2014. Data on PRBC age and clinicopathological characteristics were collected. Factors associated with perioperative outcomes were assessed using modified Poisson regression.

Results: 5,771 PRBC units were transfused (median units per patient transfused 2, IQR:2, 4). 913 (68.1%) patients received only units of blood that had been stored ≤30 days ('fresh' blood), while 428 (31.9%) patients received at least one unit of PRBC that had been stored for >30 days ('older' blood). Following surgery, one in three patients (33.1%) experienced a postoperative complication. The incidence of postoperative complications (43.2% vs. 23.4%) and prolonged hospital stay (34.6% vs. 16.7%) were higher among patients who received 'older' vs. 'fresh' blood (both P<0.001). On multivariable analysis, factors associated with a higher risk of postoperative complications included coagulopathy (RR=1.55), FFP transfusion (RR=1.25), total number of units transfused (>5 units: RR=1.36), as well as 'older' blood (RR=1.32, Figure, all P<0.05). Receipt of 'older' blood also remained associated with a prolonged hospital stay (RR=1.6, P=0.001).

Conclusion: The use of 'older' blood was an independent predictor of postoperative morbidity among patients undergoing hepatic, pancreatic and colorectal procedures. Transfusion of 'older' blood products may contribute to a higher risk of postoperative complications.

abstract_title: Direct Perineural Bupivicaine Injection Reduces Inguinodynia after Inguinal Hernia Repair
author_block: G. W. Donald<sup>1</sup>, A. Dawes<sup>1,2,3</sup>, J. Crompton<sup>1</sup>, M. Livhits<sup>1</sup>, C. Chandler<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of California - Los Angeles,Department Of General Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>2</sup>Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Medical Center,Robert Woods Johnson Clinical Scholars Program,Los Angeles, CA, USA <sup>3</sup>Fielding UCLA School Of Public Health,Department Of Health Policy And Management,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Chronic inguinodynia after open inguinal hernia repair is remarkably common, occurring in 13-37% of cases. To date, there are no published studies comparing local anesthesia techniques to reduce the incidence of this problem. We sought to determine the effect of direct perineural infiltration to diminish acute and chronic pain following open inguinal hernia repair.

Methods: Patients who presented with an inguinal hernia were recruited consecutively from a single general surgeon's clinic and were prospectively randomized to either 1) percutaneous ilioinguinal nerve block, or 2) percutaneous ilioinguinal nerve block with additional perineural infiltration of the ilioinguinal, iliohypogastric, genitofemoral nerves. All patients, in each group, recieved a total of 12 cc 0.5% bupivicaine. Self-reported faces of pain level (1-10), minutes to discharge, narcotic quantity consumed (percocet 5/325), days on narcotics, and inguinodynia at 3 months were all recorded.

Results: Ninety-one patients were randomized (46 in group 1, 46 in group 2). Patients in the treatment group had: less recovery room pain (1.23 vs. 3.71, p<0.001), shorter recovery discharge times (87.9 vs. 105.8 mins, p=0.0394), and consumed fewer narcotics (9.29 vs. 13.90 pills, p=0.019) over fewer days (3.19 vs. 4.32, p=0.055). The rate of inguinodynia at 3 months was less in the treatment group (8.7% vs. 24.4%, p=0.047)

Conclusion: We have implemented a novel and inexpensive method of local nerve blockade that decreases pain immediately after surgery and at 3 months post-operatively. Furthermore, our method leads to shorter recovery room stay, consumption of fewer narcotics after surgery.

abstract_title: Surgical and Post-Operative Risk Factors for Lymphedema Following Lymphadenectomy for Melanoma
author_block: S. J. Diljak<sup>1</sup>, R. D. Kramer<sup>1</sup>, R. J. Strobel<sup>1</sup>, B. Sunkara<sup>1</sup>, D. J. Mercante<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Jehnsen<sup>1</sup>, J. F. Friedman<sup>1</sup>, A. Durham<sup>2</sup>, M. Cohen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Department Of Dermatology,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Secondary lymphedema (SLE) is a significant complication following lymphadenectomy in melanoma patients, with a reported incidence between 9-25% for axillary dissection (ALND) and as high as 24-44% for inguinal dissections (ILND). While radiation therapy and tumor burden are positive predictors for arm lymphedema in breast cancer, this has not been as well defined in the melanoma population using large cohorts. The purpose of this study is to identify unique post-operative and surgical risk factors for SLE in patients with regionally metastatic melanoma using the largest cohort to date compiled from a prospectively collected database of melanoma patients following an ALND or ILND.

Methods: From a prospectively collected, IRB-approved database we identified 688 melanoma patients receiving a complete lymphadenectomy (June 2005-June 2015) with 557 patients having either an ALND or ILND. Patients having iliac or bilateral dissections, or pre-op chemotherapy were excluded. Demographic, clinical, and post-op data were reviewed from the electronic medical record (EMR). SLE was defined as being mentioned in more than one post-operative note or a documented referral to the lymphedema clinic. Univariate statistical analysis and odds ratios (OR) with 95% confidence intervals (CI) were used to determine independent post-op and surgical predictors of SLE.

Results: Of the cohort of 557 melanoma patients, 119 (21.4%) developed SLE following lymph node dissection. The cohort was split between ALND (N=322 (57.8%); 10.9% with SLE) and ILND (N=235 (42.2%); 35.7% with SLE). On univariate logistic regression [Table], having an ILND (OR=4.58; CI: 2.95-7.11), post-operative adjuvant (OR=1.61 CI: 1.07-2.42) or radiation therapy (OR=1.81 CI: 1.02-3.22), and developing non-SLE complications (e.g. hematoma, infection, DVT) (OR=1.84 CI: 1.21-2.80), were each significantly associated with an increased risk of developing SLE. Non-SLE post-op complications increased the risk of SLE only in the first 2 months after surgery (OR=2.25 CI: 1.35-3.74). Use of an energy device during surgery, number of nodes removed, blood loss, and operative times were not significantly associated with risk of SLE. The average post-op time to develop SLE was 103 ± 126 days and follow-up was 1.9 ± 2.2 years.

Conclusion: This is the largest study to date evaluating surgical/post-op risk factors for SLE in melanoma patients after ALND or ILND. Post-operative factors significantly increasing the risk of SLE include adjuvant or radiation therapy, having an ILND, or non-SLE post-op complications. We believe that this work, combined with further evaluation of patient pre-op characteristics, will enhance informed clinical decision-making and risk assessment.

abstract_title: True Blood: Bleeding Management for Rivaroxaban vs Warfarin in Emergency General Surgery and Trauma
author_block: S. Myers<sup>1</sup>, J. Brown<sup>1</sup>, M. Kutcher<sup>1</sup>, E. Dadashzadeh<sup>1</sup>, J. Cheung<sup>1</sup>, M. Neal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh Medical Center,Department Of General Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Rivaroxaban, a novel factor Xa inhibitor, has gained popularity as an anticoagulant (AC) for stroke prevention in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (afib) and venous thromboembolism (VTE). Although adverse bleeding events are associated with all AC, the inability to directly measure the physiologic effect of rivaroxaban in emergent situations has contributed to perceived increased risk and tempered enthusiasm for the drug amongst acute care and emergency physicians. The study objective was to describe a single center experience with trauma and emergency general surgery (EGS) patients taking rivaroxaban and evaluate outcomes compared with patients taking warfarin in this population.

Methods: Trauma and EGS patients taking rivaroxaban or warfarin for afib or VTE over a 2yr period at a single quaternary referral center were eligible for inclusion. Rivaroxaban and warfarin patients were matched for injury/illness severity in a 1:2 ratio using propensity score matching. The primary outcome was bleeding complications, defined as hemorrhage from any source during admission or as a presenting problem. Secondary outcomes included invasive interventions, AC reversal, VTE complications, and mortality. Conditional logistic regression determined the association of AC type with bleeding complications, adjusting for age, sex, AC indication, coagulation laboratory values, antiplatelet medications or other AC, comorbidities, renal impairment, and operative intervention.

Results: 192 warfarin patients were matched to 96 rivaroxaban patients (49% EGS, 51% trauma). Groups were well matched with no significant difference in age, sex, admission SBP, admission HR, admission hemoglobin, ISS in trauma patients, or need for ICU admission (p>0.05 for all). There was no difference between rivaroxaban and warfarin groups for bleeding complications (37% vs 39%, p=0.59), VTE complications (4.2% vs 5.7%, p=0.52), or mortality (4.2% vs 5.8%, p=0.60). Fewer rivaroxaban patients underwent surgical or interventional radiology (IR) procedures during admission (32% vs 43%, p=0.03), but there was no difference in surgical or IR procedures for bleeding (10% vs 12% p=0.74). Rivaroxaban patients were less likely to undergo AC reversal (34% vs 46%, p=0.02) or receive multiple reversal agents (20% vs 29%, p=0.04). Regression analysis confirmed AC type was not associated with bleeding complications (rivaroxaban vs warfarin OR 0.83; 95%CI 0.33-2.07, p=0.69).

Conclusion: Bleeding events occur commonly in a moderately ill, matched cohort of trauma and EGS patients using rivaroxaban or warfarin. Reversal of rivaroxaban was less common and intense than for warfarin; despite this, bleeding complications and hemostatic interventions do not appear different between these AC types. A quantitative assay to monitor the effect of these agents may further reduce bleeding events, VTE, and reduce delays in care by guiding reversal and management strategies.

abstract_title: Preoperative Gabapentin Decreases Postoperative Opioid Requirements- A Meta-analysis
author_block: S. Arumugam<sup>1</sup>, C. Lau<sup>1</sup>, R. Chamberlain<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Saint Barnabas Medical Center,Surgery,Livingston, NJ, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gabapentin, an anti-epileptic is currently used for the treatment of neuropathic pain. Opioids are widely used as analgesics to minimize postoperative pain, but their use is associated with various side effects as well as the potential for addiction. The versatility of gabapentin in treating a wide array of pain conditions and its favorable side effect profile has generated interest in its use in preemptive analgesia. This meta-analysis aimed to critically examine the ability of preoperative gabapentin to reduce postoperative opioid use and its' side effects.

Methods: A comprehensive literature search of Pub Med, Google Scholar, and Cochrane Review (1966-2015) was performed to identify all randomized control trials (RCTs) assessing efficacy of preoperative gabapentin in reducing postoperative opioid consumption. Key words searched included combinations of 'preemptive analgesia' 'gabapentin', 'postoperative pain'. Inclusion criteria included: RCTs comparing preoperative gabapentin administration to control which included an assessment of opioid usage in adult patients undergoing elective surgery. Data were extracted on cumulative opioid consumption within the first 24 hours (hrs) postoperative period and the incidence of nausea, vomiting and somnolence.

Results:16 RCTs involving 1,543 patients were included (770 patients received gabapentin and 773 patients received placebo or no therapy). Opioid consumption was significantly decreased in the gabapentin group (standard mean difference [SMD]: -1.211, 95% CI -1.76 to -0.65; p<0.001) at 24 hrs postoperatively. Subgroup analysis revealed a significant reduction in the morphine (SMD: -0.885, 95% CI: - 1.34 to -0.42;p<0.001), fentanyl (SMD: -2.39, 95% CI: -3.49 to -1.29; p<0.001) and tramadol consumption (SMD: -1.116, 95% CI: -2.05 to -0.22; p<0.05) in the gabapentin group. Preoperative gabapentin had no significant effect on postoperative nausea (RR=1.088; 95% CI 0.87 to 1.34; p=0.44) and vomiting (RR=0.839; 95% CI 0.61 to 1.51; p=0.277).

Conclusion:Preoperative gabapentin administration reduces opioid use in the first 24 hours postoperatively. The decreased need for postoperative opioids with the use of preoperative gabapentin was associated with some increase in postoperative somnolence, but no significant difference in the incidence of nausea and vomiting. Gabapentin is an efficacious adjunct for postoperative analgesia. Additional studies are required to optimize the gabapentin dose and timing.

abstract_title: Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Blinded Trial: ICG Angiography In Abdominal Wall Reconstruction
author_block: C. R. Huntington<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Wormer<sup>1</sup>, S. W. Ross<sup>1</sup>, P. D. Colavita<sup>1</sup>, T. Prasad<sup>1</sup>, A. E. Lincourt<sup>1</sup>, I. Belyansky<sup>2</sup>, S. B. Getz<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Heniford<sup>1</sup>, V. A. Augenstein<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Carolinas Medical Center,Charlotte, NC, USA <sup>2</sup>Anne Arundel Medical Center,Annapolis, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Indocynanine green angiography (ICG-A) has been utilized to measure tissue perfusion during surgical reconstruction procedures and intestinal anastomosis, despite a lack of high quality evidence to support its use. While unsubstantiated, ICG-A has also been proposed to reduce complications in abdominal wall reconstruction (AWR). Two tertiary referral hernia centers conducted a prospective, randomized, controlled, blinded trial to investigate the utility of ICG-A in reducing wound complications in complex AWR.

Methods: After IRB approval, all consented patients underwent ICG-A utilizing the SPY Elite deviceTM prior to flap/skin closure after AWR. In the control group, both the Hernia Surgeon and Plastic Surgeon were blinded to ICG-A images. In the experimental group, the surgery team viewed the images and modified tissue flaps if warranted. ICG-A videos were saved and reviewed by independent, blinded surgeons to ensure correct interpretation. Outcomes included medical, surgical and wound complications and reoperation over 3 months. Groups were compared with Chi square and Wilcoxon rank sum analysis.

Results: Among 95 patients, n=49 control and n=46 experimental, preoperative characteristics were similar: age (58.3vs.56.7years,p=0.4), BMI (34.9vs. 33.6kg/m2,p=0.8), tobacco use (8.2%vs. 8.7%,p=0.9), diabetes (30.6%vs.37.0%,p=0.5), and previous hernia repair (71.4%vs.60.9%,p=0.3). The mean hernia defect was 293cm2 and mesh size 1033cm2. Operative characteristics were also equivalent, including rate of panniculectomy (69.4% vs. 58.7%,p=0.3), component separation (73.5%vs. 69.6%,p=0.6), estimated blood loss (160vs.180mL,p=0.4) and mean operative time (204vs.217minutes,p=0.4). The experimental group was more likely to have skin and subcutaneous flaps modified (37%vs.4.1%,p<0.0001). However, there was no significant difference between control vs. experimental groups in wound infection (10.2%vs.21.7%,p=0.12), skin necrosis (6.1% vs. 2.2%,p=0.3), fat necrosis (10.2% vs. 13.0%,p=0.7), overall wound-related complications (32.7% vs. 37.0%,p=0.7), reoperation rates (14.3%vs. 26.1%,p=0.7), or long-term hernia recurrence (4.1% vs. 2.2%,p=0.6) with mean follow-up of 8.3 months. When limited to significantly at-risk patients (obese, diabetic, concomitant component separation, or panniculectomy), there was no significant difference in wound-related complications between groups. Patients with hypoperfusion on ICG-A (below a threshold of 10 units) had higher rates of wound infection (28%vs.9.4%,p<0.02), however flap modification after viewing images did not improve wound-related complications in these patients (15.6%vs.12.5%,p=0.99).

Conclusion: Though intra-operative ICG-A use during complex AWR may aid in identifying patients at risk of wound infection, it did not decrease wound-related complications or reoperation rates in complex abdominal wall reconstruction. The use of ICG-A in complex AWR is not warrented in ventral hernia repair.

abstract_title: Sentinel lymph node biopsy in MCC: An Australian experience
author_block: J. R. Howle<sup>1,2,3</sup>, D. A. Gunaratne<sup>4</sup>, M. J. Veness<sup>1,3,5</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Crown Princess Mary Cancer Centre, Westmead Hospital, Sydney, Australia <sup>2</sup>Department of Surgery Westmead Hospital, Sydney, Australia <sup>3</sup>University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia <sup>4</sup>Department of Otolaryngology, Head and Neck Surgery, Westmead Hospital, Sydney, Australia <sup>5</sup>Department of Radiation Oncology, Westmead Hospital, Sydney, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is an aggressive cutaneous malignancy that has a high rate of nodal metastasis. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is being increasingly utilised in MCC. We sought to calculate the rates of positive and false negative SLNB and to assess the outcome of patients with MCC who underwent SLNB at our institution.

Methods: Thirty-two patients with stage I or II MCC who had undergone SLNB were identified from a prospectively maintained database of patients who presented to Westmead hospital, Sydney, Australia between 2000 and 2015. Data on patient demographics, tumour and treatment details and patient follow-up were extracted from the database and patient medical records. All patients underwent pre-operative lymphoscintigraphy and SLNB was performed with intra-operative localisation of the sentinel node with the use of intradermal patent blue dye and a hand-held gamma probe. . Each SLN was serially sectioned then stained with haematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and subjected to immunohistochemical analysis with anti-cytokeratin 20 (anti-CK20) and AE1/AE3 panels.

Results: Twenty-three men and nine women underwent SLNB. The median age was 69 (range 37-88) and seven were immunosuppressed.

Micrometastatic disease was found in 14 patients (44%), all of whom subsequently underwent treatment of the relevant nodal basin. This consisted of radiotherapy alone in 11, and a completion lymphadenectomy with adjuvant radiotherapy in 3. The patients who had a negative SLNB did not undergo nodal treatment following SLNB. Three patients developed nodal relapse following a negative SLNB, giving a false negative rate of 17.6%. At the time of last follow-up, 5 patients (16%) had died from MCC (3 following a positive SLNB, 2 after a false negative SLNB) and all of the patients who had a true node negative SLNB remained disease free.

Conclusion: SLN status was an important determinant of management in our patients as almost 50% were upstaged and underwent nodal treatment. Given the high rate of SLNB positivity, we believe that SLNB has an important role in determining the management of the regional lymph node basin in clinically node negative patients. However, the risk of a false negative SLNB is of concern, thus close observation of the regional nodal basins is warranted in patients who have had a negative SLNB. All of the patients who succumbed to MCC had nodal involvement, emphasising the prognostic implication of regional disease and the need for an effective adjuvant systemic treatment in node positive patients.

abstract_title: Perioperative Blood Transfusion after Liver Resection: External Validation of a Predictive Model
author_block: F. Bagante<sup>1,2</sup>, G. Spolverato<sup>1</sup>, F. Gani<sup>1</sup>, A. Ruzzenente<sup>2</sup>, C. Iacono<sup>2</sup>, A. Guglielmi<sup>2</sup>, T. M. Pawlik<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Verona School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Verona, VR, Italy
abstract_body:
Introduction: Hepatic resection is the treatment of choice for many benign and malignant liver lesions. Despite improvements in surgical technique and perioperative management, liver resection can still be associated with a high risk for intraoperative blood loss and need for perioperative pack red blood (PRBC) transfusion. The Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) previously proposed a tool to help predict the probability of PRBC transfusion among patients undergoing elective hepatectomy. We sought to externally validate this nomogram using a multicenter contemporary cohort of patients.

Methods: Clinicopathological, operative, and outcome data were collected on 1,184 patients who underwent liver resection between 2005 and 2015 at two major hepatobiliary centers in the United States and Italy. Factors included in the MSKCC nomogram were number of liver segments resected, concomitant extra-hepatic organ resection, diagnosis of primary liver malignancy, preoperative hemoglobin, and platelet count. The accuracy of the nomogram was assessed using receiving operating characteristic curves and area under the curve (AUC) methodology.

Results: A majority of patients was male (n=693, 58.5%) with a median age of 63.8 years (IQR, 53.3–71.0). Preoperative hemoglobin and platelets levels were 13.5 mg/dL (IQR, 12.1–14.6) and 229 x 109/L (IQR, 179.8–288.0), respectively. The median number of resected segments was 3 (IQR, 1–3) and concomitant extra-hepatic organ resections were performed in 251 (21.2%) patients. On final pathology, 423 (35.7%) of patients had a diagnosis of primary liver malignancy, whereas other patients had secondary liver metastasis (n=566, 47.8%) or benign disease (n=196, 16.5%). A total of 404 (34.1%) patients received a transfusion. Factors associated with transfusion included number of segments resected (OR=1.45), preoperative hemoglobin level (OR=0.79), concomitant extra-hepatic organ resection (OR=1.82), and diagnosis of primary liver disease (OR=2.45)(all P<0.05). In contrast, preoperative platelet level, and prothrombin time/international normalized ratio were not associated with receipt of transfusion (both P>0.05). In assessing the MSKCC nomogram, the median predicted probability of a transfusion with liver resection was calculated to be 30.5% (IQR, 6.3–51.1). The transfusion nomogram had good discriminatory abilities, with an AUC of 0.684.

Conclusion:External validation demonstrated good performance of the MSKCC transfusion nomogram for liver surgery. The proposed nomogram may be a helpful clinical tool to identify and counsel patients regarding their risk of receiving a perioperative blood transfusion around the time of hepatic resection.

abstract_title: Predictors of Significant Weight Loss Following Bariatric Surgery: A Propensity Score Analysis
author_block: N. Shah<sup>1</sup>, E. Chen<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Greenberg<sup>1</sup>, M. J. Garren<sup>1</sup>, G. Leverson<sup>1</sup>, L. M. Funk<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Wisconsin-Madison,Madison, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Laparoscopic vertical sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) has replaced laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) as the most commonly performed bariatric operation in the U.S. Identifying patient characteristics associated with optimal bariatric surgery outcomes remains challenging. We sought to compare 90-day and one-year outcomes following LSG or LRYGB and identify predictors of >50% excess body weight loss (EBWL) at one year using propensity scoring analysis.

Methods: Billing data from the University of Wisconsin Hospital were obtained to identify morbidly obese patients who underwent LRYGB or LSG from January 2010 to March 2014. Electronic health record data were reviewed to extract preoperative and postoperative variables, including one-year weight loss and comorbidity resolution. Patient age, sex, comorbidities (coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes and gastroesophageal reflux disease), and surgeon age were hypothesized a priori to be independently associated with type of surgery and were included in a multivariable model to generate a propensity score for each patient. Propensity score-adjusted bivariate odds ratios for variables hypothesized a priori to be independently associated with EBWL >50% were calculated. Variables found to be significant at p≤0.1 were entered into a propensity score-adjusted multivariable logistic regression model with EBWL >50% as the outcome.

Results: 74 LSG patients and 270 LRYGB patients were included in the study. Preoperative body mass index (BMI) was similar between the cohorts (47.8 kg/m2 for LSG vs 47.0 for LRYGB; p=0.43). LSG patients were more likely to be male (36.5% vs 18.5%; p=0.002), older (mean age of 50.6 vs 47.3; p=0.04) and have coronary artery disease (16.2% vs 5.9%; p=0.01). 90-day complication rates were similar between the two groups (8.1% vs 10.7%; p=0.67). LRYGB was associated with greater one-year postoperative EBWL (61.1% vs 44.3%; p<0.001). Female sex (OR 2.52 [95% CI 1.31-4.84]), the presence of GERD (OR 1.67 [95% CI 0.90-3.08]), surgeon age >40 (OR 2.09 [95% CI 1.11-3.94]), and surgery performed prior to 2013 (OR 6.83 [95% CI 3.69-12.65]), were associated with a higher likelihood of undergoing LRYGB. On propensity score-adjusted multivariable analysis, lower preoperative BMI, absence of type 2 diabetes, and undergoing a LRYGB were associated with EBWL >50% (Table 1).

Conclusion: Lower preoperative BMI, the presence of type 2 diabetes, and gastric bypass surgery (compared to sleeve gastrectomy) were independently associated with greater weight loss following bariatric surgery. Incorporating these findings into preoperative discussions may help patients set reasonable postoperative goals.

abstract_title: Cost of Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy Decreases after Implementation of a Standardized Pick-list
author_block: K. Simon<sup>2</sup>, M. Frelich<sup>1</sup>, T. Duris<sup>3</sup>, J. Gould<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Division Of General Surgery,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>2</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin Affiliated Hospitals,Milwaukee, WI, USA <sup>3</sup>Froedtert & The Medical College Of Wisconsin,Perioperative Services,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is one of the most commonly performed procedures in the United States. Variation in procedural costs across the country and within single institutions has pointed out a potential avenue for standardization initiatives aimed at improving quality, value based care. We hypothesized that cost reduction is achievable for laparoscopic cholecystectomy with the implementation of a standardized pick list for disposable surgical equipment.

Methods: De-identified procedural cost and equipment utilization data were collected from the Surgical Profitability Compass Procedure Cost Manager System (The Advisory Board Company, Washington DC) for our health care system for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy (ICD-9 code 51.23). A focus group of surgeons designed a standardized equipment list for laparoscopic cholecystectomy and agreed to adhere to this list for all cases as clinically indicated. The remaining surgeons in the department who also perform laparoscopic cholecystectomy served as controls. Cost and utilization data were collected for six months prior to and six months following the implementation of this standardized pick-list. All surgeons in the department were aware of this initiative and free to make changes to their pick list regardless of which study group they were in during the time of this evaluation.

Results:A total of 281 elective laparoscopic cholecystectomies were performed during the study interval and included in the analysis. There were 5 (29%) surgeons in the focus group and another 11 who served as controls. Prior to implementation of the pick list, total disposable supply costs per case were greatest in controls compared to the focus group ($930 versus $801, p<.01). After implementation of the pick list, the focus group of surgeons demonstrated the greatest reduction in cost savings (37%, $299 savings, p<.01) compared to Controls (33%, $307 savings, p<.01), and supply costs in both study groups decreased significantly. Average case duration and length of hospital did not change in either group. Equipment utilization data demonstrated a discrepancy in surgical equipment used between study groups that persisted even after implementation of the suggested pick list.

Conclusion:Cost savings can be achieved after implementation of a standardized pick list for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. There was a ‘halo effect' observed in that even for surgeons who were not part of the focus group, significant cost savings were realized during the study time period. This suggests that awareness of the standardized pick list and the measures aimed at cost savings affected clinical practice.

abstract_title: Is There Value in Bowel Preparation Prior to Elective Right-Sided Colectomy?
author_block: S. Koller<sup>1</sup>, K. Bauer<sup>1</sup>, B. Egleston<sup>2</sup>, M. Philp<sup>1</sup>, H. Ross<sup>1</sup>, N. Esnaola<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Temple University,Philadelpha, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There is persistent skepticism regarding the value of bowel preparation prior to elective right-sided colectomy. This study analyzed rates of various types of surgical site infection (SSI) following right-sided colectomy and evaluated the relative benefits and risks of no bowel preparation versus various types of bowel preparation in this clinical setting.

Methods: We identified all patients who underwent elective right-sided colectomy and had complete information regarding preoperative bowel preparation in the American College of Surgeons National Surgery Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP) database from 2012-2013. Patient/procedure characteristics and outcomes across patients who received no bowel preparation versus various types of bowel preparation, including mechanical bowel preparation (MBP), oral antibiotics (OA), and combined oral antibiotics and mechanical bowel preparation (OA+MBP), were compared using chi square tests/ANOVA. Adjusted odds ratios (aOR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for SSI were calculated using propensity-adjusted analyses to control for non-random receipt of the various types of bowel preparation.

Results: 4,215 patients were included in the analyses (see table). Although a substantial proportion of patients (34.9%) did not receive preoperative bowel preparation, the majority did, including MBP (34.5%), OA (4.3%), or OA+MBP (26.3%). 9.7%, 6.8%, and 3.1% of patients developed any (wound or organ/space) SSI, wound SSI, and organ/space SSI, respectively. On univariate analysis, bowel preparation reduced the risk of any SSI and wound SSI, but not organ/space SSI. After propensity-adjustment, MBP was not associated with a decreased rate of SSI compared to no bowel preparation, whereas OA+MBP was independently associated with a decreased rate of both any SSI and wound SSI. Of note, OA+MBP was associated with a decreased rate of postoperative ileus and was not associated with higher rates of anastomotic leak, cardiac complications, renal complications, mortality, readmission, or longer length of stay (LOS).

Conclusion: Preoperative use of OA+MBP is associated with significantly lower rates of any SSI and wound SSI following elective right-sided colectomy and is not associated with increased rates of other adverse outcomes or longer LOS. Routine bowel preparation using OA+MBP should be strongly considered prior to elective right-sided colectomy.

abstract_title: Risk of Readmission Following Surgery for Benign Foregut Disease
author_block: A. K. Poupore<sup>2</sup>, M. Stem<sup>1</sup>, D. Molena<sup>1</sup>, B. Mungo<sup>1</sup>, A. O. Lidor<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Department Of Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School Of Public Health,Molecular Microbiology And Immunology,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body: IntroductionGastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and paraesophageal hernia (PEH) are relatively common conditions in the U.S. that can require surgery when refractory to medical intervention. With the rise in obesity and aging population, GERD and PEH prevalence is expected to increase. Although less common, achalasia is a progressive disorder that, without surgical or endoscopic intervention, often leads to end stage disease. In patients requiring surgery for these benign foregut diseases, hospital readmission is of concern as it is associated with increased morbidity and poor patient satisfaction, and thus is a focus of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services evaluation of quality of care. The aim of this study was to ascertain the incidence of, reasons for, and risk factors associated with hospital readmission within 30 days of surgery for benign foregut disease.MethodsThis was a retrospective analysis using the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program database from 2012 and 2013. Patients ≥18 years of age with a primary diagnosis of GERD, PEH, or achalasia who underwent Nissen fundoplication, PEH repair, or Heller myotomy (either laparoscopic or open) were included in the study. The primary outcome was hospital readmission within 30 days of operation. Multivariable logistic regression analysis was used to identify risk factors associated with hospital readmission.ResultsOf the 9,048 patients included in this study, 511 (5.6%) were readmitted at the median of 11 days (IQR 6-17) post-procedure. The median age of patients was 60 years (IQR 49-70) and the majority were female (66.4%) and white (87.4%). Readmitted patients were more likely to be older (64 vs 60 years, p <0.001), undergo open surgery (12.1% vs 7.0%, p <0.001), and have emergency admission (4.5% vs 1.8%, p <0.001) compared to patients not readmitted. Among the most common reasons for readmission were per os intolerance (23.5%), respiratory complications including pneumonia and pleural effusion (12.2%), abdominal pain (6.2%), and venous thromboembolic events (5.7%). Multivariable logistic regression analysis revealed that open surgical approach, prolonged length of stay, chronic steroid use, emergent admission, and pre-discharge complication were most strongly associated with hospital readmission following surgery for benign foregut disease (Table).ConclusionUnderstanding patient factors associated with readmission offers insight into ways to improve patient care in this population. Implementing standardized perioperative strategies such as nutritional counseling, early ambulation, intensive pulmonary toilet, and DVT prophylaxis may help decrease the rates of readmissions and enhance overall quality of care.

abstract_title: A quantitative study of voice dysfunction after thyroidectomy
author_block: J. C. Lee<sup>1,2</sup>, D. Breen<sup>1</sup>, S. Grodski<sup>1</sup>, A. Scott<sup>4</sup>, E. Paul<sup>3</sup>, J. W. Serpell<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Monash University,Endocrine Surgery Unit, The Alfred,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>2</sup>Monash University,Department Of Surgery,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>3</sup>Monash University,School Of Public Health & Preventative Medicine,Melbourne, VIC, Australia <sup>4</sup>The Alfred Hospital,Department Of Speech Pathology,Melbourne, VIC, Australia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Up to 80% of patients without a recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy report alteration in their voice after a thyroid procedure. The aims of this study were: 1) To quantify voice changes after thyroid surgery; 2) To correlate the changes to the extent of surgery; 3) To correlate voice changes to intraoperative RLN swelling.

Methods: Patients undergoing total and hemi-thyroidectomy were prospectively recruited from the Monash University Endocrine Surgery Unit between 2010 and 2011. Voice quality was scored subjectively using the 'Voice Disorder Index' (VDI; score 0 to 40, from best to worst) and objectively using the 'Dysphonia Severity Index' (DSI; score -5 to 5, from worst to best), before and after surgery. These assessments were carried out by 2 speech pathologists. Recurrent laryngeal nerve diameter was measured intraoperatively at the commencement and conclusion of the lobectomy, using Vernier calipers with a resolution of 0.1 mm. Statistical methods used included Student's t-test, Chi square, Wilcoxon sign-rank test, and linear regression. Means are reported with standard errors.

Results: A total of 62 patients were included in the study, with a mean age of 48 years (range 18 – 80) and a female preponderance (M 9 : F 53). Overall, the voice quality deteriorated both subjectively (Mean VDI 4.2 ± 0.7 to 9.4 ± 1.2, P < 0.001) and objectively (Mean DSI 3.9 ± 0.3 to 2.8 ± 0.3, P < 0.001) with thyroid surgery. Patients who underwent either hemi- or total thyroidectomy both reported significant deterioration of voice (Mean VDI 5.4 ± 1.5 to 7.9 ± 1.4, P = 0.02 and 3.5 ± 0.8 to 10.6 ± 1.9, P < 0.001 respectively). However, on objective assessment, only total thyroidectomy patients showed significant deterioration (Mean DSI 4.0 ± 0.3 to 2.5 ± 0.3, P < 0.001). Intraoperatively, the RLN diameter increased by 0.58 ± 0.05 mm (1.82 ± 0.05 mm to 2.40 ± 0.05 mm; P < 0.001). In hemithyroidectomy patients, the degree of nerve swelling correlated to the degree of deterioration in objective voice assessment, in that the greater the increase in RLN diameter, the worse the subjective score (coefficient 2.3 ± 1.0, P = 0.03). This was not the case in the total thyroidectomy patients.

Conclusion: Voice quality deteriorates with thyroid surgery despite functionally intact RLN. While likely multifactorial, the degree of deterioration is related to the extent of surgery, and may also be related to the degree of RLN swelling.

abstract_title: Morbidity and Mortality after Total Splenectomy for Lymphoid Neoplasms
author_block: M. G. Neuwirth<sup>1</sup>, E. K. Bartlett<sup>1</sup>, A. D. Newton<sup>1</sup>, R. E. Roses<sup>1</sup>, D. L. Fraker<sup>1</sup>, R. R. Kelz<sup>1</sup>, G. C. Karakousis<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Hospital Of The University Of Pennsylvania,Department Of Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Splenectomy is indicated for selected patients with lymphoid neoplasms. Outcomes data for this procedure are largely limited to single institution series. We sought to examine surgical morbidity and mortality in this high-risk patient population using a contemporary national cohort, with particular attention to outcomes in patients requiring hospitalization prior to surgery.

Methods: We queried the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program database (2005-2013) for all patients with lymphoid malignancies undergoing total splenectomy, excluding patients who underwent additional organ resections. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were performed to identify significant factors associated with an increased risk of morbidity and mortality. A risk stratification score was developed to stratify patients for death and serious morbidity (DSM).

Results:In 456 patients who underwent splenectomy for lymphoid neoplasm, 110(24.1%) experienced a serious post-operative complication, and 11(2.4%) died within 30 days of surgery. In a forward stepwise multivariate model, albumin<3g/dL (OR=2.6, p=0.005), hematocrit <30% (OR=2.8, p<.001) and a history of COPD (OR=3.4 p=.009) were independent predictors of DSM. The number of pre-operative risk factors present stratified DSM rates: 13.5% (0 risk factors), 34.4% (1 risk factor) and 58.5% (2-3 risk factors), p<.001. Although not an independent risk factor, patients admitted at least one day prior to surgery (IP) were more likely to have one or more of these risk factors present compared to patients who underwent surgery on the day of admission (74.6 vs 26.4%, p<001). Morbidity (39.7 vs 18.2%, p<.001) and mortality (7.1 vs .6%, p<.001) were significantly increased in the IP group compared to same day admission surgical patients.

Conclusion:Total splenectomy for lymphoid neoplasms in hospitalized patients is associated with substantial morbidity and mortality. Risk stratification using selected factors (hypoalbuminemia, pre-operative anemia and history of COPD) may better inform decision-making for surgery and offer opportunities for improved peri-operative management to mitigate DSM.

abstract_title: Influence of Specialty Training on Perioperative Outcomes of Surgery for Benign Esophageal Diseases
author_block: Z. Khoushhal<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Canner<sup>1</sup>, E. Schneider<sup>1</sup>, M. Stem<sup>1</sup>, E. Haut<sup>1</sup>, B. Mungo<sup>1</sup>, A. Lidor<sup>1</sup>, D. Molena<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Johns Hopkins University,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Taibah University,Madinah, , Saudi Arabia
abstract_body:
Introduction: Surgery for benign esophageal disease is performed either by General Surgeons (GS) or Cardiothoracic surgeons (CTS) in the United States. In this study we have evaluated intraoperative and postoperative outcomes of surgery for the most common benign esophageal diseases: para-esophageal hernia (PEH), gastro-esophageal reflux disease and achalasia, and compared the results based on the surgeon's specialty.
