Methods: This was a retrospective cohort study using the American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS-NSQIP) database (2006-2013). Adult patients (18 years and older) who underwent PEH repair, gastric fundoplication or Heller esophagomyotomy were divided into two groups according to whether the operation was performed by a GS or CTS. A comparison of intraoperative and postoperative outcomes between the groups was conducted. The primary outcome was 30-day mortality. Secondary outcomes included overall and serious morbidity, discharge destination and readmission rates (readmission reported from 2011-2013).

Results:Of the 100,566 operations, 96.48% were performed by GS while only 3.52% were done by CTS. GS performed 96% of PEH repairs, 94% of fundoplications, and 91% of Heller esophagomyotomy (p <0.001). 85.6% of the operations were done via laparoscopic approach. GS performed 86% of their procedures laparoscopically, while CTS used a laparoscopic approach in 65% of cases. Overall, CTS' patients were older and had higher comorbidities (p <0.001). Multiple regression analysis showed that mortality, morbidity, readmission and home discharge were comparable between GS and CTS while adjusting for other factors (table). However when each type of surgery was independently evaluated, PEH repair showed higher mortality and serious morbidity when performed by CTS.

Conclusion:The vast majority of esophageal operations for benign disease are performed by GS in the United States, using laparoscopic approach in most cases. Our overall finding suggests no difference in the overall outcome for patients treated by GS or CTS. Higher mortality and morbidity of PEH repair performed by CTS might be due to factors not measurable with NSQIP dataset (i.e. case complexity).

abstract_title: Functional Gallbladder Disease: Commonly Treated, Poorly Understood; Is it Time for a RCT?
author_block: C. A. Thiels<sup>1,2</sup>, E. B. Habermann<sup>2</sup>, K. T. Hanson<sup>2</sup>, J. Bingener<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Mayo Clinic,Department Of Surgery,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic,Kern Center For The Science Of Health Care Delivery,Rochester, MN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The EPISOD trial has changed interventions for functional biliary disease. Anecdotally, patients are increasingly offered cholecystectomy (CCY) for functional gallbladder disease (FGBD) with a low level of evidence for effectiveness. Our objective was to determine if the rate of CCY for FGBD is increasing and to compare patient characteristics and short term outcomes of patients who underwent CCY for FGBD to patients who underwent CCY for biliary colic (BC).

Methods: All elective CCY were selected from ACS-NSQIP 2005-2013. Non-elective cases and cases with un-related concurrent procedures were excluded. Trends over time of CCY for FGBD were calculated as a proportion of all gallbladder disease (574 & 575) using a Cochran-Armitage test. CCY for FGBD (ICD-9 code 575.8) was compared to CCY to BC (574.2). Rates of readmission were calculated using the person-years method. Chi-square, Fisher's exact, and Wilcoxon rank sum test were used for univariate analysis. Multivariable logistic regression models were used to control for resident involvement, age, gender, BMI, ASA class, and DM and a Cox proportional hazards model was used to assess adjusted readmission rates.

Results: Of 163,574 patients undergoing elective CCY 5,161 (3.2%) had a diagnosis of FGBD and 24,810 (15.2%) had a diagnosis of BC. The rate of FGBD as indication for CCY remained stable over time (1.9 in 2005 to 3.0% in 2013, p=0.29). Residents were involved in 53.9% of FGBD vs 72.3% of BC cases (p<0.001). When compared to BC, patients with FGBD were more likely to be <50 years old (63 vs 57%, p<0.001), non-Hispanic white (79 vs 63%, p<0.001), BMI <25 (29 vs 21%, p<0.001), and female (79 vs 77%, p=0.008). Rates of DM, COPD, and CHF were similar in both groups (all p>0.05). Patients with FGBD had shorter LOS (27 vs. 35% LOS ≥1 day, p<0.001) and fewer major complications (1.2 vs 1.6%, p=0.014). Rates of minor complications (1.3 for FGBD vs 1.4% for BC), return to OR rates (0.6 vs 0.8%), and readmission rates (3.5 vs 4.1% per 30 person days) were not significantly different (all p>0.05). On adjusted analysis only LOS was significantly different between BC and BD (Table 1).

Conclusion: FGBD continues to be an indication for CCY. The patient profile is different from patients with BC. These cases appear to be frequently performed without resident involvement suggesting that this may be a more common indication at non-academic hospitals. While a safe operation overall, the outcomes are comparable to CCY for BC and thus not without risk. Further research to assess the benefits of CCY for FGBD is warranted.

abstract_title: A comparative study: Acellular Dermis vs. Inferior De-epithelized Flap in Breast Reconstruction
author_block: H. Hon<sup>1</sup>, R. Mubang<sup>1</sup>, B. Wernick<sup>1</sup>, C. Corredera<sup>1</sup>, J. Stoltzfus<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Stawicki<sup>1</sup>, M. Morrissey<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>St. Luke's University Hospital,General Surgery,Bethlehem, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: There are over 200,000 new cases of breast cancer diagnosed yearly in the U.S. The corresponding need for mastectomies lead to an increase in breast reconstruction (BR). Implant-based BR continues to be the most common (~ 70%). The acellular dermal matrix (ADM) assisted expander-implant method facilitates improved lower pole breast contour, greater tissue expansion and immediate implant-based post-mastectomy reconstruction. A newer technique, known as the inferior de-epithelized flap (IDF) uses autologous tissue to create a dermal sling for the inferior pole of the implant that functions similarly. Benefits of IDF may include a thicker layer of tissue with a natural consistency and better tolerability of post-BR radiation. We hypothesized that ADM and IDF provide comparable aesthetic outcomes, with no difference in complication rates.

Methods: An IRB exempt retrospective, single-institution study was performed between July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2014, examining all immediate BR's using ADM or IDF. Abstracted data included demographics (age, BMI); known risk factors for postoperative morbidity (tobacco, diabetes, pre-BR radiation therapy); and operative characteristics (laterality, duration, cost). Primary outcomes were categorized as clinical (complications requiring surgical intervention postoperatively: hematoma, seroma, partial flap necrosis, tissue expander leakage/exposure, inframammary fold displacement) or aesthetic (five different variables including BR volume, contour, placement, scarring, inframammary fold appearance – as described by Nguyen et al. Eplasty 2012; 5:486-492). Categorical data were analyzed using Fisher's Exact Test. For continuous variables, the student's t-test was used. Statistical significance level was set at α = 0.05.

Results: A total of 65 patients (41 ADM, 24 IDF, mean age 53.4±10.7 years) were included, with 106 BR's evaluated (67 ADM, 39 IDF). Patients who underwent IDF's had significantly higher BMI's (32 vs. 25, p<0.01). There were no significant differences in tobacco, diabetes, and pre-BR radiation therapy. Major complication rates were similar between ADM and IDF groups (22% vs. 30%, p=0.34). There were no significant differences in the aesthetic outcomes. Although the unit cost per procedure was comparable, the average IDF procedure took nearly 30 minutes longer per side (192 ± 45 min. vs. 166 ± 36 min, p=0.02).

Conclusion: Our study demonstrates that there are no significant differences in major complications or aesthetic outcomes between the ADM and IDF approach to immediate BR. However, our data suggests that IDF may be more suitable for patients with ptosis and higher BMI's. On the other hand, ADM is more appropriate for patients with less available autologous tissue. On average, the ADM procedure took significantly less time. Further studies are warranted in this area, focusing on long term outcomes and value-based approaches to BR.

abstract_title: Predictors of Prolonged Postoperative Opioid Use in Patients Undergoing Breast Reconstruction
author_block: R. A. Mann<sup>1</sup>, D. P. Marcusa<sup>1</sup>, D. C. Cron<sup>1</sup>, A. K. Rzepecki<sup>1</sup>, B. R. Fillinger<sup>1</sup>, L. Zhong<sup>2</sup>, M. J. Englesbe<sup>3</sup>, J. F. Waljee<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Michigan,Medical School,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Michigan,Section Of Plastic Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA <sup>3</sup>University Of Michigan,Section Of Transplantation Surgery,Ann Arbor, MI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the United States, opioid misuse is accelerating, leading to excess morbidity and mortality. Furthermore, recent studies have suggested opioids are immunosuppressive, potentially resulting in chemoresistance among cancer patients. Opioid analgesics are commonly prescribed following surgery, but few guidelines exist regarding their use. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to examine the patient factors related to prolonged opioid use among a cohort of breast cancer patients undergoing breast reconstruction.

Methods: We identified 25,044 women who underwent immediate breast reconstruction between 1/2010-9/2013 using the Truven Health Marketscan® Research Databases, which collect insurance claims data from approximately 50 million individuals in the United States. We specifically examined the effect of patient demographics, comorbidities, co-existing mood disorders, preoperative opioid and benzodiazepine use on postoperative opioid use, controlling for procedure type (autologous vs. prosthesis-based reconstruction) and complications. We used multivariate logistic regression to assess the effects of each predictor on the probability of filling an opioid prescription a) within 6 weeks following surgery, and b) within 3 to 4 months following surgery.

Results: In this cohort, 66% of patients filled opioid prescriptions postoperatively, and 28% continued to fill opioid prescriptions 3 months following the reconstruction. Immediately following surgery, patients who had previously used opioids or benozodiazepines were more likely to fill opioid prescriptions ([OR]: 1.39, p<0.01; OR: 1.77, p<0.01). Opioid use declined with age (44-54 years: OR: 0.74, p<0.01; 55-64 years: OR: 0.66, p<0.01; 65 years and older: OR: 0.5, p<0.01). Protectors against prolonged use included autologous free perforator flap reconstruction (OR: 0.76, p<0.01). Predictors of continued opioid use at 3 months following surgery included preoperative opioid or opioid and benzodiazepine use (OR: 2.45, p<0.01; OR: 3.28, p<0.01), mood disorders (anxiety: OR: 1.20, p<0.01; depression: OR: 1.43, p<0.01), and substance abuse (OR: 1.42, p<0.01).

Conclusion: Opioid use is common following breast reconstruction, and up to 17% of all patients continue to use opioids beyond 90 days postop. Patients with pre-existing mood disorders and those who have previous exposure to opioid and benzodiazepine medications are particularly at risk of prolonged opioid use. Strategies to curb the overutilization of opioid analgesics should focus on identifying vulnerable patients and targeting additional preoperative counseling, alternative pain management techniques, and greater pain surveillance in the postoperative period.

abstract_title: DIEP Free Flap Breast Reconstruction: Review of Impact of Surgical Procedure on Donor Site Morbidity
author_block: T. Tomouk<sup>1</sup>, A. T. Mohan<sup>2,3,4</sup>, A. Azizi<sup>1</sup>, E. Conci<sup>1</sup>, E. B. Brickley<sup>5</sup>, C. M. Malata<sup>2,6</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Cambridge,School Of Clinical Medicine,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>2</sup>Addenbrooke's University Hospital,Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery Department,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>3</sup>Mayo Clinic,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>Restoration Of Appearance And Function Charitable Trust (RAFT),Research Fellow,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>5</sup>University Of Cambridge,Department Of Public Health And Primary Care,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>6</sup>Postgraduate Medical Institute At Anglia Ruskin University,Cambridge And Chelmsford, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction: The use of abdominal tissue in post-mastectomy autologous breast reconstruction is a popular choice among reconstructive surgeons. Abdominal perforator flaps have lower donor site morbidity compared to the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, though complications such as seroma formation, delayed healing, fat necrosis and abdominal wall weakness may still occur. This is the first study to evaluate donor complications based on the type of Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator (DIEP) surgical procedure and compares unilateral, bilateral and bipedicled breast reconstructions.

Methods: A retrospective chart review was conducted of all women undergoing rib-preserving abdominal free flap breast reconstruction at a University Hospital between 2008-2015 by a single surgeon. Data were collected on patient demographics, operative details and postoperative complications, with a specific focus on donor site morbidity. Patients who underwent Superficial Inferior Epigastric Artery (SIEA) flaps (n=20) or had incomplete information (n=27) were excluded.

Results: Of 177 patients identified, a total of 130 patients (73.4%) were included in this study and divided into three groups for comparison: unilateral (n=93), bilateral (n=19) and bipedicled (n=18). Age, smoking history, radiotherapy and chemotherapy exposure were similar across the three groups and did not influence complication risk. Body Mass Index (BMI) was significantly lower in the bipedicled group, as expected (p<0.01, Kruskal-Wallis test). Wound dehiscence was greatest in the unilateral group at 22.6%, compared to 15.8% in the bilateral, and 5.6% in bipedicled group (p=0.23, Chi-squared Test). Seroma rates were highest in the bilateral group at 63.2% versus 48.4% in the unilateral group and 33.3% in the bipedicled group (p=0.19, Chi-squared Test). Fat necrosis occurred in 12.9% of unilateral, 10.5% of bilateral and 0% of the bipedicled reconstructions. Prevalence of abdominal bulge was low in all three groups (≤6.5%). In univariate analyses and relative to the unipedicled, unilateral group, the overall odds of complication was approximately two-fold higher in the bilateral group (Odds ratio (95% CI): 2.16 (0.66, 7.04)), and almost halved in the bipedicled group (Odds ratio (95% CI): 0.46 (0.17, 1.28)); however these associations had wide confidence intervals and attenuated upon further adjustment. Complications were managed conservatively without recourse to surgery in 68.8%.

Conclusion: DIEP flap breast reconstruction is still fraught with donor site morbidity although most complications are minor and comprise predominantly seroma, delayed healing and fat necrosis. These are often managed conservatively. While bipedicled DIEPs were reserved for lower BMI patients they, like bilateral breast reconstructions, can be performed safely without undue increase in donor site complications. Our study suggests that the type of DIEP flap does not impact donor site morbidity.

abstract_title: A 10 Year Review of Racial Disparities in 1387 Breast Reconstruction Patients
author_block: S. Boukovalas<sup>1</sup>, D. Vibhakar<sup>1</sup>, H. Abdollahi<sup>1</sup>, R. Bleicher<sup>1</sup>, E. Chang<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Fox Chase Cancer Center,Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Socioeconomic backgrounds and ethnicity have previously been shown to impact access to various aspects of healthcare. Certainly breast reconstruction is not immune to these factors especially since reconstruction may be considered elective surgery. This study aims to evaluate whether racial disparities exist in breast reconstruction.

Methods: A retrospective review of all patients undergoing mastectomy surgery between January 2002 and December 2012 at a single cancer center was performed. Patient demographics were examined, and the rates of breast reconstruction were evaluated in relation to ethnic backgrounds. our minority outreach program was examined to assess the impact and effectiveness in ameliorating the discrepancies in breast reconstruction among different ethnicities.

Results: A total of 1387 patients were evaluated during the study period. Overall, 554 patients (39.9%) underwent breast reconstruction with 305 patients (55.1%) undergoing free tissue transfer and 249 patients (44.9%) undergoing implant reconstruction. A total of 444 free flaps were performed for breast reconstruction with 438 breasts reconstructed with implants. The incidence of breast reconstruction increased from 30.5% to 67.3% between the first and second halves of the study period. Although no significant differences were identified in rates of implant-based reconstruction among the ethnic groups, free flap reconstruction increased dramatically. There were significant racial disparities during the first half of the study period with Caucasian (11.0%) and Asian (23.1%) women being more likely to undergo autologous tissue reconstruction compared to African-American (2.7%) or Hispanic (0%) women (p<0.05).

Conclusion: Ethnicity is one of many factors that may impact the decision to undergo breast reconstruction. The previous racial disparities in breast reconstruction have dissipated in the past 5 years with near-equivalent as well as increasing rates of reconstruction across all ethnicities. Community outreach programs may play an important role in increasing the reconstructive rates in certain ethnic groups. Certainly further efforts are necessary to improve upon the delivery of breast reconstruction to all patients regardless of ethnic background.

abstract_title: Procedure Type, Post-op Pain, Recovery and Clinical Outcomes in DIEP Flap Breast Reconstruction
author_block: A. A. Azizi<sup>1,5</sup>, A. T. Mohan<sup>2,3,4</sup>, T. Tomouk<sup>5</sup>, E. Conci<sup>5</sup>, E. B. Brickley<sup>6</sup>, C. M. Malata<sup>2,7</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Royal Free Hospital NHS Foundation Trust,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>2</sup>Addenbrooke's University Hospital,Plastic And Reconstructive Surgery Department,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>3</sup>Mayo Clinic,Rochester, MN, USA <sup>4</sup>Restoration Of Appearance And Function Charitable Trust (RAFT),Research Fellow,London, LONDON, United Kingdom <sup>5</sup>University Of Cambridge,School Of Clinical Medicine,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>6</sup>University Of Cambridge,Department Of Public Health And Primary Care,Cambridge, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom <sup>7</sup>Postgraduate Medical Institute At Anglia Ruskin University,Cambridge And Chelmsford, CAMBRIDGESHIRE, United Kingdom
abstract_body:
Introduction: Reduced post-operative pain has been shown to decrease complications, accelerate discharge from hospital and improve patient experience. Although perforator flaps can reduce donor site morbidity in comparison to their muscle flap counterparts for breast reconstruction, they are still associated with considerable, local pain which has recently been the subject of various methods of control, such as TAP blocks. There has hitherto been no study of the pain associated with different perforator flap types. We therefore reviewed Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator (DIEP) flaps used for post-mastectomy breast reconstruction and compared pain and clinical outcomes based on surgical procedure type: unilateral uni-pedicled, unilateral bi-pedicled and bilateral breast reconstructions.

Methods: A 7-year retrospective study (2008-2015) was conducted at a single University Hospital of all women who underwent post-mastectomy DIEP breast reconstruction by as single surgeon using the rib preservation technique for intermammary vessel exposure. Data were collected on patient demographics, operative details, patient pain scores, analgesia requirements, postoperative course and complications. A literature review of pain and morbidity of DIEP breast reconstruction was conducted.

Results:The 177 patients (207 FLAPS) included in the study were categorized into four DIEP groups: unilateral unipedicled (N=85 flaps), unilateral bi-pedicled (N=26 flaps), total unilateral (N=147) and bilateral (N=60 flaps) reconstructions. There were no significant differences in morphine patient controlled analgesic (PCA) requirements over 24 and 48 hours, PCA duration, patient reported pain scores and time to catheter removal across all four groups. Bilateral reconstructions had an increased hospital stay by 2 days (P<0.01). 86% of patients reported their maximum pain scores in the first 24 hours.

Conclusion:This is the first study to compare the clinical outcomes and immediate postoperative morbidity of unipedicled, bipedicled and bilateral DIEP breast reconstructions. PCA requirements, time to catheter removal and pain scores were comparable across all 4 subgroups. Our study showed that there were no clinically significant differences in outcomes between unilateral and bilateral reconstructions or unipedicled against bipedicled unilateral reconstructions attributable to differences in post-operative pain.

abstract_title: The Impact of Diabetes Mellitus on Autologous Breast Reconstruction
author_block: J. Silvestre<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Serletti<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Perelman School Of Medicine,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder shown to increase the risk for microvasculature complications in autologous breast reconstruction (ABR). While controversial, these findings have been replicated in multiple case series, but have not been described in a large national dataset. Given its high prevalence in the ABR population, the impact of diabetes on surgical outcomes in ABR is of great interest.

Methods: The Nationwide Inpatient Sample was analyzed from 2008 to 2011. Hospitalizations were analyzed on the basis of International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-9) procedural codes for patients undergoing total mastectomy and immediate ABR with microvascular free tissue transfer. Patients were categorized into one of two cohorts: diabetic and non-diabetic. Data on demographics, comorbidities, systemic complications, and procedural-specific events were extracted using ICD-9 codes and compared via chi-square tests where appropriate. Regression modeling was used to determine odds ratios for complication covariates among the two cohorts.

Results: 36,028 patients met inclusion criteria and 6.7% had diabetes. Patients with diabetes had a greater risk for infection (OR 1.96, CI 1.09-2.01) and post-operative hemorrhage (OR 1.52, CI 1.12-2.06). Similar rates of flap revision, microvascular events, post-operative blood transfusions, and perioperative complications were seen between both cohorts. Patients with diabetes did not have extended hospitalization stays compared with non-diabetic patients.

Conclusion: Patients with diabetes have similar peri-operative events during ABR and can expect similar outcomes to the general ABR population.

abstract_title: The Free Flap Fast-Track: Decreasing Costs by Minimizing Hourly Monitoring Postoperatively
author_block: J. A. Ricci<sup>1</sup>, C. R. Vargas<sup>1</sup>, O. A. Ho<sup>1</sup>, B. T. Lee<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Preventing free flap loss has historically required intense postoperative monitoring for more than 24 hours in a Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU) or Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with hourly flap checks and one-to-one nursing; at a cost of thousands of dollars. Recently, the use of transcutaneous oxygen sensors (Vioptix; Freemont, CA) at our institution has resulted in the earlier detection of free flap issues, decreased flap loss and improved flap salvage when problems are identified. With the implementation of routine continuous flap monitoring on all patients using Vioptix sensors, this study aims to identify whether the postoperative paradigm can safely be changed to permit the earlier transfer of patients from the PACU or ICU, to a standard surgical inpatient unit; with the goal of substantial cost savings without jeopardizing flaps.

Methods: All consecutive Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) Flaps performed at a single institution were reviewed. Cases requiring a takeback to the operating room for flap related complications discovered by the Vioptix sensor and physical exam were collected. Data evaluated included patient demographics, the time course of the complication relative to the end of the initial procedure and outcomes like flap loss and salvage. Hourly costs for patient care in the ICU, PACU and surgical inpatient unit were obtained from the hospital financial office. A cost benefit analysis was performed with the Incremental Cost Effectiveness Ratio.

Results: Over an 11 year span, 1128 DIEP flaps were performed with 56 takebacks occurring. A total of 20 flaps were identified that required a return to the operating room within 24 hours of the original procedure for flap failure. At 14 hours postoperatively, the majority (15/20; 75%) of failing free flaps had been identified and brought back to the OR, with only six other flaps encountering problems between 15 and 24 hours postoperatively. Additional cost analysis revealed that after 14 hours of intensive monitoring, the cost of identifying each individual subsequent failing free flap exceeded the cost of one further hour of intensive monitoring.

Conclusion: The paradigm for postoperative monitoring of free flaps has historically been very intensive and costly. New monitoring techniques for flaps have improved success rates and in an effort to decrease health care expenditures, less stringent monitoring algorithms must be developed. We propose a fast-track pathway for uncomplicated free flaps, reducing the amount of time spent in the intensive monitoring setting from 24 to 14 hours, as patients can be safely transferred to a standard inpatient surgical unit and monitored with continuous oxygen sensor monitoring, with significant cost savings and minimal risk of missing a failing free flap.

abstract_title: Pediatric Versus Adult Pyoderma Gangrenosum: Is It Just Big Wounds on Little Adults?
author_block: T. Soleimani<sup>1</sup>, S. E. Sasor<sup>1</sup>, L. Spera<sup>1</sup>, B. Eppley<sup>1</sup>, R. Sood<sup>1</sup>, S. S. Tholpady<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Division Of Plastic Surgery,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is an uncommon, ulcerative, cutaneous condition of uncertain etiology. It is of importance to surgeons as it is often caused by surgical trauma and can masquerade as a pyogenic disease process requiring debridement and antibiotics. Treatment is however, medical, and delay can lead to significant morbidity. In addition to appropriate treatment of the skin lesions, medical workup for coincident gastrointestinal, rheumatologic, and hematologic has been mandated. The purpose of this study was to test the hypothesis that pediatric PG has differing disease associations and therefore requires a differing medical workup.

Methods: The National Inpatient Sample (NIS) and the Kids' Inpatient Database (KID), years 2000, 2003, 2006, and 2009, were utilized to identify all hospitalized patients, excluding those with the primary diagnosis of injury or neonatal/maternal disorders. PG patients were identified using ICD-9 diagnosis code 686.01 were divided into adults (≥18 years old) and children (<18). For each age group the PG patients were compared to non-PG patients in terms of patients' characteristics and associated diagnosis. In order to determine if the adult and child associations between PG and associated diagnoses were statistically different, Breslow-Day test for homogeneity of the Odds Ratios was utilized. Evaluated associated diagnoses included malignancy, hematologic malignancy, arteritis, arthropathy, and colitis.

Results:During the study period, there were 204 / 7,384,591 inpatient children and 10,154 / 89,674,318 inpatient adults with PG. In both age groups, patients were more likely to be female. In adults but not children patients with PG were majority white. The most common comorbidity was GI in nature, with over a third and quarter of patients affected in children and adults, respectively. Both adult and pediatric PG patients were more likely to have arteritis, arthropathy, and colitis. PG was associated with hematologic malignancies among the adults but not children. The degree of correlation between PG and associated diagnoses was significantly different between the two age groups; the PG children had a significantly greater odds ratio for having arteritis (28 vs 15.9), arthropathy (15.5 vs 5.3), and colitis (98.8 vs 43.7).

Conclusion:This is the first and largest study of PG in adult and child populations. It demonstrates the associations currently known regarding other systems and adult PG. In contrast, pediatric PG is much more highly associated with GI, rheumatologic, and vascular issues than adult PG, and much less likely to be coincident with hematologic malignancy than the general inpatient population. These differences demonstrate both a need to treat the disease differently in the pediatric population and the possibility that they are differing diseases.

abstract_title: Porcine Acellular Dermal Matrix for Hernia Repair in Transplant Patients
author_block: A. U. Gowda<sup>1</sup>, S. Chang<sup>1</sup>, K. Chopra<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Sabino<sup>1,2</sup>, D. P. Singh<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Maryland,Plastic Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA <sup>2</sup>Johns Hopkins University School Of Medicine,Plastic Surgery,Baltimore, MD, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Incisional hernia is a common complication of abdominal surgery. Further complications may result follwing repair such as recurrence, infection and dehiscence. Patients who have undergone solid organ transplantation are particularly prone to such complications as a result of impaired wound healing due to immunosuppressive requirements and comorbid conditions. Numerous techniques and products have been employed in the repair of incisional ventral hernias including the use of synthetic mesh and biologic tissue matrices. Among repair options, biologic tissue matrices are considered advantageous due to their mechanical durability and lower complication profile than synthetic mesh. Strattice™ (LifeCell Corporation, Branchburg, N.J.), a porcine-derived non-cross-linked acellular dermal matrix (PADM), shows promise in hernia repair due to its low cost and favorable biomechanical properties. The goal of this study was to compare clinical outcomes of incisional hernia repair in solid organ transplant patients using PADM with human acellular dermal matrix (HADM), Alloderm® (LifeCell Corporation, Branchburg, N.J.), and synthetic mesh.

Methods: A retrospective, single-center review of patients who underwent ventral hernia repair with PADM following pancrease and/or renal transplant at the University of Maryland Medical Center from 2008 to 2012 was conducted. Outcomes examined were: type of repair, post-operative infection, hernia recurrence, mesh removal, and length of follow-up. These results were compared to liver, renal, or pancreas transplant recipients with ventral/incisional hernias repaired with synthetic mesh or HADM at the University of Maryland Medical Center between 2000 and 2005.

Results: A total of 87 patients met study criteria and were evaluated for incidence of wound complications including hernia recurrence, wound infection and mesh removal. Of these, 27 underwent ventral hernia repair with PADM. Only patients with greater than 2 months of follow-up were included in analysis of hernia recurrence (n=15). Thirty-four patients were repaired with HADM and 26 with synthetic mesh, both with a mean follow-up of 26 months. The rate of wound infection in those repaired with PADM, HADM, and synthetic mesh were 14.3%, 14.7%, and 65.4%, respectively. Rates of recurrence were 11.7%, 23.5%, and 76.9%, respectively. Rate of mesh removal was found to be 7.1%, 11.8%, and 69.2%, respectively. These complication rates were significantly lower in patients who received HADM or PADM verses patients repaired with synthetic mesh (P<0.001). There was no statistically significant difference in the outcomes between HADM and PADM groups.

Conclusion:The use of PADM for incisional hernia repair following solid organ transplant significantly reduces the incidence of hernia recurrence, wound infection, and need for mesh removal compared to synthetic mesh. No significant difference inmorbidity between HADM and PADM was observed in this high-risk population.

abstract_title: SRS - Laparoscopy or Clinical Follow Up to Detect Occult Diaphragm Injuries Following Left Sided Thoracoabdominal Stab Wounds: A Randomized Controlled Trial
author_block: F. Malherbe<sup>1</sup>, P. H. Navsaria<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Nicol<sup>1</sup>, S. Edu<sup>1</sup>, S. M. Chowdhury<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Groote Schuur Hospital,University Of Cape Town,Cape Town, , South Africa
abstract_body:
Objective: The purpose of this study was to determine whether patients with left sided (TA) stab wounds can be safely treated with clinical and chest radiograph follow up. Background: Patients with left thoracoabdominal (TA) stab wounds should undergo routine diagnostic laparoscopy and repair of a diaphragm laceration when detected.

Methods: A prospective, randomized control study was conducted at Groote Schuur Hospital from September 2009 through to November 2014. Patients with asymptomatic left TA stab wounds included in the trial were randomized into two groups. Group A underwent diagnostic laparoscopy and Group B underwent clinical and radiological follow up.

Results: Twenty seven patients were randomized to Group A (N=27) and thirty one to Group B (N=31). All patients were young males with a median age of 26 years (range 18 to 48). The incidence of occult diaphragm injury in group A was 29%. All diaphragm injuries found at laparoscopy were repaired. The mean hospital stay for the patients in Group A was 5 days (SD 1.3), compared to a mean hospital stay of 2.9 days (SD, 1.5), in Group B (p < 0.001). All patients in group 2 had normal chest X-rays at their last visit. The mean follow up time was 24 months (range of 0 to 58). There was no morbidity or mortality in group B.

Conclusions: Clinical and radiological follow up is feasible and appears to be safe in patients who harbour occult diaphragm injuries after left TA stab wounds.

abstract_title: Initial HMGB1 Surge Drives Distinct Immune Responses and Affects Outcome in Trauma Patients.
author_block: A. W. Chen<sup>1</sup>, R. A. Namas<sup>1,2</sup>, O. Abdul-Malak<sup>1</sup>, Y. Vodovotz<sup>1,2</sup>, T. R. Billiar<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Department Of Surgery,Pittsburgh, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>University Of Pittsburgh,Center For Inflammation And Regenerative Modeling, McGowan Institute For Regenerative Medicine,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: High-mobility group box protein 1 (HMGB1) is a nuclear protein that may be released actively from immune cells or passively from damaged cells post-injury. Recent studies on human trauma patients have shown that HMGB1 displays proinflammatory cytokine-like properties, being elevated early within 4 h of injury. However, it remains unclear whether HMGB1 surge post-trauma could affect downstream production of inflammatory mediators. We hypothesized that the initial HMGB1 surge post-trauma can be associated with differential downstream immune responses which might drive outcomes in trauma patients.

Methods: From biobank data of 472 trauma survivors, we performed a retrospective case–control study, where 44 trauma patients (27 males and 17 females; age: 48 ± 3; ISS: 26.3 ± 1.7) who went on to develop nosocomial infection (NI) were identified and compared to 44 patients (27 males and 17 females; age: 47.3 ± 2; ISS: 26.1 ± 0.9) with no-NI, matched for age, gender, injury severity, and mechanism of injury. Plasma was sampled 3 times within the first 24 h for multiple inflammation biomarkers using Luminex™. Area under the curve (AUC) analysis was used at 4–8, 4–16, and 4–24 h intervals to quantify the successive total amount of production of inflammatory mediators. Spearman's correlation coefficient (cc) was calculated to determine associations between HMGB1 and inflammatory mediators' AUC. Subsequently, we computed the inflammatory mediator rank correlations vs. early HMGB1levels at 4h post-injury. We classified these biomarkers into HMGB1-associated (positive or negative) and HMGB1-disassociated mediators.

Results: Significant differences in ICU length of stay (LOS), hospital LOS, and days on mechanical ventilation were observed in the NI vs. no-NI patients. Although HMGB1 was elevated at 4h in both sub-groups, the NI patients had significantly higher levels of HMGB1 when compared to no-NI patients. Correlations of the initial HMGB1 surge at 4h post-trauma with the AUC of inflammatory mediators suggested that HMGB1 correlates positively with IL-13 (cc=0.49, P=0.04) and IL-17A (cc=0.52, P=0.03) by 20–24h post-injury in NI patients. Interestingly, HMGB1 correlated negatively with Eotaxin (cc=-0.94, P=0.02), IL-4 (cc=-0.93, P=0.02), and IL-1RA (cc=-0.89, P=0.03) by 4–8h post-injury in the no-NI patients.

Conclusion: These results suggest that divergent immune events are associated with the initial HMGB1 surge post-trauma. In addition, our analysis implies a key role of downstream mediators of Th2 and Th17 immune responses in patients who follow a complicated clinical course post-trauma.

abstract_title: HMGB1 Enriched Platelet Microparticles Increase after Trauma and Contribute to Thrombosis
author_block: Q. Chen<sup>1</sup>, J. Markel<sup>1</sup>, A. Gutierrez<sup>1</sup>, A. Hassoune<sup>1</sup>, S. Vogel<sup>1</sup>, T. Billiar<sup>1</sup>, M. D. Neal<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pittsburg Medical Center,Surgery And Critical Care Medicine,Pittsburgh, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma is characterized by microvascular thrombosis and an elevated risk of thrombotic complications although the mechanisms remain largely unknown. Recently, expression of the damage associated molecular pattern molecule, high-mobility group box 1 (HMGB1), in platelets has been identified as a critical mediator for thrombosis. Platelet microparticles (MP) are also associated with thrombus formation in many diseases. We now hypothesize that MPs contain HMGB1 and that blocking HMGB1 on MPs using the HMGB1 inhibitor, chloroquine (CQ), will attenuate thrombus formation.

Methods: ELISA and FACS were used to test HMGB1 content in MPs from activated human platelets. FACS was also applied to study MP population changes in human trauma patients. To access the ability for CQ to block MP formation and platelet function, FACS, whole blood aggregometer, and flow chamber analysis were used.

Results:MPs derived from activated platelets were rich in HMGB1 both by ELISA and FACS. HMGB1 expression on trauma patient MPs showed strong intensity compared with isotype (FACS MFI 1105.3±72.1 vs 304.2±22.1 p<0.01). Human trauma patients had an upregulation of the MP population compared to healthy controls (FACS % 4.4±0.6 vs 2.5±0.2 p<0.05). Platelet MPs were significantly inhibited after CQ treatment (FACS % 22.4±3.4 vs 5.8±1.1 p<0.01). Importantly, CQ markedly inhibited thrombus formation and HMGB1 mediated platelet aggregation in ex vivo flow chamber and aggregometry analysis from human platelets.

Conclusion:Platelet activation following trauma results in platelet MP release and strong HMGB1 surface expression. HMGB1 expression on platelets and MPs regulates thrombus formation. Strikingly, CQ treatment decreased platelet aggregation and platelet derived MP formation. This novel anti-inflammatory and anti-thrombotic effects of CQ suggest a new potential target for reducing thrombotic MP formation.

abstract_title: Trauma Team Size and Task Performance in Adult Trauma Resuscitation
author_block: P. Maluso<sup>1</sup>, M. Hernandez<sup>1</sup>, R. L. Amdur<sup>1</sup>, L. Collins<sup>1</sup>, M. E. Schroeder<sup>1</sup>, B. Sarani<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>George Washington University School Of Medicine And Health Sciences,Surgery,Washington, DC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Trauma resuscitation requires a multidisciplinary approach. The number of persons required to optimize the timely and accurate completion of the primary and secondary survey is not known. We hypothesize that there is a non-linear relationship between team size and task completion.

Methods: Video-recorded resuscitations of adult trauma patients at a level 1 trauma center were reviewed for completion of 20 tasks at 2 and 5 minutes following patient arrival. Tasks were chosen based on standard endpoints as defined in the Advanced Trauma Life Support Course. Number of team members present at patient arrival (teamN), triage status, mechanism of injury (MOI), off-hours, attending presence within 5 minutes of patient arrival, identifiable leader, and the use of closed-loop communication were abstracted. Chi-square testing was used to assess univariate relationship between team size and completed tasks and spearman correlation was used to assess the strength of associations identified. Multivariate regression (MVR) analysis was used to control for teamN, off-hours, MOI, attending presence, leadership, triage status, and closed loop communication. SAS version 9.3 was used for all analyses with p<0.05 considered significant.

Results:170 cases were reviewed, 44 of which were top tier activations. Mean teamN at patient arrival was 5.7 ± 1.9 persons. Mean maximum team size was 8.9 ± 2.1 persons. Mean tasks completed within 2 and 5 minutes of patient arrival were 10.9 ± 2.0 and 15.2 ± 1.4, respectively. There was a significant positive correlation between teamN and number of tasks completed in 2 minutes (Spearman r =0.34; p=<0.0001) and 5 minutes (Spearman r =0.22; p=0.004). Maximum team members present was also significantly associated with task completion in 2 minutes (Spearman r=0.31, p<0.0001) and 5 minutes (Spearman r=0.15, p=0.049). The presence of any identifiable and engaged leader was weakly associated with task completion (r=0.21, p<0.01) whereas the specific presence of an attending surgeon was not. No association was found between closed loop communication and task completion. Also, no association was found between activation level or time of day. Only teamN had a significant, independent, positive association with task completion at 2 and 5 minutes on MVR (p=0.005). For each additional team member present, the number of tasks completed within 2 and 5 minutes of patient arrival increased by 0.3 and 0.2, respectively.

Conclusion:After controlling for confounding variables, only team size was independently associated with task completion. Rather than focusing on optimal team size, future studies should focus on evaluating the impact of specific role assignment to each team member.

abstract_title: Traditional Autopsy Versus CT-Imaging Autopsy In Trauma: A Case of 'Synergistic Disagreement'
author_block: M. J. Lin<sup>1</sup>, N. Barry<sup>1</sup>, I. Akusoba<sup>1</sup>, H. H. Hon<sup>1</sup>, M. S. Cohen<sup>1</sup>, P. Shukla<sup>2</sup>, J. Cipolla<sup>1</sup>, S. P. Stawicki<sup>1</sup>, B. A. Hoey<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>St. Luke's University Health Network,Department Of Surgery,Bethlehem, PA, USA <sup>2</sup>St. Luke's University Health Network,Department Of Radiology,Bethlehem, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Sustained declines in traditional autopsy (TA) rates negatively impacted traumatology, especially in the areas of quality improvement and medical education. To help enhance our understanding of trauma-related mortality, a number of imaging autopsy (IA) initiatives were conceived, including the postmortem computed tomography ('CATopsy') project at our institution. Though IA is a promising concept, there are few studies describing the correlation between TA and IA findings. Consequently, we set out to improve our understanding of similarities and differences between key findings on TA and IA in a prospective, pathologist/radiologist blinded fashion.

Methods: A prospective study of TA versus IA was conducted at an Academic Level I Trauma Center (June 2001 - May 2010). All decedents underwent a postmortem whole-body, non-contrast computed tomography (CT) that was interpreted by an independent/blinded, board-certified radiologist. A blinded, board-certified pathologist then performed TA. Autopsy results were grouped into pre-defined categories of pathologic findings. Categorized findings from TA and IA were compared by determining the degree of agreement (kappa). In addition, chi-square testing was used to detect differences in 'potentially fatal' findings (e.g., aortic trauma, splenic injury, intracranial bleeding, etc) between TA and IA.

Results: Twenty-five trauma decedents (19 blunt; 9 female; median age 32.5 years) had a total of 435 unique findings on either IA or TA, grouped into 34 categories. The agreement between IA and TA was worse than what chance would predict (kappa = -0.58). The greatest agreement was seen in injuries involving axial skeleton and intracranial/cranio-facial trauma. Most discrepancies were seen in soft tissue, ectopic air, and 'incidental' categories. Findings determined to be 'potentially fatal' were seen on both TA/IA in 48/435 (11%) instances, 79/435 (18%) on TA only, and 73/435 (17%) on IA only. TA identified more 'potentially fatal' solid organ and heart/great vessel injuries while IA revealed more 'potentially fatal' procedure-related and ectopic air/fluid findings (Figure 1).

Conclusion: The current study does not support substitutive use of non-contrast CT-based IA. However, our findings suggest that the two types of post-mortem evaluation may be complementary/synergistic when performed together. Particularly in this cost-conscious era, further research is crucial for identifying applications of IA in medical education and quality improvement in the absence of TA.

abstract_title: Failure to Rescue in Emergency General Surgery
author_block: D. Metcalfe<sup>1</sup>, O. A. Olufajo<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Rios Diaz<sup>1</sup>, A. Salim<sup>1</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Chaudhary<sup>1</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>1</sup>, J. M. Havens<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School,Center For Surgery And Public Health,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Lack of health insurance and Black race are associated with worse outcomes following emergency general surgery (EGS). However, the reasons for these disparities are not fully understood. 'Failure to rescue' (FTR), death following a major adverse event (MAE), is a measure that reflects the effectiveness with which healthcare providers respond to patients with MAEs. This study sought to investigate the relationship between racial and economic factors and FTR in EGS patients. We hypothesized that disparities in EGS outcomes can be partially explained by FTR.

Methods: The Nationwide Inpatient Sample (NIS) is the largest all-payer inpatient database in the United States and includes all patients discharged from a stratified sample of 20%. Discharge weights within the NIS permit data to be scaled up to national estimates.We extracted all patients with a primary EGS diagnosis from the NIS (2001-2011) using ICD-9 codes for conditions identified by the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST). Patients that developed a MAE (myocardial infarction, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, acute renal failure, respiratory failure, pneumonia, or post-operative hemorrhage) were used to define an 'at-risk' denominator group. Patients with a MAE that subsequently died comprised the numerator and were used to calculate FTR rates for categories based on race/ethnicity (White, Black, Hispanic) and primary payer status (privately insured, public insurance, uninsured). A Chi-square test was used to compare categorical variables and the Wilcoxon rank sum test for continuous variables. Multivariable logistic regression models were used to adjust odds of MAE and FTR for patient- and hospital-level factors.

Results:A weighted total of 20 million EGS admissions were identified; 2.6 million (13.0%) developed a MAE and 200,000 died, giving an overall FTR rate of 7.7%. In this cohort, Black (adjusted odds ratio 1.13, 95% CI 1.08-1.18) and uninsured patients (aOR 1.21, 1.12-1.32) were significantly more likely to die than White patients and those with private insurance.In both the unadjusted and adjusted analyses, Black patients had higher odds of a MAE (14.2% versus 13.3%, p<0.001; adjusted odds ratio 1.28, 95% CI 1.25-1.32) but lower odds of FTR (6.9% versus 8.2%, p<0.001; aOR 0.93, 0.89-0.98).Uninsured patients had lower odds of MAE in the unadjusted analysis (6.7% versus 7.9%, p<0.001) but this finding was not significant within a multivariable logistic regression model (adjusted OR 1.00, 95% CI 0.97-1.04). Uninsured patients had increased adjusted odds of FTR when compared with privately insured patients (aOR 1.24, 1.12-1.37).

Conclusion:FTR partially explains worse outcomes for uninsured EGS patients. However, worse outcomes for Black patients are not readily explained by FTR and may instead be related to a higher proportion of MAEs. Further investigation into the causes of these disparities is needed.

abstract_title: Posttraumatic levels of liver enzymes can reduce the need for CT in children
author_block: P. J. Bruhn<sup>1</sup>, L. +sterballe<sup>1</sup>, J. Hillings<sup>1</sup>, L. B. Svendsen<sup>1</sup>, F. Helgstrand<sup>2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Rigshospitalet, Copenhagen University Hospital,Department Of Surgical Gastroenterology,Copenhagen, -, Denmark <sup>2</sup>Kge Hospital, Copenhagen University Hospital,Department Of Surgical Gastroenterology,Kge, -, Denmark
abstract_body:
Introduction: Computed tomography (CT) is the gold standard in the initial evaluation of the hemodynamically stable patient with suspected blunt liver trauma. However, the adverse effects of radiation exposure are of specific concern in the pediatric population. It is therefore desirable to explore alternative diagnostic modalities. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) are hepatic enzymes, which are elevated in peripheral blood in relation to liver injury. The aim of the present study was to investigate, if normal liver transaminase levels are of value in the decision algorithm in suspected pediatric blunt liver trauma.

Methods: Retrospective analysis of consecutively collected data from children (0-17 years) with CT-diagnosed blunt liver trauma, admitted to a single level one trauma centre, between 2000 and 2013. We included patients, who underwent abdominal CT during initial evaluation, and in whom initial AST and/or ALT was measured. Based on local guidelines, we set the threshold for blood AST and ALT level to 50 IU/L.

Results: Sixty consecutive children with liver injury following blunt abdominal trauma were enrolled in the study. All patients with normal AST and/or ALT level were treated conservatively with success. Information on both AST and ALT was available in 47 children. Of these 47 children, three children had both AST and ALT levels equal to or lower than 50 IU/l. These children suffered from grade I liver injuries, and were treated conservatively with no complications. AST and ALT levels showed significant positive correlation to liver injury grades (p=0.002 for AST, and p=0.022 for ALT).

Conclusion: Our study indicates that CT might be superfluous in the initial evaluation of hemodynamically stable children with suspected blunt liver injury and blood AST and ALT levels equal to or below 50 IU/L. On the basis of our results, we propose a revised algorithm for management of pediatric blunt liver injury, which includes evaluation of AST and ALT as a screening method to avoid abdominal CT (figure 1).

abstract_title: Victims of Violent Injury May Benefit from Brief interventions Despite Mechanism of Injury and Age
author_block: J. Passman<sup>1</sup>, D. Holena<sup>1</sup>, P. Kim<sup>1</sup>, P. Kim<sup>1</sup>, P. Reilly<sup>1</sup>, S. Allen<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>University Of Pennsylvania,Traumatology, Surgical Critical Care And Emergency Surgery,Philadelphia, PA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Injury via interpersonal violence (GSW, stab wounds and assaults) leads to nearly two million hospital visits annually in the US alone. Nearly 44% of patients admitted for such injuries sustain another violent injury, i.e. trauma recidivism. Many brief in-hospital interventions focus on young victims of gunshot injuries. We hypothesized that repeat victims of all interpersonal violent injuries are at risk of repeated injury and differ significantly in their demographic profiles.

Methods: We analyzed the institutional trauma registry of our urban Level 1 trauma center for all victims of violent injury to identify victims of violent injury such as GSW, SW and assaults. Patients who were injured more than once by a similarly violent mechanism, or trauma recidivists (TR) were identified for further study. A propensity matched control group (matched on age, gender, mechanism of injury and ISS) of those injured only a single time was identified (Non-TR). We captured basic demographics, alcohol (ETOH) and illicit drug abuse. ETOH and drug screen results were compared between TR and those in the propensity matched control group only injured once (non-TRs). Drug and alcohol screens were also compared among TRs' first and second admissions.

Results:Overall (n=410), the mechanisms of injury (GSW, SW and assault) were distributed nearly equally with GSW (38.0%), SW (32%) and assault (30%) across the study population. Victims of SW and assaults were significantly older than GSW victims (GSW: 24.4 (6.4) vs. SW: 34.7 (10.8) vs. 37.6 (11.3), P=0.001). More victims of SW and assaults tested positive for ETOH with higher blood alcohol concentration (BAC) than victims of GSW (SW: 68.0%, mean BAC 82.3 (107.3) vs. assault: 76.2%, mean BAC 125.5 (136.7) vs. GSW: 41.7%, mean BAC 24.5 (56.7), P=0.001). TRs (n=131) demonstrated significantly higher blood alcohol levels and tested positive for alcohol more often than non-TR. No difference in illicit drug use was identified between TR and non-TR. Among the TR, there was a significant increase in ISS (5.76 (6.5) to 9.28 (13.6), P=0.001) from initial injury to subsequent injury. There was nearly a 2.5-fold increase in mortality between non-TR and TRs' subsequent injuries for all mechanisms of injury studied (3.76% vs 9.03%, 0.041).

Conclusion:While most brief in-hospital interventions focus on young victims of gunshot violence, a significant proportion of those injured repeatedly by interpersonal violence are injured by other mechanisms such as SW and assault. These victims tend to be older and abuse ETOH. Due to the demonstrated increase in injury severity and increase in mortality across these mechanisms of injury, brief interventions should target all adults who are injured by any violent mechanism with an emphasis on alcohol abuse as a potentially modifiable risk factor for repeat injury.

abstract_title: Prophylactic Pleural Lavage Decreases Secondary Intervention in Patients with Traumatic Hemothorax
author_block: N. W. Kugler<sup>1</sup>, T. W. Carver<sup>1</sup>, J. S. Paul<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Medical College Of Wisconsin,Trauma And Critical Care,Milwaukee, WI, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: The majority of thoracic trauma resulting in traumatic hemothorax can be successfully managed with thoracostomy tube drainage alone. However, between 15-25% of patients develop a retained hemothorax requiring a secondary intervention like Video Assisted Thorascopic Surgery (VATS) or additional thoracostomy tube placement. Historically, our secondary intervention rate for retained hemothorax has been 26.7%. Therefore, the aim of this study was to determine if prophylactic pleural lavage decreases the need for secondary intervention.

Methods: An IRB approved, prospective, observational trial of twenty consecutive patients who underwent prophylactic pleural lavage at the time of thoracostomy tube placement was conducted. Patients with hemothorax identified on initial AP supine chest x-ray (CXR) were included. Following standard sterile bedside placement of a 36-French thoracostomy tube the hemothorax was evacuated utilizing a sterile suction catheter advanced into the thoracostomy tube. One liter of warmed sterile saline was instilled into the chest through the thoracostomy tube followed by suction catheter evacuation of fluid. The thoracostomy tube was connected to the sterile drainage atrium and -20cm2 of suction was applied for 24 hours. Thoracostomy tubes were then managed in accordance with our standard division protocol.

Results: Of the 20 patients 70% were male at median age 35 (IQR 28-54) years, median ISS 13 (IQR 9-18.3), with 55% suffering penetrating trauma. Thirteen (65%) of the patients underwent lavage within 6 hours of trauma with the remainder undergoing lavage within 48 hours. Nineteen of the 20 patients received the full 1,000mL irrigation with an average net return of +26mL. On post-procedure CXR four patients (20%) demonstrated complete resolution of the hemothorax, overall 19 (95%) demonstrated improvement on the immediate post-procedure CXR. Fifty-two percent of the total TT output was collected through the first 24 hours. The secondary intervention rate was 5% with a single patient requiring VATS on post-trauma day zero for retained hemothorax. The average thoracostomy tube duration was 5+/-1 days and median length of stay was 7 days (IQR 5-7). No adverse events related to the pleural lavage were noted.

Conclusion: Prophylactic pleural lavage at the time of thoracostomy tube placement for traumatic hemothorax decreases the rate of secondary intervention for the management of retained hemothorax. Given the possibility of selection bias in this prospective study, a randomized trial investigating the efficacy of prophylactic pleural lavage is warranted.

abstract_title: Comparative Assessment of Elixhauser vs Charlson's Comorbidity Index for Acute Care Surgery
author_block: A. A. Shah<sup>1,2</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1</sup>, M. A. Chaudhary<sup>1</sup>, W. Jiang<sup>1</sup>, A. B. Chapital<sup>2</sup>, D. J. Johnson<sup>2</sup>, A. Ashraq<sup>2</sup>, A. Salim<sup>3</sup>, J. M. Havens<sup>3</sup>, Z. Cooper<sup>1</sup>, S. Nitzschke<sup>3</sup>, A. H. Haider<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health, Harvard Medical School, Harvard T H Chan School Of Public Health,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Mayo Clinic In Arizona,Department Of Surgery,Phoenix, AZ, USA <sup>3</sup>Brigham And Women's Hospital,Division Of Trauma, Burns And Surgical Critical Care,Boston, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Multiple measures of comorbidities have emerged for risk stratification of surgical patients. The Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) and the Elixhauser Comorbidity Index (ECI), are among the most commonly used in surgical outcomes research. While extensively studied in other areas of elective surgical care, limited assessment of their utility has been conducted for acute care surgery, beyond research in burns and extremity fractures. To that end, the objective of this study was to determine the relative predictive value of CCI vs ECI as comorbidity assessments in models of mortality and major complications for various subsets of acute care surgical patients.

Methods: Five years of data from the Nationwide Inpatient Sample (2007-2011) was queried for adult patients (≥18y) with a primary diagnosis of traumatic injury, emergency general surgery (EGS) -- defined by the AAST – (critical subsets of acute care surgery) or emergent admissions for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair, coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), and colectomy (major procedures associated with prevalent morbidity/morality). Base multivariable assessment models adjusted for a commonly utilized set of patient- and hospital-related factors, without consideration of comorbidities. Elaboration models considered both CCI and ECI as summary measures as well as by inclusion of individually identified comorbidities. Model discrimination was assessed using concordance (c) statistics.

Results:A total of 5,742,935 patient records for acute care surgery were analyzed. Of these, 65.6% had an EGS conditions, 24.6% traumatic injuries, 4.3% underwent emergent CABG repair, 4.3% underwent emergent colectomy, and 1.2% underwent emergent AAA repair. Models comprising of the individual indicators of comorbidities for both Charlson and Elixhauser performed better than the weighted scores for both complications and mortality, for each diagnostic subgroup (Table). Addition of individual Elixhauser indicators of comorbidities considerably improved the discriminative ability of the model at predicting mortality (increase by 1.29% for trauma, 13.10% for AAA, 4.39% for CABG, 4.82% for colectomies & 2.72% for EGS) and complications (increase by 1.31% for trauma, 2.2% for AAA, 0.74% for CABG, 2.23% for colectomies & 3.05% for EGS) compared to the Charlson indicators of comorbidities (p<0.05).

Conclusion:Elixhauser and Charlson's comorbidity indices both displayed good discrimination ability. However individual Elixhauser comorbidity measures performed the best in both morbidity and mortality models. This bares implications on the use of Elixhauser indicators of comorbidity for risk stratification of acute care surgery patients in administrative datasets.

abstract_title: Liver Transplant Biliary Complications for Deceased Donor Grafts: Comparison of HTK and UW Solutions
author_block: W. A. Marshall<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Tector<sup>1</sup>, T. C. Borup<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Mangus<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery/Transplant,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Flushing of the biliary microvasculature at the time of whole organ liver graft procurement appears to be an important component in optimizing blood flow to the biliary system. Two primary preservation solutions are most commonly employed in the United States, University of Wisconsin (UW) and Histidine-Tryptophan-Ketoglutarate (HTK) solutions. While HTK has a viscosity similar to that of water, UW is much more viscous. It has therefore been proposed that the less viscous HTK provides a better flush of the liver graft at the time of procurement. This then leads to the question of whether or not this improved flush results in a lower rate of biliary complications in HTK preserved livers, particularly donation after circulatory death (DCD) grafts. The present study evaluates biliary complications in 1527 consecutive liver transplant patients. The primary study variable is the choice of graft preservation solution, UW or HTK. Outcomes include post-transplant biliary complications, as well as graft and patient survival. Measured biliary complications include any need for bile duct imaging, intra- and extra-hepatic stricture formation, and bile duct leak. The secondary outcome was graft survival.

Methods: Data were extracted retrospectively from a large, single center database covering the period from 2001 to 2014. All primary imaging reports were reviewed. For this study, a patient was considered to have an anastomotic stricture if this is reported, and an intervention (balloon dilation or stent placement) is performed. Patients in whom sphincterotomy alone was performed were not considered to have a stricture. Any leakage of contrast from the biliary system was considered a biliary leak, though most were easily managed with temporary stenting of the duct.

Results:There were 1527 LTs reviewed, 1360 (89%) with duct-to-duct and 163 (11%) with Roux-Y choledochojejunostomy. Preservation included 1098 HTK (72%) and 429 UW (28%) grafts. One-year graft survival favored HTK preserved livers (88% vs 84%, p=0.02). Any biliary imaging was required for 50% of HTK and 59% of UW LTs (p=0.001). The risk of any leak was higher for UW (18%) versus HTK (7%) (p<0.001). The risk of any stricture was higher for HTK (45% vs 38%, p=0.01), but intrahepatic strictures were more common for UW (5% vs 2%, p=0.001). Among donation after circulatory death (DCD) grafts, there was a higher risk of intrahepatic ischemic-type strictures in UW-preserved grafts (36% vs 8%, p=0.02). Survival at 10-years favored HTK.

Conclusion:HTK liver graft preservation in deceased donors is associated with better graft survival, less imaging, less risk of biliary leak and intrahepatic stricture, and a lower risk of intrahepatic strictures in DCD grafts.

abstract_title: Computed tomography (CT) measures of nutrition deficits in patients with end stage liver disease
author_block: J. Davis<sup>1</sup>, W. Bush<sup>1</sup>, A. J. Tector<sup>1</sup>, J. Salisbury<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Mangus<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery/Transplant,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Patients with cirrhosis and end-stage liver disease (ESLD) develop severe nutrition deficits that impact on perioperative morbidity and mortality. Previous research demonstrates that laboratory measures of nutrition status fail to assess clinical deficits in muscle mass and fat tissue. This study employs computed tomography imaging to assess (1) muscle mass and (2) subcutaneous and (3) visceral fat stores in patients with ESLD.

Methods: A 1:1 case-control study design is used to compare ESLD patients with healthy controls. Study patients were selected from a database of ESLD patients using a stratified study design to include a representative number from a range of age groups and body mass indices (BMI), from both genders, and from a range of model for end-stage liver disease scores (MELD). Controls were selected from the trauma database as patients with an injury severity score less than 10, who received an abdominal CT scan. Cases and controls were matched for age +/- 5 years, gender, and BMI +/- 2.

Results:There were 90 subjects and 90 controls. The ESLD patients had a lower albumin level (p<0.001), but similar total protein level (p=0.72). The ESLD patients had a -19% muscle mass deficit (p<0.001), a similar distribution of subcutaneous fat (-1%, p=0.35), and a -13% visceral fat deficit (p<0.001). Subgroup analysis of ESLD patients found only a lower albumin level among high MELD patients (<0.001, compared to low MELD). Females had a significantly lower muscle mass and perinephric fat volume, but a higher subcutaneous fat volume when compared to ESLD males. There was a loss of muscle mass and visceral fat with increasing age, while subcutaneous fat was similar among age groups. Finally, ESLD patients with a high BMI had a lesser deficit of muscle mass and subcutaneous and visceral fat when compared to low BMI ESLD patients.

Conclusion:These results support previous research demonstrating substantial nutritional deficits in ESLD patients that are not adequately measured by laboratory testing. Standard CT scans can be employed to assess the distribution and quantity of nutritional deficits. Patients with ESLD have significant deficits of muscle and visceral fat stores, but a similar amount of subcutaneous fat. Nutritional deficits in ESLD vary by gender, age, and BMI.

abstract_title: Hospital Characteristics Associated With Increased Conversion Rates Among Organ Donors
author_block: A. J. Rios Diaz<sup>1</sup>, O. Olufajo<sup>1,2</sup>, J. Stinebring<sup>3</sup>, S. Endicott<sup>3</sup>, B. T. McKown<sup>3</sup>, D. Metcalfe<sup>1,2</sup>, C. K. Zogg<sup>1</sup>, A. Salim<sup>1,2</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Harvard Medical School And Harvard T. H. Chan School Of Public Health. Brigham And Women's Hospital,Center For Surgery And Public Health, Department Of Surgery,Boston, MA, USA <sup>2</sup>Harvard Medical School. Brigham And Women's Hospital,Trauma, Burn And Surgical Critical Care, Department Of Surgery,Boston, 02115, USA <sup>3</sup>New England Organ Bank,Waltham, MA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: It is important to maximize donor conversion rates to increase the pool of organs available. However, it is unknown which hospitals are least successful at converting potential donors which is necessary for targeted interventions to increase the donor pool. Therefore, the objective of the present study was to determine hospital- and patient-level characteristics associated with high transplant donor conversion rates (actual donors/potential donors) after brain death (DBD) in hospitals located in New England.

Methods: Data were extracted from the New England Organ Bank (2011-2014) and American Hospital Association Annual Survey Database (2012). Hospitals with < 4 potential DBD were excluded. Conversion rates were calculated for each hospital, which were stratified into high-conversion hospitals (HCH; upper tertile) and low-conversion hospitals (LCH; lower tertile). Hospital- and patient- characteristics were explored using descriptive statistics, Fisher's exact (categorical) and Kruskal-Wallis (continuous) tests with a significance threshold set at p<0.05.

Results: There were 805 potential donors in 28 hospitals. HCH were more likely to be small (median bed size 194 vs. 337; p=0.02), non-teaching hospitals (90.0% vs. 41.2%; p=0.02), non-trauma center (72.7% vs. 23.5%; p=0.02); but did not differ in terms of rurality (p=0.692), ownership (non-for-profit 72.7% vs. 82.4%; p=0.618), ICU (100% vs. 93.3%; p>0.99) and burn (0.0% vs. 26.7%; p=0.26) services, trauma center level designation (p=0.31), stroke (9.1% vs. 29.4%; p=0.36) and transplant (0.0% vs. 32.3%; p=0.05) center status. There were significant differences in conversion rates between hospitals in different states (p=0.02). The only demographic characteristics that varied between HCHs and LCHs were potential donor race (p<0.01) and mechanism of injury/disease process (p<0.01) (Table 1). In every case, failure to convert potential donors to DBD was due to lack of consent from next-of-kin for a range of reasons, including relatives not wanting to wait or not wanting their surgery for their loved ones, cultural/religious and not being aware of the patient's wishes. However, these reasons did not differ significantly between HCHs and LCHs (p=0.243) (Table 1).

Conclusion: There is significant variation in donor conversion rates among different hospitals. In particular, a large proportion of potential donors in large regional hospitals are not successfully converted to actual donors. Further work is necessary to determine why conversion rates are lower in large regional hospitals and whether variations in the structure or processes of care are involved.

abstract_title: Comparing the Survival Benefit of Liver Transplantation in Hepatocellular and Cholangiocarcinoma
author_block: I. N. Khan<sup>1</sup>, Z. Sun<sup>1</sup>, B. Ezekian<sup>1</sup>, D. P. Nussbaum<sup>1</sup>, S. J. Knechtle<sup>1</sup>, S. Zani<sup>1</sup>, D. G. Blazer<sup>1</sup>, K. N. Shah<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Duke University Medical Center,Durham, NC, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: In the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), liver transplantation (LT) has emerged as the preferred treatment option for cirrhotic patients and for multifocal disease within Milan criteria. Unlike HCC, there is no established role for LT in the treatment of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (IHC). Though some suggest LT may have acceptable outcomes in highly selected patients, a number of smaller studies have demonstrated high rates of recurrence and worse outcomes after LT for IHC. We examined the National Cancer Data Base (NCDB) to compare survival between patients undergoing LT with HCC to those with IHC and mixed HCC-cholangiocarcinoma (HCC/IHC).

Methods: We performed a retrospective review of the NCDB, including all adult patients with a diagnosis of HCC, IHC or mixed HCC/IHC who underwent LT between 1998 and 2012. Baseline characteristics and outcomes were compared between the three groups. The Kaplan-Meier method was used to compare unadjusted overall survival. A cox proportional hazards model was then developed to compare adjusted survival outcomes between groups.

Results: In total, 8,614 subjects were identified who underwent LT: 8,287 (96%) for HCC, 192 (2%) for ICH, and 135 (2%) for mixed HCC/IHC. Significant differences were noted in the baseline characteristics of IHC and HCC patients. In general IHC patients as compared to HCC patients were younger, healthier, had fewer comorbidities and a lesser degree of cirrhosis. The tumors, on the other hand were seen to be more aggressive in IHC versus HCC patients in terms of both size and level of differentiation. There were also notable differences following pathologic examination of the explanted livers, including a higher rate of both lymph node metastases and positive margins among patients with IHC versus HCC. While short-term 30- and 90-day mortality was similar between the three groups (2.8 vs. 4 vs. 3.2% and 4.9 vs. 6.9 vs. 6.5%, respectively), overall survival was significantly shorter for patients with IHC and HCC/IHC. Unadjusted median survival was approximately 144, 48 and 84 months for patients with HCC, IHC and mixed HCC/IHC, respectively (Figure 1). Following multivariable adjustment patients with HCC had significantly better survival outcomes as compared to patients with IHC (HR 1.9, p = 0.028) and mixed HCC/IHC (HR 2.1, p = 0.008).

Conclusion: Given the demand for donor livers, efficient use of this valuable resource is important. Oncologic outcomes following LT for IHC and HCC/IHC are inferior to those observed for HCC, and this suggests that both IHC and HCC/IHC may be best served with non-transplant treatment modalities. Unlike for HCC, where LT is a well established therapeutic option, current data do not support the routine use of LT in IHC.

abstract_title: Impact of Diabetic Gastroparesis on Outcomes After Pancreas Transplantation
author_block: W. A. Marshall<sup>1</sup>, R. S. Mangus<sup>1</sup>, J. Powelson<sup>1</sup>, J. A. Fridell<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Indiana University School Of Medicine,Surgery/Transplant,Indianapolis, IN, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: Gastroparesis (GP) is a chronic disorder of the stomach characterized by a delay in gastric emptying without an identifiable mechanical obstruction. There is a prevalence of GP among Type 1 and 2 diabetics of 5% and 1%, respectively. However, chronic abdominal symptoms, similar to GP, have been described in up to 20% of diabetic patients. The present study reviews the clinical outcomes for 526 consecutive pancreas transplants in Type 1 diabetics from 2003 to 2014. This study seeks to establish the prevalence of GP in this population, define management strategies, and assess the impact of GP on post- transplant outcomes.

Methods: The medical records for all adult, deceased donor pancreas transplants at a single center were reviewed. Inclusion criteria for this analysis included all transplant recipients undergoing either simultaneous pancreas and kidney transplant (SPK), pancreas after kidney transplant (PAK) or pancreas transplant alone (PTA).GP was defined as an abnormal finding on gastric-emptying scintigraphy, other abnormal motility study, or a documented history symptoms for greater than 3 months, consistent with gastroparesis. Primary transplant outcomes included 90-day pancreas allograft loss, 1- and 5-year pancreas allograft and patient survival, causes of allograft loss or death, length of hospital stay and readmissions within 3 months. Pancreas allograft failure was defined by dependence on subcutaneous insulin administration.

Results:There were 96 of 526 patients (18%) in this sample who were diagnosed with GP or had a history of GP-like symptoms. The GP patients were equally distributed with regard to type of pancreas transplant, race and body mass index. The patients with GP were significantly more likely to be female (p=0.01) and were younger (p=0.05). Post-transplant, there was no difference between GP and non-GP patients for length of hospital stay, nor for 1-year graft and patient survival. The GP patients were much more likely to be readmitted in the post-transplant period with nausea and emesis (40% of GP patients compared to 13% of non-GP patients, p<0.001). There was a dramatic increase in use of promotility agents after transplant related to an institutional desire to optimize gastric emptying and avoid post transplant complications and readmissions. Kaplan-Meier graft survival is similar between the GP and non-GP patients up to 10-years post-transplant (Log rank p=0.78). Long term patient survival was also similar between the groups (Log rank p=0.28), however there were many more early deaths for the GP patients in the 2-4 year post transplant period. There were a total of 16 deaths among the 96 patients with gastroparesis (17%). This compared to an overall death rate among non-GP patients of 14% (58 of 430, p=0.42).

Conclusion:GP is associated with increased perioperative complications after pancreas transplant. Long term outcomes for pancreas transplant patients with and without gastroparesis are similar.

abstract_title: Outcomes after Desensitization and Alemtuzumab Induction in Pediatric Kidney Transplant Recipients
author_block: I. K. Kim<sup>1</sup>, D. Puliyanda<sup>1</sup>, A. Klein<sup>1</sup>  <sup>1</sup>Cedars-Sinai Medical Center,Transplant Surgery,Los Angeles, CA, USA
abstract_body:
Introduction: A growing proportion of patients awaiting kidney transplantation are highly sensitized (HS), including the pediatric population. Recent studies report on the safe and effective use of alemtuzumab as an induction agent in pediatric renal transplantation. Due to the relative naivety of the pediatric immune system, children are theoretically at higher risk for infectious complications following immunosuppression. In this study, we report on the safe and effective use of desensitization therapy with alemtuzumab induction in highly sensitized pediatric patients.

Methods: From Jan 2009, 37 pts (Group A:10, Group B: 27) were included. Group A had received IVIg/Rituximab for desensitization. At transplant, Group A received Alemtuzumab (15-30mg,1 dose); Group B received anti-IL-2R. Patients were maintained on CNI/MMF/steroids. Prophylaxis with antifungal (fluconazole for Group A, Nystatin for group B for 1 month), antibacterial for 3 months and antiviral (Valganciclovir for 6 months) was used. Viral monitoring was every 3 months for the 1st year and then every 3-12 months based on serostatus. Blood counts, rejection, graft and patient survival and incidence of all infections were analyzed.

Results: 1-year patient survival for both groups was 100%.
